('19', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 1
('19', 0, 1, 2, 46) 1. LETTER TO G.E. CHATFIELD
('19', 0, 2, 3, 74) ASHRAM, September 29 [1919]
('19', 0, 3, 4, 102) DEAR MR. CHATFIELD,
('19', 0, 4, 5, 122) Anasuyabehn has just shown me the order regarding the levy to be made from the inhabitants of Ahmedabad including the millhands on account of the April disturbances.
('19', 0, 4, 6, 288) I observe that the levy from the mill hands is to be collected today by the mill owners paying to the Hazur Deputy Collector one week's wages out of the amount held by them as caution money on their account.
('19', 0, 4, 7, 496) I venture to think that this levy will come upon the mill hands as a perfect surprise.
('19', 0, 4, 8, 583) Will it not be better to give them some time to realize the situation and to make individual or collective payments themselves.
('19', 0, 4, 9, 711) The proposed summary procedure may be suitable from the Government standpoint, nay, even be agreeable to the mill owners.
('19', 0, 4, 10, 833) But the principle of leaving totally out of consideration the party that is to pay seems to me to be dange rous and demoralizing.
('19', 0, 4, 11, 963) I should imagine that the Government are interested in the mill hands realizing and recognizing their own dig nity and becoming conscious of their own responsibility.
('19', 0, 5, 12, 1130) Moreover, I do not know whether you are aware that the coming days are auspicious days for both Mohammedans and Hindus.
('19', 0, 5, 13, 1250) The Moharram festival is always, all over India, a time of anxiety for the Government.
('19', 0, 5, 14, 1337) I have no doubt that this matter has been overlooked by you as well as others who are responsible for fixing the time of levy.
('19', 0, 5, 15, 1464) But you will agree with me that the mill hands who are even ordinarily suspicious will jump to the conclusion that the time chosen for collecting the levy has been specially selected in order to wound their feelings and cause them embarrassment.
('19', 0, 5, 16, 1710) I therefore venture to suggest that the collection from the mill hands may be deferred till after the Diwali holidays.
('19', 0, 5, 17, 1829) Meanwhile I need hardly assure you that you will depend upon those who are at all connected with the mill hands doing their best to facilitate collection.
('19', 0, 5, 18, 1984) I know that you will treat this matter
('19', 1, 0, 1, 2023) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 1, 1, 2, 2063) as very urgent and, if you at all agree with my argument, issue the necessary orders.
('19', 1, 2, 3, 2149) Yours sincerely,
('19', 1, 3, 4, 2166) From a photostat of the handwritten draft : S. N. 6904
('19', 1, 4, 5, 2221) 2. LETTER TO P.S. TO VICEROY
('19', 1, 5, 6, 2250) SABARMATI, September 30, 1919
('19', 1, 6, 7, 2280) TO THE HON'BLE MR. S.R. HIGNELL, C.I.E., I.C.S. PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE VICEROY
('19', 1, 7, 8, 2376) DEAR MR. HIGNELL, As His Excellency is aware, there are orders against me which, among others, prohibit me from entering the Punjab and from leaving the Bombay Presidency.
('19', 1, 7, 9, 2548) Hitherto, I have not been keen about the orders being withdrawn, if only because, so long as the Government persists in retaining on the Statute Book the Rowlatt Act, so long must my civil resistance continue in esse or in posse.
('19', 1, 7, 10, 2778) But the situation has altered somewhat now.
('19', 1, 7, 11, 2822) In my humble opinion, it is necessary for me to be in the Punjab when and some time before the forthcoming Committees begin their sittings.
('19', 1, 7, 12, 2962) I claim that my presence can only help to elucidate truth.
('19', 1, 7, 13, 3021) There is an urgent demand from the Punjab that I should be in that province before and at the time of the inquiry.
('19', 1, 7, 14, 3136) I see that so many things are alleged to have happened in my name that I am naturally interested in the proceedings.
('19', 1, 7, 15, 3253) I hope, therefore, that the orders against me, so far as the Punjab is concerned, will be removed.
('19', 1, 8, 16, 3352) N.A.I. : Home Department : Political A : October 1919 : File Nos.
('19', 1, 8, 17, 3418) 426 440; also from a photostat of the draft : S. N. 6911
('19', 1, 9, 18, 3475) 1 In his reply, G.E. Chatfield wrote the same day : “I am afraid I cannot accept the principle of recovering the amount from the mill hands by individual and collective contributions or agree that it is unreasonable to levy a fine from them without consulting them first.
('19', 1, 9, 19, 3747) I quite understand your point of view and I am sure you will understand mine and how they must inevitably differ.” The Collector agreed that the timing of the levy was awkward, but believed that delay involved even more danger, observed that he was making arrangements to avoid disturbances and appealed to Gandhiji to use his influence with the mill hands to keep the peace.
('19', 1, 9, 20, 4123) 2 Gandhiji followed this up with a telegram on October 2; the prohibitory order was withdrawn on October 15.

('19', 2, 1, 2, 4278) 3. LETTER TO SHUAIB QURESHI
('19', 2, 2, 3, 4306) [September 1919] 1
('19', 2, 3, 4, 4325) DEAR FRIEND, You will not consider me discourteous for not having replied to the letter signed by you and other friends regarding the Ali Brothers and addressed to the Editor, Young India.
('19', 2, 3, 5, 4514) The fact is I have been overwhelmed with the care of having to edit two important news papers.
('19', 2, 3, 6, 4609) 2 I must confess that I do not like your letter at all.
('19', 2, 3, 7, 4665) It is a lawyer's letter containing quibbles.
('19', 2, 3, 8, 4710) But even that would not matter.
('19', 2, 3, 9, 4742) Do you sincerely take up the position that a Mussulman may never kill a Mussulman no matter what crimes the latter may commit?
('19', 2, 3, 10, 4869) I would not be surprised if you took up that attitude, for then the rule of the Brahmin law givers will descend upon you.
('19', 2, 3, 11, 4991) They have made the life of the Brahmin, as they think, absolutely sacred, and, as the others consider possible, by providing that no matter what his crime is, a Brahmin may not be killed.
('19', 2, 3, 12, 5179) It is true that the rule has been observed more in the breach than in the performance.
('19', 2, 3, 13, 5266) For, in war, we have not hesitated to kill Brahmins.
('19', 2, 3, 14, 5319) My quarrel is, therefore, not with a mental attitude, but with your impressing a Koranic text into service for defending the position of our friends.
('19', 2, 3, 15, 5469) I would like, then, to have a letter that would appeal to reason.
('19', 2, 3, 16, 5535) Before your letter was received, I wrote to Bari Saheb 3 saying that, in my opinion, no agitation for the release of the Brothers was likely to be successful before the Turkish Peace terms were declared.
('19', 2, 3, 17, 5739) I do not know whether your letter, which I see is addressed to the Press in general, has been published elsewhere.
('19', 2, 4, 18, 5854) QURESHI, SHUAIB C/O DR.
('19', 2, 4, 19, 5878) [M.A.] ANSARI DELHI
('19', 2, 5, 20, 5898) From the original pencilled draft : S. N. 6864
('19', 2, 6, 21, 5945) 1 The exact date of this letter is not known.
('19', 2, 6, 22, 5991) It is, however, likely that it was written some time towards the end of September 1919. 2 The reference is to the weeklies Navajivan and Young India.
('19', 2, 6, 23, 6141) Though the journals appeared under his full fledged editorship only on October 7 and October 8, 1919, respectively, Gandhiji did a considerable amount of editorial writing for them even before they passed under his full control.
('19', 2, 6, 24, 6370) 3 Vide “Exact from Letter to Abdul Bari”, 27 8 1919.
('19', 3, 0, 1, 6423) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 3, 1, 2, 6463) 4. LETTER TO JETHALAL SAMPAT
('19', 3, 2, 3, 6492) ASHRAM, SABHARMATI, Wednesday, [September, 1919] 1
('19', 3, 3, 4, 6543) DEAR JETHALAL, The doubt you raise has been answered in my reply.
('19', 3, 3, 5, 6609) So I do not reproduce it in Navajivan.
('19', 3, 3, 6, 6648) We have got to stick to swadeshi in all things.
('19', 3, 3, 7, 6696) So I cling to the trunk of the tree.
('19', 3, 3, 8, 6733) I can have no interest in electricity, etc.
('19', 3, 3, 9, 6777) Others can take that up.
('19', 3, 3, 10, 6802) What I am doing harms no one.
('19', 3, 3, 11, 6832) And the handloom and the spinning wheel can never harm any one.
('19', 3, 3, 12, 6896) Even today handlooms are working side by side with the mills.
('19', 3, 3, 13, 6958) I am developing them.
('19', 3, 3, 14, 6980) We should create conditions where, 21 crores, sitting at home, can carry on their occupation.
('19', 3, 3, 15, 7074) For further clarification of your doubt, you must regularly see the Navajivan.
('19', 3, 3, 16, 7153) Everyone cer tainly cannot do everything.
('19', 3, 3, 17, 7195) Activities should be distributed.
('19', 3, 4, 18, 7229) MOHANDAS
('19', 3, 5, 19, 7238) From a copy of the Gujarati in Devanagari script: C. W. 9843. Courtesy: Narayan Jethalal Sampat
('19', 3, 6, 20, 7334) 5. THE PUNJAB STUDENTS
('19', 3, 7, 21, 7357) The letter from "One who feels" published in the Leader of the 22nd instant is an important communication confirming the many letters I have received from the Punjab, some of which have already appeared in Young India.
('19', 3, 7, 22, 7576) The action of the college authorities reflects but little credit on them.
('19', 3, 7, 23, 7650) "One who feels" is, as the Leader tells the public, "one of the most respected and foremost men in the educa tional world in the Punjab".
('19', 3, 7, 24, 7788) At the worst the action of the students consisted in absenting themselves from their respective colleges.
('19', 3, 7, 25, 7894) It amounts to nothing but a boyish method of demonstrating their opinion over the action of the Government and their affection for those whom they loved.
('19', 3, 7, 26, 8048) In any place but India, such action would
('19', 3, 8, 27, 8090) 1 The period has been inferred from the reference to Navajivan, the first issue of which appeared in September 1919 under the editorship of Gandhiji, who wrote widely on the subject of handloom and spinning wheel during the year 1919; vide also“Swadeshi V. Machinery”, 14 9 1919.
('19', 4, 0, 1, 8370) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 5
('19', 4, 1, 2, 8416) have passed unnoticed or college professors would have made common cause with the students and warned the authorities of the unpopularity of their action.
('19', 4, 1, 3, 8571) But the action of the authorities shows in a forcible manner what part terrorism has played in the public life of the Punjab.
('19', 4, 1, 4, 8697) The college authorities have given an object lesson to the students in unmanliness.
('19', 4, 1, 5, 8781) They have not hesitated to obtain by threat of punishment the names of the ring leaders in the strike.
('19', 4, 1, 6, 8884) It is evident that the strike was popular and spontaneous and all were practically ring leaders.
('19', 4, 1, 7, 8981) The prudent course in such an event is not to tempt weak students to buy exemption from penalty by blaming their fellows, but to regulate and direct their enthusiasm in the right channel.
('19', 4, 1, 8, 9169) The authorities could not have adopted a more effective course than they did if they intended to rouse the bad blood of the students and make them seek crooked ways.
('19', 4, 1, 9, 9335) His Honour the Lieut. Governor has now appointed a committee of inquiry which, according to the Leader's correspondent, is not quite satisfactory.
('19', 4, 1, 10, 9482) The Lahore Medical College, however, will have nothing to do with the committee.
('19', 4, 1, 11, 9563) The authorities will not have their action reviewed.
('19', 4, 1, 12, 9616) This unrestrained lust for power and punishment is intole rable.
('19', 4, 1, 13, 9681) I hope that His Honour will intervene, that the whole of India will insist on an inquiry into these cases.
('19', 4, 1, 14, 9788) But if the authorities prove unbending, it would, in my opinion, be necessary to find out a remedy.
('19', 4, 1, 15, 9888) If education is to be bought at the price of manliness and self respect, the price is too heavy.
('19', 4, 1, 16, 9985) "Man does not live by bread alone." Self respect and character are above means of livelihood or a career.
('19', 4, 1, 17, 10091) I am sorry that so many students have taken their expulsion so much to heart.
('19', 4, 1, 18, 10169) The parents as well as students must revise their ideas about education.
('19', 4, 1, 19, 10242) Education is treated merely as a means of earning a livelihood and acquiring a status in society.
('19', 4, 1, 20, 10340) These are not unworthy ambitions.
('19', 4, 1, 21, 10374) But they are not everything in life.
('19', 4, 1, 22, 10411) There are many other honourable means of acquiring wealth and status.
('19', 4, 1, 23, 10481) There are many independent activities in life which one many undertake without having to contemplate loss of self respect.
('19', 4, 1, 24, 10604) And there is no better or cleaner passport to status in society than honesty and selfless service of fellow beings.
('19', 4, 1, 25, 10720) If, therefore, after due effort, the college door remains banged in the students' faces, they should not lose heart but seek other means of livelihood.
('19', 4, 1, 26, 10872) And if the other students will empty the recalcitrant colleges as a matter of respectful protest, they and India will not be losers, but both will be considerable gainers.
('19', 4, 2, 27, 11044) Young India, 1 10 1919
('19', 5, 0, 1, 11067) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 5, 1, 2, 11107) 6. NATIVE STATES' SUBJECTS
('19', 5, 2, 3, 11134) Mr. M.T. Doshi has furnished me with detailed notes of an interview he had with the District Magistrate of Karachi on the 13th August last.
('19', 5, 2, 4, 11274) Mr. Doshi is a native of Vankaner in Kathiawar.
('19', 5, 2, 5, 11322) He is an accountant and commercial instructor and has been manager of a firm in Karachi.
('19', 5, 2, 6, 11411) The interview took place in virtue of a memorandum issued by the District Magistrate requesting Mr. Doshi to call on him.
('19', 5, 2, 7, 11533) I cannot help remarking that there is too much of this kind of gratuitous calling of people by means of Memoranda.
('19', 5, 2, 8, 11648) It is demora lizing alike for the officials and the public.
('19', 5, 2, 9, 11708) It is an improper way of conducting public affairs.
('19', 5, 2, 10, 11760) District Magistrates have no legal right to summon people in this manner.
('19', 5, 2, 11, 11834) If Mr. Doshi had committed anything wrong, he should have been judicially dealt with.
('19', 5, 2, 12, 11920) But to issue a non judicial, political warning causes unnecessary fright and no man can regard himself safe under a system of what may be called political espionage.
('19', 5, 2, 13, 12086) After a few preliminary questions, Mr. Doshi was asked whether he had taken the satyagraha vow and whether he had been writing letters to the newspapers.
('19', 5, 2, 14, 12240) He was told that he wanted "to stir up politi cal agitation and satyagraha in spite of the troubles caused thereby in April last".
('19', 5, 2, 15, 12371) The following conversation, being interesting, I give verba tim as supplied to me in Mr. Doshi's notes.
('19', 5, 3, 16, 12475) DOSHI : I do want political and all other kinds of national activities to go on here as elsewhere.
('19', 5, 3, 17, 12574) I have no intention to cause troubles nor do I advocate any measures that might bring about troubles.
('19', 5, 3, 18, 12676) I have done nothing to endanger the position of anybody.
('19', 5, 4, 19, 12733) D[ISTRICT] M[AGISTRATE] : Mr. Gandhi, when he started the satyagraha, never wanted to endanger anybody, but you know what happened in the Punjab and elsewhere; you want the same thing again here.
('19', 5, 5, 20, 12929) D : Troubles in the Punjab were not, in my opinion, due to any acts of Mahatma Gandhi, but to the peculiar attitude of the officials there.
('19', 5, 5, 21, 13069) However, I do nothing that might cause trouble.
('19', 5, 5, 22, 13117) And you know there never was any trouble here though here also we had the Saytagraha Day.
('19', 5, 6, 23, 13207) D. M. : You must be knowing that some time back I have called some of your Kathiawari people and warned them not to take any part in any movement against the Government or the laws of the place which afford them
('19', 6, 0, 1, 13419) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 7
('19', 6, 1, 2, 13465) protection here, for if they did not obey the laws, they shall have to be expelled to their own States.
('19', 6, 1, 3, 13569) And you are doing just the same thing.
('19', 6, 1, 4, 13608) Your case is just analogous to those of the other Kathiawaris already deported.
('19', 6, 1, 5, 13688) They were asked to leave the country not only because they agitated themselves but they also tried to make others agitate, as you do now.
('19', 6, 1, 6, 13826) You have not yet given up the satyagraha vow.
('19', 6, 1, 7, 13872) Have you?
('19', 6, 2, 8, 13882) D : I have not as I cannot.
('19', 6, 3, 9, 13910) D.M. : Well, I tell you that I give you this warning personally.
('19', 6, 3, 10, 13975) I am not moved by the authorities…the Commissioner.
('19', 6, 3, 11, 14027) I just read your letters in the paper, two of which bear your signature and the third only initials and I thought it better to advise you as a good man.
('19', 6, 4, 12, 14180) D : Oh, I thank you for that.
('19', 6, 5, 13, 14210) D.M. : (while taking note on the paper) You say that "you are not prepared to cease taking part in political activities".
('19', 6, 6, 14, 14332) D : I would rather word it differently.
('19', 6, 6, 15, 14372) I would say, "I am not prepared to cease taking part in any activities connected with the Indian national welfare."
('19', 6, 7, 16, 14488) D.M. : Why do you work here and not within the bounds of your State?
('19', 6, 8, 17, 14557) D : My State is only a part of India and it is only a narrow field whereas this is a vast one.
('19', 6, 8, 18, 14652) If we make any progress here, sure enough that goes for progress in my own State which is well up.
('19', 6, 9, 19, 14751) D.M. : Besides trying to stir up agitation, you try to help those that have been externed and want to take up their cause, but you must be careful, lest you meet with a similar fate.
('19', 6, 10, 20, 14934) D : I must try to help my friends as much as I can.
('19', 6, 10, 21, 14986) I don't mind the rest.
('19', 6, 11, 22, 15009) D.M. : When the whole city is quiet you try to stir up troubles.
('19', 6, 11, 23, 15074) I will make you responsible if anything occurs.
('19', 6, 12, 24, 15122) D : I am not attempting to stir up troubles.
('19', 6, 12, 25, 15167) There have been never any troubles in Karachi and none likely to be.
('19', 6, 12, 26, 15236) I don't understand why I shall be responsible.
('19', 6, 13, 27, 15283) D.M. : You are a subject of another State, and His Majesty's Government and its laws afford you protection here, so you must obey its laws, otherwise you must depart.
('19', 6, 14, 28, 15450) D : How do you call us subjects of another State and treat us as foreigners?
('19', 6, 14, 29, 15527) Is not our State within India?
('19', 6, 15, 30, 15558) D.M. : I do not wish to argue with you on the matter; such is the law and law is law.
('19', 6, 15, 31, 15644) I am not here to explain that, I only want you to stop partaking in such works.
('19', 7, 0, 1, 15724) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 7, 1, 2, 15764) D : May I know what works you mean?
('19', 7, 1, 3, 15800) Do you include satyagraha and ordinary national political work in what you say?
('19', 7, 2, 4, 15880) D.M. : You should not take part in the political movements, surely you should not partake in the satyagraha or the disobedience of the law and such other matters.
('19', 7, 3, 5, 16043) D : I do not think satyagraha is criminal or illegal.
('19', 7, 3, 6, 16097) It is not harmful.
('19', 7, 4, 7, 16116) D.M. : I do not want to discuss and argue over the case.
('19', 7, 4, 8, 16173) I only want to warn you to stop writing to the Press and such other works as trying to help the externees and so on.
('19', 7, 4, 9, 16290) I warn you that, if you persist in attempting to stir up violent political agitation and movements for breaking the laws in British
('19', 7, 5, 10, 16422) India where you enjoy the protection of its laws and Government, I shall have to recommend action against you.
('19', 7, 6, 11, 16533) D : I have never tried to stir up nor will stir up violent political
('19', 7, 7, 12, 16602) agitation, but I cannot in any case give up working for the activities connected with the Indian national welfare.
('19', 7, 7, 13, 16717) For I consider that my own good and the good of my State lie in the good of my country India.
('19', 7, 7, 14, 16811) The above extracts from Mr. Doshi's notes make painful reading and show the difficulty of carrying on political agitation.
('19', 7, 7, 15, 16934) Any day the District Magistrate may prove as good as his word and expel Mr. Doshi from British India and thus ruin his career, as has been done in the case of Mr. Manilal Vyas and others.
('19', 7, 7, 16, 17122) Apart from the general question of the propriety of such notices and conversations, the question of the status of the subjects of native States is of very great importance.
('19', 7, 7, 17, 17295) A law that makes it possible to coop up people without any trial in small areas must surely be altered.
('19', 7, 7, 18, 17399) It is obvious that imprisonment is better than internment without provision for maintenance.
('19', 7, 7, 19, 17492) On the one hand, the Government appoint subjects of native States to high office and on the other subordinate officials are permitted to treat them as foreigners.
('19', 7, 7, 20, 17655) Sir Prabhashanker Pattani can become an honoured colleague of Mr. Montagu.
('19', 7, 7, 21, 17730) The Hon'ble Mr. Lallubhai Samaldas is a trusted councillor.
('19', 7, 7, 22, 17790) The Government welcome the financial and other assistance of subjects of native States and shower titles on them.
('19', 7, 7, 23, 17904) They are dubbed 'loyal'.
('19', 7, 7, 24, 17929) What can be the meaning of the loyalty of foreigners?
('19', 7, 7, 25, 17983) Can foreigners be or be expected to be 'loyal' to a State to which they do not belong?
('19', 7, 7, 26, 18070) Must the suzerain power take everything from the people of the States in alliance and give nothing?
('19', 7, 7, 27, 18170) It is a suicidal policy that has been laid down in Sindh.
('19', 7, 7, 28, 18228) Let one hope that His Excellency's Government will nip the evil in the bud.
('19', 7, 8, 29, 18304) Young India, 1 10 1919
('19', 8, 0, 1, 18327) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 9

('19', 9, 0, 1, 19673) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 9, 1, 2, 19714) 8. SPEECH AT ANNIE BESANT FELICITATION MEETING 1
('19', 9, 2, 3, 19763) BOMBAY, October 1, 1919
('19', 9, 3, 4, 19787) In opening the proceedings, Mr. Gandhi said that it gave him great pleasure to attending the meeting to celebrate the anniversary of the person who had devoted the greater part of her life for the public cause and they could feel justly proud in celebrating the event.
('19', 9, 3, 5, 20056) He first knew her in England in 1889. He was introduced to her at the Blavatsky Lodge in England.
('19', 9, 3, 6, 20154) He saw her answering the various queries and giving reasons for renouncing atheism and adopting Theosophy.
('19', 9, 3, 7, 20261) After replying to all the allegations, she had then said that she would be satisfied if, after her death, it would be said that she lived for truth and died for the cause of truth.
('19', 9, 3, 8, 20442) When he had been to South Africa, he came in contact with many Theosophists there and from them he came to know the work of Mrs. Besant, and they furnished him with more particulars of the work of Mrs. Besant, which information was not contained in the books published by Mrs. Besant.
('19', 9, 3, 9, 20727) From all this, he was convinced that Mrs. Besant continued to work according to her own convictions, little caring whether she was praised or abused.
('19', 9, 4, 10, 20877) Coming to the satyagraha movement, Mr. Gandhi pointed out to the audience
('19', 9, 5, 11, 20951) how Mrs. Besant stood by her own convictions, which made her believe that
('19', 9, 6, 12, 21025) satyagraha had its shortcomings and the common people were not able to grasp the
('19', 9, 7, 13, 21106) full significance of satyagraha.
('19', 9, 7, 14, 21139) That furnished another instance that she cared for
('19', 9, 8, 15, 21190) convictions of the inner soul more.
('19', 9, 8, 16, 21226) She did not care whether these convictions were
('19', 9, 9, 17, 21274) liked by the public or not.
('19', 9, 10, 18, 21302) He then referred to Mrs. Besant's work and said that he never in his life found
('19', 9, 11, 19, 21382) Mrs. Besant at leisure, but found her always toiling for the public cause even when
('19', 9, 12, 20, 21466) she was travelling in trains.
('19', 9, 12, 21, 21496) Though he found her in her 73rd year, he was glad to see
('19', 9, 13, 22, 21553) her working with such zeal and earnestness as none of them could equal.
('19', 9, 14, 23, 21625) opinion, the services that Mrs. Besant had rendered to India were immense and
('19', 9, 15, 24, 21703) invaluable.
('19', 9, 15, 25, 21715) She had dedicated her whole life and all her own for the good of India.
('19', 9, 16, 26, 21787) Referring to the present political differences with Mrs. Besant, Mr. Gandhi was pleased to see that even those who differed from her were proud to testify to the great services that she was rendering in England for India.
('19', 9, 16, 27, 22009) By espousing the cause of Indians, she had suffered much in body and mind.
('19', 9, 16, 28, 22084) Her company was even shunned by
('19', 9, 17, 29, 22116) 1 Gandhiji presided over a public meeting held at the Excelsior Theatre to celebrate the 73rd birthday of Annie Besant.
('19', 9, 17, 30, 22236) The report was reproduced in New India, 4 10 1919.
('19', 10, 0, 1, 22287) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 11
('19', 10, 1, 2, 22334) Europeans.
('19', 10, 1, 3, 22345) But the greatest services, to the speaker's mind, which she rendered and which will ever remain a monument to her memorable career in India, was the introduction of Home Rule propaganda.
('19', 10, 1, 4, 22532) It was only by her initiation that the movement was set afoot and now it had spread to every nook and corner of India, so that in whatever village he went, he found the villagers there awakened to the necessity of winning Home Rule for India.
('19', 10, 2, 5, 22775) Concluding, Mr. Gandhi said that Mrs. Besant had inculcated the Mantra of
('19', 10, 3, 6, 22849) Home Rule into the minds of Indians and it was his fervent prayer to Almighty God
('19', 10, 4, 7, 22931) that she might live long for India's sake and might be able to see India secure Home
('19', 10, 5, 8, 23016) Rule in her lifetime, so that contentment might reign supreme everywhere in India
('19', 10, 6, 9, 23098) and India would achieve her pristine glory once again.
('19', 10, 7, 10, 23153) After two other speakers had paid tributes to the work of Mrs. Besant, Gandhiji
('19', 10, 8, 11, 23233) asked the audience to give him permission to send a suitable message to Mrs. Besant,
('19', 10, 9, 12, 23318) which was agreed to.

('19', 10, 10, 14, 23371) 9. MESSAGE ON ANNIE BESANT'S BIRTHDAY 1
('19', 10, 11, 15, 23411) BOMBAY, October 1, 1919 I gladly respond to the request to add my humble quota to the many appreciations that would be tendered to the Editor of New India on Mrs. Besant's birthday.
('19', 10, 11, 16, 23593) It was in 1889 that I first paid my respects to Mrs. Besant when I was studying as a lad in London.
('19', 10, 11, 17, 23693) I was privileged to do so by the courtesy of two English friends who were at the time ardent Theosophical students.
('19', 10, 11, 18, 23809) She had only just joined the Theosophical Society there.
('19', 10, 11, 19, 23866) Not much impression was created on my mind then.
('19', 10, 11, 20, 23915) I really went not to have impressions but out of mere curiosity to see what this lady who was once an atheist looked like.
('19', 10, 11, 21, 24038) My friends had told me that she was the best among the living women orators in the world, and that Madame Blavatsky was in great joy over this big "capture".
('19', 10, 11, 22, 24196) But when, immediately after, I went to Queen's Hall, I went not to look at Mrs. Besant but to listen to her.
('19', 10, 11, 23, 24305) And the words she uttered then as she rose to answer the charge of inconsistency have never faded from my memory.
('19', 10, 11, 24, 24419) She said as she wound up her great speech which held her audience spell bound that she would be quite satisfied to have the epitaph written on her tomb that she lived for
('19', 10, 12, 25, 24590) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('19', 11, 0, 1, 24617) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 11, 1, 2, 24658) truth and she died for truth.
('19', 11, 1, 3, 24688) I had from my childhood an instinctive fascination for truth.
('19', 11, 1, 4, 24750) The utter sincerity with which, I felt, she spoke these words captivated me and ever since I have followed her career with unabated interest and always with admiration for her boundless energy, her great organizing ability and her devotion to the work she might have made her own for the moment.
('19', 11, 1, 5, 25046) I have sharp differences of opinion with her as to methods of work.
('19', 11, 1, 6, 25114) I have also been hurt to feel at times that she has lost her robust independence of 1888 and her uncompromising search after and adherence to truth at all cost.
('19', 11, 1, 7, 25275) But in the midst of all my doubts I have never wavered in my belief in her great devotion to India.
('19', 11, 1, 8, 25375) It is no small gain for India to have her many gifts dedicated to her cause with a single mindedness few of her natural born sons and daughters can claim.
('19', 11, 1, 9, 25530) I have no doubt that she has popularized Home Rule in a manner no other person has.
('19', 11, 1, 10, 25614) May she be spared for many a long year to serve the country she has made her own.

('19', 13, 1, 2, 27581) 13. SPEECH AT BHAGINI SAMAJ 1
('19', 13, 2, 3, 27611) BOMBAY, October 2, 1919
('19', 13, 3, 4, 27635) President, ladies and gentlemen, as I have said in the Navajivan, I cannot find words to express to you my gratitude.
('19', 13, 3, 5, 27753) 2 Presentation of this purse places on me a great responsibility.
('19', 13, 3, 6, 27819) On the occasion of my birthday, many men and women have done some work or other which I have liked.
('19', 13, 3, 7, 27919) At every such function I have said that if we have respect and affection for somebody, the best way of expressing that respect and affection is to follow in his footsteps.
('19', 13, 3, 8, 28091) The best way to celebrate my birthday is to absorb whatever appears good in my life.
('19', 13, 3, 9, 28176) If I go out to beg in India I can collect lakhs and crores of rupees.
('19', 13, 3, 10, 28246) But that will not make for progress.
('19', 13, 3, 11, 28283) This does not mean that money has no importance.
('19', 13, 3, 12, 28332) It only means that every thing has importance in its own place.
('19', 13, 3, 13, 28396) If something made of gold goes to a wrong place, we have to discard it.
('19', 13, 3, 14, 28468) Many people have piles and piles of money, but if they cannot spend it for a good purpose, their having the money is of no conse quence.
('19', 13, 3, 15, 28605) There is scarcity of food and clothing in our country.
('19', 13, 3, 16, 28660) People have to satisfy themselves with one meal a day and many people go naked.
('19', 13, 3, 17, 28740) You ladies do not know what cold means.
('19', 13, 3, 18, 28780) But if you come with me to the fields, I will show you that some women use straw and cowdung to keep themselves warm.
('19', 13, 3, 19, 28898) I want to be known as a farmer and a weaver.
('19', 13, 3, 20, 28943) If some people, instead of spending a single paisa on milk for their children, squander money on gambling, how can they rise at all?
('19', 13, 3, 21, 29076) With my head bared and my hand stretched I am begging from the rich in India.
('19', 13, 3, 22, 29154) I tell them about my experiments and they help me.
('19', 13, 3, 23, 29205) I intend to use this money for a good purpose and so I have agreed to accept this present.
('19', 13, 3, 24, 29296) A large number of women have contributed towards it.
('19', 13, 3, 25, 29349) Avantikabai and I can tell the story of Champaran.
('19', 13, 3, 26, 29400) The women there told me that they went without bath and
('19', 13, 4, 27, 29456) 1 The Bhagini Samaj had collected a sum of Rs. 23,000 for the Golden Jubilee Fund in connection with Gandhiji’s 51st birthday.
('19', 13, 4, 28, 29583) The purse was presented to him on October 2. For a brief account of Gandhi’s speech on the occasion, vide “Speech att Felicitation meeting, Bombay”, 2 10 1919 2 Ibid
('19', 14, 0, 1, 29749) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 15
('19', 14, 1, 2, 29796) remained dirty because they did not have any change of clothes.
('19', 14, 1, 3, 29860) I felt sad that I had no extra clothes with me.
('19', 14, 1, 4, 29908) The responsibilities I have to shoulder at present are beyond telling.
('19', 14, 1, 5, 29979) I believe I shall be able to account for it to you and to God.
('19', 14, 1, 6, 30042) I have solicited the views of many men and women as to the use of this money, and I hope to use it accordingly.
('19', 14, 1, 7, 30154) What I am seeking is the resurgence of Satya Yuga in India.
('19', 14, 1, 8, 30214) We had a Golden Age at one time.
('19', 14, 1, 9, 30247) In that age men and women in India spontaneously and automatically spoke only the truth.
('19', 14, 1, 10, 30336) Women in those days maintained their chastity.
('19', 14, 1, 11, 30383) In those days even when men and women got together, they did not have lustful thoughts in their minds.
('19', 14, 1, 12, 30486) That is how things were in the Satya Yuga or the Golden Age.
('19', 14, 1, 13, 30547) In this Kali Yuga it is difficult for women to remain chaste.
('19', 14, 1, 14, 30609) When I went to the Harijan quarters at Dahod, I was told that in the past the women there had not worked for wages but that lately they had started working.
('19', 14, 1, 15, 30766) Earlier the men had been weavers and their women assisted them.
('19', 14, 1, 16, 30830) Hence they were able to preserve their chastity.
('19', 14, 1, 17, 30879) Lately they have not been doing any spinning and have taken to working as labonrers.
('19', 14, 1, 18, 30964) The condition of women there is very sad.
('19', 14, 1, 19, 31006) The overseers tyrannize over them.
('19', 14, 1, 20, 31041) Education of women is the paramount task in India.
('19', 14, 1, 21, 31092) With education women can remain chaste.
('19', 14, 1, 22, 31132) For such education we do not require great learning.
('19', 14, 1, 23, 31185) All that is needed is character.
('19', 14, 1, 24, 31218) It needs no money.
('19', 14, 1, 25, 31237) Four hundred Muslim women are today helping themselves, and they are earning adequate wages from spinning.
('19', 14, 1, 26, 31344) Since you have shown me so much love today, I appeal to you to show me the love that will bring back Satya Yuga.
('19', 14, 1, 27, 31457) India is in a position to take care of itself.
('19', 14, 1, 28, 31504) If we use only the cloth produced in the country, we shall be able to make the country secure in a very short time.
('19', 14, 1, 29, 31620) I have been campaigning for the spinning wheel.
('19', 14, 1, 30, 31668) The chastity of women can be protected with the help of the spinning wheel.
('19', 14, 1, 31, 31744) There is no other occupation in which our millions of women can engage themselves while staying at home.
('19', 14, 1, 32, 31849) This does not call for much intelligence.
('19', 14, 1, 33, 31891) India must learn to be self reliant.
('19', 14, 1, 34, 31928) When India produces brave men and women we shall become self reliant.
('19', 14, 1, 35, 31998) We have to show the gallantry of satyagraha.
('19', 14, 1, 36, 32043) This needs more bravery than the bravery of arms.
('19', 14, 1, 37, 32093) If that happens we shall be free right away.
('19', 14, 1, 38, 32138) Protect your women and save those millions of rupees being drained out of India.
('19', 14, 1, 39, 32219) You can work wonders even if you work only for an hour every day.
('19', 14, 1, 40, 32285) You have shown me boundless affection.
('19', 14, 1, 41, 32324) You call this money a small
('19', 15, 0, 1, 32352) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 15, 1, 2, 32393) amount but it is bountiful.
('19', 15, 1, 3, 32421) This gift given willingly and with good intention is bound to bear fruit.
('19', 15, 1, 4, 32495) To me it has the value of a billion rupees.
('19', 15, 1, 5, 32539) Hence, do not think that this is inadequate.
('19', 15, 1, 6, 32584) If you find my appeal for work appropriate, prepare to train yourselves for that work in the interest of your country.

('19', 17, 7, 27, 36586) 18. FINING THE LABOURERS
('19', 17, 8, 28, 36611) Ahmedabad, the Government has decided, has to pay a fine of nearly nine lacs of rupees in connection with the April disturbances.
('19', 17, 8, 29, 36741) This is under the same section of the British Police Act 1 as Nadiad has been dealt with.
('19', 17, 8, 30, 36831) A law that allows a Government thus arbitrarily to impose a penalty is bad law.
('19', 17, 8, 31, 36911) All laws that place a Government above
('19', 17, 9, 32, 36950) 1 The Bombay District Police Act IV of 1890 as amended by Act III of 1915.
('19', 18, 0, 1, 37025) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 19
('19', 18, 1, 2, 37072) law and enable them to impose their will upon people without consultation with them or without the authority of a properly constituted judicial tribunal are bad, and should not be tolerated where there is an enlightened and liberal Government or where the people are jealous of their freedom.
('19', 18, 1, 3, 37365) But it is not my purpose to discuss the badness of the law.
('19', 18, 1, 4, 37425) My object at the present moment is to bring to public notice an unwise and untimely and an almost despotic appli cation of that bad law.
('19', 18, 1, 5, 37562) The principle that the wanton damage done to life and property by crowds of people should be made good by them is beyond dispute.
('19', 18, 1, 6, 37692) But acceptance of that principle cannot and does not involve acceptance of arbitrary powers.
('19', 18, 1, 7, 37785) In the case of the Ahmedabad mill hands a fine of 176 thousand rupees has been fixed.
('19', 18, 1, 8, 37871) Recovery is to be made from all mill hands employed during Septem ber 1919, within the Municipal limits.
('19', 18, 1, 9, 37976) Now the disturbances took place in April last.
('19', 18, 1, 10, 38023) It is a notorious fact that mill hands have changed somewhat and new comers constantly come in.
('19', 18, 1, 11, 38119) Why should those who joined after the disturbances and have no connection with them be made to pay anything whatsoever?
('19', 18, 1, 12, 38239) Why should women and children of whom there is a considerable number in the mills have to pay?
('19', 18, 1, 13, 38334) There are probably sixty thousand labourers in the mills.
('19', 18, 1, 14, 38392) Is it right to fine them nearly two lacs of rupees?
('19', 18, 1, 15, 38444) The manner of collection and the time chosen are still more unfortunate.
('19', 18, 1, 16, 38517) The order is dated 26th September, 1919, and on the same day the following was served upon the mill owners:
('19', 18, 2, 17, 38625) The Collector of Ahmedabad hereby calls upon the agents of the .
('19', 18, 3, 18, 38690) mill to pay to the Huzur Deputy Collector, Ahmedabad, on Monday, September
('19', 18, 4, 19, 38765) 29th, before 3 p.m., an amount equal to one week's wages of the manual
('19', 18, 5, 20, 38836) labourers employed during September, 1919, in the .
('19', 18, 5, 21, 38888) mill out of the amount
('19', 18, 6, 22, 38911) held by him as caution money on their account.
('19', 18, 6, 23, 38958) The law contemplates the possibility of an appeal to the Government against such orders by the parties aggrieved.
('19', 18, 6, 24, 39072) The order has not been served upon the mill hands.
('19', 18, 6, 25, 39123) They have not been given the chance of appeal nor have they been given the option of paying the fine themselves.
('19', 18, 6, 26, 39236) The caution money, i.e., the money retained by the mill owners out of the wages due to the mill hands, has been summarily attached without notice to or consent of the labourers con cerned.
('19', 18, 6, 27, 39425) Such treatment of labourers debases them, needlessly irritates them and keeps them in a helpless condition.
('19', 18, 6, 28, 39533) This manner of dealing
('19', 19, 0, 1, 39556) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 19, 1, 2, 39597) with the labourers shows that they are not considered responsible human beings.
('19', 19, 1, 3, 39677) It is almost like collecting fine from owners of cattle for trespass without referrence to the latter, the difference being that the labourers are not dumb like cattle and, unlike cattle, the burden ultimately falls on their shoulders.
('19', 19, 1, 4, 39913) It is surprising that the mill owners have, as I understand they have, become willing parties to such a monstrous procedure.
('19', 19, 1, 5, 40038) Information in my possession goes to show that the mill owners are to recoup themselves for the above payment out of the wages immediately to fall due.
('19', 19, 1, 6, 40190) This means that the enormous sum of one hundred and seventy six thousand rupees is to be collected during a festival season common to both the Hindus and Mohammedans.
('19', 19, 1, 7, 40357) The impropriety of such a step can hardly be questioned.
('19', 19, 1, 8, 40414) The coincidence is no doubt unintended but the unsophisticated labourers will conclude that the festival season has been intentionally chosen to wound their feelings.
('19', 19, 1, 9, 40581) The Collector of Ahmedabad is a gentleman.
('19', 19, 1, 10, 40624) He has given every satisfaction to the inhabitants of the district.
('19', 19, 1, 11, 40692) At a time of intense excitement, he acted with remarkable coolness.
('19', 19, 1, 12, 40760) He is a man full of broad humanity.
('19', 19, 1, 13, 40796) It is a matter, therefore, of special regret to me to have to criticize his actions and I cannot help saying that, if he was not a slave to a system which makes arbitrary procedure possible at almost every step of national life, he could not have helped seeing the absurdity and the injustice of the action taken by him.
('19', 19, 1, 14, 41117) The matter is now before His Excellency the Governor and I venture to express the hope that the wrong done to the labourers of Ahmedabad will be redressed.
('19', 19, 1, 15, 41273) The sum apportioned for the labourers is too much for them.
('19', 19, 1, 16, 41333) It should be reduced.
('19', 19, 1, 17, 41355) Women and boys should be exempted and the payment received by easy stages.
('19', 19, 1, 18, 41430) I admit the difficulty of collection by instalment from a large number of labourers but that difficulty is nothing compared to the infliction of a serious injustice upon a large number of human beings.
('19', 19, 1, 19, 41632) Terrorizing punishment is hardly the best method of weaning offenders from wrongdoing and, in the present instance, the punishment will fall upon many innocent shoulders.
('19', 19, 2, 20, 41803) The authorities have recognized the delicacy of the situation in that they have drafted special police to Ahmedabad and taken
('19', 20, 0, 1, 41929) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 21
('19', 20, 1, 2, 41976) extraordinary precautions in order to avoid unruliness on the part of the labourers and to cow them down into submission.
('19', 20, 2, 3, 42098) Young India, 4 10 1919
('19', 20, 3, 4, 42121) 19. PRAYER AND FASTING
('19', 20, 4, 5, 42144) In spite of the Herculean efforts made by the Punjab Government to crush the spirit of the people, prayer and fasting and hartal are institutions as old as the hills and cannot be stopped.
('19', 20, 4, 6, 42333) Two illuminating abstracts from the bulky volumes published by the Government and containing a record of sentences inflicted by Martial Law Commissions and Summary Courts show, although dimly, what has happened during the past few months to the people of the Punjab.
('19', 20, 4, 7, 42600) The leading cases examined by me have shaken my faith in the justice of these sentences.
('19', 20, 4, 8, 42689) The sentence of stripes is beyond recall as are the 18 death sentences.
('19', 20, 4, 9, 42761) Who will answer for them if they are proved to have been unjustly pronounced?
('19', 20, 4, 10, 42839) But sentences or no sentences, the spirit of the people is unbreakable.
('19', 20, 4, 11, 42911) The Moslem Conference of Lucknow has proclaimed Friday the 17th instant as a day of fasting and prayer.
('19', 20, 4, 12, 43015) The prelimi naries will be presently arranged.
('19', 20, 4, 13, 43062) The day is to be called the Khilafat Day.
('19', 20, 4, 14, 43104) Mr. Andrews’ letter shows clearly what the Khilafat question is and how just is the case of the Mohammedans.
('19', 20, 4, 15, 43213) He agrees with the suggestion I have ventured to make, viz., that if justice cannot be obtained for Turkey, Mr. Montagu and Lord Chelmsford must resign.
('19', 20, 4, 16, 43366) But better than resignations, better than protests, are prayers of the just.
('19', 20, 4, 17, 43443) I therefore welcome the Lucknow resolution.
('19', 20, 4, 18, 43487) Prayer expresses the soul's longing and fasting sets the soul free for efficacious prayer.
('19', 20, 4, 19, 43578) In my opinion, a national fast and national prayer should be accompanied by suspension of business.
('19', 20, 4, 20, 43678) I therefore without hesitation advice suspension of business provided it is carried out with calmness and dignity and provided it is entirely voluntary.
('19', 20, 4, 21, 43831) Those who are required for necessary work such as hospital, sanitation, off loading of steamers, etc., should not be entitled to suspend work.
('19', 20, 4, 22, 43974) And I suggest that to this day of fast there are no processions, no meetings.
('19', 20, 4, 23, 44052) People should remain indoors and devote themselves entirely to prayer.
('19', 20, 4, 24, 44123) It goes without saying that it is the bounden duty of the Hindus and other religious denominations to associate themselves with their Mohammedan brethren.
('19', 20, 4, 25, 44278) It is the surest and simplest method of
('19', 21, 0, 1, 44318) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 21, 1, 2, 44359) bringing about the Hindu Mohammedan unity.
('19', 21, 1, 3, 44402) It is the privilege of friendship to extend the hand of fellowship, and adversity is the crucible in which friendship is tested.
('19', 21, 1, 4, 44531) Let millions of Hindus show to the Mohammedans that they are one with them in sorrow.
('19', 21, 1, 5, 44617) I would respectfully urge the Government to make common cause with the people and encourage and regulate this peaceful exhibition of their feelings.
('19', 21, 1, 6, 44766) Let the people not think that Government will put any obstacles directly or indirectly in their way.
('19', 21, 1, 7, 44867) I would urge the modern generation not to regard fasting and prayer with scepticism or distrust.
('19', 21, 1, 8, 44964) The greatest teachers of the world have derived extraordinary powers for the good of humanity and attained clarity of vision through fasting and prayer.
('19', 21, 1, 9, 45117) Much of this discipline runs to waste because instead of being matter of the heart, it is often resorted to for stage effect.
('19', 21, 1, 10, 45243) I would therefore warn the bodies of this movement against any such suicidal manoeuvring.
('19', 21, 1, 11, 45333) Let them have a living faith in what they urge or let them drop it.
('19', 21, 1, 12, 45401) We are now beginning to attract millions of our countrymen.
('19', 21, 1, 13, 45461) We shall deserve their curses if we consciously lead them astray.
('19', 21, 1, 14, 45527) Whether Hindus or Mohammedans, we have all got the religious spirit in us.
('19', 21, 1, 15, 45602) Let it not be undermined by our playing at relgion.
('19', 21, 2, 16, 45654) Young India, 4 10 1919

('19', 22, 7, 8, 46638) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, October 4, 1919
('19', 22, 8, 9, 46684) DEAR MR. CHATFIELD, Messrs Banker and Desai have described to me the whole of the discussion they had with you over your proposal to demand security regarding Navajivan and Young India.
('19', 22, 8, 10, 46870) I know that what ever decision you will give would be actuated by nothing but a strict sense of duty.
('19', 22, 8, 11, 46972) Nor have I the slightest desire to seek any special exemption.
('19', 22, 8, 12, 47035) I would however like to put just one thought before you.
('19', 22, 8, 13, 47092) People and, I venture to think, the Government consider that my acts are not actuated by any enmity to the latter, and if I find myself in opposition to many measurers of the latter, it is because I want what I consider to be the wrong to be righted.
('19', 22, 8, 14, 47343) Any security therefore taken in connection with newspapers whose policy I am permitted entirely to control will excite strong ill feeling amongst the people and therefore diminish to that extent the prestige of the Government.
('19', 22, 8, 15, 47570) If you agree with me in the views submitted by me I would ask you not to impose any security.
('19', 22, 8, 16, 47664) But if you do impose it, as I have already said, I shall not misun derstand your action.
('19', 22, 8, 17, 47753) And if you do and if you could see your way, I would like you to give your grounds for imposing security.
('19', 22, 8, 18, 47859) I may add

('19', 23, 4, 5, 48536) 23. LETTER TO N.P. COWIE
('19', 23, 5, 6, 48561) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, October 4, 1919
('19', 23, 6, 7, 48607) DEAR MR. COWIE, I sent you a telegram on Wednesday last regarding the levy of rupees one hundred and seventy six thousand from the mill hands of Ahmedabad.
('19', 23, 6, 8, 48763) I said in the telegram that I would submit for His Excellency's consideraton the argument against the amount of the levy, as also the class of labourers from whom it is being or to be exacted.
('19', 23, 6, 9, 48956) It seems to me that the labourers have been put on a par with the wealthiest citizens of Ahmedabad; and whilst the payment to be made by the latter will take some time before it is collected, the labourers are being required to pay the (to them) terrible sum of Rs. 1,76,000 at once.
('19', 23, 6, 10, 49240) I hope it will not be replied that the Government's duty is finished as soon as they have paid themselves out of the caution money retained by the mill owners and that the mill owners may collect as they choose.
('19', 23, 6, 11, 49452) It is a well known fact that labourers are continuously changed.
('19', 23, 6, 12, 49517) All, therefore, who were employed in April were not necessarily under employment in September.
('19', 23, 6, 13, 49612) It is therefore difficult to understand the justice of levying from the labourers to be found on the books of the mill owners in the month of September.
('19', 23, 6, 14, 49765) In my humble opinion, justice demands that any levy imposed should be recovered from the labourers on the books of the several mills on the 10th of April.
('19', 23, 6, 15, 49920) I venture to think, too, that collection from women and boys employed in the mills is also an injustice.
('19', 23, 6, 16, 50025) I submit therefore that the amount to be collected should be reduced; that all the labourers who were not employed on the 10th of April, women and boys under the age of eighteen, should be exempted from
('19', 23, 7, 17, 50228) 1 Vide “Notes”, 5 10 1919.
('19', 24, 0, 1, 50255) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 25
('19', 24, 1, 2, 50302) payment; and as submitted in my telegram, the payment ought not to be recovered during the current festival month but the recovery should be spread over a long enough period to enable the labourers to pay without extreme inconvenience to them.
('19', 24, 2, 3, 50546) Yours sincerely,

('19', 24, 9, 24, 51688) 25. FORTHCOMING SESSION OF GUJARAT POLITICAL CONFERENCE
('19', 24, 10, 25, 51744) On the election of the Hon'ble Gokuldas Kahandas Parekh as president of the forthcoming session of the Gujarat Political Confe 
('19', 24, 11, 26, 51872) 1 The first issue of Young India, as a weekly, was published from Ahmedabad on October 8; the Wednesday before it was October 5. 2 This is not available.
('19', 25, 0, 1, 52026) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 25, 1, 2, 52067) rence to be held in Surat, we congratulate him as well as the Reception Committee.
('19', 25, 1, 3, 52150) The Hon'ble Mr. Parekh has rendered no mean service to Gujarat.
('19', 25, 1, 4, 52214) At a time when very few Gujaratis used to come forward for public service, being afraid of expressing their thoughts before the Government, the Hon'ble Mr. Parekh would fight the Government and apprise it of public opinion.
('19', 25, 1, 5, 52438) These days we often find a tendency among us that, if the older people refuse to go along in every matter with the young, the growing generation, and declare their differences with them, they are treated as of no account and their earlier services are forgotten.
('19', 25, 1, 6, 52701) It is our conviction that our customary practice of respecting elders is an invaluable one, that giving it up will harm the nation.
('19', 25, 1, 7, 52833) Maybe we have a difference of opinion with someone on some matter; we can politely express it, but we should not feel any the less respect for him.
('19', 25, 1, 8, 52981) Hence we welcome the choice of the Reception Committee as an instance worthy of emulation and congratulate the Hon'ble Mr. Parekh, too, on having been duly honoured by Gujarat and on his services having been appreciated.
('19', 25, 1, 9, 53202) ARRANGEMENTS FOR CONFERENCE On this occasion, we shall take the liberty of making some suggestions to the Reception Committee.
('19', 25, 1, 10, 53329) Our experience tells us that we incur some unnecessary expenses during these conferences.
('19', 25, 1, 11, 53419) We have with us some very fine observations of Professor Patrick Geddes 1
('19', 25, 2, 12, 53493) which we hope to give some other time.
('19', 25, 2, 13, 53532) On many matters, we always imitate the West blindly and harm our country.
('19', 25, 2, 14, 53606) In fact, our knowledge of the West is very little.
('19', 25, 2, 15, 53657) The West means England, America, France and Germany; these countries are very prosperous.
('19', 25, 2, 16, 53747) We can never rival them in prosperity.
('19', 25, 2, 17, 53786) The expense that they can afford is entirely beyond India's means.
('19', 25, 2, 18, 53853) Hence, in making arrangements for confe rences, we ought to give due consideration to India's climate, her economic condition and her manners and customs.
('19', 25, 2, 19, 54008) Looking at the matter from this point of view, we cannot approve of the spending of thousands of rupees on pandals and countless flags and buntings.
('19', 25, 2, 20, 54157) If cleanliness and comfort are ensured, beauty will follow as a matter of course.
('19', 25, 2, 21, 54239) If we have a clean and open plot, with plenty of trees at the right spots, we cannot imagine a better pandal than this.
('19', 25, 2, 22, 54359) We want lakhs of people to attend our conferences.
('19', 25, 2, 23, 54410) If we do not, we ought to.
('19', 25, 2, 24, 54437) Even in England pandals are not erected when lakhs attend.
('19', 25, 2, 25, 54496) A wooden framework is erected in the middle for the president and some leading
('19', 25, 3, 26, 54575) 1 Vide “Letter to Patrick Geddes”, 12 4 1918
('19', 26, 0, 1, 54620) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 27
('19', 26, 1, 2, 54667) figures and round this seating arrangements are made for the general public.
('19', 26, 1, 3, 54744) The audience takes up very little space, a large number can hear the speeches made from the platform and the arrangements cost very little.
('19', 26, 1, 4, 54884) Where thousands assemble, we cannot detain them for long.
('19', 26, 1, 5, 54942) The main work of the Conference should be done in committee.
('19', 26, 1, 6, 55003) The resolutions should be finalized there and the arguments should be presented [in the plenary session] in the fewest words possible, in simple language, free of all pomposity, such as the people can understand.
('19', 26, 1, 7, 55216) In this way we can go through the work of the Conference, working only from 7 to 9 in the morning and from 5 to 7 in the evening, and save time for the committee.
('19', 26, 1, 8, 55379) If we fear excessive heat even during these hours, we can have lights and finish the work of the Conference at a sitting from 6 p.m.
('19', 26, 1, 9, 55512) to 9 p.m., or even later.
('19', 26, 2, 10, 55538) EXHIBITION AT CONFERENCE We also take the liberty to make another suggesion.

('19', 26, 2, 12, 55717) We amend this and suggest a swadesi exhibition.
('19', 26, 2, 13, 55765) We believe that we can easily arrange such an exhibition within the short time at our disposal.
('19', 26, 2, 14, 55861) Only recently an exhibition was held at Amreli and we have been told that not only did everything go off very well but that it was visited by thousands of men and women with great interest.
('19', 26, 2, 15, 56051) We hope that the Reception Committee and the enterprising citizens of Surat will do their best to carry out this suggestion.

('19', 26, 5, 18, 56213) 26. FATHER OF THE WORLD [ II]
('19', 26, 6, 19, 56243) In the last issue we briefly described the peasant's lot.
('19', 26, 6, 20, 56301) We have now to consider ways and means of improving it.
('19', 26, 6, 21, 56357) Mr. Lionel Curtis 2 , who came into limelight during the Luck now Congress, has in one place drawn a realistic picture of the Indian villages.
('19', 26, 6, 22, 56500) He says that the villages of India are situated on dunghills.
('19', 26, 6, 23, 56562) The huts are in ruins and the inhabitants feeble.
('19', 26, 6, 24, 56612) Temples are to be
('19', 26, 7, 25, 56630) 1 Public worker, Panch Mahals district, Gujarat 2 Member, Transvaal Legislative Council; vide “Interview to the Star”, 6 1 1908.
('19', 27, 0, 1, 56759) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 27, 1, 2, 56800) found at all sorts of places.
('19', 27, 1, 3, 56830) Cleanliness is non existent.
('19', 27, 1, 4, 56859) The lanes are full of dust.
('19', 27, 1, 5, 56887) The general appearance would suggest that no one was responsible for the management of the village.
('19', 27, 2, 6, 56987) There is little exaggeration in this account; in fact it could be extended.
('19', 27, 2, 7, 57063) There ought to be some method in the lay out of a well ordered village.
('19', 27, 2, 8, 57135) The streets should follow a definite pattern and not be laid out in the present arbitrary fashion.
('19', 27, 2, 9, 57234) And in India, where crores of people walk bare foot, the roads should be so clean that walking or even lying on them should not seem disagreeable.
('19', 27, 2, 10, 57381) The streets should be metalled and have gutters to drain away the water.
('19', 27, 2, 11, 57454) The temples and mosques should be clean and look ever fresh and should evoke in those who enter them a sense of peace and sanctity.
('19', 27, 2, 12, 57586) In and around the village there should be useful trees and orchards.
('19', 27, 2, 13, 57655) There should be a dharmashala, a school and a small hospital for the treatment of the sick.
('19', 27, 2, 14, 57747) Arrangements should be made for the bodily needs of the inhabitants so that the air, the streets, etc., are not polluted.
('19', 27, 2, 15, 57869) The inhabitants of every village should be able to raise their own food and produce their own cloth and should be capable of defending them selves from thieves, marauders or wild beasts.
('19', 27, 2, 16, 58056) Most of these things were to be seen in the Indian village in olden days.
('19', 27, 2, 17, 58130) Those which were wanting were probably unnecessary at that time.
('19', 27, 2, 18, 58195) In any case, whether once they existed or not, no one can deny that villages should be planned on the lines I have indicated above.
('19', 27, 2, 19, 58327) It is only such villages that can be regarded as self sufficient.
('19', 27, 2, 20, 58393) And, if all our villages could be so organized, there is little that can afflict the country.
('19', 27, 3, 21, 58487) Not only is it possible to bring about such conditions, but it is not even as difficult as we imagine.
('19', 27, 3, 22, 58590) It is said that there are seven and a half lakhs of villages in India.
('19', 27, 3, 23, 58661) In that case the average population of a village is 400. In many villages the population is less than 1,000. It is my firm conviction that to make proper arrangements in a village with such a small population is a very easy matter.
('19', 27, 3, 24, 58893) It does not need long speeches or legislative assemblies or laws.
('19', 27, 3, 25, 58959) All that is required is a few sincere and willing workers, both men and women, as many as may be counted on the fingers of one hand.
('19', 27, 3, 26, 59092) These will be able, by their own exemplary conduct and spirit of service, to bring about the necessary transformation in every village.
('19', 27, 3, 27, 59228) Nor does this mean that these men and women must confine themselves day and night exclusively to this task.
('19', 27, 3, 28, 59336) Even while earning their livelihood they can, through their spirit of service, bring about important changes in the village.
('19', 28, 0, 1, 59461) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 29
('19', 28, 1, 2, 59508) It is not at all necessary that these workers be highly educated.
('19', 28, 1, 3, 59574) Village uplift can be undertaken even by the illiterate.
('19', 28, 1, 4, 59631) Neither the Government nor the princes can obstruct such efforts and there is little need for their help.
('19', 28, 1, 5, 59737) If such volunteers come forward in each village, the work of the entire nation can be done without any fuss or big movement.
('19', 28, 1, 6, 59862) Even a limited effort will produce results far beyond our expectations.
('19', 28, 1, 7, 59934) The reader will easily realize that even money would not be necessary for such work.
('19', 28, 1, 8, 60019) What is indispensable is character and religious zeal.
('19', 28, 1, 9, 60074) I know from experience that this is the easiest way of amelio rating the peasant’s lot.
('19', 28, 1, 10, 60162) In making such an effort, it is not necessary for any village or for any individual to wait for another to make a beginning.
('19', 28, 1, 11, 60287) If in any village there is even one man or woman with the sincere desire to serve the people, he or she can immediately start such work.
('19', 28, 1, 12, 60424) Such service will amount to the service of the entire nation.
('19', 28, 1, 13, 60486) I hope that those village dwellers into whose hands this issue of Navajivan falls will give a trial to the experiments suggested by me and, within a short time, demonstrate the results of their experiments to the rest of the country.
('19', 28, 1, 14, 60720) In the next issue I plan to place before my readers some of my experiences which may suggest how to make a beginning with these experiments.
('19', 28, 1, 15, 60861) But I also hope that any worker who has realized the importance of this task will start work on his own initiative without waiting even for a week.

('19', 28, 4, 18, 61046) 27. NOTES
('19', 28, 5, 19, 61056) LONG LIVE MRS.
('19', 28, 5, 20, 61071) BESANT!
('19', 28, 5, 21, 61079) Mrs. Besant entered her 73rd year last Wednesday.
('19', 28, 5, 22, 61129) On that day thousands of Indians must have prayed to God to grant this great lady many more years on this earth.
('19', 28, 5, 23, 61242) Few among us can, at the age of 33, show the diligence and industry Mrs. Besant continues to do at the age of 73. It is indisputable that the service rendered to India by Mrs. Besant will ever remain memorable in the country's history.
('19', 28, 5, 24, 61478) The enthusiasm with which the Indians seized the term "Home Rule" is due solely to this good lady and it was due to her courage that branches of the Home Rule League were established everywhere.
('19', 28, 5, 25, 61673) She has had a great share in the political education of India.
('19', 28, 5, 26, 61736) Even in England Mrs.
('19', 29, 0, 1, 61757) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 29, 1, 2, 61798) Besant is agitating for Home Rule for India.
('19', 29, 1, 3, 61843) She is using all her resources for the cause of Home Rule.
('19', 29, 1, 4, 61902) There may be differences of opinion about Mrs. Besant's ideas and her methods of work, but there can be none about her service to India.
('19', 29, 1, 5, 62039) Not only is she considered the best woman speaker in the world, very few even among men could rival her eloquence.
('19', 29, 1, 6, 62154) Her pen, too, has great force.
('19', 29, 1, 7, 62185) For many years, this lady has been using all these great powers in the service of India, and for this the country will ever remain grateful to her.
('19', 29, 1, 8, 62333) And so the prayer, "Long live Mrs. Besant!" is, really speaking, a prayer for our benefit.
('19', 29, 2, 9, 62424) CLOUD OVER "NAVAJIVAN"
('19', 29, 3, 10, 62447) As the navajivan 1 of India progresses extremely slowly and comes upon many a check on the way, so does Navajivan, the paper.
('19', 29, 3, 11, 62573) It has to contend against both internal and external difficulties.
('19', 29, 3, 12, 62640) The external difficulty consists in harassment by the government and, deterred by this harassment, people hesitate to help in printing the paper and in other ways.
('19', 29, 3, 13, 62804) The reader is aware of some of the facts of the official harassment.
('19', 29, 3, 14, 62873) When the Government asked questions and pointed out that, Navajivan being a new paper, it was necessary under the regulations framed under the Defence of India Act to obtain the Bombay Govern ment's permission for publishing it, Mr. Indulal Yagnik, believing that the Government's interpretation must be correct, admitted straightaway that a mistake had been made in publishing Navajivan.
('19', 29, 3, 15, 63262) At that time I was in Dhoraji.
('19', 29, 3, 16, 63293) On reaching the Ashram and reading the Act, I felt that Mr. Indulal was wrong.
('19', 29, 3, 17, 63372) Being a satyagrahi, he frankly admitted what he believed to be true, so that his action in admitting the error does him nothing but credit.
('19', 29, 3, 18, 63512) But I could see that this admission was the result of a mistake.
('19', 29, 3, 19, 63577) Navajivan cannot be described as a new paper.
('19', 29, 3, 20, 63623) Everyone recognizes and knows it as a fact that the monthly Nava jivan has been changed into this weekly.
('19', 29, 3, 21, 63729) The dropping of the words Ane Satya 2 , as redundant, from the title of the monthly Navajivan does not make it a new journal.
('19', 29, 3, 22, 63855) Accordingly, with his consent, I decided that Navajivan ought not to be withheld from the public till the Government had made up its mind.

('19', 30, 2, 11, 65154) SPINNING WHEEL The success of the swadeshi movement depends in a large measure on our producing simple but quick working machines for ginning cotton, on our making the process of carding easy and effec ting possible improvements in the spinning wheel and the loom.
('19', 30, 2, 12, 65419) It seems a few people believe that, in Mr. Gandhi's movement, there is no scope for improvement in ancient or modern machines.This is a mistaken belief.
('19', 30, 2, 13, 65572) His opinion is this.
('19', 30, 2, 14, 65593) The machines or the improvements in the machines must be such as will suit our country and lend themselves to use in one's home.
('19', 30, 2, 15, 65722) Keeping this in mind, Mr. Gandhi is ever on the watch for possible improvements.
('19', 30, 2, 16, 65803) No farmer, and not all artisans, can work in big factories.
('19', 30, 2, 17, 65863) The farmers cannot leave their fields; it is the duty of every well wisher of India to discover some means and take steps for intorducing an industry in their homes in addition to their work in the fields.
('19', 30, 2, 18, 66069) Hence we announce in this number and welcome the prize offered by Mr. Rewashankar Jagjivan Mehta.

('19', 31, 1, 2, 66505) spinning wheel is our first need.

('19', 31, 1, 5, 66792) There is absolutely no doubt that the type of spinning wheel in use at present can be improved.
('19', 31, 1, 6, 66888) Some patriotic artisans are already working to that end.
('19', 31, 1, 7, 66945) An expert artisan from Gondal has made a delicate spinning wheel of brass.
('19', 31, 1, 8, 67020) His aim is not to increase the turn out of yarn but to produce a wheel that will be easy to carry from place to place and be also durable.
('19', 31, 1, 9, 67159) This artisan is still at work devising improvements in that model.

('19', 31, 1, 11, 67411) In Broach, a spinning wheel with two spindles working simultanously has already been invented.

('19', 31, 1, 16, 68011) We hope that a great many competent artisans will strive to win the prize offered by Mr. Rewashankar Mehta.
('19', 31, 2, 17, 68119) IMPROVEMENT IN METHOD OF CREMATION
('19', 31, 3, 18, 68154) We have had two or three letters from Shri Chhotalal Tejpal, and also some literature on the movement he is carrying on.
('19', 31, 3, 19, 68275) There is so much of it and so thick laid with secondary details that we are unable to publish it 1 Hence we intend merely to describe here his purpose, which has appeared useful to us.
('19', 31, 3, 20, 68460) Day by day the difficulties of disposing of dead bodies are increasing.
('19', 31, 3, 21, 68532) Those of the poor are greater.
('19', 31, 3, 22, 68563) Many lack even the facili ties for carrying the bodies.
('19', 31, 3, 23, 68619) The plague and such other epidemics break out frequently in the country and at such times the condition of the people is indeed pitiable.
('19', 31, 3, 24, 68757) Moreover, time is wasted in waiting for
('19', 31, 4, 25, 68797) 1 Vide “Letter to Chhotalal Tejpal”, 17 9 1919.
('19', 32, 0, 1, 68845) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 33
('19', 32, 1, 2, 68892) the body to be fully consumed.
('19', 32, 1, 3, 68923) Sometimes the logs on the pyre are so arranged that the body is not even fully covered by them.
('19', 32, 1, 4, 69019) Hence Mr. Chhotalal has been trying for some time to reform the manner of carrying the dead body and of cremating it.
('19', 32, 1, 5, 69137) We think the enterprise deserves encouragement.
('19', 32, 1, 6, 69185) He suggests that the body should be removed in a vehicle and that the crematorium should be cons tructed scientifically so that the body will be put into a furnace and be quickly reduced to ashes by a strong fire.
('19', 32, 1, 7, 69399) This will save money and time without hurting religious sentiment in any way.
('19', 32, 1, 8, 69477) All the same, it would be better for the present not to make it compulsory for dead bodies to be carried in vehicles and scientifically cremated, but to leave them to people's choice.
('19', 32, 1, 9, 69661) In such matters, it is necessary to educate the people.
('19', 32, 1, 10, 69717) Customs, even when undesirable, can be reformed but slowly.
('19', 32, 1, 11, 69777) Real reform lies in the people's willing acceptance of the change, in full knowledge of what it means, or on faith.
('19', 32, 1, 12, 69893) Therefore, if there are a few venturesome persons in a place, money is readily available and some persons at any rate are ready to accept the new method of cremation, if at such a place vehicles for transport and facilities for [scientific] cremation are provided and these are good enough, this important change will soon become popular and, in times of epidemics, the poor in any case are bound to welcome it gratefully.
