('19', 34, 7, 29, 72819) 32. WE ARE APT TO MAKE MISTAKES
('19', 34, 8, 30, 72851) The Hon'ble Mr. Sinha, whilst he was speaking on the Indemnity Bill, was led into a confusion of terms.
('19', 34, 8, 31, 72955) He was pulled up by Sir George Lowndes, and His Excellency the President defended Mr.
('19', 34, 9, 32, 73041) 1 From the contents.
('19', 34, 9, 33, 73062) The first issue of Young India as a weekly was published from Ahmedabad on October 8, 1919 with Gandhiji as editor.
('19', 35, 0, 1, 73178) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 35, 1, 2, 73219) Sinha saying it was a slip of the tongue.
('19', 35, 1, 3, 73261) Mr. Sinha then made these frank and dignified remarks:
('19', 35, 2, 4, 73316) It is hard for Your Excellency to realize what our difficulties are in speaking a
('19', 35, 3, 5, 73398) foreign tongue in this Council.
('19', 35, 3, 6, 73430) We are apt to make mistakes.
('19', 35, 3, 7, 73459) This is only too true.
('19', 35, 3, 8, 73482) We are apt to make mistakes in our own mother tongue.
('19', 35, 3, 9, 73536) But they are never so ludicrous as when we attempt to speak in a foreign tongue.
('19', 35, 3, 10, 73617) Professor Jadunath Sarkar has remarked that our having to speak and think in English puts a strain upon us from which we never fully recover.
('19', 35, 3, 11, 73759) The remedy for the evil is that we must begin self government by introducing our own speech in our own assemblies provincial vernaculars in the provincial legislatures, and Hindustani a resultant of Hindi and Urdu in the Imperial Council.
('19', 35, 3, 12, 73998) We cannot make a better beginning than by adopting the change in the Congress and the conferences.
('19', 35, 3, 13, 74097) In adopting English as the medium at these gatherings we have done a positive disservice to the masses who have but a vague idea of the proceedings of these annual gatherings.
('19', 35, 3, 14, 74273) By persisting to conduct them in English we have actually put obstacles in the way of the masses getting political education.
('19', 35, 3, 15, 74399) I imagine what would have happened if we had, during the thirty five years' existence of the National Congress, deliberated in Hindustani instead of English which is understood only by a microscopic minority of our countrymen.
('19', 35, 4, 16, 74626) Young India, 8 10 1919
('19', 35, 5, 17, 74649) 33. TO THE SUBSCRIBERS AND THE READERS
('19', 35, 6, 18, 74688) Young India from this week enters upon a new stage.
('19', 35, 6, 19, 74740) It became a bi weekly when Mr. Horniman was deported and the Chronicle was strangled.
('19', 35, 6, 20, 74826) Ever since the Chronicle's rebirth, the syndicate and I have been considering the advisability of reverting to the weekly issue.
('19', 35, 6, 21, 74955) The conversion of Navajivan into a weekly and its coming under my charge has hastened the decision.
('19', 35, 6, 22, 75055) The burden of conducting a bi weekly and a weekly is too great a strain on me and a weekly Young India will now serve almost as well as a bi weekly.
('19', 35, 6, 23, 75204) An endeavour will be made to give as much matter as was given in the bi weekly.
('19', 35, 6, 24, 75284) The annual subscription will now be Rs. 4 instead of Rs. 8 and the price of single copy will be one anna instead of two without postage.
('19', 35, 6, 25, 75421) Subscribers may either have the balance due to this change returned to them or the amount may be credited to the next year's account.
('19', 36, 0, 1, 75555) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 37
('19', 36, 1, 2, 75602) Those subscribers who may be dissatisfied with the change can have the proportionate payment refunded to them on application.
('19', 36, 1, 3, 75728) The headquarters of Young India have been transferred to Ahmedabad for better management, and in order to enable me to devote some time to the Satyagraha Ashram which, owing to my continued absence from it, was being somewhat neglected by me.
('19', 36, 1, 4, 75971) Moreover, it was obviously uneconomical in every respect to edit two papers at two different places.
('19', 36, 1, 5, 76072) This deprives me of the privilege of being with Bombay friends as much as I have lately been.
('19', 36, 1, 6, 76166) But I hope they will forgive me, if the new arrangement results, as I hope it will, in greater service to the country.
('19', 36, 1, 7, 76285) Young India has hitherto been chiefly occupied in dealing with the Punjab affairs.
('19', 36, 1, 8, 76368) But one may reasonably hope that the cloud will lift in the near future.
('19', 36, 1, 9, 76441) What will Young India then present to its readers?
('19', 36, 1, 10, 76492) I frankly confess that to me, editing a newspaper in English is no pleasure.
('19', 36, 1, 11, 76569) I feel that, in occupying myself with that work, I am not making the best use of my time.
('19', 36, 1, 12, 76659) And but for the Madras Presidency, I should now leave the work of editing Young India.
('19', 36, 1, 13, 76746) It is true that I should at times like to make my views in matters of general interest known to the Government.
('19', 36, 1, 14, 76858) But I do not need to control a newspaper merely for that purpose.
('19', 36, 1, 15, 76924) The editing of Navajivan has been a perfect revelation to me.
('19', 36, 1, 16, 76986) Whilst Young India has a little more than 1,200 subscribers, Navajivan has 12,000. The number would leap to 20,000 if we would but get printers to print that number.
('19', 36, 1, 17, 77152) It shows that a vernacular newspaper is a felt want.
('19', 36, 1, 18, 77205) I am proud to think that I have numerous readers among farmers and workers.
('19', 36, 1, 19, 77281) They make India.
('19', 36, 1, 20, 77298) Their poverty is India's curse and crime.
('19', 36, 1, 21, 77340) Their prosperity alone can make India a country fit to live.
('19', 36, 1, 22, 77401) They represent nearly 80 per cent of India's population.
('19', 36, 1, 23, 77458) The English journals touch but the fringe of the ocean of India's population.
('19', 36, 1, 24, 77536) Whilst, therefore, I hold it to be the duty of every English knowing Indian to translate the best of the English thought in the vernaculars for the benefit of the masses, I recognize that for a few years to come, i.e., until we have accepted Hindustani as the common medium among the cultured classes and until Hindustani becomes compulsory in our schools as a second language, educated India, especially in the Madras Presidency, must be addressed in English.
('19', 37, 0, 1, 77997) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 37, 1, 2, 78038) But I will not be party to editing a newspaper that does not pay its way.
('19', 37, 1, 3, 78112) Young India cannot pay its way unless it has at least 2,500 paying subscriber.
('19', 37, 1, 4, 78191) I must appeal to my Tamil friends to see to it that the requisite number of subscribers are found, if they wish to see Young India continued.
('19', 37, 1, 5, 78333) The more so now because the proprietors of Young India have decided to give up all advertisements.
('19', 37, 1, 6, 78432) I know that they have not been entirely, if at all, converted to my view that a newspaper ought to be conducted without advertisements.
('19', 37, 1, 7, 78568) But they are willing to let me make the experiment.
('19', 37, 1, 8, 78620) I invited those who wish to see Young India free from the curse of advertisements to help me to make the venture a success.
('19', 37, 1, 9, 78744) The Gujarati Navajivan has already demonstrated the possibility of conducting a newspaper without advertisements soiling its pages.
('19', 37, 1, 10, 78876) What a financial gain it would be to the country if there was for each province only one advertising medium not a newspaper containing innocent unvarnished notices of things useful for the public.
('19', 37, 1, 11, 79073) But for our criminal indifference, we would decline to pay the huge indirect taxation by way of mischievous advertisements.
('19', 37, 1, 12, 79197) Some readers who are interested in the purity of journalism recently sent me a most indecent advertisement extracted from a well known newspaper.
('19', 37, 1, 13, 79343) I have refused to soil the pages of Navajivan by reproducing it.
('19', 37, 1, 14, 79408) But anyone turning to the advertisement sheets of even leading journals can verify the aptness of my criticism.
('19', 37, 1, 15, 79520) A word as to the policy of Young India.
('19', 37, 1, 16, 79560) Apart from its duty of drawing attention to injustices to individuals, it will devote its attention to constructive satyagraha as also sometimes cleansing satyagraha.
('19', 37, 1, 17, 79727) Cleansing satyagraha is civil resistance where resistance becomes a duty to remove a persistent and degrading injustice such as the Rowlatt Act.
('19', 37, 2, 18, 79872) Young India, 8 10 1919
('19', 37, 3, 19, 79895) 34. SPEECH AT BARODA
('19', 37, 4, 20, 79916) [October 9, 1919] We have enthusiasm; we also have good ideals; but these will not ensure us our freedom.
('19', 37, 4, 21, 80022) They will not bring us what we seek.
('19', 37, 4, 22, 80059) Our deeds alone will go with us and decide the shape of the future.
('19', 37, 4, 23, 80127) If we do not translate our enthusiasm into action and see that it yields excellent results, it will have been to no purpose.

('19', 38, 1, 4, 80387) But instead of occupying ourselves with rousing idealism in people, if we applied ourselves to work, the effect would be better and we would succeed in awakening a steadier idealism through the example of work.
('19', 38, 1, 5, 80598) Yesterday there was great disorder at the station.
('19', 38, 1, 6, 80649) With order liness, men can work quietly , however large their number.
('19', 38, 1, 7, 80719) It is not enough that I came to no harm.
('19', 38, 1, 8, 80760) So many friends worked hard trying to ensure my safety.
('19', 38, 1, 9, 80816) What is necessary, however, is to maintain conditions in which no one would come to harm.
('19', 38, 1, 10, 80906) However large the crowd, if there is good order peace will be preserved.
('19', 38, 1, 11, 80979) Here conditions are favourable for this purpose.
('19', 38, 1, 12, 81028) This place has a fine gymnasium.
('19', 38, 1, 13, 81061) I have always said that drill is essential in any system of education.
('19', 38, 1, 14, 81132) If lakhs of people went ahead calmly according to a fixed plan, if at a sign they knew what was to be done, they could do things.
('19', 38, 1, 15, 81262) We ought to get such strength.
('19', 38, 1, 16, 81293) In the straits in which we find ourselves at present, we must learn how to finish the job on hand expeditiously.
('19', 38, 1, 17, 81406) Yesterday, two hours were wasted in taking out the procession.
('19', 38, 1, 18, 81469) I do not mean to say that such processions should be altogether dispensed with.
('19', 38, 1, 19, 81549) But we should be alive to the times.
('19', 38, 1, 20, 81586) India is in such a plight today that we cannot afford to waste our time in processions and such public demonst rations.
('19', 38, 1, 21, 81706) We shall not serve the motherland by parading in processions, raising slogans of "Vande Mataram" and shouting "Glory to the Motherland!" Today our India is aflame with a triple fire.
('19', 38, 1, 22, 81889) To rescue her from it, what is needed is not processions but physicians, not demonstrations but effective remedies.
('19', 38, 1, 23, 82005) We need heroic men and heroic mothers.
('19', 38, 1, 24, 82044) The time which belongs to the leaders of the people is the people's own and we should save it.
('19', 38, 1, 25, 82139) I make a simple reckoning.
('19', 38, 1, 26, 82166) Yesterday there must have been no less than four to five thousand people in the procession.
('19', 38, 1, 27, 82258) At the rate of two hours each, some eight to ten thousand hours from people's time were wasted.
('19', 38, 1, 28, 82354) If these many hours had been utilized at the spinning wheel…this being on my mind at the present time, I can speak of nothing else…or on the loom, what an amount of work could have been turned out?
('19', 38, 1, 29, 82552) Instead of wasting one's time thus, I think one would employ it to better purpose by sitting quietly in one's little cottage and thinking a few good thoughts.
('19', 38, 1, 30, 82711) We shall be able to compete with America, Japan and Europe only if we learn the value of time.

('19', 39, 1, 2, 82847) Those among us who know about the triple fire blazing in our country should work to put it out.
('19', 39, 1, 3, 82943) When a fire has broken out, we cannot afford to go looking for principles or formulating rules how to quench it; we fetch water and put it out and afterwards formulate rules for future guidance.

('19', 39, 1, 27, 85040) Men can live in that way, but surely we would not wish that women should.

('19', 42, 3, 4, 89015) TO THE EDITOR THE [BOMBAY] CHRONICLE
('19', 42, 4, 5, 89052) SIR, The Khilafat Conference at Lucknow has decided to observe Friday next, the 17th instant, as a day of fasting and prayer.
('19', 42, 4, 6, 89178) There can be no doubt about the intensity of Moslem feeling on this very important matter.
('19', 42, 4, 7, 89269) There is no doubt also that the intentions of the league are distrusted.
('19', 42, 4, 8, 89342) In one's darkest hour, God is the only refuge and it is to Him that millions of Moslems all over India are expected to turn for comfort, guidance and relief.
('19', 42, 4, 9, 89500) Millions of mouths will, that day, ask the Almighty if it be His will to avert the impending doom.
('19', 42, 4, 10, 89599) A true Moslem can no more contemplate with equanimity the dismem berment of Turkey than a Christian can so contemplate the desecra tion of what is dearest and nearest to him.
('19', 42, 4, 11, 89774) What are the Hindus to do?
('19', 42, 4, 12, 89801) I feel that they could do no less than their Mohammedan brethren.
('19', 42, 4, 13, 89867) Their fast and prayer will be the truest test of friendship and fellow feeling.
('19', 42, 4, 14, 89947) I hope that every Hindu, man and woman, will observe the 17th instant and thus put a sacred seal on the Hindu Mohammedan bond.
('19', 42, 4, 15, 90074) There is also to be a hartal.
('19', 42, 4, 16, 90104) It is intended to impress upon His Majesty's Ministers the seriousness of the position.
('19', 42, 4, 17, 90192) But, in order to be impressive, it has to be absolutely peaceful and voluntary.
('19', 42, 4, 18, 90272) Any exercise of force will make it thoroughly useless for the purpose for which it is intended.
('19', 42, 4, 19, 90368) If the Mohammedans really feel, and if the Hindus are sincere in their professions of friendship, naturally they will both voluntarily stop work on the 17th.
('19', 42, 4, 20, 90526) I have ventured tenderly to advise that, in view of past experience, there should be no processions, no meetings.
('19', 42, 4, 21, 90640) 1 Everyone must remain indoors except
('19', 42, 5, 22, 90678) 1 Vide the following item.

('19', 43, 1, 3, 90805) Any breach of the peace will simply mar a most excellent cause.
('19', 43, 1, 4, 90869) I have, therefore, further suggested that the mill hands should in no way be encouraged to stop work, nor those who are engaged in the interests of the public health.
('19', 43, 1, 5, 91036) I venture to hope that the Government will rise to the occasion.

('19', 44, 2, 3, 92177) SABARMATI, October 10, 1919 I hope you have seen my remarks in Young India of 4th October 1919 as also my public letter 2 regarding demonstration of the 17th.
('19', 44, 2, 4, 92336) I think all non Mohammedans should join the Mohammedans in fasting, prayer and hartal.
('19', 44, 2, 5, 92423) Fasting and prayer I regard as a purely religious function and no part of demonstration.
('19', 44, 2, 6, 92512) Hartal is intended to be purely a demonstration.
('19', 44, 2, 7, 92561) It must be voluntary.
('19', 44, 2, 8, 92583) Personally I do not care if only a few Hindus join, and I should be exceedingly sorry if any join out of fear be they ever so many.
('19', 44, 2, 9, 92715) In order to avoid untoward consequences, I have suggested that there should be no processions, no meetings, people should keep indoors and that volunteers should parade business quarters in order to protect those who might wish to keep their shops open.
('19', 44, 2, 10, 92969) Mill hands should not be called out and those who may be required for sanitary and such other daily work should be specially advised not to stop work.
('19', 44, 2, 11, 93120) I hope you will take what steps you may consider necessary to give effect to my proposal if you agree with me.
('19', 44, 3, 12, 93231) Yours sincerely,
('19', 44, 4, 13, 93248) M. K. GANDHI

('19', 45, 13, 18, 95207) 40. FASTING AND PRAYER
('19', 45, 14, 19, 95230) It is my conviction and my experience that, if fasting and prayer are done with a sincere heart and in a religious spirit, marvellous results could be obtained from them.
('19', 45, 14, 20, 95401) There is nothing as purifying as a fast, but fasting without prayer is barren; it may result in a diseased person being restored to health or may only mean a healthy person
('19', 45, 15, 21, 95574) 1 Vide “Letter to the Press” and “Circular Letter”, 10 10 1919.
('19', 46, 0, 1, 95638) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 47
('19', 46, 1, 2, 95685) suffering unnecessarily.
('19', 46, 1, 3, 95710) A fast undertaken purely for ostentation or to inflict pain on others is an unmitigated sin.
('19', 46, 1, 4, 95803) Hence, it is only a prayerful fast undertaken by way of penance to produce some effect on oneself which can be called a religious fast.
('19', 46, 1, 5, 95939) Prayer does not mean begging God for worldly happiness or for the things which advance one's interests; it is the earnest cry of a soul in anguish.
('19', 46, 1, 6, 96087) It cannot but influence the whole world and cannot but make itself heard in the divine court.
('19', 46, 1, 7, 96181) When an individual or a nation suffers because of a great calamity, the true awareness of that suffering is prayer; in the presence of this purifying knowledge, physical functions like eating, etc., become less urgent.
('19', 46, 1, 8, 96400) A mother suffers when her only son dies.
('19', 46, 1, 9, 96441) She has no desire for eating.
('19', 46, 1, 10, 96471) A nation is born when all feel the same sort of grief at the suffering of any one among them; such a nation deserves to be immortal.
('19', 46, 1, 11, 96604) We are well aware that quite a large number of our brothers and sisters in India live in great suffering and so, truly speaking, we have occasion at every step for prayerful fasting.
('19', 46, 1, 12, 96787) But our national life has not attained to this degree of intensity and purity.
('19', 46, 1, 13, 96866) Even so, occasions arise when we suffer acutely.
('19', 46, 1, 14, 96915) Such an occasion has arisen for our Muslim brethren.
('19', 46, 1, 15, 96968) Readers of Navajivan know what it is: if Turkey is partitioned, the Khilafat will disappear.
('19', 46, 1, 16, 97061) If the Khilafat disappears, Islam will lose its vitality.
('19', 46, 1, 17, 97119) This the Muslims can never tolerate.
('19', 46, 1, 18, 97156) Supporting my view, the good Mr. Andrews said that, if the Muslims feel they have not received justice, then Mr. Montagu and His Excellency the Viceroy should resign.
('19', 46, 1, 19, 97323) This remedy is essential, but external.
('19', 46, 1, 20, 97363) A far, far more powerful remedy lies in the hands of our Muslim brethren themselves.
('19', 46, 1, 21, 97448) It has been decided that on Friday, October 17, Muslims should observe a roza, that is, a fast of twenty four hours; accordingly, beginning from the evening of the 16th, they should spend the whole of the 17th in prayers.
('19', 46, 1, 22, 97670) This is a beautiful idea.
('19', 46, 1, 23, 97696) The peace and the good that ensue from turning our thoughts to God in a time of sorrow are not to be had in any other way.
('19', 46, 1, 24, 97819) The duty of Hindus at such a time is obvious.
('19', 46, 1, 25, 97865) If they regard the Muslims as their brethren, they should fully share their suffering.
('19', 46, 1, 26, 97952) This is the best and the easiest method of promoting unity between Hindus and Muslims.
('19', 46, 1, 27, 98039) Sharing another's sorrow is the only real sign of brotherly regard.
('19', 46, 1, 28, 98107) I hope, therefore, that every man and woman in India will spend October 17 in prayer and fasting.
('19', 46, 1, 29, 98205) The Gita is universally accepted among Hindus.
('19', 46, 1, 30, 98252) They should read it through from the beginning to the end, along with a rendering of its meaning.
('19', 47, 0, 1, 98350) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 47, 1, 2, 98391) This way the whole day will be spent in a religious spirit, and that will be the prayer of the Hindus.
('19', 47, 1, 3, 98494) I think we may, without fear, observe a hartal on that day.
('19', 47, 1, 4, 98554) Those who are independent should stop their work.
('19', 47, 1, 5, 98604) People in service, the labourers and those who serve in hospitals, etc., need not stop work.
('19', 47, 1, 6, 98697) If people remain within doors on the day and take out no processions, there will be no cause for fear.
('19', 47, 1, 7, 98800) There can be no coercion in fasting and prayer; and this should also be true about stopping work.
('19', 47, 1, 8, 98898) A hartal can be effective only if it is purely voluntary.
('19', 47, 1, 9, 98956) Such a hartal alone can provide the true measure of the feelings of Hindus and Muslims.
('19', 47, 1, 10, 99044) In order that the hartal may remain voluntary, those who are appointed volunteers may move about.
('19', 47, 1, 11, 99142) It should be their duty to see that no one offers violence to, or exerts undue pressure on, those who open their shops or attend to their work.
('19', 47, 1, 12, 99286) If the Government is wise, it will encourage the people in this step.
('19', 47, 1, 13, 99356) It is the duty of His Excellency the Viceroy, if he would demonstrate to the Muslims his sympathy for them, to instruct the officers not to come in the way of the people observing a hartal.
('19', 47, 1, 14, 99546) If His Excellency can go further, he could stop work on that day and thereby assuage the people a great deal.
('19', 47, 1, 15, 99656) Whether the Government does this or not, the duty of the people is clear.
('19', 47, 1, 16, 99730) Hindus and Muslims should unite to observe October 17 in the manner suggested above.
('19', 47, 2, 17, 99815) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 12 10 1919
('19', 47, 3, 18, 99853) 41. WIDOWS' OUTPOURING
('19', 47, 4, 19, 99876) Eleven sisters from Surat have written two letters, pouring out their suffering.
('19', 47, 4, 20, 99957) They begin their letters with the words: "We are Vaishnava, Vanik widows, widowed in childhood." They have given their own names but concealed the names of their parents and their addresses.
('19', 47, 4, 21, 100148) I am sorry that they have not given full particulars about themselves.
('19', 47, 4, 22, 100219) The law governing newspapers requires that the editor should pay no attention to anonymous letters, and this law is necessary.
('19', 47, 4, 23, 100346) It is the editor's duty, if a correspondent does not desire his name to be published, to respect it fully, but the writer must give his full name for the information of the editor.
('19', 47, 4, 24, 100527) If this is not done, the editor, despite his keenness to help, cannot help as much as he otherwise could.
('19', 47, 4, 25, 100633) In the case of these sisters themselves, I see that, if I

('19', 48, 1, 2, 100738) knew their names and addresses, I could inquire for more details and also find persons who would befriend them in their suffering.

('19', 49, 1, 2, 103225) purity be expected of widows without placing them in conditions in which they could live a life if illustrious widowhood?
('19', 49, 1, 3, 103347) These complex problems are not easy to solve.
('19', 49, 1, 4, 103393) There is an element of truth on either side.
('19', 49, 1, 5, 103438) Without entering into argument I wish to place before the Hindu society the following conclusions: 1. The attempt to end the practice of widowhood is injurious to religion.
('19', 49, 1, 6, 103611) 2. Marriage is a sacrament.
('19', 49, 1, 7, 103639) Love can marry only once.
('19', 49, 1, 8, 103665) 3. A widow deserves to be looked upon with reverence.
('19', 49, 1, 9, 103719) It is a sin to despise her.
('19', 49, 1, 10, 103747) The sight of a pure widow is a good omen.
('19', 49, 1, 11, 103789) It is a sin to count it as an ill omen.
('19', 49, 1, 12, 103829) 4. If marriage is, or is considered to be, a sacrament, and if it is a symbol of pure love, then marrying children and ill matched partners must be considered a sin.
('19', 49, 1, 13, 103995) If it is not wrong for a man of fifty to marry a girl of nine, and if such a man is not excommunicated, then it is also a sin to excommunicate or otherwise punish that girl if, becomming a widow, she marries again.
('19', 49, 1, 14, 104210) There is no room for coercion in the matter of dharma.
('19', 49, 1, 15, 104265) And therefore, my advice to the Vaishnava and other Hindu families regarding child widows in Surat is that they should think out a plan to keep to minds and bodies of the widows occupied and save them from temptations, and put the plan into action.
('19', 49, 1, 16, 104514) Even so, if it is important that a child widow should not be induced to remarry, it is equally important that, should such a widow want to remarry, she should not be prevented from doing so.
('19', 49, 1, 17, 104705) To live a widow's life is a holy thing, but it is not entirely sinful for a widow to remarry.
('19', 49, 1, 18, 104799) If the various communities would live so as to bring credit to varnashrama, if they do not want it to disappear, they will have to eliminate the innumerable evils that have arisen in it and see that the problems which arise in practice are solved with due regard for dharma.
('19', 49, 1, 19, 105074) To the widows, therefore, I would say: "Look upon your widowhood as sacred and live a life worthy of it.
('19', 49, 1, 20, 105179) There are many instances of such widows in Hindu society." To people of the various communities I would say: "If any child widows want to remarry, do not despise or outcast them."

('19', 50, 1, 2, 105444) 42. NOTES
('19', 50, 2, 3, 105454) EXEMPTION FROM SECURITY
('19', 50, 3, 4, 105478) The reader probably remembers that, when Navajivan was turned into a weekly, a security of five hundred rupees was ordered.
('19', 50, 3, 5, 105602) We have also told him of the cloud that subsequently gathered over us and dispersed.
('19', 50, 3, 6, 105687) 1 The management realized that a paper like Navajivan, in printing which one must be prepared for risks and copies of which should be made available to the public regularly and in large numbers, could be printed unhindered only in its own printing press; that is, only in this way can its external difficulties be reduced to a minimum.
('19', 50, 3, 7, 106023) And so Mr. Shankerlal Ghelabhai Banker, who shoulders the financial responsibility, has purchased the Manahar Press and it will henceforth be known as "Navajivan Mudranalaya".
('19', 50, 3, 8, 106199) Moreover, it was felt to be a difficult arrangement under which Young India, for which the editor of Navajivan is responsible, was published in Bombay while the latter was published in Ahmedabad.
('19', 50, 3, 9, 106395) It was, therefore, decided to publish Young India, too, in Ahmedabad.
('19', 50, 3, 10, 106465) This made it necessary to make declarations in respect of Young India, Navajivan and the Navajivan Press.
('19', 50, 3, 11, 106571) These declarations were made before the Magistrate in Ahmedabad.
('19', 50, 3, 12, 106636) He decided not to ask for security from either of the papers or from the Press.
('19', 50, 3, 13, 106716) We congratulate the District Magistrate on this decision of his.
('19', 50, 3, 14, 106781) So long as the sword of the unjust provisions in the Press Act continues to flash over Indian newspapers, we can feel or express no joy at Young India and Navajivan having been exempted from security.
('19', 50, 3, 15, 106982) A security cannot place any kind of check on our pen.
('19', 50, 3, 16, 107036) Exemption from it does not increase by one jot our freedom from inhibition; it increases our responsibility a little, lest we express, knowingly or unknowingly, views which may once again make them think that we deserved being called upon to furnish a security.
('19', 50, 3, 17, 107298) No matter whether our responsibility has increased or decreased, we will strive hard to place before the public our views with politeness and restraint, but without fear.
('19', 50, 4, 18, 107469) 1 Vide “Notes”, 5 10 1919.
('19', 51, 0, 1, 107496) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 51, 1, 2, 107537) "YOU CANNOT UNDERSTAND OUR DIFFICULTIES" The Hon'ble Mr. Sachchidanada Sinha, the well known journalist 1 of Bihar and member of the Imperial Legislative Council, while speaking on the Indemnity Bill made some mistake.
('19', 51, 1, 3, 107756) Sir George Lowndes tried to correct him.
('19', 51, 1, 4, 107797) His Excellency the Viceroy observed that it was a slip.
('19', 51, 1, 5, 107853) But the Hon'ble Mr. Sinha replied: "You can have no idea of the difficulty we experience in speaking in a foreign tongue.
('19', 51, 1, 6, 107975) We commit mistakes again and again." These words are worthy of Mr. Sinha.
('19', 51, 1, 7, 108049) Obliged to speak in a foreign tongue, even the ablest members find themselves in difficulties and time and again we are worsted when it comes to returning a quick retort.
('19', 51, 1, 8, 108220) This happens not because our case is weak or our knowledge is less but because we have to speak in a foreign language.
('19', 51, 1, 9, 108339) Every Indian who has been to England knows how even those among them who are proficient in English fumble when speaking it in English families of even ordinary education and often become the butt of ridicule.
('19', 51, 1, 10, 108548) Jadunath Sircar has shown that having to think and speak in English imposes a heavy burden on the educated class, so heavy, indeed, that it has lost its vigour and is ailing.
('19', 51, 1, 11, 108723) Justice Ranade, likewise, pointed out several years ago that many of them came to an untimely end and they possessed little inventive power.
('19', 51, 1, 12, 108864) Sooner or later we shall have to find a remedy for this painful situation, and the sooner the better.
('19', 51, 1, 13, 108966) The business of provincial legislatures should be conducted in their respective languages and that of the Imperial Legislative Council in the national language, namely, Hindustani.
('19', 51, 1, 14, 109147) The movement should start with the sessions of the Congress and various conferences.
('19', 51, 1, 15, 109232) If the former would take its message to the millions, it can never do so through English but only through Hindustani.

('19', 55, 8, 23, 117469) Whereas under Rule 3 of the Defence of India (Consolidated) Rules, 1915 and with the previous sanction of the Governor General in Council, the Lieut.
('19', 55, 8, 24, 117619) Governor of the Punjab was pleased on the 9th April, 1919, to prohibit the entry of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi into the Punjab and was further pleased to order him to return to and reside within the limits of the Bombay Presidency;
('19', 55, 9, 25, 117851) 1 The petition was reproduced in the same issue of Young India.
('19', 55, 10, 26, 117915) 2 This was published in several leading newspapers.

('19', 56, 1, 2, 118014) And whereas the necessity for this order has ceased to exist;
('19', 56, 2, 3, 118076) Now therefore the Lieut. Governor is pleased with the sanction of the Governor General hereby to cancel the said order with effect from this day, the 15th Oct.
('19', 56, 2, 4, 118236) 1919. 1
('19', 56, 3, 5, 118244) I am naturally thankful for it in that it enables me to visit the Punjab and to render such service as I may be capable of rendering.
('19', 56, 3, 6, 118378) At the same time, I cannot help saying that it was not with unmixed pleasure that I received the release order.
('19', 56, 3, 7, 118490) The order of internment and externment was no discredit to me; my conscience was absolutely clear.
('19', 56, 3, 8, 118589) When it was served upon me, it appeared to me to be an act of criminal folly on the part of the Government.
('19', 56, 3, 9, 118697) And now, though the release order is creditable to Government, it cannot recall the precious lives for whose loss the prohibitory order must be held responsible.
('19', 56, 3, 10, 118859) Moreover, so long as the Rowlatt Act remains on the statute book, the release order can be no joy for me.
('19', 56, 3, 11, 118965) In the internment order I had a ready made weapon for offering civil resistance.
('19', 56, 3, 12, 119046) I hear people saying that satyagraha is as dead as Queen Anne, 2 and that Mr. Montagu will never repeal the Rowlatt Act, although he is quite sure that the act will never be enforced.
('19', 56, 3, 13, 119230) Those who make the first statement do not know what satyagraha is and how it works.
('19', 56, 3, 14, 119314) Those who make the second do not know the power of satyagraha.
('19', 56, 3, 15, 119377) He who make the second do not know the power of satyagraha.
('19', 56, 3, 16, 119437) He who runs may see that satyagraha is slowly but surely pervading the land.
('19', 56, 3, 17, 119514) So far as Mr. Montagu's
('19', 56, 4, 18, 119538) 1 The removal of restriction on Gandhiji was, in fact, being seriously considered as early as September.

('19', 56, 4, 20, 119672) 1917, Home Department) of the Government of India, dated September 8, observed: “Conditions are now comparatively normal and there seems no immediate intention on his part of advocating civil disobedience.
('19', 56, 4, 21, 119878) In view of His Excellency’s opening speech in the Imperial Legislative Council, the Government of India think that a suitable opportunity now presents itself to relax the existing orders and that there is not sufficient ground for maintaining the restrictions on him and they propose that, when Lord Hunter lands in India, all restrictions should be relaxed.” 2 This reflected the official reading of the situation.
('19', 56, 4, 22, 120294) The Bombay Government wrote on September 12, in a confidential note to the Chief Secretary, Madras Government: “His Excellency in Council considers that Gandhi’s satyagraha movement may, for the present, be regarded as extinct.
('19', 56, 4, 23, 120522) Even in Gujarat, which is Gandhi’s headquarters and where the movement originated, the local organization have fallen to pieces.

('19', 57, 3, 8, 121710) 47. LETTER TO H.S.L. AND MILLIE GRAHAM POLAK
('19', 57, 4, 9, 121755) M.K. GANDHI Khilafat Day, October 17 [1919] 1
('19', 57, 5, 10, 121801) MY DEAR HENRY AND MILLIE,
('19', 57, 6, 11, 121827) You have both blessed me with your letters.
('19', 57, 6, 12, 121871) I thank you.

('19', 59, 4, 5, 124420) 50. FATHER OF THE WORLD [ III]
('19', 59, 5, 6, 124451) I have promised to give some of my experiences in connection with village uplift.
('19', 59, 5, 7, 124533) Dr. Hariprasad, describing how Sister Nivedita improved a lane in Calcutta, has illustrated by this example what one man or woman can do if he or she so wills.
('19', 59, 5, 8, 124693) To do this sort of work in villages is even easier than improving lanes in a city.
('19', 59, 5, 9, 124776) When it was decided to open self sufficient schools in Champaran, 1 I appealed for volunteers.
('19', 59, 5, 10, 124871) Among those who arrived were the late Dr. Dev and Mr. Soman, a lawyer from Belgaum.
('19', 59, 5, 11, 124955) These volunteers had to perform only three tasks…teach any boys and girls who came, show the villagers how to maintain cleanliness in the streets, in the village and their homes, etc., and give medicine to any patients who might come for it.
('19', 59, 5, 12, 125197) Mr. Soman was sent to a village called Bhitiharva and Dr. Dev was to organize medical aid in villages having schools.
('19', 59, 5, 13, 125315) He happened to stay for a longer period at the school in Bhitiharva.
('19', 59, 5, 14, 125384) It was very difficult to induce the people there to effect any improvements.
('19', 59, 5, 15, 125461) Dr. Dev showed them that improvements were necessary.
('19', 59, 5, 16, 125515) But the villagers paid no attention to him.
('19', 59, 5, 17, 125559) His proposal was about cleaning the streets and constructing a sloping platform round the well and removing the mud from around it.
('19', 59, 5, 18, 125691) Dr. Dev and Mr. Soman then took pickaxes in their hands and began to make a sloping platform round the well and to clean the streets.
('19', 59, 5, 19, 125825) The news spread like wildfire through the tiny village and the villagers understood Dr. Dev's advice.
('19', 59, 5, 20, 125927) His action were more potent than his words.
('19', 59, 5, 21, 125971) The villagers than sallied forth themselves to do the cleaning and very soon the well and streets of Bhitiharva took on an attractive appearance.
('19', 59, 5, 22, 126117) Rubbish heaps disappeared.
('19', 59, 5, 23, 126144) Meanwhile, the thatched school house which had been erected was burnt down by some miscreants.
('19', 59, 5, 24, 126239) This posed a serious problem.
('19', 59, 5, 25, 126269) Should a similar construction be put up and a fire risked again?
('19', 59, 5, 26, 126334) Mr. Soman and Dr. Dev decided to put up a brick structure for the school.
('19', 59, 5, 27, 126408) By now both of them had learnt the art of public speaking.
('19', 59, 5, 28, 126467) They begged for the requisite materials.
('19', 59, 5, 29, 126508) When necesssary they supplied
('19', 59, 6, 30, 126538) 1 Vide “Letter to J.l.
('19', 59, 6, 31, 126561) Merriman”, 22 11 1917.
('19', 60, 0, 1, 126584) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 61
('19', 60, 1, 2, 126631) money themselves and both began to work as labourers.
('19', 60, 1, 3, 126685) By the time they had completed the foundation for a durable school building, the villagers joined them.
('19', 60, 1, 4, 126789) Artisans gave all possible assistance, and even today the Bhitiharva school stands there as an example of what can be achieved if one or two individuals make up their mind to do a thing.
('19', 60, 1, 5, 126976) This sort of work was done not only in one village but to a greater or less extent in every place where a school was established and everywhere the villagers' response was in proportion to the teacher's capacity to inspire co operation.
('19', 60, 1, 6, 127213) The service did not demand any great intelligence.
('19', 60, 1, 7, 127264) What was needed was ardour and perseverance.
('19', 60, 1, 8, 127309) Intelligence and skill were available from others.
('19', 60, 1, 9, 127360) In the Kheda district, the crop had to be valued.
('19', 60, 1, 10, 127410) This could not be done unless all the villagers co operated.
('19', 60, 1, 11, 127471) Volunteers were detailed, one for each village, to collect the information; they not only succeeded in doing so but also won the affection of the villagers.
('19', 60, 1, 12, 127628) I can multiply such examples from many other places.
('19', 60, 1, 13, 127681) Now we can see how a start may be made by one who wants to organize a village properly.
('19', 60, 1, 14, 127769) He should select the place where he himself lives.
('19', 60, 1, 15, 127820) He should get acquainted with all the other residents and share in their tribulations without making a show of any kind.
('19', 60, 1, 16, 127941) He would then appeal for their help in cleaning the lanes.
('19', 60, 1, 17, 128000) The worker would bear the neighbour's ridicule and insults and continue, in spite of them, to share in their suffering and would clean the streets single handed.
('19', 60, 1, 18, 128162) His wife, mother and sister should, by and by, join in this work.
('19', 60, 1, 19, 128228) Whether the neighbours join or not, the road would be cleaned and experience would show that this does not require much time.
('19', 60, 1, 20, 128354) At last the neighbours would start working themselves and the fragrance of one lane would sweeten the entire village.
('19', 60, 1, 21, 128472) If this volunteer has further enthusiasm and is himself an educated man, he would teach boys and unlettered adults in his street to read and write.
('19', 60, 1, 22, 128620) If anyone in the street falls ill and is unable to take medical treatment, the worker would find a good vaid for him.
('19', 60, 1, 23, 128738) If there is no one to look after the patient, he would do so himself.
('19', 60, 1, 24, 128808) While doing these things he would get an intimate knowledge of the economic and moral condition of his neighbours.
('19', 60, 1, 25, 128923) Having obtained this knowledge, he would plan how to bring about the desired improvement in them.
('19', 60, 1, 26, 129021) Working on in this manner he would gradually get an insight into the political inclination of his neighbours and through them of the entire village.
('19', 60, 1, 27, 129170) If, along with this insight, he also
('19', 61, 0, 1, 129207) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 61, 1, 2, 129248) develops the capacity to evoke co operation in the people, he could improve their political condition as well.
('19', 61, 1, 3, 129359) I have seen in Africa, Champaran, Kheda and elsewhere that those whom we regard as uneducated have, by dine of sheer perseverance and sympathy, been able to do great service and also make a fine impact on the public.
('19', 61, 1, 4, 129576) In every village where I found even one zealous man or woman, I have also discovered that he or she was doing excellent work in that village.
('19', 61, 1, 5, 129718) We shall examine next certain rules of cleanliness and of physical, moral, and economic health.
('19', 61, 1, 6, 129814) I hope that those who approve of them will start work on those lines in their respective villages.
('19', 61, 1, 7, 129913) If this happens, we shall be able to produce a powerful effect on the condition of some villages in a very short time.
('19', 61, 2, 8, 130032) [From Gujarati]
('19', 61, 3, 9, 130048) Navajivan, 19 10 1919
('19', 61, 4, 10, 130070) 51. GUJARAT'S GIFT
('19', 61, 5, 11, 130089) The friends of Prof.
('19', 61, 5, 12, 130110) Anandshankar Bapubhai Dhruva knew for some time that this jewel from Gujarat was joining the Banaras University, ending his 27 years' connnection with the Gujarat College.
('19', 61, 5, 13, 130282) The thing became public at two functions held during this week, one under the auspices of the Sahitya Sabha and the other organized by the students of Gujarat College.
('19', 61, 5, 14, 130450) At the second function, the Principal of the College was in the chair.
('19', 61, 5, 15, 130521) Addresses were presented to Prof.
('19', 61, 5, 16, 130555) Dhruva at both these functions.
('19', 61, 5, 17, 130587) By honouring him in this way, Gujaratis have honoured themselves.
('19', 61, 5, 18, 130653) We come across very few Indians who combine learning and dharma in the measure in which Prof.
('19', 61, 5, 19, 130747) Dhruva does.
('19', 61, 5, 20, 130760) He has not taken to the profession of teaching with a mercenary motive.
('19', 61, 5, 21, 130832) I believe he became a professor because he thought that thereby he would be able to serve the country better.
('19', 61, 5, 22, 130942) As an author, he has maintained his integrity with the utmost conscientiousness.
('19', 61, 5, 23, 131023) It is no ordinary responsibility which rests on an author, and that of one who would dive into the sea of ancient literature to bring up pearls is all the greater.
('19', 61, 5, 24, 131187) Sanskrit literature is like a sea, difficult to fathom.
('19', 61, 5, 25, 131243) Very few possess even a cursory knowledge of this literature.
('19', 61, 5, 26, 131305) It offers much scope for laziness and dishonesty.
('19', 61, 5, 27, 131355) We see at every step instances of this in our modern literature.
('19', 61, 5, 28, 131420) How many translations of the Bhagavad Gita do we have!
('19', 61, 5, 29, 131475) It is difficult to be pleased with any of them.
('19', 61, 5, 30, 131523) The translations of Manusmriti at the disposal of the people of Gujarat are
('19', 62, 0, 1, 131599) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 63
('19', 62, 1, 2, 131646) not entirely reliable.
('19', 62, 1, 3, 131669) Thanks to laziness, ignorance and sometimes deliberate mischief, people get faulty and incomplete translations of Sanskrit works.
('19', 62, 1, 4, 131799) At a time like this, everything which Anandshankarbhai has given stands like a beacon.
('19', 62, 1, 5, 131886) With regard to his interpretations, it is impossible to suspect dishonesty, ignorance, haste or laziness.
('19', 62, 1, 6, 131992) He has written whatever he has in a liberal and objective spirit believing in all good faith that it is true.
('19', 62, 1, 7, 132102) And, therefore, people need have no fear in accepting it.
('19', 62, 1, 8, 132160) Moreover, those who have come into contact with him have observed in his personal life the same qualities of character which he has shown in his public actions and in publc life.
('19', 62, 1, 9, 132339) By the force of his character, he has been able to maintain his influence both on the old and the new generations.
('19', 62, 1, 10, 132454) Though duly respecting old ideas, the ancient way of life and ancient traditions, he has never sought to check the waves of modern life and its enthusiasms.
('19', 62, 1, 11, 132611) Rather, he has tried to correct the excesses of both.
('19', 62, 1, 12, 132665) Gujarat has not till now made full use of Prof.
('19', 62, 1, 13, 132713) Dhruva's services, as was stated in the address presented by the students.
('19', 62, 1, 14, 132788) We have not freely availed ourselves of the treasure he possesses.
('19', 62, 1, 15, 132855) We have not recognized his full worth.
('19', 62, 1, 16, 132894) He is now entering a larger field.
('19', 62, 1, 17, 132929) The Banaras University is but an infant.
('19', 62, 1, 18, 132970) Its father is the celebrated Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, known all over India, who looks like the patriarch of Hinduism and is endowed with qualities of character signified by his name.
('19', 62, 1, 19, 133157) By the tireless efforts of one person, an amount of one crore has been collected.
('19', 62, 1, 20, 133239) The University owes its existence to the labours of this one man.
('19', 62, 1, 21, 133305) His child has however not learnt to walk.
('19', 62, 1, 22, 133347) It can only move about on its knees.
('19', 62, 1, 23, 133384) It needs someone to look after it.
('19', 62, 1, 24, 133419) Panditji was on the look out for such a person.
('19', 62, 1, 25, 133467) There are all kinds of difficulties in running a university; besides, a university which seeks to give its due place to religion is bound to be in the utmost need of men of religion.
('19', 62, 1, 26, 133650) Gujarat can be proud that Panditji found such a man here.
('19', 62, 1, 27, 133708) The university will provide full scope to Anandshankarbhai's intelligence, his earnestness, his integrity, his straightforwardness, his large heartedness and his imperturbable temper.
('19', 62, 1, 28, 133892) We congratulate Gujarat on making this incomparable gift and the university on receiving it, and we are confident that Anandshankarbhai will render excellent services to India in this wider field.
('19', 62, 1, 29, 134089) We pray to God to grant him a long life and all the strength which he will need in this difficult task.
('19', 62, 2, 30, 134193) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 10 1919
('19', 63, 0, 1, 134231) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 63, 1, 2, 134272) 52. NOTES
('19', 63, 2, 3, 134282) FOOLISH EXPENDITURE We draw our readers' attention to Shri Gopalji's letter.
('19', 63, 2, 4, 134359) The custom of sending a card for the New Year's Day has no meaning whatever and involves an unnecessary expenditure besides.
('19', 63, 2, 5, 134484) Shri Gopalji's point is that, instead of wasting money in this way, we should donate the amount to the Punjab Relief Fund.
('19', 63, 2, 6, 134607) If all of us do what he and his friends have done, we shall have shared the sufferings of the Punjab at no cost to ourselves.
('19', 63, 2, 7, 134733) Is it an old custom to get New Year cards printed and send them?
('19', 63, 2, 8, 134798) We do not know if it is.
('19', 63, 2, 9, 134823) We do not say either that we should not introduce new customs or that everything old is good.
('19', 63, 2, 10, 134917) We should think before giving up anything old.
('19', 63, 2, 11, 134964) It is wise not to be hasty in introducing a new custom.
('19', 63, 2, 12, 135020) The practice of sending cards has come from Europe.
('19', 63, 2, 13, 135072) Had we not been blinded by Europe, we would not have adopted this practice of sending cards and friends would have taken no pleasure in receiving them.
('19', 63, 2, 14, 135224) The practice is something like the prayer circles in Tibet.
('19', 63, 2, 15, 135284) Some people there want to repeat a prayer or jai lakhs of times over but, unable to spare so much time, keep wheels and count the number of its rotations as so many repetitions of the prayer.
('19', 63, 2, 16, 135476) In the same manner, we offer our greetings to friends through cards, at no trouble to ourselves.
('19', 63, 2, 17, 135573) To us this seems to be a barbarous custom.
('19', 63, 2, 18, 135616) It is understandable that we write letters specially to people whom we would remember.
('19', 63, 2, 19, 135703) Sending a card has become so common a practice that it can have no value.
('19', 63, 2, 20, 135777) Maybe sending the same type of card to one's father, brothers, sisters, wife, friend is treated as a sign of equal regard for all; to us it appears an insult to them all.
('19', 63, 2, 21, 135948) Hence we altogether disapprove of the practice of sending cards.
('19', 63, 2, 22, 136013) Be that as it may, the alternative to sending cards, suggested on the present occasion, deserves to be welcomed.
('19', 63, 3, 23, 136126) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 10 1919

('19', 65, 1, 2, 136885) 55. LETTER TO WATTAL
('19', 65, 2, 3, 136906) [AHMEDABAD, Before October 22, 1919] 1
('19', 65, 3, 4, 136945) DEAR MR. WATTAL, You will pardon me for some delay in replying to your letter, which was received in Bombay.
('19', 65, 3, 5, 137054) I wanted on my return from Bombay to search my papers, to see what I could find.
('19', 65, 3, 6, 137135) You have asked me for papers regarding an event that happened nearly 18 years ago.
('19', 65, 3, 7, 137218) I have searched my old files and I have not succeeded in getting all you want.
('19', 65, 3, 8, 137297) You will, however, have some idea of the impression created in S. Africa by the action of the Indian Community at the time of the Boer War.
('19', 65, 3, 9, 137437) Mr. Escombe, who addressed us, was sometime Premier of Natal and commander of the Natal militia, and so was the late Sir John Robinson, Premier at another time.
('19', 65, 3, 10, 137598) I give you these references, because you will find these names in the papers 2 I am sending you.
('19', 65, 3, 11, 137695) We were present at the battle of Colenso, Spion Kop and the action at Vaalkranz.
('19', 65, 3, 12, 137776) We had to carry the wounded on our stretchers a distance of about 20 miles, feed and nurse them on the way.
('19', 65, 3, 13, 137884) I was mentioned in Gen.
('19', 65, 3, 14, 137908) Buller's Despatch, on the relief of Ladysmith.
('19', 65, 3, 15, 137955) The leaders of the Corps were recipients of the South African War Medal.
('19', 65, 3, 16, 138028) In Ladysmith itself, an indentured Indian named Ganga Singh 3 sat perched up in a tree facing the hill from which the Boers were shelling Ladysmith with their pom pom.
('19', 65, 3, 17, 138196) He watched the flash of the gun each time it was fired, and rang a gong, informing the besieged of the coming shell, and warning them to seek shelter.
('19', 65, 3, 18, 138347) He performed his dangerous and onerous task with unfailing regularity, and for this brave and faithful service Lord Curzon sent him a toga, which was publicly presented to him, on Lord Curzon's behalf, by the Mayor of Durban at the Durban Town Hall.
('19', 65, 3, 19, 138597) I am sorry I have not been able to trace the verses referred to in your letter.
('19', 65, 3, 20, 138677) I am asking my friends in Durban to send them.
('19', 65, 4, 21, 138724) 1 The letter appears to have been written from Ahmedabad.
('19', 65, 4, 22, 138782) The exact date is not known.
('19', 65, 4, 23, 138811) It is, however, likely that this and the following item were written some time before October 22, 1919, after which Gandhiji was away in the Punjab for the rest of the year.
('19', 65, 4, 24, 138985) 2 These are not available.
('19', 65, 4, 25, 139012) 3 This should be Prabhu Singh; vide “Letter to Dadabhai Naoroji”, 8 10 1900
('19', 66, 0, 1, 139088) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 67
('19', 66, 1, 2, 139135) time of the Boer War, we were over 1,000 strong.
('19', 66, 1, 3, 139184) So much for the Boer War.
('19', 66, 1, 4, 139210) In 1906, there was the Zulu rebellion.
('19', 66, 1, 5, 139249) At that time also we offered our services.
('19', 66, 1, 6, 139292) They required only a small number.
('19', 66, 1, 7, 139327) We were about 20 strong, a compact body of the Nurse, Orderly and Stretcher bearers.
('19', 66, 1, 8, 139412) We had to carry the wounded many miles at a time and march behind the cavalry sometimes at the rate of 40 miles per day.
('19', 66, 1, 9, 139533) At this time there was no restriction as to the zone of fire.
('19', 66, 1, 10, 139595) This little party took all the risks of war.
('19', 66, 1, 11, 139640) A personal letter eulogizing the services of the Corps was addressed by the then Governor of Natal, Sir Henry MacCullum.
('19', 66, 1, 12, 139761) And then there was the European War.
('19', 66, 1, 13, 139798) Indians formed a corps.
('19', 66, 1, 14, 139822) I forget the number that served in East Africa directly under General Smuts, and I hear from one of the friends in S.A., who was a memeber of the Corps, that they gave entire satisfaction to their officer.

('19', 66, 5, 20, 140254) 56. LETTER TO A FRIEND
('19', 66, 6, 21, 140277) [Before October 22, 1919]
('19', 66, 7, 22, 140303) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.

('19', 68, 1, 2, 143589) 57. THE SATYAGRAHI LAWYERS 1
('19', 68, 2, 3, 143618) The judgment 2 of the High Court in the case of the Satyagrahi lawyers is, to say the least, highly unsatisfactory.
('19', 68, 2, 4, 143734) It has shirked the issue.
('19', 68, 2, 5, 143760) The logical outcome of the judgment should have been punishment and not a postponement of it.
('19', 68, 2, 6, 143854) The lawyers in question had shown no repentance.
('19', 68, 2, 7, 143903) So far as the public know, they will be ready to offer civil disobedience should the occasion arise.
('19', 68, 2, 8, 144004) The issue having been raised, the lawyers did not ask for mercy but a clear decision.
('19', 68, 2, 9, 144090) As it is, they do not know where they are.
('19', 68, 3, 10, 144133) The learned Judges have laid down principles of legal conduct which, in our humble opinion, are open to question.
('19', 68, 3, 11, 144247) For instance, what is the meaning of "those who live by the law must keep the law"?
('19', 68, 3, 12, 144331) If it means that no lawyer may ever commit a civil breach without incurring the displeasure of the Court, it means utter stagnation.
('19', 68, 3, 13, 144464) Lawyers are the persons most able to appreciate the dangers of bad legislation and it must be with them a sacred duty by committing civil breach to prevent a crminal breach.
('19', 68, 3, 14, 144638) Lawyers should be guardians of law and liberty and as such are interested in keeping the statute book of the country 'pure and undefiled'.
('19', 68, 3, 15, 144777) But the Judges of the Bombay High Court have presented to them a mercenary view of their profession and have even confounded the functions of judges and lawyers.
('19', 68, 3, 16, 144939) The only escape from the intolerable situation created by the
('19', 68, 4, 17, 145001) 1 This appeared among the “Notes”.
('19', 68, 4, 18, 145036) 2 This was reproduced in the same issue, and read as follows: “Separate but concurring judgments were delivered by the Chief Justice and Justices Heaton and Kajiji of the Bombay High Court in the case of the satyagrahi lawyers of Ahmedabad on 15th October, 1919. In summing up, the Chief Justice in his judgment said: ‘I wish to make it perfectly clear that, apart from any other considerations, those who are enrolled as advocates or pleaders of this High Court or of the District Courts cannot serve two masters.
('19', 68, 4, 19, 145551) It may be that after due consideration of this expression of our opinion, the respondents may see the force of it.
('19', 68, 4, 20, 145666) We have no desire to deal harshly with them and for the present we shall content ourselves with giving them the warning.
('19', 68, 4, 21, 145787) We do so because we are told that the Satyagraha Sabha since the riots of April has been quiescent.
('19', 68, 4, 22, 145887) Whether we shall take any further action depends entirely on the development, if any, of the satyagraha movement, so that these notices will be adjourned with leave to the Advocate General and the respondents to move for their restoration to the Board should occasion arise.’ ”
('19', 69, 0, 1, 146165) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 69, 1, 2, 146206) judgment is for the respondents to have the case restored to the Board, reargued, and to ask for a final decision.
('19', 69, 1, 3, 146321) Fortunately, the Judges have left the course open to the satyagrahi lawyers.

('19', 70, 3, 4, 147001) TO THE REGISTRAR HIGH COURT BOMBAY
('19', 70, 4, 5, 147036) DEAR SIR, I am in receipt of your letter of the 20th instant regarding the "publication in Young India on the 6th August of a private letter addressed by Mr. Kennedy, Dt.
('19', 70, 4, 6, 147207) Judge of Ahmedabad" and comments thereon in Young India.
('19', 70, 4, 7, 147264) I am grateful to the Hon'ble the Chief Justice for not interrupting my preparations for going to the Punjab.
('19', 70, 4, 8, 147373) The letter in question was in no way understood by me to be private, nor did the contents lead me to think so.
('19', 70, 4, 9, 147484) It came into my possession in the ordinary course, and I decided to publish it only after I understood that it was received by the giver in a proper, regular and open manner.
('19', 70, 4, 10, 147659) In my humble opinion I was within the rights of a journalist in publishing the letter in question and making comments thereon.
('19', 70, 4, 11, 147786) I believed the letter to be of great public importance and one that called for public criticism.
('19', 70, 5, 12, 147883) 1 On October 18, Gandhiji received a letter from the Registrar of the Bombay High Court as follows: “I am directed by the Hon’ble the Chief Justice to request you to attend His Lordship’s Chamber on Monday the 20th instant at 11 a.m.

('19', 73, 14, 15, 152423) 65. TO THE PEOPLE OF KATHIAWAR
('19', 73, 15, 16, 152454) A gentleman from Kathiawar has given Rs. 25,000 as a gift.
('19', 73, 15, 17, 152513) His original aim was that I should use the sum in propagating swadeshi in one definite place only.
('19', 73, 15, 18, 152612) I felt that such a large sum could not be spent in that way.
('19', 73, 15, 19, 152673) Then he suggested my utilizing the amount [for promoting swadeshi] among the people in the particular State.
('19', 73, 15, 20, 152782) Under this restriction, too, I felt I could not use it to good purpose.
('19', 73, 15, 21, 152854) He has,
('19', 73, 16, 22, 152862) 1 The reference apparently is to the reception accorded to Gandhiji on arrival at Lahore.
('19', 74, 0, 1, 152952) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 75
('19', 74, 1, 2, 152999) therefore, given me the freedom to spend the sum for the whole of Kathiawar and I have agreed.
('19', 74, 1, 3, 153094) Even so I visualize difficulties in using the amount in a way which would be worthy of this gentleman's liberality.
('19', 74, 1, 4, 153210) If the people of Kathiawar do not help me to the utmost, I would not be able to utilize the sum satisfactorily.
('19', 74, 1, 5, 153322) It is to be used only for promoting swadeshi.
('19', 74, 1, 6, 153368) He has accepted my definition of swadeshi, which is, to increase the production of cloth in the country mainly by promoting hand spinning and hand weaving, and thereby saving the crores of rupees going out every year on account of cloth.
('19', 74, 1, 7, 153606) Promoting hand spinning and hand weaving is the easiest thing if spinners and weavers are available.
('19', 74, 1, 8, 153707) If the Indian States take up the matter, the work can be done easily enough.
('19', 74, 1, 9, 153784) The following are my humble suggestions to the States and their Diwans: 1. Remove the levy in your State, if any, on hand made cloth produced in Kathiawar.
('19', 74, 1, 10, 153940) 2. Do not tax hand spun yarn produced elsewhere or yarn from Indian mills.
('19', 74, 1, 11, 154015) 3. Do not encourage the peasants to sell cotton; encourage them rather to store it.
('19', 74, 1, 12, 154099) 4. Improve the cotton.
('19', 74, 1, 13, 154122) This can easily be done.
('19', 74, 1, 14, 154147) 5. Encourage the use of cloth woven in your own State from yarn spun there.
('19', 74, 1, 15, 154223) You, too, should wear only such cloth.
('19', 74, 1, 16, 154262) 6. Have Indian style spinning wheels and looms manufactured in your State and offer them to your subjects at cost price.
('19', 74, 1, 17, 154383) 7. Introduce the spinning wheel and the loom in your primary schools and let the boys and girls be taught this craft as a compulsory subject.
('19', 74, 1, 18, 154525) If the Rajas, Maharajas and the Diwans take up this work, I can keep the foregoing donation unspent; I may then have to request the donor to permit me to use it for another purpose.
('19', 74, 1, 19, 154707) However, it cannot be expected that all the States will accept so very readily the importance of the swadeshi dharma.
('19', 74, 1, 20, 154825) It is likely, therefore, that the amount will have to be used among the people.
('19', 74, 1, 21, 154905) Men can do a lot if they will.
('19', 74, 1, 22, 154936) They may find out the weavers in various places and give them encouragement.
('19', 75, 0, 1, 155013) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 75, 1, 2, 155054) They may advise the peasants to store their cotton.
('19', 75, 1, 3, 155106) They may advise the women among their relations to take to spinning.
('19', 75, 1, 4, 155175) For this purpose, it is necessary to make arrangements 1. to supply spinning wheels; 2. to supply slivers; and 3. to collect yarn in exchange for the slivers and pay for it.
('19', 75, 1, 5, 155349) Then, for weaving, it is necessary to make arrangements 1. to supply yarn; and 2. to collect an equal quantity of cloth and pay for it.
('19', 75, 1, 6, 155485) Finally, it is necessary to promote its use, that is, to run a shop for its sale.
('19', 75, 1, 7, 155567) For all this work, diligent and honest workers are required.
('19', 75, 1, 8, 155628) Since people cannot afford to work without payment, the donation can be used to pay a living wage to honest workers, if available.
('19', 75, 1, 9, 155759) The associations of voluntary workers in Kathiawar can give the fullest help in this matter.
('19', 75, 1, 10, 155852) If a large committee consisting of respectable men and women, who would be prepared to work, can be formed for this purpose and if a sub committee is appointed under it, the work can be done promptly.
('19', 75, 1, 11, 156053) It is hoped that people willing to join in this work, with or without payment, will immediately write to us at the Ashram address.
('19', 75, 1, 12, 156184) However, until the women take a leading part in this movement it will not gather momentum.
('19', 75, 1, 13, 156275) It is women mostly who do spinning.
('19', 75, 1, 14, 156311) They are in possession of an inexhaustible treasure of the nation, having plenty of time on their hands.
('19', 75, 1, 15, 156416) By utilizing it, they will be serving the nation, even if they ask to be paid.
('19', 75, 1, 16, 156495) Whenever I go to Kathiawar, I receive much love.
('19', 75, 1, 17, 156544) As a token of their love, I want all of them…the old and the young, the high and the low, the Rajas and their subjects…to observe strict swadeshi dharma and this they can easily do.
('19', 75, 1, 18, 156726) From Kathiawar, I expect cloth worth one crore of rupees annually; that is, I am endeavouring to put one crore of rupees into circulation among the people there.
('19', 75, 1, 19, 156888) I wish to spend the foregoing Rs. 25,000 for this purpose.
('19', 75, 1, 20, 156947) There are many intelligent women and weavers in Kathiawar; what is needed is men who will bring them together and set them working.
('19', 76, 0, 1, 157079) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 77
('19', 76, 1, 2, 157126) I feel pained to see large numbers of men and women from Kathiawar crowding every train going to Bombay in a mad rush to get their.
('19', 76, 1, 3, 157258) Unable to earn their livelihood in Kathiawar, they go running about.
('19', 76, 1, 4, 157327) So many of them, at any rate, who may set a crore of rupees in circulation during a year, have no need at all to leave Kathiawar for a living.
('19', 76, 1, 5, 157470) There are indeed few places in India which people may leave as affording no means of making a living.
('19', 76, 1, 6, 157572) I know fully well that the number of our railway passengers is no index of the country's prosperity.
('19', 76, 1, 7, 157673) The giving up of swadeshi is a potent cause of our miserable condition.
('19', 76, 1, 8, 157745) Our prosperity lies in its revival.

('19', 76, 3, 10, 157819) 66. NOTES
('19', 76, 4, 11, 157829) WOMEN LABOURERS In writing about women labourers, Mrs. Vidyagouri 1 has not touched upon a new subject.
('19', 76, 4, 12, 157933) However, when our attention is drawn to any matter of which we knew but had taken no notice, it should be treated as a new subject.
('19', 76, 4, 13, 158065) The solution offered by Mrs. Vidyagouri is as difficult, it seems to us, as the two remedies which she found to be almost impracticable.
('19', 76, 4, 14, 158202) It is too much to expect that employers will be kind to women labourers.
('19', 76, 4, 15, 158275) We think it possible for masons, etc., to be civilized without making themselves angels.
('19', 76, 4, 16, 158364) Women labourers can learn to protect their honour.
('19', 76, 4, 17, 158415) All three need education; they all need to be enlightened as to their condition.
('19', 76, 4, 18, 158496) The group which we approach first will be the first to have decency and self respect introduced among them.
('19', 76, 4, 19, 158604) We must necessarily approach all three; those who have patriotism in them and have occasion for contact with all three classes may entreat members of each class.
('19', 76, 4, 20, 158766) If Mrs. Vidyagouri were to start an association of thoughtful women like herself and go among women labourers, what seems impossible to her will become possible.
('19', 76, 5, 21, 158928) DIFFICULTIES OF CLERKS Shri Popatlal Nanji sends us for our readers a letter on the hardships of clerks in which he says that a good many shopowners are rude, say all manner of harsh things to clerks and exact excessive
('19', 76, 6, 22, 159148) 1 Vidyagouri Nilkanth, a social worker
('19', 77, 0, 1, 159187) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 77, 1, 2, 159228) work from them.
('19', 77, 1, 3, 159244) Shop owners should look kindly upon their employees, whether clerks or gate keepers, and be polite to them.
('19', 77, 1, 4, 159352) But can it be that the masters alone are to blame?
('19', 77, 1, 5, 159403) In keeping up slavery, slaves too play no less important a part any day.
('19', 77, 1, 6, 159476) A servant's loyalty consists in his honesty and industry; he is not bound to tolerate unseemly behaviour.
('19', 77, 1, 7, 159582) Servants show themselves to be so completely broken in spirit that they look upon service as their all in all.
('19', 77, 1, 8, 159693) They ought to shake off this helplessness.
('19', 77, 1, 9, 159736) We believe that a man who is sincerely ready to work, has sound health and is not ashamed to work with his body will never find it difficult to earn enough for his livelihood.
('19', 77, 1, 10, 159912) The many movements in our country make no progress for want of sincere and diligent workers.
('19', 77, 1, 11, 160005) These movements can absorb men who live by service.
('19', 77, 1, 12, 160057) We, therefore, advise such men not to be submissive but to stand up.
('19', 77, 1, 13, 160126) There is no need for them at all to continue in service where they are insulted, where they have to drudge and where their health is undermined.
('19', 77, 1, 14, 160271) Before national life can make progress, it is necessary that a great many men and women acquire self respect.
('19', 77, 2, 15, 160381) RELIEF TO THOSE IN DISTRESS
('19', 77, 3, 16, 160409) It is our moral duty to think, as the new years begins, of the people who suffer.
('19', 77, 3, 17, 160491) That is in our interest.
('19', 77, 3, 18, 160516) We can be happy only by making happy the people who suffer.
('19', 77, 3, 19, 160576) To have this happiness, we should look around and send relief wherever we find suffering.
('19', 77, 3, 20, 160666) At present it is the Punjab which suffers especially, and Bengal, where, borne away by floods, many people have become homeless and go naked.
('19', 77, 3, 21, 160808) It is our particular duty, at the beginning of the new year, to send them what help we can.
('19', 77, 3, 22, 160900) We spend a great deal, giving dinners to friends and sending costly gifts and sweets to them.
('19', 77, 3, 23, 160994) People are welcome to do so if they can afford it.
('19', 77, 3, 24, 161045) But, in everything we do, it is our duty to remember that those who suffer have the first claim on us.
('19', 77, 4, 25, 161148) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 26 10 1919
('19', 78, 0, 1, 161186) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 79
('19', 78, 1, 2, 161233) 67. "RING OUT THE OLD, RING IN THE NEW" 1
('19', 78, 2, 3, 161275) [October 26, 1919]
('19', 78, 3, 4, 161294) (THE YEAR WHICH HAS ENDED)
('19', 78, 4, 5, 161321) It is difficult to strike the last year's balance.
('19', 78, 4, 6, 161372) The War has ended but with little result.
('19', 78, 4, 7, 161414) The hopes it nourished have remained unfulfilled.
('19', 78, 4, 8, 161464) The Peace, which was expected to be a permanent one, has turned out to be one in name.
('19', 78, 4, 9, 161551) The War which was greater than the Mahabharat war has been proved to be but a prelude to a still greater war.
('19', 78, 4, 10, 161661) Widespread discontent all over France, America and England after the War ≈ enough to bewilder one.
('19', 78, 4, 11, 161760) All that has followed seems to be a huge enigma.
('19', 78, 4, 12, 161809) Here in India we are faced with despair everywhere.
('19', 78, 4, 13, 161861) It was confidently hoped that, at the close of the War, India would get something substantial, but the hope turned out to be false.
('19', 78, 4, 14, 161993) For aught we know the reforms may not come.
('19', 78, 4, 15, 162037) Even if they do, they will be worthless.
('19', 78, 4, 16, 162078) The Congress League Scheme, then the Delhi Congress Scheme and subsequent schemes are now airy nothings.
('19', 78, 4, 17, 162183) We have to wait and see.
('19', 78, 4, 18, 162208) The Punjab has been a scene of most revolting episodes.
('19', 78, 4, 19, 162264) Innocent lives have been lost.
('19', 78, 4, 20, 162295) There reigned a reign of terror.
('19', 78, 4, 21, 162328) The gulf between the rulers and the ruled has been widened.
('19', 78, 4, 22, 162388) In these matters it is impossible to strike a correct balance.
('19', 78, 4, 23, 162451) What is the sum total on the credit side?
('19', 78, 4, 24, 162493) Or is there something to be debited, and if so, what?
('19', 78, 4, 25, 162547) Or is it that there is no credit side at all and we have simply to sum up the debit figures?
('19', 78, 4, 26, 162640) Was there any silver lining to such a thick, dark cloud of despair?
('19', 78, 4, 27, 162708) The sun of satyagraha dawned all over India on the 6th of April.
('19', 78, 4, 28, 162773) The clouds were scattered and the rays could be distinctly seen.
('19', 78, 4, 29, 162838) But the sun underwent an eclipse in the Punjab and Ahmedabad and its shadows are still haunting us.
('19', 78, 4, 30, 162938) And yet satyagraha is again seen dawning on most minds, though slowly.
('19', 78, 4, 31, 163009) There was hartal in many parts of India on the 17th of October amid perfect peace and quiet.
('19', 78, 4, 32, 163102) Those who believe in God passed that day in fasting and prayer.
('19', 78, 4, 33, 163166) The Hindus participated in the Moslems' mourning, strengthened the latter's hopes and the bonds of union with them.
('19', 78, 4, 34, 163282) It may now be very difficult to break the bonds.
('19', 78, 5, 35, 163331) 1 The original of this article appeared in two parts in Navajivan, 26 10 1919. The occasion was the new year’s day according to the Vikram Era.
('19', 79, 0, 1, 163475) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 79, 1, 2, 163516) If someone were to ask: "What was the greatest event of the last year?", we would unhesitatingly say, "It was the acceptance of satyagraha, however slightly and consciously or unconsciously, both by the rulers and the ruled." And in proof of the statement we would cite October the 17th.
('19', 79, 2, 3, 163804) (THE YEAR WHICH HAS COMMENCED) The hope of India lies in satyagraha.
('19', 79, 2, 4, 163873) And what is satyagraha?
('19', 79, 2, 5, 163897) It has often been described.
('19', 79, 2, 6, 163926) But just as the sun cannot be fully described even by the myriad tongued sheshnaga, so also the sun of satyagraha cannot be adequately described.
('19', 79, 2, 7, 164072) And though we always see the sun but know really very little of it, even so we do ever seem to see the sun of satyagraha but we know precious little about it.
('19', 79, 2, 8, 164231) The spheres of satyagraha are swadeshi, social reforms and political reform.
('19', 79, 2, 9, 164308) And in so far as these are based on satyagraha, so far only, and no further, is their permanence assured.
('19', 79, 2, 10, 164414) The way of satyagraha is distinct from the beaten track and it is not always easy to discover it.
('19', 79, 2, 11, 164512) Few have ventured along that path and the footprints on it are few and far between and indistinct, and hence the people's dread of it.
('19', 79, 2, 12, 164647) And still we clearly find people taking that course, be it ever so slowly.
('19', 79, 2, 13, 164722) He to whom satyagraha means nothing more than civil disobedience has never understood satyagraha.
('19', 79, 2, 14, 164820) No doubt the rigid interpretation of satyagraha does include within its meaning civil disobedience.
('19', 79, 2, 15, 164920) But only he who has mastered the art of obedience to law knows the art of disobedience to law.
('19', 79, 2, 16, 165015) Only he who thoroughly knows how to construct may destroy.
('19', 79, 2, 17, 165074) The poet has sung, The path of Truth is the path of the brave, It is beyond the power of the cowards.
('19', 79, 2, 18, 165176) Swadeshi is satyagraha.
('19', 79, 2, 19, 165200) It is beyond the power of cowardly spirits to observe or to propagate swadeshi.
('19', 79, 2, 20, 165280) It is impossible for a coward to foster Hindu Moslem unity.
('19', 79, 2, 21, 165340) It takes anyone but a cowardly Mussulman to receive a wound from a Hindu's dagger and vice versa and to preserve his mental balance.
('19', 79, 2, 22, 165473) If both could muster this much forbearance, swarajya would be instantaneously obtained.
('19', 79, 2, 23, 165561) There is none to forbid us the path of satyagraha, and both swadeshi and Hindu Moslem unity being in their essence religious, India would incidentally perform an act of religion.
('19', 79, 2, 24, 165740) This, then, is our prayer for the new year:
('19', 80, 0, 1, 165784) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 81
('19', 80, 1, 2, 165831) "Lord, lead India towards the path of Truth, this doing teach her the religion of swadeshi, and knit the Hindus, Mussulmans, Parsis, Christians and Jews living in India closer together." Young India, 5 11 1919
