('19', 80, 4, 7, 166307) 69. PUNJAB LETTER
('19', 80, 5, 8, 166325) [October 27, 1919] 2
('19', 80, 6, 9, 166346) When I tried to go to the Punjab last April, I had imagined that my going to Delhi and Lahore would result in restoring peace.
('19', 80, 6, 10, 166473) In Delhi Swami Shraddhanand had sought permission to go to the Punjab as had Dr. Satyapal from Amritsar.
('19', 80, 6, 11, 166578) Both had hoped to pacify the people.
('19', 80, 6, 12, 166615) Meanwhile Dr. Satyapal and Dr. Kichlew received orders restraining them from speaking in public and they obeyed, too.
('19', 80, 6, 13, 166733) Before I could reach Delhi, I was stopped and taken into custody.
('19', 80, 6, 14, 166799) Finally, I was ordered to remain in Bombay Presidency and not go to the Punjab.
('19', 80, 6, 15, 166879) We know the result.
('19', 80, 6, 16, 166899) If I had not been arrested, the subsequent disturbances would not have occurred.
('19', 80, 6, 17, 166980) The restriction on my movements was later removed and I was at last able to go to the Punjab.
('19', 80, 6, 18, 167074) I reached Lahore on the 24th of October.
('19', 80, 6, 19, 167115) There was a vast concourse at the station.
('19', 80, 6, 20, 167158) The Hon'ble Pandit Malaviyaji was there.
('19', 80, 6, 21, 167199) It took us 40 minutes to go from the station to the car.
('19', 80, 6, 22, 167256) It was extremely difficult to make one's way through the crowd.
('19', 80, 6, 23, 167320) Twice or thrice I was convinced that someone would be crushed.
('19', 80, 6, 24, 167383) But where men are overwhelmed with love, accidents are few.
('19', 80, 7, 25, 167443) 1 Gandhiji was expected to visit Amritsar on the afternoon of October 27. This teleprinter message was sent at 8 p.m.
('19', 80, 7, 26, 167561) 2 Gandhiji’s interview with the Lt. Governor mentioned in the last paragraph took place on this date.
('19', 80, 7, 27, 167663) It was Monday, and some of the subsequent instalments in the series were also written on Mondays.
('19', 81, 0, 1, 167761) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 81, 1, 2, 167802) This was the case here.
('19', 81, 1, 3, 167826) Yet there is no doubt that it is very necessary that we learn to make proper arrangements where such crowds gather.
('19', 81, 1, 4, 167942) As awakening grows day by day, the people will take greater interest in national activities and there will be ever larger crowds.
('19', 81, 1, 5, 168072) If people learn one extremely simple rule, there need be no accident.
('19', 81, 1, 6, 168142) When we gather in order to meet someone, those who are behind him and on either side of him should remain at a distance and those in front of him should press forward.
('19', 81, 1, 7, 168310) Today we do exactly the opposite.
('19', 81, 1, 8, 168344) Those at the back rush upon the front lines so that the people in between are squeezed between the two.
('19', 81, 1, 9, 168448) People are pushed about and there is risk of accidents.
('19', 81, 1, 10, 168504) Consequently, it becomes necessary to protect the person in the centre by holding him right in one's embrace.
('19', 81, 1, 11, 168614) Everyone will agree that this should not happen.
('19', 81, 1, 12, 168663) All that is necessary is to give the people some training.
('19', 81, 1, 13, 168722) And it is imperative that such training be given to the people through volunteers as soon as possible.
('19', 81, 1, 14, 168825) In Lahore, I am staying at the house of Sarladevi Choudhrani, the wife of Pandit Rambhuj Dutt.
('19', 81, 1, 15, 168920) Readers will recollect that Pandit Rambhuj is in jail.
('19', 81, 1, 16, 168975) As the Punjab Committee will start meeting from the 29th October 1, I have had very regretfully to cancel my proposed visit to Surat.
('19', 81, 1, 17, 169109) Discussions are afoot regarding three requests to be made to the Government, viz., that the leaders be released during the Committee's investigations; that among the judges to be appointed to review the cases, one at least should be from outside the Punjab; and that, if the judges feel it necessary to take fresh evidence, they should have the power to do so.
('19', 81, 1, 18, 169470) These matters are under discussion and Pandit Malaviya is giving them serious thought.
('19', 81, 1, 19, 169557) It is also rumoured that our lawyers will not be allowed to appear before the Committee.
('19', 81, 1, 20, 169646) 2 It is expected that some settlement will be arrived at on this point also.
('19', 81, 1, 21, 169723) If this does not happen, I at any rate am of the opinion that we should refuse to lead evidence before the Committee.
('19', 81, 1, 22, 169841) If it is decided to lead evidence, it is likely that Mr. C.R. Das and Pandit Motilal Nehru will be our counsel.
('19', 81, 1, 23, 169953) Apart from these, a British lawyer also has been invited.
('19', 81, 1, 24, 170011) His name is Mr. Neville.
('19', 81, 1, 25, 170036) It is learnt that it will take 15 or 20 days for him to arrive from England.
('19', 81, 1, 26, 170113) It is universally acknowledged that Pandit Malaviya and Pandit Motilal Nehru have rendered unique services to the Punjab.
('19', 81, 1, 27, 170235) At a time
('19', 81, 2, 28, 170245) 1 The Committee held its first sitting, however, on October 31 at Delhi.
('19', 81, 2, 29, 170318) 2 C.R. Das and Madan Mohan Malaviya were, however, later permitted.

('19', 87, 7, 16, 177994) 77. SPEECH TO LAHORE STUDENTS
('19', 87, 8, 17, 178024) [October 28, 1919]
('19', 87, 9, 18, 178043) On 28th October at 3.30 p.m.
('19', 87, 9, 19, 178072) Mahatma Gandhi addressed a large number of students of Lahore at Pandit Rambhuj Dutt Chaudhri's house.
('19', 87, 9, 20, 178175) Preluding his remarks with a few questions as to which of the colleges they belonged to, what was the numerical strength of the latter and how many students were still under the ban of expulsion…to all of which he received answers…, the speaker proceeded further.
('19', 87, 9, 21, 178439) To get degrees, he said, was not the be all and end all of education; moreover, it spoiled their health as well as their pecuniary prospects.
('19', 87, 9, 22, 178581) Lest he might be misunderstood he explained himself by saying that education, as at present imparted, was too theoretical.
('19', 87, 9, 23, 178704) Now they ought to supplement it by practical instruction in arts and crafts so that they might be sure of an independent livelihood.
('19', 87, 9, 24, 178837) They should curtail their needs to a minimum.
('19', 87, 9, 25, 178883) Ninety five per cent of India’s population was agriculturists, who could not improve their agriculature as long as they remained uneducated.
('19', 87, 10, 26, 179024) Mahatma Gandhi continuing said he was sorry to see students living under a cloud of fear.
('19', 87, 10, 27, 179114) He admonished them to practise nirbhaya (fearlessness) which was,
('19', 87, 11, 28, 179180) according to him, an essential adjunct of education.
('19', 87, 11, 29, 179233) Let them study the problem of their poverty.
('19', 87, 11, 30, 179278) They should refuse “to become blotting sheets of civilization”, but instead be trustful and self reliant.
('19', 87, 11, 31, 179384) He appealed to them first to know what the duty of
('19', 88, 0, 1, 179435) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 89
('19', 88, 1, 2, 179482) each of them was and then to perform it.
('19', 88, 1, 3, 179523) He concluded with the advice that they should observe the five yamas and niyamas, i.e., ahimsa, Satya, etc.
('19', 88, 1, 4, 179631) He laid great stress on the practice of brahmacharya which was sure to remove all their difficulties.
('19', 88, 1, 5, 179733) The Tribune, 30 10 1919
('19', 88, 2, 6, 179757) 78. ANOTHER MARTIAL LAW CASE FROM THE PUNJAB
('19', 88, 3, 7, 179802) Mr. Parshotam Singh, son of Mr. Jamiat Singh Bagga of Wazirabad, has sent me a statement of his father's case, and what is miscalled record of his case and judgment.
('19', 88, 3, 8, 179968) Mr. Jamiat Singh Bagga is a merchant and banker of Wazirabad.
('19', 88, 3, 9, 180030) He is 62 years old and suffering from a bad cataract in the eye.
('19', 88, 3, 10, 180095) He was sentenced to 18 months’ rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000 or in default to undergo further rigorous imprisonment for six months.
('19', 88, 3, 11, 180243) I have no hesitation in saying that the judgment is utterly unworthy of anybody calling himself a judge.
('19', 88, 3, 12, 180348) It is devoid of reasoning and full of imputations and bad logic and if the facts set forth in the son’s statement are true, the convicting Magistrate is utterly unfit to sit as a judge.
('19', 88, 3, 13, 180534) Mr. Jamiat Singh’s crime seems to have been that he was present at the mosque meeting and advocated hartal, and that he was a rich man, for the Magistrate disbelieves the testimony of impartial witnesses because “Jamiat Singh is a rich man”.
('19', 88, 3, 14, 180776) It is sufficient for the Magistrate that the accused was with the mob that stoned the troopers, that “if he prevented boys from breaking fencing, there may have been some other reason, but he certainly was in the mob.” Thus, everything in favour of the accused is deliberately disregarded by the Magistrate.
('19', 88, 3, 15, 181084) The reader must go through the judgment to feel the force of my remarks regarding its incoherence.
('19', 88, 3, 16, 181183) But the son's statement makes what seems apparently to be an injustice appear blacker still.
('19', 88, 3, 17, 181276) Is it true that the Magistrate confiscated the accused’s property without a moment’s notice, that the inmates were subjected to the treatment described in the statement, and if it is true, was it not a lawless act?
('19', 88, 3, 18, 181491) Is it true that the witnesses cited for the defence were not called, that the defence counsel was not allowed to appear, when the charge was framed against the accused?
('19', 88, 3, 19, 181660) So much for the precious judgment.
('19', 88, 3, 20, 181695) The treatment received by the accused before and after judgment seems to have been in keeping with the proceedings of the court.
('19', 88, 3, 21, 181824) It was an inhuman act to make him walk handcuffed with his bedding under his armpit.
('19', 88, 3, 22, 181909) It reminds one of General Hudson’s speech about the hand and knee order, which, by the way, should be,
('19', 89, 0, 1, 182012) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 89, 1, 2, 182053) according to the correction made by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, described as the crawling order.
('19', 89, 1, 3, 182147) It is evident that the proceedings taken by the authorities were intended, like the crawling order, to produce an impression on the people.
('19', 89, 1, 4, 182287) It is difficult on any other ground to understand the insulting and cruel treatment to which the accused was subjected.
('19', 89, 1, 5, 182407) Even the help he rendered the Government during the war period by subscribing the largest amount in Wazirabad to the war loan, and by recruiting, was of no avail.
('19', 89, 1, 6, 182570) The sanad granted to him for his loyal services was of no service to him when he was put in the dock, and treated as a common felon.
('19', 89, 1, 7, 182703) I cannot congratulate the Punjab Government on the reduction of the sentence to six months, when the accused seems clearly to be entitled to a full discharge.
('19', 89, 1, 8, 182862) The case, as appears from the statement, is now to be investigated by the Revision Judges.
('19', 89, 1, 9, 182953) I have already ventured to express my misgivings about this Revision Tribunal.
('19', 89, 1, 10, 183032) Its composition cannot inspire any confidence or hope.
('19', 89, 1, 11, 183087) If the Government fail to repair the irreparable mistakes, create tribunals merely in order to cover themselves, they will forfeit all title to respect and intelligent co operation.
('19', 89, 1, 12, 183269) The dead are buried and gone, but it is intolerable that the living, who are now suffering undeserved punishment, are not given an opportunity of showing their innocence before a tribunal in which they and the public can have full confidence.
('19', 89, 2, 13, 183512) Young India, 29 10 1919

('19', 94, 1, 2, 188980) 87. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('19', 94, 2, 3, 189006) DELHI, November 1, 1919 Several friends have inquired what should be the position regarding the forthcoming peace celebrations.
('19', 94, 2, 4, 189134) On the Khilafat Day, I know that resolutions were passed at some meetings to the effect that Mohammedans could not participate in the celebrations if the Khilafat question was not satisfactorily settled.
('19', 94, 2, 5, 189338) There can be no peace in Indian estimation so long as the great question remains unsolved and the Mohammedan sentiment is in danger of being lacerated, and millions of Mohammedans remaining in suspense or grief, it is hardly possible for the Hindus, Parsis, Christians, Jews and others for whom India is the land of their adoption or birth to take part in the forthcoming rejoicing.
('19', 94, 2, 6, 189721) I venture to think that His Excellency the Viceroy can, if he will, tell His Majesty’s ministers that Indians cannot participate in the celebration, so long as the Khilafat question remains unsettled.
('19', 94, 2, 7, 189922) And I do hope that His Majesty’s ministers will recognize the necessity of securing and publishing an honourable settlement of the question before asking us to take part in peace celebrations.
('19', 94, 2, 8, 190115) The Leader, 3 11 1919

('19', 96, 5, 23, 194210) 90. FATHER OF THE WORLD [ IV]
('19', 96, 6, 24, 194240) We have, so far, given some thought to the peasant’s condition.
('19', 96, 6, 25, 194304) We have also seen that the rules of cleanliness are not followed in villages.
('19', 96, 6, 26, 194382) The saying that good health is the first condition of happiness has much truth in it.
('19', 96, 6, 27, 194468) Men and women who have reached a high position can look after themselves even when they fall ill.
('19', 96, 6, 28, 194566) But we who have yet to rise to the top, will fall by the way if we do not keep fit.
('19', 96, 6, 29, 194650) There is a saying in English: “One cannot reach heaven with cold feet.” In a cold country like England, if the feet remain cold one can suffer agonies.
('19', 96, 6, 30, 194802) One cannot remember God in such a state.
('19', 96, 6, 31, 194843) It is said that “cleanliness is next to godliness”.
('19', 96, 6, 32, 194895) There is no reason why
('19', 96, 7, 33, 194918) 1 For the series of reports about Punjab, vide “Punjab Letter”, 27 10 1919, “Punjab Letter”, 3 11 1919. ; 17 11 1919, ; 25 11 1919, ; About 1 12 1919, ; 7 12 1919, ; About 15 12 1919, ; 27 1 1920 2 Vide”Telegram to P.S. to Viceroy”, 3 10 1919
('19', 97, 0, 1, 195161) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 97, 1, 2, 195202) we should be dirty or live in dirty surroundings.
('19', 97, 1, 3, 195252) There is no sanctity in dirt!
('19', 97, 1, 4, 195282) Filth is a sign of ignorance and sloth.
('19', 97, 1, 5, 195322) How, then, are peasants to be rescued from it?
('19', 97, 1, 6, 195369) Let us examine the rules of cleanliness.
('19', 97, 1, 7, 195410) 1. Many of our diseases originate from our latrines or from our custom of going to the fields for evacuation.
('19', 97, 1, 8, 195520) Every house must have a latrine.
('19', 97, 1, 9, 195553) Only able bodied adults can go out.
('19', 97, 1, 10, 195589) If there is no latrine available, the rest turn their courtyard, lanes or houses into latrines, dirtying the place and poisoning the air.
('19', 97, 1, 11, 195727) We can, therefore, lay down two rules.
('19', 97, 1, 12, 195766) If anyone wants to evacuate in the open, it must be a distance of a mile from the village.
('19', 97, 1, 13, 195857) There must be no habitation in its vicinity, nor any human traffic near by.
('19', 97, 1, 14, 195933) The person must dig a hole and after using it must cover the faeces with earth.
('19', 97, 1, 15, 196013) If all the earth that has been dug out is put back, the faeces will be properly covered.
('19', 97, 1, 16, 196102) By taking this little trouble, we can observe an important rule of cleanliness.
('19', 97, 1, 17, 196182) Sensible peasants may evacuate in their fields and obtain free manure.
('19', 97, 1, 18, 196253) This is one rule.
('19', 97, 1, 19, 196271) Even if the open space is thus availed of, every house should necessarily have a latrine.
('19', 97, 1, 20, 196361) This should have a bucket.
('19', 97, 1, 21, 196388) Here also every person should, after use, cover the faeces with earth in order to obviate offensive odours, prevent buzzing of flies and the breeding of vermin.
('19', 97, 1, 22, 196549) This bucket must be regularly cleaned.
('19', 97, 1, 23, 196588) A pit sunk to serve as a latrine is useless.
('19', 97, 1, 24, 196633) The earth’s crust, to the depth of one foot, is swarming with germs.
('19', 97, 1, 25, 196702) The refuse buried in this portion is immediately transformed into manure.
('19', 97, 1, 26, 196776) Earth very deep down does not contain enough germs to turn filth into manure.
('19', 97, 1, 27, 196854) Consequently, filth which has been buried very deep produces foul gases and pollutes the air.
('19', 97, 1, 28, 196948) The bucket may be of iron or earth coated with paint.
('19', 97, 1, 29, 197002) This also requires not money but industry.
('19', 97, 1, 30, 197045) Urine too should not be passed in any and every place.

('19', 103, 2, 3, 210006) SPINNING WHEEL MOVEMENT
('19', 103, 3, 4, 210030) We invite reader’ attention to the report, published in this issue, of the spinning wheel movement started by the Ahmedabad Swadeshi Sabha.
('19', 103, 3, 5, 210170) Some important conclusions may easily be drawn from it.
('19', 103, 3, 6, 210226) First of all, as in Bombay, there is a class of women in Ahmedabad who find it worth their while to spin and earn two or three annas a day.
('19', 103, 3, 7, 210366) Secondly, a large number of spinning wheels are being plied in Lunsawad 1 ; in fact, so far the number has been increasing every month.
('19', 103, 3, 8, 210502) In Khadia 2, on the other hand, the number seems to have decreased a little during the third month.
('19', 103, 3, 9, 210602) Drawing up a list, community wise, of the women who have bought spinning wheels will throw some light on this rise and fall in numbers.
('19', 103, 3, 10, 210738) On a superficial view, it may seem that the residents of Lunsawad, being poorer, have resorted to the spinning wheel in greater number and on a larger scale.
('19', 103, 3, 11, 210896) It cannot be denied that there is an element of truth in this conclusion.
('19', 103, 3, 12, 210970) But it is also worth considering to what extent these figures provide an example of the tendency of the higher castes, proud of their superior status, to shrink from work generally regarded as mean even when they feel the pinch of poverty, and of the relatively lower communities to welcome suitable work, under the pressure of necessity.
('19', 103, 3, 13, 211309) Another question, the answer to which will be more instructive, is this: As between the women, on the one hand, in cities like Bombay, Ahmedabad, Surat, etc., and in smaller places, who at present work on the spinning wheel and, on the other, the thousands and hundreds of thousands of other women of the same class, what percentage earns how much in which work?
('19', 103, 3, 14, 211672) We request everyone to start immediately collecting figures to find the reply to this instructive question and hope that, meanwhile, all the volunteers and [Swadeshi] Sabhas will oblige us by sending us detailed reports, on the lines of the Ahmedabad report, on the spinning wheel movements at various places.

('19', 104, 1, 2, 212063) TANNERIES
('19', 104, 2, 3, 212073) Tanneries 1 means the shops and establishments of Chamars 2 .
('19', 104, 2, 4, 212135) A correspondent informs us that a good many such firms are coming up in the country these days.
('19', 104, 2, 5, 212231) He adds that it is not desirable that India’s trade should increase in this way because this involves the destruction of our cattle wealth.
('19', 104, 2, 6, 212371) In saying this, the correspondent has in his goodness raised the issue of compassion to animals.
('19', 104, 2, 7, 212468) We do not think that tanneries will mean more destruction.
('19', 104, 2, 8, 212527) There is no reason to believe that increase in the number of tanneries will mean destruction of cattle in greater numbers.
('19', 104, 2, 9, 212650) In our view, the use of hide from cattle dying in the natural course is no sin.
('19', 104, 2, 10, 212730) The Chamar’s profession is an essential one.
('19', 104, 2, 11, 212775) Man cannot do without shoes.
('19', 104, 2, 12, 212804) In agriculture, hide is needed at every turn.
('19', 104, 2, 13, 212850) The countless scoops for drawing water are made of hide.
('19', 104, 2, 14, 212907) Earnings through this occupation amount to lakhs.
('19', 104, 2, 15, 212957) At present this occupation is in the hands of Chamars and Mochis 3. We should see to it that it does not pass on to firms and leave these starving.
('19', 104, 2, 16, 213105) If we do not wake up betimes, the result will be as we have feared.
('19', 104, 2, 17, 213173) We have never been careful of the interests of our artisans.
('19', 104, 2, 18, 213234) Looking upon them as dependent on other classes, we have despised them and done the country harm.
('19', 104, 2, 19, 213332) We treated skilled work as low and exalted clerical work, and thus invited slavery for ourselves.
('19', 104, 2, 20, 213430) We looked upon masons, shoe makers, carpenters, blacksmiths and barbers as inferior to us and kept them suppressed.
('19', 104, 2, 21, 213546) From their trades and their homes we have taken away all courtesy, learning, decency and culture.
('19', 104, 2, 22, 213644) In the result, their life has become dull and they themselves do not think highly of it.
('19', 104, 2, 23, 213733) Hence, if they receive school education, they give up their profession; the tailor, likewise, will have nothing to do with the needle; the weaver swears at the loom; as for the scavenger, is it ever possible that, after being educated, he will clean latrines?
('19', 104, 2, 24, 213993) If we had not despised professions which required one to use one’s hands and feet, we would not have fallen into this unhappy state and graduates would have felt no shame in working even as scavengers.

('19', 106, 1, 2, 216141) 93. NOTE OF INTERVIEW ON SOUTH AFRICA 1
('19', 106, 2, 3, 216181) November 3, 1919
('19', 106, 3, 4, 216198) He [Gandhiji] said that he was very sorry that the Union Government were unwilling to allow representatives from India to sit upon the Commission.
('19', 106, 3, 5, 216345) He said that he was going to do what I had asked him to do in my letter, namely, not to raise an agitation himself on the subject, and to do all he could to repress any agitation raised by others.
('19', 106, 3, 6, 216542) He told me that he had been interviewed during the last day or two, and he had said that he regarded the arrangement made as second best.
('19', 106, 4, 7, 216680) I asked him whether he had any strong views on the point, whether the terms of reference to the Commission ought to be enlarged beyond trading rights, and pointed out to him that the recent effort of the Indians to get an enquiry had resulted in what might be regarded as a restriction of the existing rights.
('19', 106, 4, 8, 216990) He said that he felt strongly that the enquiry ought to extend to the Law of 1885, and considered that an extension in this direction could not possibly result in a restriction of the existing rights.
('19', 106, 5, 9, 217191) I asked him his views on the subject of inter provincial emigration.
('19', 106, 5, 10, 217260) He said: I would not ask for this, for I know that we shall not get it.
('19', 106, 5, 11, 217332) Freedom of emigration between the Provinces would mean freedom to migrate from the Transvaal into the Orange Free State.
('19', 106, 5, 12, 217453) The Orange Free State has always prohibited the entry of Indians, and there is hardly any Indian in the whole State.
('19', 106, 6, 13, 217570) I further asked him what he felt about movement from one Province to another with the intention of returning.
('19', 106, 6, 14, 217680) A man might, for instance, want to attend the funeral of a relative living over the border.
('19', 106, 6, 15, 217772) He said: This is a very small matter, and I think we can rely upon General Smuts to deal with it by executive order.
('19', 106, 7, 16, 217889) No legislation, he said, would be required.
('19', 106, 8, 17, 217933) He said he was starting for Amritsar (November 3rd), but would consider the
('19', 106, 9, 18, 218009) question of the enlargement of the terms of reference very carefully, and would let me
('19', 106, 10, 19, 218096) have his considered views.
('19', 106, 10, 20, 218123) He said: I know the South African people, and I fully realize the diffculties which exist.
('19', 106, 10, 21, 218214) I do not want to fall into the error of asking for what is unwise and what we know we shall not get.

('19', 107, 12, 18, 219572) 95. PUNJAB LETTER
('19', 107, 13, 19, 219590) DELHI, Monday, Kartak Sud 8 2 [November 3, 1919] The affection that I am receiving from men and women here in Lahore puts me to shame, while at the same time the unique faith of India and the frankness and generosity of our people enchant me.
('19', 107, 13, 20, 219833) Young and old continue to come all day to have darshan 3 of me.
('19', 107, 13, 21, 219897) It is impossible for me to go out anywhere alone.
('19', 107, 13, 22, 219947) As soon as the people catch sight of me, they crowd round.
('19', 107, 13, 23, 220006) I simply cannot check them.
('19', 107, 13, 24, 220034) I know of nothing in me which may make me worthy of giving darshan.
('19', 107, 13, 25, 220102) Man’s instinctive urge to worship is admirable.
('19', 107, 13, 26, 220150) But that people should crowd round to have darshan of a mere servant is
('19', 107, 14, 27, 220222) 1 The draft reply was scribbled on a letter dated October 29 from the addressee, in which he had said that if they were permitted to buy yarn packed in boxes and get it woven, they could get yarn of excellent quality on order.
('19', 107, 14, 28, 220449) 2 This should be 10 3 Sight of a person, place or thing considered holy
('19', 108, 0, 1, 220521) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 109
('19', 108, 1, 2, 220569) intolerable to me.
('19', 108, 1, 3, 220588) If I keep on giving darshan, my work will suffer.
('19', 108, 1, 4, 220638) I do not believe that people profit in any way by having darshan.
('19', 108, 1, 5, 220704) The condition of him who gives it is even worse.
('19', 108, 1, 6, 220753) On one occasion, a friend of mine asked me, “Are you sure that the people’s adulation does not make you vain?” He asked the question in all sincerity.
('19', 108, 1, 7, 220904) What could I reply?
('19', 108, 1, 8, 220924) I said, “God forbid!” This friend was a prominent Muslim.
('19', 108, 1, 9, 220982) However, it is no ordinary responsibility which rests on him who gives darshan.
('19', 108, 1, 10, 221062) No man is great enough to give it.
('19', 108, 1, 11, 221097) I can say truthfully that this only embarrasses me and, if I could put a stop to this practice without hurting people’s feelings, I would do so immediately.
('19', 108, 1, 12, 221254) I have not yet found it possible to do this.
('19', 108, 1, 13, 221299) I have failed either because my courage is inadequate or my judgment is yet clouded or, perhaps, my principle of non violence does not allow me to hurt people’s feelings.
('19', 108, 1, 14, 221470) My opinion is that I suffer from both the defects and also that I have a strong inclination to non violence.
('19', 108, 1, 15, 221579) I do indeed make every effort to extricate myself from this dilemma.
('19', 108, 1, 16, 221648) At present, even when people come for darshan, I continue to write and do other work.
('19', 108, 1, 17, 221734) Even as I write this, people come and go but I do not interrupt my work.
('19', 108, 1, 18, 221807) I salute them and go on with my writing.
('19', 108, 1, 19, 221848) It is perfectly clear to me that this is the miracle wrought by even a small measure of devoting to truth and service.
('19', 108, 1, 20, 221967) I cannot claim that I always conduct myself, in thought, word and deed, according to the truth as I know it.
('19', 108, 1, 21, 222076) Nor can I say that I always follow the principle of service as I understand it.
('19', 108, 1, 22, 222156) My only claim is that I am making a prodigious effort to live up to these two principles.
('19', 108, 1, 23, 222246) And the incomparable love that I have received has made it clear to me that they in whom truth and the spirit of service are manifested in their fulness will assuredly sway the hearts of men and so accomplish their chosen task.
('19', 108, 1, 24, 222474) I have also come to realize that, in these difficult times, the observance of the principles of truth, service and compassion gives infinite peace to men.

('19', 109, 3, 13, 223847) DELHI MEETING A large meeting was convened in Delhi on Saturday.

('19', 109, 3, 15, 224055) The meeting was held in the open air but the crowd was so dense that people were constantly falling on one another.

('19', 110, 2, 7, 225924) SPINNING WHEEL To the women who came to visit me in Lahore I spoke at great length about the spinning wheel, and also begged yarn from them.
('19', 110, 2, 8, 226065) Hundreds of women came to see me and there was rarely one among them who said she did not know spinning.
('19', 110, 2, 9, 226170) As soon as I asked for yarn, they began to bring it to me and many of them promised to take up spinning again.
('19', 110, 2, 10, 226281) There is not much difference between the Punjab spinning wheel and the old spinning wheel of Gujarat.
('19', 110, 2, 11, 226383) The more I discover the similarity in the spinning wheels and spinning processes all over the country, the more I am convinced that India was one nation in the past and that the people were conscious of their being one nation.
('19', 110, 2, 12, 226610) So far I have met few men or women who see any harm in spinning.

('19', 111, 5, 22, 229155) SISTERS, Amritsar has become a place of pilgrimage not only for me but for evey Indian.
('19', 111, 5, 23, 229243) No penance will suffice for the evil that has been wrought by our hand in Amritsar.
('19', 111, 5, 24, 229327) It is true that a large number of our people were killed in Jallianwala Bagh.
('19', 111, 5, 25, 229405) But we ought to have maintained peace even if everyone present had been killed.
('19', 111, 5, 26, 229485) It is not right, in my opinion, to take blood for blood.
('19', 111, 5, 27, 229542) Our religion teaches us not to inflict pain on anyone.
('19', 111, 5, 28, 229597) I regard Amritsar as a place of pilgrimage because our brethren here have recently suffered much.
('19', 111, 5, 29, 229695) The Government had detained me at Bombay, and I had been
('19', 111, 6, 30, 229752) 1 The Tibbia College 2 The meeting was held at the house of Lala Girdhari Lal, a Congress leader of Amritsar.

('19', 112, 1, 2, 229910) wondering when I would have my freedom and be able to visit Amritsar.
('19', 112, 1, 3, 229980) Now, having been freed, I have had the good fortune of meeting you.
('19', 112, 1, 4, 230048) I will have peace only when I have done the work that I ought to do.
('19', 112, 1, 5, 230117) You mothers, who must have had either a son, a brother or other relative killed or imprisoned and for whom you sorrow, should not regard it as an infliction.

('19', 114, 7, 9, 233716) 100. LETTER TO SIR GEORGE BARNES 2, MOZANG ROAD, LAHORE, [November 7, 1919]
('19', 114, 9, 10, 233792) THE HON’BLE SIR GEORGE BARNES, K.C.B. MEMBER VICEROY’S EXECUTIVE COUNCIL DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE AND INDUSTRY
('19', 114, 10, 11, 233901) [DELHI] With reference to our conversation, 3 I enclose herewith my note as to the minimum to be included in the reference to the forthcoming South African Commission.
('19', 114, 11, 12, 234069) 1The letter ran as follows: “I am directed to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, and to inform you that the Hon’ble the Chief Justice regrets that he cannot regard your explanation as satisfactory.
('19', 114, 11, 13, 234292) However, His Lordship is willing to concede that you were unaware that you were exceeding the privilege of a journalist provided that you publish in the next issue of Young India an apology in the accompanying form.” The apology was worded thus: “Whereas on th 6th August 1919, we published in Young India a private letter written by Mr. Kennedy, District Judge of Ahmedabad, to the Registrar of the High Court of Justice at Bombay, and whereas on the same date we also published certain comments on the said letter and whereas it has been pointed out to us that pending certain proceedings in the said High Court in connection with the said letter, we were not justified in publishing the said letter or in commenting thereon.
('19', 114, 11, 14, 235020) Now we do hereby express our regret and apologise to the Hon’ble the Chief Justice and Judges of the said High Court for the publication of the said letter and the comments thereon.” For Gandhiji’s reaction to the form of the apology, vide “Letter to Registrar, High Court, Bombay”, 11 12 1919. 2 Gandhiji sought Vallabhbhai Patel’s advice.
('19', 114, 11, 15, 235361) On November 16, Mahadev Desai wired to Gandhiji at Lahore: “Saw Vallabhbhai.
('19', 114, 11, 16, 235438) He thinks publication letter within rights.
('19', 114, 11, 17, 235482) However case being subjudice clearly contempt of court.” 3 Vide “Note of Interview on South Africa”, 3 11 1919.
('19', 115, 0, 1, 235594) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 115, 1, 2, 235636) It is assumed for the purpose of this note that General Smuts contemplates referring to the Commission the question of trading rights of Indians in the Transvaal only.
('19', 115, 1, 3, 235804) If so, it will not in any way settle the most urgent questions.
('19', 115, 1, 4, 235868) The new Act deals with and adversely affects the rights of owning land and trading.
('19', 115, 1, 5, 235952) It is therefore suggested that the question of trading and owning land, i.e., the laws of 1885 and the Townships Act and the Gold Law in so far as the latter two affect the rights of Indians to own land and to trade within the townships or the Gold areas be referred to the Commission.
('19', 115, 1, 6, 236238) It should be clearly understood as between the Union Govern ment and the Government of India that the new Act in so far as it diminishes existing rights should be revised and that the findings of the Commission should not in any way restrict existing rights.
('19', 115, 1, 7, 236497) The Commission is likely to prove injurious to the existing rights, small as they are, if the above two conditions are not fulfilled.My proposal should be taken and treated as a whole or rejected altogether.
('19', 115, 1, 8, 236705) In making the proposal, I am going against the most moderate public opinion here and against the demands made by the South Africa Indians’ Conference recently held at Johannesburg.
('19', 115, 1, 9, 236886) Public opinion here as expressed by The Times of India requires the restoration of trading rights and ownership of land throughout the Union and the inter provincial migration.
('19', 115, 1, 10, 237063) This means entry into the Orange Free State and the rights to trade and own land there.
('19', 115, 1, 11, 237151) In the present state of public feeling this may be difficult for General Smuts to achieve even if he himself is willing.
('19', 115, 1, 12, 237272) The demand of the Conference is wider still and includes the restoration of the political status and the abolition of all legal disabilities.
('19', 115, 1, 13, 237414) Though this and this alone must be the goal to be aimed at, I recognize that it is not practical politics to strive for it as an immediate aim.
('19', 115, 1, 14, 237558) But, if neither the Indian demand nor the lesser one expressed by The Times of India is to be urged, it must be clearly understood that there should be no diminution of the existing status.
('19', 115, 1, 15, 237748) The Union Government having already opened the question of trade and ownership of property in the Transvaal, through the Select Committee and then the recent legislation, the Commission can well be asked to entertain both these questions without ruffling the prejudices of the white population.
('19', 115, 1, 16, 238043) It should be remembered that, at the time of
('19', 116, 0, 1, 238088) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 117
('19', 116, 1, 2, 238136) the passage of the recent Act, Indians in the Transvaal had the right to Europeans and could under the existing law becom receive licenses to trade practically on the same footing as the virtual owners of land by taking mortgages or forming limited liability companies.
('19', 116, 1, 3, 238406) I contemplate statutory recognition of the right to trade under general sanitary control and the direct ownership of land in the Transvaal.
('19', 116, 1, 4, 238546) This is not claiming much or more than they have virtually enjoyed.
('19', 116, 1, 5, 238614) So far regarding the reference.
('19', 116, 1, 6, 238646) There is the unsatisfactory administration of the Immigrant’s Restriction Act which can be improved by diplomatic action without troubling the Commission.
('19', 116, 1, 7, 238801) The points requiring attention are: (1) The movement of the Indian settler from one province to another not for residing but for ceremonial or business visits or for mere passage to the province of domicile.
('19', 116, 1, 8, 239009) Full facilities without fee should be granted.
('19', 116, 1, 9, 239056) (2) The entry of fresh Indians for supplying the needs of the resident population should be placed on a better and more liberal basis.
('19', 116, 1, 10, 239191) (3) There should be greater liberality in permitting plural wives to visit their husbands without creating any legal rights for them or their issue.
('19', 116, 1, 11, 239340) (4) Restrictions on passports from India or from the Union require complete overhauling whether regarding identification or otherwise.
('19', 116, 1, 12, 239475) (5) Men and women of status and students should have freedom to travel to South Africa.
('19', 116, 1, 13, 239563) These matters, if they cannot be dealt with diplomatically, should be included in the reference to the forthcoming Commission.
('19', 116, 2, 14, 239690) M. K. GANDHI
('19', 116, 3, 15, 239703) India Office : Judicial and Public Records : 6140/19

('19', 117, 7, 21, 240815) 102. SOUTH AFRICA
('19', 117, 8, 22, 240833) The news about South Africa appearing in the papers is both startling and distressing.
('19', 117, 8, 23, 240920) We were led by Mr. Montagu’s words to believe that the Commission on the rights of Indians, which is to be appointed in South Africa, would have some members to represent us.
('19', 117, 8, 24, 241095) Mr. Montagu now informs us that his words were misunderstood and
('19', 117, 9, 25, 241160) 1 The year has been inferred form the contents.
('19', 117, 9, 26, 241208) The letter appears to have been written about the same time as the letter to the addressee dated November 1, 1919. The Friday following fell on November 7. Gandhiji’s notes on Khilafat appeared in Navajivan, 9 11 1919 and 7 12 1919; vide “Notes”, Before 12 11 1919 and “Punjab Letter”, About 1 12 1919. 2 Scheduled to be held form December 29, 1919 to January 1, 1920
('19', 118, 0, 1, 241576) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 119
('19', 118, 1, 2, 241624) that no one will be appointed on the Commission to represent India.
('19', 118, 1, 3, 241692) However, Sir Benjamin Robertson will be accompanied by a non official and the two will present our case.
('19', 118, 1, 4, 241797) This is disappointing news for us.
('19', 118, 1, 5, 241832) We think General Smuts did not have his way and it did not become possible to include anyone from India.
('19', 118, 1, 6, 241937) So we have had to telegraph 1 Mr. Montagu to set the matter right.
('19', 118, 1, 7, 242004) But we shall not succeed, through agitation, in getting our men appointed on the Commission.
('19', 118, 1, 8, 242097) Mr. Montagu can insist on justice being done to us, but it is the South African Government alone which can decide the manner of doing it.
('19', 118, 1, 9, 242235) Hence, we cannot compel it to appoint anybody from here on its Commission.
('19', 118, 1, 10, 242310) Even then, if an able man like Mr. Shastriar is appointed by the Government, he and Sir Benjamin Robertson together will be able to secure justice.
('19', 118, 1, 11, 242458) The more startling news which we have received is that the Commission will investigate only the issue of trading licences.
('19', 118, 1, 12, 242581) Such a limited inquiry will not serve the purpose.
('19', 118, 1, 13, 242632) We shall have to carry on a strong agitation about this.
('19', 118, 1, 14, 242689) The Commission should be given more powers.
('19', 118, 1, 15, 242733) The Indians in South Africa have demanded that the inquiry should cover all their rights.
('19', 118, 1, 16, 242823) We think it will be difficult to bring this about.
('19', 118, 1, 17, 242874) But we can certainly demand that the inquiry should cover rights of trading and ownership of land; these are our minimum rights.
('19', 118, 1, 18, 243003) What we have to be more vigilant about is lest the Commission should be empowered to recommend deprivation of the existing rights.
('19', 118, 1, 19, 243134) It should have no power to recommend abrogation of any of the rights which existed at the time of the passing of the new law.
('19', 118, 1, 20, 243260) Indians have now almost stopped emigrating to South Africa.
('19', 118, 1, 21, 243320) The system of indentured labour having been discontinued, the resulting increase in the Indian population there has also stopped.
('19', 118, 1, 22, 243450) Hence the only question that remains is that of the rights of Indians settled there.
('19', 118, 1, 23, 243535) They must be allowed to trade honestly and to acquire and dispose of land.
('19', 118, 1, 24, 243610) There is no room for difference of opinion on this point.
('19', 118, 1, 25, 243668) The whites of South Africa cannot keep the Indians there merely as slaves or coolies.
('19', 118, 1, 26, 243754) Fortunately, the good Mr. Andrews has come forward to help our brethren and is proceeding there.
('19', 118, 1, 27, 243851) The service he has rendered it is impossible to estimate.
('19', 118, 1, 28, 243909) Wherever he hears the cry of Indians in distress, he runs to their help.
('19', 118, 1, 29, 243982) Fiji,, Ceylon and the Punjab bear witness

('19', 119, 3, 6, 244319) 103. FIJI
('19', 119, 4, 7, 244329) Only a few days ago it was feared that our indentured brothers and sisters in Fiji would not be released, even at the end of the current years, from their slavery.
('19', 119, 4, 8, 244493) The Fiji legislature has passed a resolution to the effect that the indenture of the Indian labourers will be terminated in August.
('19', 119, 4, 9, 244625) We cannot tolerate for a single moment a practice that does not safeguard the modesty of our women.
('19', 119, 4, 10, 244725) Had the good Mr. Andrews not visited Fiji and brought this evil to our notice, we should still be in the dark about it.
('19', 119, 4, 11, 244845) Fortunately, fresh news has arrived removing our fear of the prolongation of this slavery and the Indian government has been informed that those firms which are unable to introduce the reforms suggested by Mr. Andrews will terminate the indentures by the 1st January.
('19', 119, 4, 12, 245113) On the other hand, those firms which are prepared to introduce these reforms will not terminate the indentures without compensation.
('19', 119, 4, 13, 245246) The reader will probably fail to follow this complicated point.
('19', 119, 4, 14, 245310) Under a Fiji law, many whites hold indentured Indian labourers.
('19', 119, 4, 15, 245374) These labourers are under contract to serve for a period of five years.
('19', 119, 4, 16, 245446) Emigration of fresh indentured labourers stopped in 1917, but, after Mr. Andrews report, we demanded that even those serving terms of indenture should be released before the expiry of the five year term.
('19', 119, 4, 17, 245650) A contract which is based on immorality or which leads to immorality must be terminated and there can be no question of paying compen sation for terminating it.
('19', 119, 4, 18, 245811) But the Fiji planters are not prepared to forgo any part of their legal rights.
('19', 119, 4, 19, 245891) Hence the question of compensation which I have referred to above.
('19', 119, 4, 20, 245958) It is our bounden duty to secure the release of the Indian labourers even by paying this compensation.
('19', 119, 4, 21, 246061) The question is merely that of paying £20,000 at the most.
('19', 119, 4, 22, 246120) I hope that the Government of India will pay this amount and get them released soon.
('19', 119, 4, 23, 246205) Congratulations on this are due to Sir George Barnes, the Secretary of the Department.
('19', 119, 4, 24, 246292) Had he not taken a firm stand, the happy results we can expect now would not have been
('19', 120, 0, 1, 246379) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 121
('19', 120, 1, 2, 246427) possible.
('19', 120, 1, 3, 246437) What shall I say about Mr. Andrews?
('19', 120, 1, 4, 246473) In what way may I congratulate him?
('19', 120, 1, 5, 246509) He has dedicated his whole life to us.
('19', 120, 1, 6, 246548) He finds his happiness in the service of India.
('19', 120, 1, 7, 246596) The Fiji Indians will bless him from the depths of their being.
('19', 120, 2, 8, 246660) [From Gujarati]

('19', 120, 4, 10, 246697) 104. NOTES
('19', 120, 5, 11, 246708) KHILAFAT AND PEACE CELEBRATIONS
('19', 120, 6, 12, 246740) Friends have asked me what we should do during the forthcoming Peace Celebrations.
('19', 120, 6, 13, 246823) I know that, in some of the meetings held on Khilafat Day, a resolution was passed to the effect that, if the Khilafat problem was not solved to their satisfaction, Muslims would not be able to take part in these celebrations since Indians would, in those circumstances, have no peace of mind.
('19', 120, 6, 14, 247117) So long as this important problem remains unsolved and there is a fear that Muslim sentiment would be hurt, and so long as our Muslim brethren suffer in suspense and are worried, so long Hindus, Parsis, Christians, Jews and all others for whom India is their land of birth or adoption, can hardly take part in the forthcoming Peace Celebrations.
('19', 120, 6, 15, 247463) I am bold enough even to imagine.
('19', 120, 6, 16, 247497) His Excellency the Viceroy informing the Ministers of the King emperor that, while the Khilafat problem remains unsolved, Indians would not be able to take part in the Peace Celebrations, and I am confident that before inviting us to join the celebrations the Ministers would accept the need for finding an honourable solution and announcing it.
('19', 120, 7, 17, 247843) [From Gujarati]
('19', 120, 8, 18, 247859) Navajivan, 9 11 1919

('19', 121, 1, 3, 247949) GOVERNOR, PUNJAB 1
('19', 121, 2, 4, 247968) [LAHORE, Before November 12, 1919] Firstly the right of public body or bodies to lead evidence should be definitely recogized and such bodies as well as the parties themselves should be allowed to be represented by counsel who should be permitted to help in the elucidation of facts by cross examination.
('19', 121, 2, 5, 248273) Secondly, some at any rate of the more prominent leaders, now in jail, should be released, if necessary on adequate security alike with a view to giving their own evidence from a position of comparative freedom and to their leading evidence on the non official side and inspiring confidence in the people by their presence.
('19', 121, 2, 6, 248597) Thirdly, the tribunal already appointed to revise sentences of summary courts should be so reconstituted and should follow such a procedure as to command public confidence.

('19', 123, 1, 2, 251038) 108. LETTER TO P.S. TO LT. GOVERNOR, PUNJAB
('19', 123, 2, 3, 251082) LAHORE, November 15, 1919 Will you please tell His Honour that I informed the members of the Congress Sub committee yesterday that he had kindly consented to consider the principle advanced by the Sub committee to the extent that six leaders could be released on parole for the day or days they might actually be giving evidence before the Disorders Inquiry Committee.
('19', 123, 2, 4, 251451) Members admitted that the concession satisfied the principle just barely, but was of no practical value if, no other days, they were not permitted, as prisoners in custody, to attend the Committee meetings in order to instruct counsel in matters specially within their knowledge.
('19', 123, 2, 5, 251731) This would mean the attendance of say, Drs.
('19', 123, 2, 6, 251775) Kitchlew and Satyapal in custody during the Amritsar hearing generally and their release on parole on the day or days they might be examined.
('19', 123, 2, 7, 251917) I felt that the point raised was clear and covered by Lord Hunter’s letter 1 to Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, but Mr. Andrews offered to have it definitely cleared.
('19', 123, 2, 8, 252081) Deep, therefore, was the disappointment when he returned to say that His Honour would not allow leaders to attend even in the manner suggested.
('19', 123, 2, 9, 252225) The Congress Sub committee had, therefore, no course left open to it but to adhere to its decision not to appear before Lord Hunter’s Committee.
('19', 123, 3, 10, 252370) I cannot help expressing my great regret that His Honour should have declined to grant what an ordinary criminal could claim as a matter of right.
('19', 123, 4, 11, 252517) The Leader, 19 11 1919
('19', 123, 5, 12, 252540) 1 For this letter, vide Appendix “Letter fro Secretary, Hunter Committee, to Malaviya”, 19 11 1919. 2 For the Congress Sub committee’s Statement in this regard, vide “Statement on the Punjab by Congress Enquiry Committee”, 17 11 1919.
('19', 124, 0, 1, 252775) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 125
('19', 124, 1, 2, 252823) 109. SPEECH AT FAREWELL TO ANDREWS 1
('19', 124, 2, 3, 252860) LAHORE, November 15, 1919
('19', 124, 3, 4, 252886) He [Gandhiji] said that it was not possible for him to say much about Mr. Andrews who was like a brother to him.
('19', 124, 3, 5, 252999) The sacred bond between them prevented him from giving expression to his feelings on that occasion.
('19', 124, 3, 6, 253099) He would, however, like to say one thing: Mr. Andrews, a true Englishman that he was, had given his whole life to the cause of India and through his actions and his love for India seemed to say to us: “You may feel you are oppressed by my countrymen, but do not think ill of them; look at me.” If the audience wanted to show their regard for Mr. Andrews, they should copy his love and he pleaded not for a blind love but for an enlightened love, the same that was shown by Bhakta Prahlad in his dealing with his own father.
('19', 124, 3, 7, 253623) The lesson that Mr. Andrews’ life taught them was that though we would and must resent and resist injustice and oppression wherever we found them, we were to bear no ill will towards the wrongdoer.
('19', 124, 3, 8, 253821) They were placed by the Government in a most difficult position.
('19', 124, 3, 9, 253886) They had made it impossible for them, by their refusal to release leaders, to co operate with Lord Hunter’s Committee, as they had hoped to do.
('19', 124, 3, 10, 254030) Inspite, however, of the imprudent action of the Government, whilst they would not yield to it, they would not be angry.
('19', 124, 3, 11, 254151) Mr. Andrews had done more for India than many Indians.
('19', 124, 3, 12, 254206) He had not spared his countrymen, but he did not on that account love them the less, and so could they, without harbouring ill will against Englishmen or the Government, go on fighting for the sake of justice and their honour.
('19', 124, 4, 13, 254433) Young India, 26 11 1919
('19', 124, 5, 14, 254457) 1 Young India prefaced authorized versions of Gandhiji’s and Andrews’ speeches as follows: “A most impressive and touching function was the meeting held at Lahore in the Bradlaugh Hall on the 15th instant to bid farewell to Mr. Andrews who was leaving for South Africa .
('19', 124, 5, 15, 254728) .Mr. Gandhi, on being called upon to propose the resolution recording grateful appreciation of Mr. Andrews’ very valuable services rendered to the Punjab in its hour of distress, addressed the meeting in Hindi.” Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya presided.
('19', 124, 5, 16, 254978) Among those who attended the meeting were Pandit Motilal Nehru and C.R. Das.
('19', 124, 5, 17, 255055) 2 Gandhiji then moved the following resolution: “This meeting of the citizens of Lahore hereby places on record its grateful appreciation of the very valuable services rendered to the Punjab in its hour of distress by Mr. C.F. Andrews and wishes him success in his humanitarian mission to South Africa.” C.R. Das supported the resolution.

('19', 125, 1, 2, 255436) 110. PUNJAB LETTER
('19', 125, 2, 3, 255455) LAHORE, Monday, Kartak Vad 11 1 [November 17, 1919]
('19', 125, 3, 4, 255507) AMRITSAR’S LOVE
('19', 125, 4, 5, 255523) From Delhi, I went to Amritsar with Mr. Andrews.
('19', 125, 4, 6, 255572) What I experienced there was truly unique.
('19', 125, 4, 7, 255615) It was well nigh impossible to make our way through the crowds.
('19', 125, 4, 8, 255679) The entire area outside the station was packed with the citizens of Amritsar.
('19', 125, 4, 9, 255757) Their cheers and shouts almost overwhelmed me.
('19', 125, 4, 10, 255804) This huge procession proceeded towards the city.
('19', 125, 4, 11, 255853) The people filled the car with flowers.
('19', 125, 4, 12, 255893) I was taken to the mosque, which was thronged with Hindus and Muslims.
('19', 125, 4, 13, 255964) With great difficulty I made my way from the mosque back to the car, and it was a long time before it reached the Golden Temple of the Sikhs.
('19', 125, 4, 14, 256106) They call this temple the Durbar Sahib.
('19', 125, 4, 15, 256146) Its dome and some other parts are gilt and there is a large lake by its side.
('19', 125, 4, 16, 256224) The adjoining area is also fairly extensive.
('19', 125, 4, 17, 256269) I found it an impossible feat to cross this open space and reach the main temple.
('19', 125, 4, 18, 256351) Thousands stood on all sides.
('19', 125, 4, 19, 256381) There was no dearth of women.
('19', 125, 4, 20, 256411) I saw them boldly joining this thick crowd.
('19', 125, 4, 21, 256455) Yet the men were conducting themselves with the utmost courtesy and restraint.
('19', 125, 4, 22, 256534) This made me particularly happy.
('19', 125, 4, 23, 256567) This should not, of course, be any special cause for joy.
('19', 125, 4, 24, 256625) But I know only too well that this is not the usual state of affairs in India.
('19', 125, 4, 25, 256704) It is my experience that in such crowds restraint is not always observed.
('19', 125, 4, 26, 256778) We have read that it is disappearing even from the pilgrim bands which proceed to Dakor.
('19', 125, 4, 27, 256867) Consequently, I was greatly pleased to see it at Durbar Sahib and I should very much like to see it at every place.
('19', 125, 4, 28, 256983) I took it upon myself, in this multitude, to teach discipline for a while.
('19', 125, 4, 29, 257058) Just as the crowd surged forward I would stop, ask the men and women to be seated and remain so until I reached the Durbar Sahib.
('19', 125, 4, 30, 257188) As long as I stood before them, they remained sitting, but the minute I began to walk, all would sudddenly stand up and try to follow me.
('19', 125, 4, 31, 257326) I made five or six such attempts.
('19', 125, 4, 32, 257360) I even walked backwards, but the people could not control themselves.
('19', 125, 4, 33, 257430) Finally, I decided to go ahead and, by the end of about an hour, I had covered the distance of a few
('19', 125, 5, 34, 257531) 1 This should be 10.
('19', 126, 0, 1, 257552) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 127
('19', 126, 1, 2, 257600) This was obstinacy on the people’s parts.
('19', 126, 1, 3, 257642) They could not repress their affection.
('19', 126, 1, 4, 257682) Those who had suffered much washed away their grief with the waters of love.
('19', 126, 1, 5, 257759) But what about me?
('19', 126, 1, 6, 257778) How much of this did I deserve?
('19', 126, 1, 7, 257810) Those who showered their love were of course blessed, but what about the one on whom it was showered?
('19', 126, 1, 8, 257912) Many women whose relatives were in jail expected, perhaps, that they would be released through my efforts.
('19', 126, 1, 9, 258019) But who was I to secure their release?
('19', 126, 1, 10, 258058) All I can say is that I offer all this love at the feet of the Lord in whose name I serve.
('19', 126, 1, 11, 258149) When I had paid my respects at the shrine, I was presented with a scarf and turban; I tied the turban over my cap and put the scarf round my neck.
('19', 126, 1, 12, 258296) It was no less difficult to go out of the temple than it had been to enter it.
('19', 126, 1, 13, 258375) This going and coming in a procession took five hours.
('19', 126, 1, 14, 258430) Yet the people were not satisfied.
('19', 126, 1, 15, 258465) I was taken to Lala Girdhari Lal’s.
('19', 126, 1, 16, 258501) Thousands remained round the house till six in the evening and I had repeatedly to go out to meet them.
('19', 126, 1, 17, 258605) Both men and women came.
('19', 126, 1, 18, 258630) The people of Amritsar say that never before had women come out in such large numbers.
('19', 126, 1, 19, 258717) They refused to disperse without upadesh 1 “Let us have upadesh” is a phrase in common use here.
('19', 126, 1, 20, 258814) I tried to comfort the women in their sorrow and encouraged them to abandon fear.
('19', 126, 1, 21, 258896) I requested them not to grieve for those who were in jail and told them that, as long as we did not have thousands of Indians courting the hardships of jail deliberately, we could not make progress.
('19', 126, 1, 22, 259095) I then advised them to use only swadeshi and suggested that they should spin every day, for some time at least, as a religious duty.
('19', 126, 2, 23, 259228) FLOOD OF ENERGY These were solemn scenes.
('19', 126, 2, 24, 259270) Just as the Americans get energy from the Niagara Falls for their use, so can we also make use of the energy which exists at Amritsar and other places.
('19', 126, 2, 25, 259422) Today this energy flows to waste like that of a waterfall.
('19', 126, 2, 26, 259481) But it can be turned to valuable use.
('19', 126, 2, 27, 259519) Patriotic pride has been awakened in the hearts of thousands of men and women.
('19', 126, 2, 28, 259598) They realize, too, that this patriotism should be informed with the spirit of dharma.
('19', 126, 2, 29, 259684) They have time, but no discipline, no knowledge, nor have they the zeal and diligence which will endure.
('19', 126, 2, 30, 259789) Even more than reading and writing, they require the knowledge that touches the heart and the diligence that such knowledge brings.
('19', 126, 2, 31, 259921) In real fact, however, there is a vast gap between the
('19', 126, 3, 32, 259976) 1 Spiritual counsel or advice
('19', 127, 0, 1, 260006) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 127, 1, 2, 260048) educated and the people generally regarded as illiterate.
('19', 127, 1, 3, 260106) There were educated people, too, in this procession.
('19', 127, 1, 4, 260159) They also were proud of their country.
('19', 127, 1, 5, 260198) But their way of life differs from that of the illiterate and they believe that, until the latter are given education, the country can make no progress.
('19', 127, 1, 6, 260351) But, for the uplift of the nation, nothing more is required than love for one’s country and readiness to serve her or, in other words, a spiritual awakening.
('19', 127, 1, 7, 260509) A spiritual awakening means devotion to duty.
('19', 127, 1, 8, 260555) If each individual understands his present duty and performs it, the next duty will of itself become clear to him.
('19', 127, 1, 9, 260670) Today’s duty is this: (1) to fear no man; (2) to follow the truth always; (3) to follow the swadeshi dharma for fighting starvation in the country; (4) that this dharma may be easily followed, to introduce the spinning wheel into our homes, help in increasing the production of hand made cloth and to wear garments made of it.
('19', 127, 1, 10, 260997) One who fears God will never fear man; hence he will not fear the Government or kings or officers.
('19', 127, 1, 11, 261096) And who can frighten him who has no fear?
('19', 127, 1, 12, 261138) None can rule over such a one by force.
('19', 127, 1, 13, 261178) The Government and similar embodiments of authority will then realize their true functions and prove a beneficial power for subjects who are unafraid.
('19', 127, 1, 14, 261329) The State’s power of punishing is an instrument of fear.
('19', 127, 1, 15, 261386) When the subjects have abandoned fear, this instrument loses its effectiveness.
('19', 127, 1, 16, 261466) This fearlessness can be cultivated only through irreproachable conduct and such purity of conduct is impossible without truth.
('19', 127, 1, 17, 261594) Thus, practice of truth is the only gateway to our freedom.
('19', 127, 1, 18, 261654) Every year we send 60 crores of rupees abroad for our cloth.
('19', 127, 1, 19, 261715) That is why we need swadeshi.
('19', 127, 1, 20, 261745) It can spread rapidly only through the spinning wheel and the handloom.
('19', 127, 1, 21, 261817) The wheel and the loom, therefore, hold the key to our developing a trade worth 60 crores.
('19', 127, 1, 22, 261908) There can be no fearlessness without truth and no wealth without swadeshi.
('19', 127, 1, 23, 261983) Swaraj, therefore, lies in the practice of these two.
('19', 127, 1, 24, 262037) If we have the right kind of workers, these two ideas can be taught to be people in no time.
('19', 127, 1, 25, 262130) In the villages where such workers exist, a beginning should be made to teach these two principles.
('19', 127, 1, 26, 262230) For this no large buildings or funds are required.
('19', 127, 1, 27, 262281) What is necessary is zeal and sincerity of purpose.

('19', 128, 1, 2, 262381) These thoughts come repeatedly to me after my experiences at Lahore and Amritsar.

('19', 128, 2, 4, 262498) IN LAHORE We stayed for a day in Amritsar and then came to Lahore.
('19', 128, 2, 5, 262565) There was much to be done here.
('19', 128, 2, 6, 262597) Both the Pandits were still away Motilalji in Prayag and Malaviyaji in Delhi.
('19', 128, 2, 7, 262675) I therefore busied myself in doing all I could about the evidence to be presented.
('19', 128, 2, 8, 262758) I also wrote a letter to the Lt. Governor reminding him that two of the three conditions were yet to be fulfilled.
('19', 128, 3, 9, 262873) TWO CONDITIONS The first was that one of the judges who are to review the cases tried in the summary courts should be from outside the Punjab.
('19', 128, 3, 10, 263016) The second was that the leaders who are in jail should be released during the time that the Committee sat.
('19', 128, 3, 11, 263123) Explaining the reasons for this condition, I said that without them evidence could not be properly presented.
('19', 128, 3, 12, 263233) Even their temporary release would give the people courage to give evidence and create faith in the Government’s bona fides.
('19', 128, 3, 13, 263358) In the meanwhile, Pandit Malaviya and Mr. Das arrived from Delhi and Motilalji from Prayag.
('19', 128, 3, 14, 263450) The members of the Committee also arrived.
('19', 128, 3, 15, 263493) They inspected Jallianwala Bagh and other places in Amritsar where the people had suffered most.
('19', 128, 3, 16, 263590) The Committee commenced its sittings on Thursday, the 13th, and the examination of witnesses about the Amritsar incidents started.
('19', 128, 4, 17, 263721) COMMITTEE BOYCOTTED From our side, however, the Committee is being boycotted.
('19', 128, 4, 18, 263799) On Monday, the 10th, a reply came from the Lt. Governor that a judge from outside the Punjab had been appointed.
('19', 128, 4, 19, 263912) He was Justice Mullik of the Bihar High Court.
('19', 128, 4, 20, 263959) The Government had not however, agreed to the third condition.
('19', 128, 4, 21, 264022) The Governor said that only prisoners required by the Committee would be brought before it to give evidence.
('19', 128, 4, 22, 264131) This letter was addressed to Malaviyaji and I, too, received the same reply.
('19', 128, 4, 23, 264208) The Congress Sub committee met and Panditji explained the situation.
('19', 128, 4, 24, 264277) I also made some observations.
('19', 128, 4, 25, 264308) After much discussion, Panditji as Chairman wrote letters to the Lt. Governor and Lord Hunter.
('19', 128, 4, 26, 264403) These have now been released to the Press.
('19', 128, 4, 27, 264446) They make it clear that, as long as the chief leaders were not released, the Hunter Committee would be boycotted by the people.
('19', 128, 4, 28, 264574) The reasons for this were stated in the letter
('19', 129, 0, 1, 264621) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 129, 1, 2, 264663) to Lord Hunter and a request was made to him that the leaders should be released just as I and some others had been freed in South Africa.
('19', 129, 1, 3, 264802) Lord Hunter has also replied in the negative.
('19', 129, 1, 4, 264848) Meanwhile, Mr. Andrews called on the Governor and pressed him to accede to the request.
('19', 129, 1, 5, 264936) Then I saw the Governor.
('19', 129, 1, 6, 264961) As a result there was a further small concession.: It was agreed that, when the leaders were brought out to give evidence, they would be set free on condition that they returned to sleep in jail.
('19', 129, 1, 7, 265157) In this the principle behind our demand was being conceded in part and so the Congress Committee met again to consider the issue.
('19', 129, 1, 8, 265287) It was resolved that the Lt. Governor's offer be accepted, provided the prisoners were left free on the other days as on parole and permitted to be present in the court to assist our lawyers.
('19', 129, 1, 9, 265479) Mr. Andrews then went to finalize the matter, but the Governor refused to agree.
('19', 129, 1, 10, 265560) Panditji has written again to Lord Hunter.
('19', 129, 1, 11, 265603) The Government officials whose actions are under scrutiny, the Government Pleader among them, are permitted to attend the sittings of the Hunter Committee.
('19', 129, 1, 12, 265759) Malaviyaji has pointed out that the Congress Committee cannot possibly agree to a partial arrangement whereby Government officers who are in the position of defendants are allowed to be present while our imprisoned leaders may not come to assist our lawyer.
('19', 129, 1, 13, 266017) The result is that our boycott continues.
('19', 129, 2, 14, 266059) EVIDENCE BEFORE HUNTER COMMITTEE Evidence is still being taken from the Amritsar officers.
('19', 129, 2, 15, 266150) It seems they admit the main charges.
('19', 129, 2, 16, 266188) All three Indian members are doing good work.
('19', 129, 2, 17, 266234) Pandit Jagat Narain's cross examination is extremely severe.
('19', 129, 2, 18, 266295) I feel that at times it is harsher than it need be.

('19', 129, 2, 20, 266401) Having conducted criminal cases for a long time, he has got into this habit.

('19', 129, 2, 25, 266796) Whether or not this is so, it is admitted by all that the Indian members are no 'yes men'.
('19', 129, 3, 26, 266887) OUR COMMITTEE As we are boycotting the Committee, it is necessary that we do something else instead.

('19', 132, 1, 2, 270570) 113. BHAI PARMANAND
('19', 132, 2, 3, 270590) Mr. Andrews has dealt with the case of Bhai Parmanand in pathetic language in the columns of the Tribune.
('19', 132, 2, 4, 270696) Bhai Parmanand belongs to the band of Indians daily growing in numbers who have set apart their lives for India's service and have accepted comparative poverty as their lot.
('19', 132, 2, 5, 270870) It was in that spirit that, under the influence of Lala Hansraj, he joined the D.A.V. College at Lahore as a professor.
('19', 132, 2, 6, 270990) By his unassuming manners, industry and sterling character he made himself popular with the students as also the staff.
('19', 132, 2, 7, 271110) He then paid a visit to South Africa and preached on the necessity of religion as a factor in life building.
('19', 132, 2, 8, 271219) He left on my mind a deep impression as a man full of truth and nobility.
('19', 132, 2, 9, 271293) He came in close touch with me during his visit to that sub continent and was for nearly a month my honoured guest.
('19', 132, 2, 10, 271409) I had many a chat with hiim on various matters and I believe that his patriotism was of a lofty type a patriotism that would disdain to use violence to serve national ends.
('19', 132, 2, 11, 271582) He went to England from South Africa.
('19', 132, 2, 12, 271620) There he came in touch with the school of violence headed by Pandit Shyamji Krishnavarma 1. But the truth in him burnt as brightly as ever even in the midst of temptation.
('19', 132, 2, 13, 271792) His frank and fearless statement before the court shows that he has hidden nothing.
('19', 132, 2, 14, 271876) He has made admissions which are damaging to him.
('19', 132, 2, 15, 271926) He was not bound to make any statement, but he would not flinch.
('19', 132, 2, 16, 271991) He felt that he would hide nothing even though his statement involved a conviction.
('19', 132, 2, 17, 272075) His statement itself provides no material for a conviction.
('19', 132, 2, 18, 272135) But the special court tacked to it other evidence and condemned him.
('19', 132, 2, 19, 272204) The able petition presented by his wife and reproduced elsewhere contains a convincing analysis of the case.
('19', 132, 2, 20, 272313) I do not propose to refer to it for the moment.
('19', 132, 2, 21, 272361) My purpose is to show that the Government have greviously erred in treating an honourable man as a common felon.
('19', 132, 2, 22, 272474) Assume his guilt.
('19', 132, 2, 23, 272492) It was still wrong to send hiim to the Andamans.
('19', 132, 2, 24, 272541) It was easy, if he was an enemy, to turn him into a friend by humane treatment.
('19', 132, 2, 25, 272621) If he was really dangerous, it was right to deprive him of his liberty.
('19', 132, 2, 26, 272693) But it was cruel to herd him with ordinary prisoners or to send him to the Andamans.
('19', 132, 2, 27, 272778) I have taken care to ask many men in Lahore and elsewhere about Bhai Parmanand.
('19', 132, 2, 28, 272858) Not one man believed in his guilt.
('19', 132, 2, 29, 272893) Every one of them considers him to be
('19', 132, 3, 30, 272931) 1 Editor of The Indian Sociologist; vide “An Indian Philanthropist”, 3 6 1905
('19', 133, 0, 1, 273009) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 133, 1, 2, 273051) innocent of the crime imputed to him.
('19', 133, 1, 3, 273089) A government that exists by terror does not deserve to exist at all.
('19', 133, 1, 4, 273158) For such a government has cowards, not brave men and women, to govern.
('19', 133, 1, 5, 273229) Bhai Parmanand has been long enough in jail.
('19', 133, 1, 6, 273274) His wife and children were deprived (I think illegally) of their personal effects under the order of forefeiture.
('19', 133, 1, 7, 273388) His letters show that Bhai Parmanand, instead of being embittered, has been leading in the Andamans a life of religious introspection.
('19', 133, 1, 8, 273523) It is not right for the government to keep such a man in prison.
('19', 133, 1, 9, 273588) I trust that His Honour the Lieut. Governor of the Punjab will examine the case, and what is more, inquire about Bhai Parmanand's record in the Andamans and discharge him without delay.

('19', 134, 1, 2, 274868) 115. HOW TO PROTECT THE COW
('19', 134, 2, 3, 274896) I have been receiving letters from many people on the question of cow protection.
('19', 134, 2, 4, 274978) The latest of them says that I should work for the cause, even giving up that of swadeshi for the purpose.
('19', 134, 2, 5, 275085) I formed my views on this subject many years ago.
('19', 134, 2, 6, 275135) They run contrary to the current efforts.
('19', 134, 2, 7, 275177) I feel that, in the name of cow protection, we knowingly or unknowingly kill cows.
('19', 134, 2, 8, 275260) But I have no desire, just now, to place before the reader all my views on cow protection.
('19', 134, 2, 9, 275351) I merely want to place before him some portion of the letter I have received from Maulana Abdul Bari Saheb.
('19', 134, 2, 10, 275459) He says:
('19', 134, 3, 11, 275468) I thank you for the success of the day of prayer for Khilafat appointed
('19', 134, 4, 12, 275540) for promoting unity between Hindus and Muslims.
('19', 134, 4, 13, 275588) The stand you have taken in
('19', 134, 5, 14, 275616) this matter has made a deep impression on the Muslims, especially on those among them who are religious minded.
('19', 134, 5, 15, 275728) Some Ulemas have particularly asked
('19', 134, 6, 16, 275764) me in their letters to convey their congratulations to you.
('19', 134, 6, 17, 275824) One of them is
('19', 134, 7, 18, 275839) Maulana Suleman Saheb of Fulwari.
('19', 134, 7, 19, 275873) He writes to say that he has decided not to
('19', 134, 8, 20, 275917) kill cows in future and to dissuade others likewise from doing so.
('19', 134, 8, 21, 275984) If people like
('19', 134, 9, 22, 275999) you go on working for unity, the country will progress the sooner and the
('19', 134, 10, 23, 276073) causes of discord will disappear.
('19', 134, 10, 24, 276107) Let us leave aside what part I have played in bringing about unity.
('19', 134, 10, 25, 276175) The lesson I want to draw for the reader from this letter is that, if we would protect cows, we could do so only through service of our Muslim brethren.
('19', 134, 10, 26, 276328) A gentleman sent me a message to the effect that we should help the Muslims on the Khilafat issue only on condition that they stop killing cows.
('19', 134, 10, 27, 276473) The letter referred to above gives a reply to that gentleman.
('19', 134, 10, 28, 276535) There can be no zest or point in giving help in expectation of a return.
('19', 134, 10, 29, 276608) Our Muslim brethren have not sought our help on the issue of Khilafat.
('19', 134, 10, 30, 276679) If, however, we want their friendship, if we regard them as our brethren, it is our duty to help them.
('19', 134, 10, 31, 276782) If, as a result, they stop cow slaughter, it will be a different matter.
('19', 134, 10, 32, 276855) That will not be surprising.
('19', 134, 10, 33, 276884) But we cannot offer them our help on condition that they stop cow slaughter.
('19', 134, 10, 34, 276961) Duty seeks no reward.
('19', 134, 10, 35, 276983) But it is the obvious duty of those who are eager to protect cows to give all possible help to the Muslims on the Khilafat issue.
('19', 134, 10, 36, 277113) In December, we shall again have occasion for giving this help.
('19', 134, 10, 37, 277177) There will be Peace Celebrations from the 13th to the 16th December.
('19', 134, 10, 38, 277246) I am convinced that, so long as the Muslims have not been satisfied,
('19', 135, 0, 1, 277315) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 135, 1, 2, 277357) we ought not to participate in those celebrations.
('19', 135, 1, 3, 277408) So long as those who have a heavy stake in the outcome of the War do not know what their position will be, so long as they entertain the utmost fears about it, Peace Celebrations can have no meaning for them.
('19', 135, 2, 4, 277617) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 23 11 1919
('19', 135, 3, 5, 277655) 116. SPEECH AT KHILAFAT CONFERENCE, DELHI1
('19', 135, 4, 6, 277698) [November 23, 1919]
('19', 135, 5, 7, 277718) PRESIDENT AND BRETHREN, You will pardon me for keeping my seat for I cannot address standing.
('19', 135, 5, 8, 277812) It had been said that Hindus have laid Mussulmans under a debt by sharing their feelings of sorrow and protest, but I maintain that they have done no more than their duty.
('19', 135, 5, 9, 277984) You have passed a resolution of thanks to Hindus, but the fulfilment of duty and the settlement of debts deserve no thanks.
('19', 135, 5, 10, 278108) It was their duty because there has been much talk of unity lately.
('19', 135, 5, 11, 278176) But the test of unity and real fraternal feeling lies in sharing one another’s sorrow and happiness alike.
('19', 135, 5, 12, 278283) How can twenty two crore Hindus have peace and happiness if eight crore of their Muslim brethren are torn in anguish?
('19', 135, 5, 13, 278401) The pain of eight crores is also the pain of the other twenty two crore inhabitants of India; therefore, although peace has been concluded, India has not known any real peace.
('19', 135, 6, 14, 278577) He then continued to say that he had been telling the Viceroy and Government to secure a just and honourable peace for Turkey, if it was intended that Mussulmans should be satisfied and then all Indians would join the rejoicings in the best spirit.
('19', 135, 6, 15, 278826) He then admonished his hearers not to lose faith in their spiritual potency nor to lose hope.
('19', 135, 7, 16, 278920) Theirs was a just cause and if they meant to succeed, it was their duty to be prepared for sacrifices, for sacrifices would be demanded by so sacred a cause as theirs.
('19', 135, 7, 17, 279088) They should not play at religion or trifle with such great issues, but embark on their task in all humility, firmness, sincerity and a determination to succeed.
