('19', 141, 5, 8, 293189) MR. ANDREWS’ SPEECH In the last issue I had promised to give my readers the speech delivered by Mr. Andrews on the occasion of his departure from Lahore for South Africa, and my own speech, as both are of great importance.
('19', 141, 5, 9, 293412) The following is the gist of Mr. Andrews’ speech: 2
('19', 141, 6, 10, 293464) It is a very difficult thing to say goodbye after months of such close and intimate fellowship in work, as we have had together both in Delhi and in the Punjab.
('19', 141, 6, 11, 293625) My words will therefore be few.
('19', 141, 6, 12, 293657) Except for matters of immediate practical urgency, I have kept my lips sealed on all controversial points (both on the platform and in the Press during the time I have been personally working).
('19', 141, 6, 13, 293851) But now that I am leaving immediately for South Africa and shall not be returning for at least four months, I don’t think it would be honest on my part to go away silently without any statement at all (of what I have seen and witnessed).
('19', 141, 6, 14, 294089) I wish to go at once to the main issues and I think I can put my own position quite briefly in the following manner: I hold as strongly as possible (after my inquiry) that no provocation whatever can excuse the cowardly and brutal murders of Englishmen by the mob which occurred at Amritsar and elsewhere, nor the burning of the holy places of the Christian religion.
('19', 141, 6, 15, 294457) Most cowardly and dastardly of all I regard the murderous attack on
('19', 141, 7, 16, 294525) 1 At the conclusion of the address, the following resolution was adopted: “That this meeting of Muslim and non Muslim representatives of India convened to consider the Khilafat question is of opinion that in as much as the Khilafat question, which is part of the Peace programme and affects the vital interest of eight crores of Mussulmans of India and is therefore a national question, is still unsettled, it is not possible for Indians to participate in the forthcoming celebrations, and further respectfully requests His Excellency the Viceroy of India to postpone the celebration of Peace pending a satisfactory and honoured settlement of the Khilafat question.” 2 What follows is the English report of the speech found in Young India, 26 11 1919. ('19', 144, 1, 5, 300752) As long as there is even one Andrews among the British people, we must, for the sake of such a one, bear no hatred to them.
('19', 144, 1, 6, 300876) If we hate them, we cannot bear real love for Mr. Andrews and we shall forfeit the right to accept his service.
('19', 144, 1, 7, 300988) This is clear enough.
('19', 144, 1, 8, 301010) “The question is: When massacres like the one at Jallianwala Bagh take place, when British soldiers abuse us, kick us, debar us from sitting with them in trains, British officers want to keep all power to themselves and British merchants try to monopolize the principal trade of India, how can we help being angry with them?
('19', 144, 1, 9, 301335) How can we ever feel affection for them?
('19', 144, 1, 10, 301376) The difficulty is obvious.
('19', 144, 1, 11, 301403) Wherever one turns, one finds hatred, anger, scorn and falsehood.
('19', 144, 1, 12, 301469) When Indians do not always feel affection for one another, what can we expect from them with regard to the British?
('19', 144, 1, 13, 301585) But these doubts arise from want of faith in God.
('19', 144, 1, 14, 301635) An intellectual acceptance of the existence of God does not make one a believer.
('19', 144, 1, 15, 301716) To believe in God but not to love people is a contradiction in terms.
('19', 144, 1, 16, 301786) Faith implies truth and love.
('19', 144, 1, 17, 301816) If these qualities could shine forth within us in their perfection, we would ourselves be God.
('19', 144, 1, 18, 301911) “Accepting this truth, we should move in its direction.
('19', 144, 1, 19, 301967) This is the lesson to be learnt from Mr. Andrews’ life: his penance is for this, it is the true meaning of his tapascharya hidden from the eyes of men.
('19', 144, 1, 20, 302119) I have seen him sitting silent for hours in our homes.
('19', 144, 1, 21, 302174) Even when we have disregarded him I have seen that he has shown no anger.
('19', 144, 1, 22, 302248) I have seen him eating contentedly whatever was offered him in our homes.
('19', 144, 1, 23, 302322) I have known him setting out for South Africa at a moment’s notice at the late Mr. Gokhale’s behest.
('19', 144, 1, 24, 302423) 1 This is true and silent tapascharya.
('19', 144, 1, 25, 302462) His work on our behalf in South Africa and other countries is there for us all to see and, therefore, we recognize it as such.
('19', 144, 1, 26, 302589) But the invisible sacrifices that he is ever making are even more precious.
('19', 144, 1, 27, 302665) “But it is not only out of respect for Mr. Andrews that we must banish all hatred for the British.
('19', 144, 1, 28, 302764) By doing so we shall ensure early success of our efforts for if we work on in patience, as he does with
('19', 144, 2, 29, 302868) 1 In December 1913
('19', 145, 0, 1, 302887) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 145, 1, 2, 302929) perseverance and with all regard for truth, the British will have no occasion to visit their evil propensities on us.
('19', 145, 1, 3, 303047) And just as he is able to do the work of many, standing alone, so also if even one Indian follows in his footsteps, he will do as much alone, and will accelerate our progress.”
('19', 145, 2, 4, 303224) GUJRANWALA Last week I visited Gujranwala.
('19', 145, 2, 5, 303267) It is a township with a population of 30,000. There also I found the same love as in Amritsar.
('19', 145, 2, 6, 303362) As I had to examine the evidence there, I had taken Mr. Purushottamdas Tandon and Dr. Parasaram with me.
('19', 145, 2, 7, 303467) We stayed at the house of Divan Mangalsen, who is at present in jail.
('19', 145, 2, 8, 303537) I had, therefore, the privilege of meeting his wife and was indebted to her for her hospitality.
('19', 145, 2, 9, 303634) In Lahore I am the guest of Smt.
('19', 145, 2, 10, 303667) Sarladevi Choudhrani and have been bathing in her deep affection.
('19', 145, 2, 11, 303733) I first met Sarladevi in 1901. She comes from the famous Tagore family.
('19', 145, 2, 12, 303805) Of her learning and sincerity, too, I get evidence in ever so many ways.
('19', 145, 2, 13, 303878) In Amritsar, I also met the wives of Dr. Kitchlew and Dr. Satyapal.
('19', 145, 2, 14, 303946) All these ladies bear their sorrow with great fortitude.
('19', 145, 2, 15, 304003) Two large meetings were held in Gujranwala ≈ one for women, the other for men.
('19', 145, 2, 16, 304082) I explained the philosophy of the spinning wheel to the women and they, in their turn, promised to take up spinning.
('19', 145, 2, 17, 304199) Gujranwala is the birthplace of Ranjit Singh.
('19', 145, 2, 18, 304245) I saw the house in which he was born and in which he lived.
('19', 145, 2, 19, 304305) I drew the people’s attention to the extensive damage done to this place.
('19', 145, 2, 20, 304379) I observe that I meet with no difficulty in consequence of my pointing out to people their lapses at every place.
('19', 145, 2, 21, 304493) All acknowledge the fact that they have made mistakes.
('19', 145, 2, 22, 304548) In Gujranwala the officers stopped at nothing by way of revenge and cruelty.
('19', 145, 2, 23, 304625) It is not necessary to describe these.

('19', 148, 3, 4, 308183) KHILAFAT MEETING
('19', 148, 4, 5, 308200) From Gujranwala we proceeded direct to Delhi.
('19', 148, 4, 6, 308246) On the 23rd a meeting was held there only for Muslims and on the 24th there was a public meeting for both Hindus and Muslims.
('19', 148, 4, 7, 308372) The meeting of the 23rd was private and there were very few non Muslims present.
('19', 148, 4, 8, 308453) I was present by special invitation.
('19', 148, 4, 9, 308490) The Hon.
('19', 148, 4, 10, 308499) Maulvi Fazlul Haq presided over the meeting.
('19', 148, 4, 11, 308544) It will be recalled that he has also been appointed one of the Commissioners in connection with the work in the Punjab.
('19', 148, 4, 12, 308664) A number of resolutions were to be passed in the meeting and a Subjects Committee had been appointed for drafting them.
('19', 148, 4, 13, 308784) This Committee sat from 4 to 9.30 in the evening.
('19', 148, 4, 14, 308834) There was a great deal of discussion.
('19', 148, 4, 15, 308872) One resolution, in which the Hindus were thanked, was unanimously accepted.
('19', 148, 4, 16, 308948) The second resolution, calling for non participation in the Peace Celebrations, was also passed.
('19', 148, 4, 17, 309045) The third important resolution was about boycott and was hotly debated.
('19', 148, 4, 18, 309117) Many violent speeches were made and it was suggested that the boycott should cover articles from other countries of Europe also, but few were agreeable to this.
('19', 148, 4, 19, 309278) My advice was sought and my suggestions listened to with great attention and courtesy.
('19', 148, 4, 20, 309365) Many agreed with my view.
('19', 148, 4, 21, 309391) I explained that boycott implied bitterness and enmity.
('19', 148, 4, 22, 309447) As a result, our task would be made difficult rather than easy.
('19', 148, 4, 23, 309511) The resolution, however, was accepted by a majority.
('19', 148, 4, 24, 309564) I suggested that, instead of advising boycott, they could, if they had the strength, resolve to withhold co operation.
('19', 148, 4, 25, 309683) We had the right to pass such a resolution and it could also be regarded as our duty.
('19', 148, 4, 26, 309769) This suggestion too met with general approval and was accepted.
('19', 148, 4, 27, 309833) Finally, the general meeting commenced at night.
('19', 148, 4, 28, 309882) The resolutions prepared by the Subjects Committee were placed before it and there was much discussion on the boycott resolution.
('19', 148, 4, 29, 310012) Usually, the resolutions presented by the Subjects Committee are not debated at any length in the general meeting, but on this occasion

('19', 149, 1, 2, 310374) permission was given for an exhaustive debate.
('19', 149, 1, 3, 310421) The Hon’ble.
('19', 149, 1, 4, 310434) Mr. Reza Ali, Mr. Abdulla Haroon, Mr. Syed Hussain and I spoke against boycott and made an effective impression on the audience, which gave us a patient hearing.
('19', 149, 1, 5, 310596) Finally, however, the boycott resolution was passed.
('19', 149, 1, 6, 310649) This meeting continued till 3 a.m.
('19', 149, 1, 7, 310684) Many well known Muslims such as Haji ul Mulk Hakim Ajmal Khan, Dr. Ansari, Maulana Abdul Bari Saheb and others were present.
('19', 149, 2, 8, 310809) JOINT MEETING OF HINDUS AND MUSLIMS A joint meeting was held on the following day to which pressmen were invited.
('19', 149, 2, 9, 310923) Mr. Sheppard of The Times of India was also present.
('19', 149, 2, 10, 310976) I was in the chair.
('19', 149, 2, 11, 310996) The meeting was held in the Sangram Theatre which was filled to capacity.
('19', 149, 2, 12, 311070) Admission was by tickets.
('19', 149, 2, 13, 311096) Sannyasi Swami Shraddhanand, Mr. Bomanji of Saharanpur, Dr. Choithram 1 of Sind, Mr. Krishnakant Malaviya of Prayag and others were present.
('19', 149, 2, 14, 311237) The Hon’ble Pandit Motilal Nehru, Mr. C.R. Das, and others had sent telegrams intimating their moral support.
('19', 149, 2, 15, 311347) The Secretary of the Conference, Mr. Asaf Ali, had intimated in the papers circulated by him that the issues of cow protection and the Punjab would also be considered at this meeting.
('19', 149, 2, 16, 311531) Many had looked forward to their being discussed.
('19', 149, 2, 17, 311581) My ideas on both had been already formed.
('19', 149, 2, 18, 311623) If I allowed the issue of cow protection to be discussed, the cause would be harmed.
('19', 149, 2, 19, 311708) If I threw open the Punjab issue for debate, both the Punjab and the Khilafat causes would suffer.
('19', 149, 2, 20, 311807) I could not let this happen.
('19', 149, 2, 21, 311836) My position, therefore, was extremely delicate.
('19', 149, 2, 22, 311884) I had to take upon myself the responsibility of causing pain to people whom I knew.
('19', 149, 2, 23, 311968) I was obliged, therefore, to refer to all these matters in my speech, the gist of which I give here so that readers will understand my intentions.
('19', 149, 2, 24, 312115) The English report of it which has been published was also prepared by me.
('19', 149, 2, 25, 312190) But it does not contain all the arguments.
('19', 149, 2, 26, 312233) My speeches here, as also those of others, were in Urdu and I could see that those present followed everything well.
('19', 149, 3, 27, 312350) MY SPEECH “I am grateful for the resolution passed yesterday thanking the Hindus in general and me in particular.
('19', 149, 3, 28, 312464) I wish also to say that whatever help the Hindus and others have rendered in connection with the Khilafat is no more than their duty.
('19', 149, 3, 29, 312598) Duty is a kind of debt.
('19', 149, 3, 30, 312622) There can be no return for its payment.
('19', 149, 3, 31, 312662) Mr. Asaf Ali has, in the notices he
('19', 149, 4, 32, 312698) 1 Dr. Choithram Gidwani
('19', 150, 0, 1, 312722) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 151
('19', 150, 1, 2, 312770) sent about this meeting, mentioned the subject of cow protection.
('19', 150, 1, 3, 312836) My humble opinion is that the issue of cow protection may not be raised on this occasion by the Hindus.
('19', 150, 1, 4, 312940) If we are one people, if we regard one another as brothers, then Hindus, Parsis, Christians and Jews born in India have the clear duty of helping the Muslims, their fellow countrymen, in their suffering.
('19', 150, 1, 5, 313144) That help which demands a return is mercenary and can never be a symbol of brotherhood.
('19', 150, 1, 6, 313232) Just as adulterated cement cannot hold bricks together, so mercenary help cannot make for brotherhood.
('19', 150, 1, 7, 313335) The noble traditions of the Hindus require that they help their Muslim brethren.
('19', 150, 1, 8, 313416) If the Muslims feel themselves bound in honour to spare the feelings of Hindus, then, whether we help in the matter of the Khilafat or not, they may stop the slaughter of cows.
('19', 150, 1, 9, 313593) Though, therefore, I yield to none in my reverence for the cow, I do not wish to make my help in the Khilafat conditional on anything.
('19', 150, 1, 10, 313728) On the contrary, I feel that there is greater protection for cows in help given unconditionally.
('19', 150, 1, 11, 313825) Only if we serve one another without laying down conditions can affection and fraternal love grow amongst us and the path to cow protection be cleared.
('19', 150, 1, 12, 313977) I, therefore, hope that all Hindus will make the Khilafat cause their own without insisting on any conditions.
('19', 150, 1, 13, 314088) “Our second problem is the issue of the Punjab.
('19', 150, 1, 14, 314136) A demand has been made by several persons that we keep away from the Peace Celebrations because of the sufferings of the Punjab.
('19', 150, 1, 15, 314265) I differ here also.
('19', 150, 1, 16, 314285) I have probed deeply into these sufferings of the Punjab.
('19', 150, 1, 17, 314343) Others may have felt these equally, but I will not admit that anyone was more grieved than I was.
('19', 150, 1, 18, 314441) Even so, I am of the opinion that we cannot mix up this issue with that of the Khilafat.
('19', 150, 1, 19, 314530) Personally, I feel that, whatever the sufferings of the Punjab, we cannot, on a local issue, dissociate ourselves from a celebration which concerns the whole Empire.
('19', 150, 1, 20, 314696) We have other means by which to publicize the wrongs of the Punjab.
('19', 150, 1, 21, 314764) Nor can we dissociate ourselves from the celebrations on the ground that justice has not been done in the matter of the Punjab, because we still hope for justice.
('19', 150, 1, 22, 314927) It is for this purpose that the Hunter Committee is sitting and our Commissioners are working.
('19', 150, 1, 23, 315022) We may abstain from the Peace Celebrations only if we have any cause for dissatisfaction or doubt arising directly from the peace terms.
('19', 150, 1, 24, 315159) The Khilafat is the only issue of this kind.
('19', 150, 1, 25, 315204) Though it is among the issues to be settled in the peace terms, not only are we quite in the dark about it but we have good reasons to suspect that the final settlement will not be satisfactory to us.
('19', 150, 1, 26, 315405) Hence it is only on the Khilafat issue that we can
('19', 151, 0, 1, 315456) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 151, 1, 2, 315498) refuse to join the Peace Celebrations.
('19', 151, 1, 3, 315537) If we mix up the Punjab issue with this one, we shall be accused of thoughtlessness and of lacking a sense of proportion, and the causes, both of the Khilafat and the Punjab, will suffer in consequence.
('19', 151, 1, 4, 315740) The Khilafat issue is a grave matter and one which demands immediate solution.
('19', 151, 1, 5, 315819) A decision in this regard will soon be taken.
('19', 151, 1, 6, 315865) We may not, therefore, risk harm to this cause by dragging in other issues on this occasion.
('19', 151, 1, 7, 315958) I, therefore, hope that the Punjab issue will not be brought up for consideration here.
('19', 151, 1, 8, 316046) “The question now is whether or not on the Khilafat issue our Muslim brethren have justice on their side.
('19', 151, 1, 9, 316152) If their demand has no justice in it, then, neither the Hindus nor any others should help them, nor can they expect help.
('19', 151, 1, 10, 316274) Even if they receive help, they will not succeed.
('19', 151, 1, 11, 316324) But the Prime Minister of England has himself testified to the justice of the Muslim demand, as also some former distinguished officers of India.
('19', 151, 1, 12, 316470) We have a right, therefore, to keep away from the Peace Celebrations.
('19', 151, 1, 13, 316540) So long as the future of Turkey is not known, peace has no meaning either for the Muslims or for the rest of us.
('19', 151, 1, 14, 316653) It would not be surprising if France refrained from joining the Peace Celebrations in case the matter of the Alsace Lorraine were not settled.
('19', 151, 1, 15, 316796) The Khilafat issue affects the Muslims in the same way.
('19', 151, 1, 16, 316852) I hope that the Viceroy will himself postpone the Peace Celebrations until after the problem of Turkey is settled.
('19', 151, 1, 17, 316967) “The Muslims took one more important decision also last night.
('19', 151, 1, 18, 317030) Should the conditions for peace go against them, which God forbid, they would no longer co operate with the Government.
('19', 151, 1, 19, 317150) In my opinion, subjects have this right.
('19', 151, 1, 20, 317191) No one is bound to accept titles or employment from the Government.
('19', 151, 1, 21, 317259) This is a matter of one’s own free choice.
('19', 151, 1, 22, 317302) It is clear that there can be no obligation to help anyone whose actions are not for our good.
('19', 151, 1, 23, 317397) We accept Government employ ment for the purpose of livelihood and, if we are alive to the good of society, then, in order to serve it.
('19', 151, 1, 24, 317533) If, on the contrary , there is a likelihood of our being harmed instead of benefited, we should certainly not serve [the Government].
('19', 151, 1, 25, 317667) How, then, can we assist a Government which harms us on an urgent, religious cause like the Khilafat?
('19', 151, 1, 26, 317769) If, therefore, the decision about the Khilafat goes against us, we have the right to refuse our co operation.
('19', 151, 1, 27, 317879) “But to proceed from non co operation to boycott is like abandoning a seat on an elephant to ride on a donkey.
('19', 151, 1, 28, 317990) To refuse co operation is our right and we can, by this method, bring about striking
('19', 152, 0, 1, 318075) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 153
('19', 152, 1, 2, 318123) results.
('19', 152, 1, 3, 318132) But we have no right to resort to boycott; and its result is bound to be undesirable.
('19', 152, 1, 4, 318218) We do not have this right because boycott implies an intention to punish the British people, and such an intention ought to be eschewed.
('19', 152, 1, 5, 318355) Our grievance is against the Government.
('19', 152, 1, 6, 318396) The results, too, will be unfortunate because a satisfactory solution to a problem like that of the Khilafat can be secured by winning world opinion over to our side.
('19', 152, 1, 7, 318563) By resorting to boycott it is very likely, on the contrary, that we may antagonize it.
('19', 152, 1, 8, 318650) Thus, boycott is as much objectionable as non co operation is advisable.
('19', 152, 1, 9, 318723) Moreover, the British have extra ordinary commercial skill and they can, by many devious means, ensure that their goods reach us.
('19', 152, 1, 10, 318853) They can do that by way of Japan.
('19', 152, 1, 11, 318887) Thus, the effect of boycott will be to invite the hold of other foreign powers on our country, rather than to keep out British goods.
('19', 152, 1, 12, 319021) “Boycott is a sign of anger; to refuse co operation, on the other hand, is a sign of firmness.
('19', 152, 1, 13, 319116) Boycott indicates our weakness; non co operation proves our strength.
('19', 152, 1, 14, 319186) The solution to a momentous issue like the Khilafat can be secured not by weakness but only through strength.
('19', 152, 1, 15, 319296) “I would therefore submit to the people that, if we want a happy solution to this problem, we should develop qualities such as patience, firmness, truth and fearlessness.
('19', 152, 1, 16, 319467) We have all come across examples of worthy causes being spoilt by the weakness, ignorance, foolishness or impatience of the workers.
('19', 152, 1, 17, 319600) It is not enough that we merely refrain from acts of violence.
('19', 152, 1, 18, 319663) We have known of murders committed by words.
('19', 152, 1, 19, 319708) Therefore, just as our hands and feet should be kept under control, so should our tongue be.
('19', 152, 1, 20, 319801) Our struggle has truth on its side.
('19', 152, 1, 21, 319837) I am, therefore, confident that, if we fight on in the faith that truth is ever victorious, we may still succeed in securing a happy solution to this problem.”
('19', 152, 2, 22, 319997) RESOLUTION PASSED BY MEETING
('19', 152, 3, 23, 320026) I could see that this speech had very good effect.
('19', 152, 3, 24, 320077) My fears that many objections would be raised at the meeting turned out to be mistaken and the resolution was passed without a single dissident comment.
('19', 152, 3, 25, 320230) In fact it was passed enthusiastically, all standing.
('19', 152, 3, 26, 320284) The resolution was to the effect that, as the Khilafat issue was a part of the peace settlement and was one which intimately affected one fourth of India’s population, viz., the Muslims, and, as such, the whole country, no Indian would be able to take part in the Peace Celebrations.

('19', 153, 1, 2, 320610) meeting, therefore, requested H.E. the Viceroy that he be pleased to postpone these celebrations until such time as the question of the Khilafat was satisfactorily settled.
('19', 153, 2, 3, 320783) 501 FOR ONE PICE Great enthusiasm was evident among the audience.
('19', 153, 2, 4, 320849) A committee has been appointed to instruct the public how to keep away from the Peace Celebrations.
('19', 153, 2, 5, 320949) I proposed that money be collected for the purpose and I was asked to contribute one pice.
('19', 153, 2, 6, 321040) I did not in fact possess even that.
('19', 153, 2, 7, 321077) It was given by Khwaja Sahib Hasan Nizami.
('19', 153, 2, 8, 321120) The coin was then auctioned by Brother Syed Hussain and Mia Chhotani bought it for Rs. 501. In ten minutes Rs. 2,000 were collected on the spot in cash and many others promised contributions.
('19', 153, 2, 9, 321312) Hakim Ajmal Khan, Swami Shraddhanand, Shri Krishnakant Malaviya, Shri Bomanji and others spoke on the resolutions.
('19', 153, 2, 10, 321427) All the speeches were restrained but forceful.
('19', 153, 3, 11, 321474) MAULANA ABDUL BARI Maulana Abdul Bari Sahib then stood up to thank the Chair.
('19', 153, 3, 12, 321552) He said:
('19', 153, 4, 13, 321561) Mahatma Gandhi may say what he pleases with regard to keeping the subject of cow protection out of the matter in hand.
('19', 153, 4, 14, 321680) It is to his credit and to that of our Hindu brethren.
('19', 153, 4, 15, 321735) Should the Muslims, however, forget the assistance rendered by their Hindu brethren, they will have forgotten their noble traditions.
('19', 153, 4, 16, 321869) I say that, whether they help us in the Khilafat issue or not, we and they are of one land and, therefore, it behoves us to stop the slaughter of cows.
('19', 153, 4, 17, 322021) As a Maulvi, I say that, in refraining from cow slaughter of our own free will, we in no way go against our faith.
('19', 153, 4, 18, 322136) Nothing else has created so real a spirit of brotherhood between us as the magnanimity shown by the Hindus on the Khilafat issue.
('19', 153, 4, 19, 322266) I pray that God may preserve for ever this friendship between the two communities.
('19', 153, 4, 20, 322349) The audience responded to this speech with cries of “Amen”.
('19', 153, 4, 21, 322409) After this, Bari Sahib spoke very feelingly about the Khilafat and made a deep impression.
('19', 153, 5, 22, 322500) HINDUS’ DUTY Thus, the Khilafat Conference came to an end.
('19', 153, 5, 23, 322559) But this does not mean that everything is now over.
('19', 153, 5, 24, 322611) On the contrary, the responsibility of each one of us has increased.

('19', 153, 5, 26, 322746) They can help a great deal in this matter and, by doing so they will succeed in drawing the Muslims

('19', 154, 1, 2, 322894) closer to them than by any other means.
('19', 154, 1, 3, 322934) To bring about unity between Hindus and Muslims will be no mean achievement.
('19', 154, 1, 4, 323011) That eight crores of people live in genuine amity with 22 crores of another community is a consummation greatly to be desired.
('19', 154, 1, 5, 323138) It is certain, too, that for either to live suppressed by the other will do no good.

('19', 154, 2, 12, 323812) VISIT TO KASUR When I went to Delhi, a wire had arrived from Kasur that the local Deputy Collector had severely belaboured a Muslim.
('19', 154, 2, 13, 323945) The reason was that a notice of the Khilafat Conference had been pasted on his wall.
('19', 154, 2, 14, 324030) The notice was entirely harmless and, in any case, had not been put up by the man himself.

('19', 154, 2, 17, 324278) I, therefore, returned from Delhi and proceeded to Kasur, accompanied by Dr. Parasram who is acquainted with that place.

('19', 154, 2, 21, 324612) He informed me that he had apologized to the Muslims and had also paid him Rs. 10. I replied that, as he had severely beaten an innocent man, it behoved him to make a public apology.
('19', 154, 2, 22, 324795) It was undesirable that people should be beaten up by British officers.
('19', 154, 2, 23, 324867) He thereupon gave me permission to make his apology public.
('19', 154, 2, 24, 324927) He had already ordered the notice to be put up again.

('19', 154, 2, 29, 325234) Kasur is 35 miles from Lahore and had a population of about 20,000. In April people had committed most reprehensible things there.

('19', 155, 2, 3, 325567) WAZIRABAD From there, I went to Wazirabad on the following day.
('19', 155, 2, 4, 325631) I had to investigate what had happened there during the Martial Law.
('19', 155, 2, 5, 325700) Wazirabad is a small town but it is a railway junction, through which, moreover, all main line trains pass.
('19', 155, 2, 6, 325808) The town is more than 50 miles from Lahore.

('19', 155, 3, 14, 326305) VISIT TO NIZAMABAD Nizamabad is scarcely three quarters of a mile from Wazirabad.
('19', 155, 3, 15, 326387) The people there are held responsible for the same crime as the people at Wazirabad.
('19', 155, 3, 16, 326472) Nizamabad may be said to be a village consisting of a narrow lane.
('19', 155, 3, 17, 326539) Its population is 2,000 and is mainly Muslim.
('19', 155, 3, 18, 326585) Most of them are blacksmiths.
('19', 155, 3, 19, 326615) The best knives in India are made here.
('19', 155, 3, 20, 326655) I had a look at the shops; almost all tools were old but the work had a finish and was of the best quantity.
('19', 155, 3, 21, 326764) Excellent wooden handles are also made here and the finest guns are manufactured by hand.
('19', 155, 3, 22, 326854) A double barrelled gun which I saw had elaborate carving too.

('19', 155, 3, 24, 326996) The price, he said, was Rs. 200. I felt proud of the skill of our craftsmen when I saw this workmanship and felt extremely grieved that we should have turned our back on swadeshi.
('19', 155, 3, 25, 327176) When we do not make full use of such skill, what can we expect but starvation?
('19', 155, 3, 26, 327255) The craftsmanship of Nizamabad ought to be known all over India, whereas even a man like me so much in love with swadeshi had not heard of this small village.
('19', 155, 4, 27, 327414) OUR FILTHINESS But the craftsmanship of Nizamabad was equalled by its filth.
('19', 155, 4, 28, 327491) It has only one lane.

('19', 156, 1, 6, 328064) If I clean my house and throw the refuse on to the street, or keep my urinal clean and dirty the street, it shows that I have no consideration for the feelings of my neighbour, no pity or love for him.
('19', 156, 1, 7, 328266) When this is so, how can I claim to be one with the people?

('19', 156, 4, 16, 329008) 123. DURGADAS ADWANI

('19', 156, 6, 23, 329496) In my humble opinion the judgment is unsound.
('19', 156, 6, 24, 329542) The Court has erred in holding that “New Call” was a seditious leaflet and it has strained the analysis of evidence to record a finding against Durgadas.
('19', 156, 6, 25, 329696) But in giving this opinion, I admit I may be biased in favour of Durgadas.
('19', 156, 6, 26, 329771) I do not believe him to be capable of telling an untruth in order to avoid imprisonment.

('19', 157, 1, 2, 330030) But as a friend and as a satyagrahi, I must decline to condole with Durgadas or his family upon his incarceration.
('19', 157, 1, 3, 330145) Durgadas has after great deliberation taken the Satyagraha Pledge.
('19', 157, 1, 4, 330212) And I seize the opportunity offered by this case of placing before the reader my views about such cases.
('19', 157, 1, 5, 330317) We spend too much money in litigation and in appeals.
('19', 157, 1, 6, 330371) We have an excessive dread of prisons.
('19', 157, 1, 7, 330410) I have not a shadow of doubt that society will be much cleaner and healthier if there was less resort to law courts than there is.
('19', 157, 1, 8, 330541) The rush after the best counsel is undignified.

('19', 157, 1, 10, 330650) But it is sinful when a satyagrahi spends money after the best legal talent or after appeals.

('19', 157, 1, 16, 331387) The best and quickest way to deliverance from the distrust and secret police department is to rid the country of false fear and all violence.

('19', 157, 1, 21, 332080) I understand that the“New Call” cases have cost nearly Rs. 15,000. The money could certainly have been utilised to better purpose.
('19', 157, 1, 22, 332211) It is not right to beggar ourselves by fighting against odds.
('19', 157, 1, 23, 332273) It is hardly manful to be over anxious about the result of political trials that involve no disgrace.
('19', 157, 1, 24, 332375) Here in the Punjab I find mothers with stricken hearts coming and shedding tears over the imprisonment of their sons whom they regard as innocent.

('19', 160, 9, 16, 335649) VISIT TO OTHER PLACES From Wazirabad, we proceeded to Akalgarh and then to Ramnagar.
('19', 160, 9, 17, 335734) The two places are close by; Ramnagar is about four miles from Akalgarh.
('19', 160, 9, 18, 335807) The population of the latter is not likely to be more than 4,000, it may even be less; that of Ramnagar may be 3,000. At one time, both were prosperous villages and as such enjoyed the favour of Ranjit Singh.
('19', 160, 9, 19, 336016) They are both so small that one can go round either in ten minutes.
('19', 160, 9, 20, 336084) In Akalgarh live the grand children of Mulraj, the well known Nizam Diwan of Multan.
('19', 160, 9, 21, 336169) Both the places have fallen on evil days now.
('19', 160, 9, 22, 336215) I was touched by the sight of Ramnagar.
('19', 160, 9, 23, 336255) There were, here, the beautiful mansion and the garden of a governor of Ranjit Singh’s.
('19', 160, 9, 24, 336343) Today they are inhabited only by birds.
('19', 160, 9, 25, 336383) The mansion is slowly crumbling away.
('19', 160, 9, 26, 336421) One storey has come down altogether and
('19', 160, 10, 27, 336461) 1 The year and month are from the postmark, and Magsar Sud 14 corresponded to December 6 in 1919.
('19', 161, 0, 1, 336559) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 161, 1, 2, 336601) the remainder is gradually decaying.
('19', 161, 1, 3, 336638) The garden looks like a waste land.
('19', 161, 1, 4, 336674) One sees other ruined building too.
('19', 161, 1, 5, 336710) At one time Ramnagar had a flourishing trade in leather bottles for carrying ghee.
('19', 161, 1, 6, 336793) One entire street was inhabited by people who made these.
('19', 161, 1, 7, 336851) That street is now desolate.
('19', 161, 1, 8, 336880) There is only one worker living there now.
('19', 161, 1, 9, 336923) Tin cans have taken the place of leather bottles and, in consequence, India loses that amount of money to foreign countries.
('19', 161, 1, 10, 337048) Similarly, formerly there were many weavers in Ramnagar.
('19', 161, 1, 11, 337105) This class has not yet been completely wiped out.
('19', 161, 1, 12, 337155) A few looms are still working, but their business is declining day by day.
('19', 161, 1, 13, 337230) At one time Ramnagar produced all the cloth it needed, and some more for others.
('19', 161, 1, 14, 337311) The people of this same Ramnagar now get their cloth from abroad.
('19', 161, 1, 15, 337377) To be sure, it is not that Akalgarh, Ramnagar and similar other towns do not have enough workers with courage and a spirit of service in them.
('19', 161, 1, 16, 337520) Only, everyone labours under the delusion that, as a matter of course, cloth must be imported and that ghee must be stored in tin cans.
('19', 161, 1, 17, 337656) To be in the fashion, one should engage oneself in some kind of political activity, or work to provide relief in times of epidemics such as the plague and, if possible, collect money and start a school, forgetting all about it afterwards.
('19', 161, 1, 18, 337895) Consequently, these are the things on which workers waste their time.
('19', 161, 1, 19, 337965) Of course, they are not satisfied with these things and so, when I speak of truth, fearlessness, swadeshi and national education to them, those to whom these things appeal listen to me attentively and do not like to leave my side.
('19', 161, 1, 20, 338196) If I am ready to give darshan all day, they would willingly sit by me all the time.
('19', 161, 1, 21, 338280) That is the state of both men and women.
('19', 161, 1, 22, 338321) At Akalgarh and Ramnagar, both men and women were beside themselves with love.
('19', 161, 1, 23, 338400) They showered flowers on me.
('19', 161, 1, 24, 338429) At both places, besides collecting evidence, I spoke at great length on swadeshi and other matters.
('19', 161, 2, 25, 338529) GARLANDS OF YARN I am distressed with these masses of flowers and the useless expenditure incurred on them.
('19', 161, 2, 26, 338637) I have, therefore, started asking for garlands of hand spun yarn and I have been getting them.
('19', 161, 2, 27, 338732) In Akalgarh, they piled up by my side heaps of yarn spun by ladies of good family, and of cloth woven from such yarn, which included beautiful khadi sheets and towels.
('19', 162, 0, 1, 338900) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 163
('19', 162, 1, 2, 338948) THESE INNOCENT VILLAGES I got the impression that the people of Akalgarh and Ramnagar were entirely innocent.
('19', 162, 1, 3, 339058) The best among them have been arrested and put to harassment.
('19', 162, 1, 4, 339120) They have been imprisoned, insulted, abused and fined.
('19', 162, 1, 5, 339175) We in Bombay Presidency cannot even imagine some of the things which I saw here.
('19', 162, 1, 6, 339256) HAFIZABAD I do not, however, want to keep the reader too long over the tale of suffering of the Punjab people.
('19', 162, 1, 7, 339367) Having forged a bond of love with these two villages, we moved on to Hafizabad.
('19', 162, 1, 8, 339447) This is, comparatively, a larger village.

('19', 167, 5, 12, 350317) 130. SWARAJ IN SWADESHI
('19', 167, 6, 13, 350341) The much talked of Reforms Bill 1 will become the law of the land within a few days and in due course the new legislatures will take the place of the old.
('19', 167, 6, 14, 350496) H.E. the Viceroy has announced that he is going loyally to abide by the new scheme and that he will try to make it a success.

('19', 167, 6, 17, 350849) So far, therefore, as the Reform Scheme is concerned, I would simply urge that we should take the fullest advantage of it and, like the Viceroy, loyally work to make it a success.
('19', 167, 6, 18, 351029) That it is an improvement upon the original measure is admitted by all.
('19', 167, 6, 19, 351101) But the real reform that India needs is swadeshi in its true sense.
('19', 167, 6, 20, 351169) The immediate problem before us is not how to run the government of the country, but how to feed and clothe ourselves.
('19', 167, 6, 21, 351288) In 1918 we sent sixty crores of rupees out of India for buying cloth.
('19', 167, 6, 22, 351358) If we continue to purchase foreign cloth at that rate, we deprive the Indian weaver and spinner of that amount from year to year without practically giving

('19', 168, 1, 2, 351669) him or her any other work in exchange.

('19', 168, 1, 4, 351816) He who has eyes may see for himself that the middle class people are already being underfed and our babies are not getting enough milk for themselves.

('19', 168, 1, 8, 352160) God be thanked that the beautiful women of the Punjab have not yet lost the cunning of their fingers.

('19', 168, 1, 20, 353085) The women who have ceased to spin are not utilising their time in any other or better manner than gossiping.
('19', 168, 1, 21, 353194) But one thing is needful to undo the mischief.

('19', 172, 4, 7, 360193) 133. LETTER TO REGISTRAR, HIGH COURT, BOMBAY 1
('19', 172, 5, 8, 360240) [DELHI] December 11, 1919 With reference to your letter regarding the publication of the letter of the District Judge, Ahmedabad, in the matter of the satyagrahi lawyers, I beg to state that I have now consulted legal friends and given much anxious consideration to the suggestion made by His Lordship the Chief Justice.
('19', 172, 5, 9, 360561) But I regret to state that I find myself unable to publish the suggested apology.
('19', 172, 5, 10, 360643) The document in question came into my possession in the ordinary course and being of great public importance I decided to publish and comment upon it.
('19', 172, 5, 11, 360794) In doing so I performed in my humble opinion a useful public duty at a time when there was great tension and when even the judiciary was being affected by the popular prejudice.
('19', 172, 5, 12, 360972) I need hardly say that I had no desire whatsoever to prejudge the issues that their Lordships had to decide.
('19', 172, 5, 13, 361081) I am anxious to assure His Lordship the Chief Justice that at the time I decided to publish the document in question, I had fully in mind the honour of journalism as also the fact that I was a member of the Bombay Bar and as such expected to be aware of the tradition thereof.
('19', 172, 5, 14, 361358) But thinking of my action in the light of what has happened I am unable to say that in similar circumstances I would act differently from what I did when I decided to publish and comment upon Mr. Kennedy’s letter.
('19', 172, 5, 15, 361572) Much, therefore, as I would like to act upon His Lordship’s suggestion, I feel that I could not conscientiously offer any apology for my action.
('19', 172, 5, 16, 361717) Should this explanation be not considered sufficient by His Lordship, I shall respectfully suffer the penalty that their Lordships may be pleased to impose upon me.
('19', 172, 6, 17, 361882) 1 This was published also in Young India, 10 3 1920.

('19', 173, 3, 5, 362243) 134. REFORMS
('19', 173, 4, 6, 362256) By the time this article appears in print, the Reforms Bill will have become or will be about to become law.
('19', 173, 4, 7, 362365) What shall we do with these reforms?
('19', 173, 4, 8, 362402) The answer to this question depends on the kind of reforms they are.
('19', 173, 4, 9, 362471) If we measure them with the yardstick of the Congress League Scheme 2, we ought to reject them; if we accept the resolutions passes at the last Congress, we shall find an ocean of difference between them and the reforms.
('19', 173, 4, 10, 362692) What do we mean by “rejecting” the reforms?
('19', 173, 4, 11, 362736) “Rejecting” them means refusing to work them.
('19', 173, 4, 12, 362782) Not working them means abstaining from voting, from enlisting ourselves as voters or standing for election as members.
('19', 173, 4, 13, 362901) No one is ready for such rejection, nor have we made any efforts towards that end.
('19', 173, 4, 14, 362984) The deputations 3 which went to England gave no indications to that effect.
('19', 173, 4, 15, 363060) It must also be admitted that the nation is not yet ready for such rejection; it has not had the required political education.
('19', 173, 4, 16, 363187) Whenever something is disapproved by us so utterly that its acceptance will kill the soul, then we are entitled, we owe it as a duty, to reject that thing; the idea that it is only by such rejection that we can raise ourselves in the shortest possible time has not yet taken root in us.
('19', 173, 5, 17, 363474) 1 Before however this letter reached the Registrar, he had, on the same day, “ suo moto applied for a rule nisi calling upon Messrs Gandhi and Desai to show cause why they should not be committed or otherwise dealt with according to law for contempt of court in respect of the publication of the said letter”.
('19', 173, 5, 18, 363784) The application was granted by Justices Shah and Crump on that day, but the rule itself was not actually issued till December 19. 2 Vide “The Congress League Scheme”.
('19', 173, 5, 19, 363951) 3 The reference is to the several deputations which visited Britain to represent the reactions of different schools of political thought to the Government of India Bill, which was introduced in the House of Commons in July, 1919. These were: the Congress deputation, among whose members were Vithalbhai Patel, Lokamanya Tilak, B.C. Pal and V.P. Madhava Rao, the Moderate deputation, the Justice Party deputation and two Home Rule deputations representing the division of opinion in the All India Home Rule League.
('19', 174, 0, 1, 364465) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 175
('19', 174, 1, 2, 364513) According to the canon ‘the doubter goes to destruction,’ 1 we shall not be ready for great sacrifices so long as we doubt this idea.
('19', 174, 1, 3, 364647) We are able to experiment thus only in small matters.
('19', 174, 1, 4, 364701) By “small” we mean such matters as those in which sacrifice brings immediate result and involves no risk of serious danger.
('19', 174, 1, 5, 364825) If we reject the reforms, it seems more likely that we shall get no immediate benefit.
('19', 174, 1, 6, 364912) Hence, it will not be advisable for us to reject them.
('19', 174, 1, 7, 364967) We may certainly criticize the reforms, but the criticism should be moderate and intended only as an expression of our disappoint ment.
('19', 174, 1, 8, 365103) We can and must say that we will struggle for more.
('19', 174, 1, 9, 365155) But the more important thing is to find out how we can make the best use of these reforms and use them so.
('19', 174, 1, 10, 365262) We must acknowledge here that the Bill introduced in the House of Commons has been amended and important rights have been conceded to us.
('19', 174, 1, 11, 365400) At one time we had very little hope of securing them.
('19', 174, 1, 12, 365454) It even used to be said that the Reforms Bill would not be passed at all at present.
('19', 174, 1, 13, 365539) Instead, the Bill will now pass with some welcome amendments.
('19', 174, 1, 14, 365601) We may derive what comfort we can from these things.
('19', 174, 1, 15, 365654) There is no doubt that the real credit for these improvements goes to Mr. Montagu.
('19', 174, 1, 16, 365737) That the Reforms Bill will pass in no more than a few days now should also be credited to Mr. Montagu’s account.
('19', 174, 1, 17, 365850) After studying the reforms, the nation should try to send honest and competent representatives to the legislatures.To the extent that the representatives care little for honour, for position and consequential material benefits, to the extent that the service of the people is their chief aim, the reforms will be better used and we shall be qualified the sooner for full responsibility and succeed in securing it.
('19', 174, 1, 18, 366264) What about the Rowlatt Act?
('19', 174, 1, 19, 366292) What about the Punjab?
('19', 174, 1, 20, 366315) We had the best remedy for these, if we could have rejected the reforms.
('19', 174, 1, 21, 366388) Now the only course for us is to make good use of the new councils for securing justice in both these matters.
('19', 174, 1, 22, 366499) The Rowlatt Act ought to be repealed and agitation to that end can be carried on in the Legislative Assembly.
('19', 174, 1, 23, 366609) If we fail, our weapon is ever ready with us.
('19', 174, 1, 24, 366655) The same about the Punjab.
('19', 174, 1, 25, 366682) It has yet to get justice and the place where we can secure this, too, is the Legislative Assembly.
('19', 174, 1, 26, 366782) In both these matters, the new representatives and the reforms will be on their trial.

('19', 176, 1, 2, 368002) 136. LETTER TO EDMUND CANDLER
('19', 176, 2, 3, 368032) 2, MOZANG ROAD, LAHORE, December 15, 1919
('19', 176, 3, 4, 368074) DEAR MR. CANDLER,
('19', 176, 4, 5, 368092) I thank you for your letter 1 of the 12th instant.
('19', 176, 4, 6, 368143) I appreciate the friendliness underlying it and I entirely accept your assurance that no offence whatsoever was intended by you.
('19', 176, 4, 7, 368272) My attention was drawn to the article in question and I did consider that it was unwisely worded.
('19', 176, 4, 8, 368370) I felt too that both Hindus and Mahomedans were likely to be offended by the manner in which I was caricatured.
('19', 176, 4, 9, 368482) But your letter must silence all hostile criticism.
('19', 176, 4, 10, 368534) Modern journalism certainly permits attacks on the supposed weak points of those whose policy is criticised and I grant that you intended to do no more.
('19', 176, 4, 11, 368687) I thank you too for putting me the questions you have.
('19', 176, 4, 12, 368742) They enable me to explain my position more fully than perhaps it has been by my writings and speeches.
('19', 176, 4, 13, 368845) As to your first question I do not wish and have never wished to embarrass Government and I have never worked up an anti British campaign for any cause whatsoever.
('19', 176, 4, 14, 369009) My personal religion would forbid me to do either the one or the other.
('19', 176, 4, 15, 369081) But sometimes one’s right conduct does embarrass those who do not for the moment appreciate it and in that sense I admit that my conduct like that of any reformer has embarrassed people.
('19', 176, 4, 16, 369268) But I cannot be accused of partiality.
('19', 176, 4, 17, 369307) Relentless pursuits of truth and conduct flowing from it have embarrassed the dearest ones not excluding my wife and children.
('19', 176, 4, 18, 369434) But I was no more anti the dear ones than I am anti British.
('19', 176, 4, 19, 369495) I have the privilege of the friendship or the goodwill of hundreds of Englishmen and Englishwomen.
('19', 176, 4, 20, 369594) I would be unworthy of their friendship or goodwill if I harboured anti British feelings.
('19', 176, 4, 21, 369684) My stubborn opposition to some acts of the British Government must not be mistaken for unfriendliness.
('19', 176, 4, 22, 369787) Such peculiar notions are entertained about friendliness and loyalty in India that any strong expression of displeasure in regard to acts of Government passes for disloyalty.
('19', 176, 5, 23, 369962) 1 Vide “Swaraj in Swadeshi”, 10 12 1919.
('19', 177, 0, 1, 370003) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 177, 1, 2, 370045) will agree with me that real loyalty that dares to utter unpalatable truths must in such an atmosphere be a rare virtue.
('19', 177, 1, 3, 370166) As to your second question, I confess that my regard for the claims of the Turk is derived totally from my regard for my fellow countrymen, the Mahomedans.
('19', 177, 1, 4, 370322) I should forfeit the right to call them fellow countrymen if I did not feel for them in everything vitally affecting them provided that their cause was just.
('19', 177, 1, 5, 370480) The peace of my country is likely to be placed in jeopardy, not by my earnest effort to guide the Mahomedan feeling in the right channel, but it certainly will be by any thoughtless or ignorant action of British Ministers.
('19', 177, 1, 6, 370703) I venture to claim that I have rendered a service of the highest order by advising the Mahomedans of India to express their sentiments in a restrained manner and by advising the Hindus to make common cause with them.
('19', 177, 1, 7, 370920) You are right, however, in questioning the wisdom of going against the opinions of men like Gladstone, Morley and Bryce, for whom I certainly entertain high regard, but the necessity for the question really arises from your not knowing the Mahomedan claim for Turkey.
('19', 177, 1, 8, 371188) I invite you to study their view point.
('19', 177, 1, 9, 371228) They ask for nothing that has not been granted to the other Powers or that was not vouchsafed to them by the British Ministers themselves.
('19', 177, 1, 10, 371367) Their claims, as you may be aware, has been backed by the majority of the ex Governors and other distinguished Anglo Indians.
('19', 177, 1, 11, 371493) What has the treatment or ill treatment by Turks of subject races to do with the Khilafat question, i.e., the integrity of Turkey or the Turk’s custody of the holy places of Islam?
('19', 177, 1, 12, 371674) Must Constantinople be wrenched from the Turks in order to safeguard the rights of subject races?
('19', 177, 1, 13, 371772) If you as a journalist and an Englishman would preserve the peace of India and would have India to celebrate peace in a true manner, you would ask Englishmen living in India to make common cause with the Mahomedans and thus let the British Ministers know the real feeling of India so that justice might be done whilst there is yet time.
('19', 177, 1, 14, 372109) As you have permitted me to publish your letter, I am sending it and my reply to the Press.
('19', 177, 2, 15, 372201) Yours sincerely,
('19', 177, 3, 16, 372218) M. K. GANDHI The Tribune, 18 12 1919

('19', 179, 0, 1, 374129) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 179, 1, 2, 374171) From Sheikhupura we went to Chuharkana.
('19', 179, 1, 3, 374211) This village is some distance from the station.
('19', 179, 1, 4, 374259) Our work was in the Chuharkana mandi.
('19', 179, 1, 5, 374297) Here the market is called mandi.
('19', 179, 1, 6, 374330) But there is a difference between the bazaar of Gujarat and the mandi of the Punjab.
('19', 179, 1, 7, 374415) Here the mandi means a large square surrounded by houses.
('19', 179, 1, 8, 374473) All kinds of goods are brought to the square and the shops are situated round it.
('19', 179, 1, 9, 374555) The mandi in Chuharkana is comparatively large and goods worth thousands lie there.
('19', 179, 1, 10, 374639) Some big canals start from near Chuharkana and, as a result, there is a large yield of cotton and other crops.
('19', 179, 1, 11, 374750) We noticed that the people had set the station on fire and had done other damage also.
('19', 179, 1, 12, 374837) As usual, a large meeting was arranged near the mandi.
('19', 179, 1, 13, 374892) Crowds had collected at the Chuharkana station and we have to walk with them to the place where we were to stay.
('19', 179, 1, 14, 375005) But the crowd surged towards me with such force that we could scarcely proceed.
('19', 179, 1, 15, 375085) The people around me tried their best to protect me but my bare feet were crushed all the same.
('19', 179, 1, 16, 375181) Every person coveted darshan.
('19', 179, 1, 17, 375211) There is always much dust near a village and not a little of it went into our mouths, noses and ears.
('19', 179, 1, 18, 375313) The noise was no less.
('19', 179, 1, 19, 375336) At the meeting, therefore, I spoke to the people at great length about the need for discipline.
('19', 179, 1, 20, 375432) I said that it was certainly to be welcomed that people feel respect for those whom they look upon as great, but that, unless this feeling of respect expressed itself in the right manner it was bound to harm the country.
('19', 179, 1, 21, 375653) There is greater inconvenience, moreover, where proper arrangements have not been made and people trained in advance.
('19', 179, 1, 22, 375771) It is easy to ensure, with a little training, that people make way for others and walk behind and at some distance from the person whom they wish to honour, make no unnecessary noise and follow the directions of a leader.
('19', 179, 1, 23, 375993) DISORDER AT MEETING
('19', 179, 2, 24, 376013) When the meeting commenced, the uproar was beyond description.
('19', 179, 2, 25, 376076) Everyone was shouting.
('19', 179, 2, 26, 376099) This state of affairs became intolerable to me.
('19', 179, 2, 27, 376147) I immediately made a polite appeal to the people, telling them that, if they did not become quiet and sit down, they would prevent themselves from hearing the very words for which all this noise was being made.
('19', 179, 2, 28, 376358) The people then sat down and became perfectly quiet.
('19', 179, 2, 29, 376411) I pointed out the mistakes they had, out of their love, made when we were near the station.
('19', 179, 2, 30, 376503) When the meeting ended, the crowd dispersed quietly and did not press round me.
('19', 179, 2, 31, 376583) There is no lack of understanding or power of thinking among the people, they only need someone to guide them.
('19', 179, 2, 32, 376694) I explained to them in this meeting that
('19', 180, 0, 1, 376735) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 181
('19', 180, 1, 2, 376783) the mistakes they had committed in attempting to set fire to buildings were also the result of lack of training.
('19', 180, 1, 3, 376896) Many had had no intention of setting fire to buildings but, when one person started doing so, another followed suit.
('19', 180, 1, 4, 377013) If the people had been trained to think before doing anything and to follow a responsible leader, such incidents would not have occurred.
('19', 180, 2, 5, 377151) A SCENE IN DELHI On December 11, I had occasion to pay a flying visit to Delhi.
('19', 180, 2, 6, 377231) I was to go there for work in connection with South Africa, but I accepted an invitation to preside over a function of the Seva Mandal established by Shri Ram, a well known barrister there.
('19', 180, 2, 7, 377421) It became known that I was to preside.
('19', 180, 2, 8, 377460) Consequently, uninvited guests flocked in their thousands and pushed their way in through the entrance.
('19', 180, 2, 9, 377564) They could not tolerate the idea that only ticket holders should be allowed entry on such an occasion.
('19', 180, 2, 10, 377667) All were embarrassed.
('19', 180, 2, 11, 377689) So was I. How unseemly that these people who had come to see and honour me should not have been able to behave with greater restraint!
('19', 180, 3, 12, 377824) LEADERS AND PUBLIC But this was not due to discourtesy.
('19', 180, 3, 13, 377880) Are we taught anywhere that our habit of rushing towards a person whose darshan we seek is improper?
('19', 180, 3, 14, 377981) Not in places of pilgrimage.
('19', 180, 3, 15, 378010) Whether in temples or in havelis 1, “first come first served” and “might is right” are the laws that prevail.
('19', 180, 3, 16, 378120) The educated or highly placed either avoid such places or, if they visit them at all, make special arrangements for themselves.
('19', 180, 3, 17, 378248) The evils remain as they are.
('19', 180, 3, 18, 378278) The Seva Mandal gave assistance during the plague, arranged for cremation of dead bodies and provided medicines.
('19', 180, 3, 19, 378391) All this is certainly necessary.
('19', 180, 3, 20, 378424) If even this had not been made available all over the country, we would have been wiped out long ago.
('19', 180, 3, 21, 378526) But this is not enough.
('19', 180, 3, 22, 378550) It is very limited service.
('19', 180, 3, 23, 378578) Prizes and certificates were to be distributed at the Seva Mandal meeting.
('19', 180, 3, 24, 378653) These were all in English!
('19', 180, 3, 25, 378680) The reason for the rush then became clear to me.
('19', 180, 3, 26, 378729) There is no close touch between the leaders and the people.
('19', 180, 3, 27, 378789) We do not realize the need to provide the people the most necessary training, nor have we secured the means for it.
('19', 180, 3, 28, 378905) Those who had forced their way in did not know English.
('19', 180, 3, 29, 378961) We gave medicine but, when the patients were cured, we did not know how to teach them to play their part in a democracy.
('19', 180, 3, 30, 379082) We think that for this they must first learn English

('19', 181, 1, 2, 379197) because we think we ourselves have got the training through English.
('19', 181, 1, 3, 379266) And so the common people rushed in today, as is their wont.
('19', 181, 1, 4, 379326) I placed these facts before the meeting.
('19', 181, 1, 5, 379367) The audience understood my meaning and was ashamed.

('19', 181, 2, 10, 379681) LYALLPUR I shall now revert to Chuharkana.
('19', 181, 2, 11, 379724) From there we went to Lyallpur.
('19', 181, 2, 12, 379756) This is a separate district and is one of the five where Martial Law had been proclaimed.
('19', 181, 2, 13, 379846) The district takes its name from Lyallpur, which is quite a new town named after Sir Charles Lyall 1. The town came into being in 1896. There is a clock tower at the centre of the city, set in a large circle from which eight roads fan out.
('19', 181, 2, 14, 380086) Houses and shops have been built along them.
('19', 181, 2, 15, 380131) We can see that all these have been newly built.
('19', 181, 2, 16, 380180) This is the place known as the main canal colony.
('19', 181, 2, 17, 380230) The finest wheat and cotton crops grow in this canal area and the people are fairly prosperous.
('19', 181, 2, 18, 380326) Lyallpur has a population of about 30,000. During the Martial Law, hell had been let loose here.
('19', 181, 2, 19, 380423) The people had done no harm whatsoever, yet many prominent persons were arrested and unnecessarily harassed.
('19', 181, 2, 20, 380532) Here also there was a huge meeting.
('19', 181, 2, 21, 380568) There was a separate meeting for women and, although the men’s meeting was held far from the town, women were present in large numbers.
('19', 181, 2, 22, 380704) The arrangements at Lyallpur were comparatively good.
('19', 181, 2, 23, 380758) Wherever the people have received even a little training, the effects are immediately apparent.
('19', 181, 2, 24, 380854) I have been informed that the spinning programme can succeed very well in the Lyallpur area.
('19', 181, 3, 25, 380947) SPINNING WHEEL WITH TEN SPINDLES A craftsman from Ludhiana has left a ten spindled spinning wheel with me.
('19', 181, 3, 26, 381054) The design is quite good, simple and cheap.
('19', 181, 3, 27, 381098) But he could not spin on all the spindles simultaneously.
('19', 181, 3, 28, 381156) He was intelligent but had not been able to make progress for want of experience.
('19', 181, 3, 29, 381238) When the thing was explained to him, he followed it all right, and he has promised to try again.
('19', 181, 3, 30, 381335) Having seen this spinning wheel, I have a hope that we may see a ten spindled spinning wheel in India.
('19', 181, 3, 31, 381438) Someone
('19', 181, 4, 32, 381446) 1 Sir Charles James Lyall (1845 1920); English orientalist; served in Bengal Civil Service, Chief Commissioner of Central Provinces, 1895 98; Secretary, Judicial and Public Department, India Office, 1898 1910

('19', 182, 1, 3, 381774) I hope that craftsmen familiar with this work will make efforts and produce, within the time limit, a spinning wheel which will win the prize.

('19', 182, 2, 5, 381984) Still the Gujarat district remains.

('19', 182, 2, 7, 382081) After giving a week to this, I hope to tour the Gujarat district.

('19', 183, 1, 2, 383441) 139. INDIAN SITUATION IN EAST AFRICA 1
('19', 183, 2, 3, 383480) LAHORE, December 16, 1919
('19', 183, 3, 4, 383506) Mr. Gandhi, in explaining the position, states that: The anti Indian agitation in East Africa is utterly unscrupulous and lacks even the plausibility that attached to the kindred agitation in South Africa, for the European colonist in South Africa claims South Africa as his home and further claims that he is the pioneer settler, whereas in East Africa the European can advance no such claims.
('19', 183, 3, 5, 383901) He is there purely and simply for exploitation.
('19', 183, 3, 6, 383949) It is the Indian who was the pioneer settler in East Africa long before a single European set foot on the East African soil.
('19', 183, 3, 7, 384074) Before the uplands of East Africa were developed through Indian labour, European greed had found no scope for itself; but now that Nairobi affords a beautiful climate and an unlimited opportunity for game, the European has become impatient of the Indian merchant and landed proprietor.
('19', 183, 3, 8, 384360) It is impossible to tolerate any diminution in our right in East Africa to settle there and to exercise even political influence.
('19', 183, 3, 9, 384490) It is to be hoped that the Government of India and the Imperial Government will jealously guard the rights of Indians in East Africa and that the public bodies throughout India will speak with no uncertain voice upon the question.
('19', 183, 3, 10, 384721) The Bombay Chronicle, 17 12 1919
('19', 183, 4, 11, 384754) 1 This was Gandhiji’s explanatory note with reference to the following message received from C.F. Andrews, from Nairobi: “The East African Indian situation is most critically dangerous because a united attempt is being made by European Associations to close the door against future immigration and to stop Indian franchise.
('19', 183, 4, 12, 385078) The chief reason is stated to be that through the Indian contact depravity is the result, but advance under Christian Western civilization.
('19', 183, 4, 13, 385218) The Government Economic Commission report recently published takes the same attitude mentioning specifically the Indian moral depravity and approving the South African exclusion policy.
('19', 183, 4, 14, 385404) Intense indignation was expressed here by the local Indian Congress gathering which was remarkable for its weight and numbers.
('19', 183, 4, 15, 385531) I have decided, on urgent request, to stay till January here.
('19', 183, 4, 16, 385593) The Congress Committee decided on my suggestion to abandon the claim for preferential treatment in German East Africa while demanding complete continuance of all existing rights.
('19', 183, 4, 17, 385772) Circulate and explain the situation.” The statement appears to have been released generally to the Press as an Associated Press message and was published in several newspapers.
('19', 183, 4, 18, 385949) The text of the cable quoted here has verbal variations from that quoted by Gandhiji in the following item.

('19', 184, 5, 15, 386823) 141. INDIANS ABROAD
('19', 184, 6, 16, 386843) South Africa, East Africa and Fiji present to day problems for solution and test our capacity for nationalism.
('19', 184, 6, 17, 386954) Not until we feel for the meanest of our countrymen as each one of us feels for himself, can we be said to have a consciousness of our nationality.
('19', 184, 6, 18, 387102) Those of our countrymen who have settled in the different parts of the world look to us for guidance, help and protection.
('19', 184, 7, 19, 387225) And just as the spirit of nationality is being tested, so is that of imperialism.
('19', 184, 7, 20, 387307) If imperialism means anything, it must mean and include the capacity for protecting all interests that belong to it.
('19', 184, 7, 21, 387424) According to that test, Indians who have settled abroad claim double protection, viz., from us and from the Imperial Government.
('19', 184, 7, 22, 387553) And yet, both seem so far to have mainly failed in the discharge of their trust.
('19', 184, 7, 23, 387634) For though we may gain before the end of the year a final declaration that the Fiji indentures are over once and for all, it reflects no credit either on the Imperial power or on us that the corrupt and immoral system could persist for so many years.
('19', 184, 7, 24, 387885) And if we gain the

('19', 185, 14, 27, 389698) The cablegram shows the unscrupulousness of the agitation against the Indians.
('19', 185, 14, 28, 389777) Those who prate about the Christian civilization are strangers to the Christian teaching and know nothing of the manner in which the Indian settler has raised the native of Africa.
('19', 185, 14, 29, 389958) They ignore the teaching of history that the Indian settler penetrated East Africa when there was no European there and affected for the better manners and customs of the people.
('19', 185, 14, 30, 390137) The Indians who went to South Africa did not force their customs upon the Africans nor did they take the brandy bottle in the one hand and the gun in the other, for they did not go to East Africa with the intention of “civilizing” the barbarians.
('19', 185, 14, 31, 390384) They frankly went there to trade among the natives of the soil with their permission and left traces of their civilization among them in the same manner as any two sets of people are bound silently to be affected by each other’s conduct.
('19', 185, 14, 32, 390622) It is a simple misrepres entation of known facts to say that the presence of Indians in the
('19', 186, 0, 1, 390714) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 187
('19', 186, 1, 2, 390762) midst of East Africans has been in any shape or form detrimental to the latter.
('19', 186, 1, 3, 390842) What are we to do in the teeth of this unscrupulous agitation?
('19', 186, 1, 4, 390905) In East Africa the European has not even the plausible argument, that he has in South Africa, of being the pioneer settler, for the Indian is the pioneer.
('19', 186, 1, 5, 391060) The development of East Africa is due to Indian labour which worked in the midst of grave danger to health.
('19', 186, 1, 6, 391168) If the Imperial Government surrenders an iota of the rights of Indians to the interested agitation of the European rivals, it would be a betrayal of trust.
('19', 186, 1, 7, 391324) Mr. Andrews mentions the claim of domiciled Indians to preferential treatment.
('19', 186, 1, 8, 391403) They have wisely give it up; not that they are not entitled to it in accordance with the standard of their detractors, but they give it up in order to smooth the situation an in order to keep themselves absolutely in the right.
('19', 186, 1, 9, 391631) Here then is another problem for us and the Imperial Government, if we are to justify our respective claims.
('19', 186, 1, 10, 391740) Then there remains South Africa, which is really the most difficult of all.
('19', 186, 1, 11, 391816) We reproduce in this issue the text of General Smuts’ not unsympathetic reply 1 to the Indian Deputation that waited on him.
('19', 186, 1, 12, 391941) Never has a community been engaged in an unequal fight such as our countrymen are in South Africa.
('19', 186, 1, 13, 392040) Compared to their rivals they are poor.
('19', 186, 1, 14, 392080) They have no political power and they have been engaged ever since 1880 in protecting the right to exist with self respect a right which any civilized Government would not deny even to utter strangers.
('19', 186, 1, 15, 392282) It speaks volumes for their courage and resourcefulness that they have been able to hold their own in the manner they have.

('19', 191, 1, 2, 399664) 147. SPEECH AT AMRITSAR CONGRESS 1
('19', 191, 2, 3, 399699) December 29, 1919
('19', 191, 3, 4, 399717) Mahatma Gandhi rose 2 amid tremendous cheering and in proposing the second resolution said the resolution 3 entrusted to him was a very important one.
('19', 191, 3, 5, 399868) All the Indians were agreed that India was entitled to responsible Government.
('19', 191, 3, 6, 399947) If that was so, they must render help to their brothers and sisters who were at that time suffering in South Africa.
('19', 191, 3, 7, 400064) The atrocities to which their brethren in the Punjab had been subjected this year were heart rending, and there was not a man in India who did not sympathise with them in their troubles.
('19', 191, 3, 8, 400251) But the conditions in South and East Africa were still worse and demanded their immediate attention.
('19', 191, 3, 9, 400352) Mahatma Gandhi traced the introduction of the indentured system to the request of the whitemen of Natal in South Africa to the Indian Government for Indian labour.
('19', 191, 3, 10, 400516) That system, he was bound to say, was enormously worse than life in the Indian jails.
('19', 191, 3, 11, 400602) Sir William Hunter had called it a system of slavery.
('19', 191, 3, 12, 400656) Under this system their brethren had gone to South Africa.
('19', 191, 3, 13, 400715) 4 The success of Indians in trade had given rise to those tyrannies under which they were now suffering.
('19', 191, 3, 14, 400820) Their trade was crushed.
('19', 191, 3, 15, 400845) It was ruled that indentured labourers could not enter into trade but must live under indenture.
('19', 191, 3, 16, 400942) It was said that Indians were of dirty habits, and being of a different civilization from the whitemen’s, the latter could not live with them.
('19', 191, 3, 17, 401085) False charges were laid against them and it was tried to send them back to India.
('19', 191, 3, 18, 401167) South Africa was the place where the Indians had fought in order to keep up the honour of their country and twenty thousand 5 men had to go to jail for it.
('19', 191, 3, 19, 401323) The result was that they were allowed to remain there.
('19', 191, 3, 20, 401378) In 1914 several privileges were granted to the Indians.
('19', 191, 3, 21, 401434) Similar was the case of the Transvaal.
('19', 191, 3, 22, 401473) The Indians there wanted proprietary rights and rights of trade, but these were denied to them.
('19', 191, 3, 23, 401569) They wanted the Indian Government to secure those rights for them and to use means to maintain the honour of India.
('19', 191, 3, 24, 401685) The second part of the resolution related to East Africa.
('19', 191, 3, 25, 401743) There the people had not gone under indenture, but for purposes of trade.
('19', 191, 3, 26, 401817) Several Mohammedan brethren had gone to Zanzibar and had succeeded so well in trade that even the

('19', 192, 1, 2, 402551) Africans had come under their influence.

('19', 192, 1, 4, 402726) After a time the whitemen too plucked courage to go to those places.

('19', 192, 1, 8, 403096) Mahatma Gandhi proceeded to say that they asked the Indian Government, who was a trustee for India, and the Indian National Congress, which was a representative body, to interfere 1 in the matter and to save their suffering Indian brethren in Africa.
('19', 192, 1, 9, 403347) Mahatma Gandhi then read the resolution which was as follows: (a) This Congress protests against the attempt being made in South Africa and particularly to deprive the Indian settlers of the right of property and trade hitherto enjoyed by them and trusts that the Government of India will secure the repeal of the recently enacted legislation and otherwise ensure the protection of the status of the Indian settlers in South Africa.
('19', 192, 1, 10, 403780) (b) This Congress is of opinion that the anti Indian agitation now going on in East Africa is utterly unscrupulous and trusts that the Government of India will safeguard the right of free and unrestricted emigration from India to East Africa and the full civic and political rights of the Indian settlers in East Africa including the East African territory conquered from Germany.
('19', 192, 2, 11, 404161) Mahatma M.K. Gandhi speaking in English said: This is the letter addressed to the Congress by Mr. C.F. Andrews.
('19', 192, 2, 12, 404273) 2 As you know, he was at the time in East Africa investigating the position there.

('19', 192, 3, 16, 404677) My indignation has grown deeper still since I have seen with my own eyes how unjustified the attack on Indian moral character has been.

('19', 193, 1, 2, 405241) called more industrious and thrifty than other people, and hitherto, this has been the only ground, openly alleged, for refusing Indian immigration.
('19', 193, 1, 3, 405390) But this new challenge from East Africa is of an entirely different nature.
('19', 193, 1, 4, 405466) Here the main line of attack is against the Indian moral character itself.
('19', 193, 1, 5, 405541) It is brutally stated, the Indian moral depravity is so great that Indians cannot be allowed to contaminate the Africans any longer.
('19', 193, 1, 6, 405674) Let me quote from the two main documents which have levelled this gross charge against us.
('19', 193, 1, 7, 405765) The first is a declaration of the Convention of Associations of East Africa, the most important non official body of Europeans in the country, which has often gone by the name of the Whiteman’s Parliament.
('19', 193, 1, 8, 405971) The declaration beings as follows: “This Convention wishes to point out to the Government that during the discussion of a petition regarding Indians as also those affecting the native peoples of this country, they had the assistance of four missionaries, one being a Roman Catholic and three being from the Missionary Conference which was sitting in Nairobi at the same time as the Convention.” It proceeds in this way: “That whereas our national ideals of enlightenment and progress are crystallised in our Christian Western civilisation and it is our duty to make sure that the best contained therein is readily available for the needs of awakening Africa, and whereas the maintenance of this country depends entirely on the prestige and force of character of the white man, and, whereas certain Indians have entered this country as traders, clerks and assistants and whereas these people follow in all things a civilisation which is Eastern and in many respects repugnant to ours.” Here then is the main charge stated in somewhat guarded language.
('19', 193, 1, 9, 407022) It is more openly explained in the conclusion.
('19', 193, 1, 10, 407069) The Declaration proceeds: “We conceive short of the retrocession of the territory to Germany, of no transaction more immoral and more certain to recoil on our heads than the betrayal to the Asiatic of a section of the African peoples whose destinies have fallen into our hands and who at present are unable to protect themselves.
('19', 193, 1, 11, 407399) We submit that to buy off Indian or other agitation at the expense of the natives of Africa would be a policy neither wise nor honourable.”
('19', 193, 2, 12, 407539) The second document is of even greater practical significance.
('19', 193, 2, 13, 407602) It is, to all intents and purposes, an official record.
('19', 193, 2, 14, 407658) It forms part of the report of the Economic Commission which was presided over by one of the leading Government officials.

('19', 193, 5, 19, 407980) or, indeed, any part of Africa.
('19', 193, 5, 20, 408012) Physically, the Indian is not a wholesome
('19', 193, 6, 21, 408054) influence because of his incurable repugnance to sanitation and hygiene.

('19', 194, 2, 4, 408320) The Indian is

('19', 195, 5, 8, 411606) This Congress offers its respectful sympathy and condolences to the relatives of those whether English or Indian who were killed or wounded during the April disturbances.

R. Das and Swami Shraddhanand, with power to devise the best method of perpetuating the memory of the dead, to have a proper trust prepared, and to collect subscriptions for the purpose and otherwise to carry out the trust.
('19', 195, 5, 10, 412517) This Congress is of opinion that it is impossible to have real peace in India until the legislation popularly known the Rowlatt Act which was passed in the face of the unanimous opposition of the country [is withdrawn].
('19', 195, 5, 11, 412737) This Congress therefore respectfully urges upon the Rt.
('19', 195, 5, 12, 412793) the Secretary of State for India to advise His Majesty to veto the said Act.
