('19', 196, 3, 5, 413646) 149. THE ROYAL PROCLAMATION
('19', 196, 4, 6, 413674) The Proclamation issued by the Sovereign on the 24th inst.
('19', 196, 4, 7, 413733) is a document of which the British people have every reason to be proud, and with which every Indian ought to feel satisfied.
('19', 196, 4, 8, 413859) Coming on the top of the disclosures made before Lord Hunter’s Committee, the Proclamation gives one an insight into the true British character.
('19', 196, 4, 9, 414004) For, as the Proclamation shows it at its best, General Dyer’s inhumanity shows it at its worst.
('19', 196, 4, 10, 414100) The Proclamation is the evidence of the intention to do justice, as General Dyer’s deed is proof of man becoming devil under fear and excitement.
('19', 196, 4, 11, 414246) I believe that the juxtaposition of the two events is a pure accident.
('19', 196, 4, 12, 414317) The Proclamation was the inevitable consequence of the great measure which has received Royal assent.
('19', 196, 4, 13, 414419) It was the finishing touch.
('19', 196, 4, 14, 414447) The Reforms Act coupled with the Proclamation is an earnest of the intention of the British people to do justice to India.
('19', 196, 4, 15, 414570) And it ought to remove suspicion on that score.
('19', 196, 4, 16, 414618) But that does not mean that we may sit with folded hands and may still expect to get what we want.
('19', 196, 4, 17, 414717) Under the British Constitution no one gets anything without a hard fight for it.
('19', 196, 4, 18, 414798) No one for a moment believes the statements made in the Parliament that the reforms have not been granted because of the agitation.
('19', 196, 4, 19, 414930) We must lay to heart the advice of the President of the Congress that we shall gain nothing without agitation.
('19', 196, 4, 20, 415041) We would have been nowhere if there had been no Congress to agitate for the rights of the people.
('19', 196, 4, 21, 415139) Agitation means no more than movement towards something.
('19', 196, 4, 22, 415196) But just as all movement does not mean progress, so does all agitation not mean success.
('19', 196, 4, 23, 415285) Undisciplined agitation, which is a paraphrase of violence of speech or deed, can only retard national growth and bring about even unmerited retribution such as the Jallianwalla Bagh massacre.
('19', 196, 4, 24, 415478) Disciplined agitation is the condition of national growth.
('19', 196, 4, 25, 415537) The most correct agitation, therefore, consists in the most correct action and we have
('19', 197, 0, 1, 415624) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 197, 1, 2, 415666) little doubt that the Royal Proclamation and the Reforms mean not less agitation and less work but more agitation and more work of the correct type.
('19', 197, 1, 3, 415815) The Reforms are undoubtedly incomplete; they do not give us enough; we were entitled to more, we could have managed more.
('19', 197, 1, 4, 415937) But the Reforms are not such as we may reject.
('19', 197, 1, 5, 415984) On the contrary they are such as to enable us to expand.
('19', 197, 1, 6, 416041) Our duty, therefore, is not to subject them to carping criticism, but to settle down quietly to work so as to make them a thorough success and thus anticipate the time for a full measure of responsibility.
('19', 197, 1, 7, 416247) Our work, therefore, may now well consist in agitation turned inward.
('19', 197, 1, 8, 416317) Let us concentrate on riding ourselves of social abuses, on producing a strong electorate and on sending to the councils men who would seek election not for self advertisement but for national service.
('19', 197, 1, 9, 416519) There has been much mutual distrust between us ≈ the English and ourselves.
('19', 197, 1, 10, 416595) General Dyer forgot the dignity of man and became unmanly because he was seized with distrust and consequent fear.
('19', 197, 1, 11, 416710) He feared that he might be “assaulted”.
('19', 197, 1, 12, 416750) The Proclamation, more than the Reforms, replaces distrust by trust.
('19', 197, 1, 13, 416819) It remains to be seen whether the trust will filter down to the Civil Service.
('19', 197, 1, 14, 416898) But let us assume that it will, and let us respond in the fullest measure.
('19', 197, 1, 15, 416973) We cannot be wrong in so doing.
('19', 197, 1, 16, 417005) To trust is a virtue.
('19', 197, 1, 17, 417027) It is weakness that begets distrust.
('19', 197, 1, 18, 417064) The best satisfaction we can show is undoubtedly to work gracefully and ungrudgingly.
('19', 197, 1, 19, 417150) Our honest work will constitute the best guarantee for quickening the pace of progress towards the goal.
('19', 197, 1, 20, 417255) Throughout all these years, the one figure that has laboured for India without, for a single moment, turning back is Mr. Montagu.
('19', 197, 1, 21, 417385) We have had many Secretaries of State who have adorned their office.
('19', 197, 1, 22, 417454) But no Secretary has so well adorned it as Mr. Montagu.
('19', 197, 1, 23, 417510) He has been a true friend of India.
('19', 197, 1, 24, 417546) He has earned our gratitude.
('19', 197, 1, 25, 417575) And for Lord Sinha?
('19', 197, 1, 26, 417595) He has added lustre to his country.
('19', 197, 1, 27, 417631) India has every reason to be proud of him.
('19', 197, 2, 28, 417674) Young India, 31 12 1919

('19', 198, 7, 15, 418204) 151. LETTER TO STUDENTS
('19', 198, 8, 16, 418228) [1919] 3
('19', 198, 9, 17, 418237) A student means one who is hungry for learning.
('19', 198, 9, 18, 418285) Learning is knowledge of what is worth knowing about.
('19', 198, 9, 19, 418339) The only thing worth knowing about is the atman.
('19', 198, 9, 20, 418388) True knowledge is thus knowledge of the Self.
('19', 198, 9, 21, 418434) But in order to attain this knowledge, one has to know Literature, History, Geography, Mathematics, etc.
('19', 198, 9, 22, 418539) All these are by way of means.
('19', 198, 9, 23, 418570) Knowledge of letters is considered essential in order that one might acquire knowledge of these subjects.
('19', 198, 9, 24, 418676) It is not as if men of knowledge without this equipment do not exist within our experience.
('19', 198, 9, 25, 418768) One who knows this would not go mad after knowledge of letters or of literature and other subjects; he would become mad only after knowledge of the Self.
('19', 198, 9, 26, 418922) He will give up anything which proves an obstacle in the pursuit of this knowledge and dedicate himself only to that which helps him in that pursuit.
('19', 198, 9, 27, 419072) The student life of one who realizes this never ends and, whether eating, drinking, sleeping,
('19', 198, 10, 28, 419166) 1 From the reference to Gandhiji’s talk with the judges, presumably of the Hunter Committee; also from the reference to Gandhiji’s reaching Ahmedabad on Sunday.
('19', 198, 10, 29, 419327) Gandhiji reached Ahmedabad on January 4, 1920, which was a Sunday and the Wednesday preceding this date fell on December 31, 1919. 2 Saraladevi Chowdharani 3 The date of this letter is not available.
('19', 199, 0, 1, 419527) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 199, 1, 2, 419569) playing, digging, weaving, spinning or doing any other work, he is all the time growing in this knowledge.
('19', 199, 1, 3, 419676) For this purpose, one has to develop one’s faculty of observation.
('19', 199, 1, 4, 419743) One would not, then, always need a multitude of teachers or, rather, would look upon the whole world as one’s teacher and accept everything in it which is good.

('19', 199, 4, 6, 419961) 152. SPEECH ON REFORMS RESOLUTION AT AMRITSAR CONGRESS 1
('19', 199, 5, 7, 420018) January 1, 1920
('19', 199, 6, 8, 420034) Mr. Gandhi, speaking in Hindi, said that he was pained to speak against the resolution moved by Mr. Das and seconded by Mr. Tilak.
('19', 199, 6, 9, 420165) He agreed with the resolution to a great extent but he was not prepared to characterize the Reform as “disappointing” 2 .
('19', 199, 7, 10, 420287) By “disappointing” it was meant that one was unable to do any work in that connection.
('19', 199, 7, 11, 420374) But those who called the Reforms “disappointing” had said that they would fill the Council with their own candidates.
('19', 199, 7, 12, 420492) Mr. Gandhi asked the Congress to consider that.
('19', 199, 7, 13, 420540) If they wanted to utilize the Reforms Act, why should they call it “disappointing”?
('19', 199, 8, 14, 420624) He, then, moved his amendment which different from the one printed in the agenda paper yesterday.

('19', 205, 0, 1, 433693) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 205, 1, 2, 433735) 155. STATEMENT TO DISORDERS INQUIRY COMMITTEE
('19', 205, 2, 3, 433781) [SABARMATI, January 5, 1920] For the past thirty years I have been preaching and practising satyagraha.
('19', 205, 2, 4, 433885) The principles of satyagraha, as I know it today, constitute a gradual evolution.
('19', 205, 2, 5, 433967) Satyagraha differs from passive resistance as North Pole from South.
('19', 205, 2, 6, 434036) The latter has been conceived as a weapon of the weak and does not exclude the use of physical force or violence for the purpose of gaining one’s end, whereas the former has been conceived as a weapon of the strongest and excludes the use of violence in any shape or form.
('19', 205, 2, 7, 434309) The term satyagraha was coined by me in South Africa to express the force that the Indians there used for full eight years and it was coined in order to distinguish it from the movement then going on in the United Kingdom and South Africa under the name of passive resistance.
('19', 205, 3, 8, 434586) Its root meaning is holding on to truth, hence truth force.
('19', 205, 3, 9, 434646) I have also called it love force or soul force.
('19', 205, 3, 10, 434694) In the application of satyagraha, I discovered in the earliest stages that pursuit of truth did not admit of violence being inflicted on one’s opponent but that he must be weaned from error by patience and sympathy.
('19', 205, 3, 11, 434910) For what appears to be truth to the one may appear to be error to the other.
('19', 205, 3, 12, 434987) And patience means self suffering.
('19', 205, 3, 13, 435022) So the doctrine came to mean vindication of truth, not by infliction of suffering on the opponent, but on one’s self.
('19', 205, 3, 14, 435140) But on the political field, the struggle on behalf of the people mostly consists in opposing error in the shape of unjust laws.
('19', 205, 3, 15, 435268) When you have failed to bring the error home to the law giver by way of petitions and the like, the only remedy open to you, if you do not wish to submit to error, is to compel him by physical force to yield to you or by suffering in your own person by inviting the penalty for the breach of the law.
('19', 205, 3, 16, 435569) Hence satyagraha largely appears to the public as civil disobedience or civil resistance.
('19', 205, 3, 17, 435659) It is civil in the sense that it is not criminal.
('19', 205, 4, 18, 435709) 1 Vide “Gujarati Equivalents forPassive Resistance Etc.”, 7 3 1908 and Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XII.
('19', 206, 0, 1, 435817) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 207
('19', 206, 1, 2, 435865) The law breaker breaks the law surreptitiously and tries to avoid the penalty; not so the civil resister.
('19', 206, 1, 3, 435971) He ever obeys the laws of the State to which he belongs not out of fear of the sanctions but because he considers them to be good for the welfare of society.
('19', 206, 1, 4, 436129) But there come occasion, generally rare, when he considers certain laws to be so unjust as to render obedience to them a dishonour.
('19', 206, 1, 5, 436261) He then openly and civilly breaks them and quietly suffers the penalty for their breach.
('19', 206, 1, 6, 436350) And in order to register his protest against the action of the law givers, it is open to him to withdraw his co operation from the State by disobeying such other laws whose breach does not involve moral turpitude.
('19', 206, 1, 7, 436564) In my opinion, the beauty and efficacy of satyagraha are so great and the doctrine so simple that it can be preached even to children.
('19', 206, 1, 8, 436699) It was preached by me to thousands of men, women and children commonly called indentured Indians, with excellent results.
('19', 206, 1, 9, 436821) When the Rowlatt Bills were published I felt that they were so restrictive of human liberty that they must be resisted to the utmost.
('19', 206, 1, 10, 436955) I observed too that the opposition to them was universal among Indians.
('19', 206, 1, 11, 437027) I submit that no State however despotic has the right to enact laws which are repugnant to the whole body of the people, much less a government guided by constitutional usage and precedent such as the Indian Government.
('19', 206, 1, 12, 437247) I felt too that the oncoming agitation needed a definite direction if it was neither to collapse not to run into violent channels.
('19', 206, 1, 13, 437378) I ventured therefore to present satyagraha to the country emphasizing its civil resistance aspect.
('19', 206, 1, 14, 437477) And as it is purely an inward and purifying movement, I suggested the observance of fast, prayer and suspension of all work for one day the 6th of April.
('19', 206, 1, 15, 437631) There was a magnificent response throughout the length and breadth of India, even in little villages, although there was no organization and no great previous preparation.
('19', 206, 1, 16, 437803) The idea was given to the public as soon as it was conceived.
('19', 206, 1, 17, 437865) On the 6th April there was no violence used by the people and no collision with the police worth naming.
('19', 206, 1, 18, 437970) The hartal was purely voluntary and spontaneous.
('19', 206, 1, 19, 438019) I attach here to the letter 1 in which the idea was announced.
('19', 206, 1, 20, 438082) The observance of the 6th April was to be followed by civil disobedience.
('19', 206, 1, 21, 438156) For the purpose the Committee of the Satyagraha Sabha had selected certain political laws for disobedience.
('19', 206, 2, 22, 438264) 1 This was given as Annexure A; vide “Letter to the Press on Satyagraha Movement”, 23 3 1919.
('19', 207, 0, 1, 438358) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 207, 1, 2, 438400) commenced the distribution of prohibited literature of a perfectly healthy type, e.g., a pamphlet 1 written by me on Home Rule, a translation of Ruskin’s Unto This Last, The Defence and Death of Socrates, etc.
('19', 207, 1, 3, 438610) But there is no doubt that the 6th of April found India vitalized as never before.
('19', 207, 1, 4, 438693) The people who were fear stricken ceased to fear authority.
('19', 207, 1, 5, 438753) Moreover, hitherto the masses had lain inert.
('19', 207, 1, 6, 438799) The leaders had not really acted upon them.
('19', 207, 1, 7, 438843) They were undisciplined.
('19', 207, 1, 8, 438868) They had found a new force but they did not know what it was and how to use it.
('19', 207, 1, 9, 438948) At Delhi, the leaders found it difficult to restrain the very large number of people who had remained unmoved before.
('19', 207, 1, 10, 439066) At Amritsar, Dr. Satyapal was anxious that I should go there and show to the people the peaceful nature of satyagraha.
('19', 207, 1, 11, 439185) Swami Shraddhanandji from Delhi and Dr. Satyapal from Amritsar wrote to me asking me to go to their respective places for pacifying the people and for explaining to them the nature of satyagraha.
('19', 207, 1, 12, 439381) I had never been to Amritsar and, for that matter, to the Punjab before.
('19', 207, 1, 13, 439454) These two messages were seen by the authorities and they knew that I was invited to both the places for peaceful purposes.
('19', 207, 1, 14, 439577) I left Bombay for Delhi and the Punjab on the 8th April and had telegraphed to Dr. Satyapal, whom I had never met before, to meet me at Delhi.
('19', 207, 1, 15, 439720) But after passing Muttra 2 I was served with an order prohibiting me from entering the province of Delhi.
('19', 207, 1, 16, 439826) I felt that I was bound to disregard this order and I proceeded on my journey.
('19', 207, 1, 17, 439905) At Palwal, I was served with an[other] order prohibiting me from entering the Punjab and confining me to the Bombay Presidency.
('19', 207, 1, 18, 440033) And I was arrested by a party of police and taken off the train at that station.
('19', 207, 1, 19, 440114) The Superintendent of Police who arrested me acted with every courtesy.
('19', 207, 1, 20, 440186) I was taken to Muttra by the first available train the thence by goods trains early in the morning to Sawai Madhopur, where I joined the Bombay Mail from Peshawar and was taken charge of by Superintendent Bowring.
('19', 207, 1, 21, 440400) I was discharged at Bombay on the 10th April.
('19', 207, 1, 22, 440446) But the people of Ahmedabad and Viramgam and in Gujarat generally had heard of my arrest.
('19', 207, 1, 23, 440536) They became furious, shops were
('19', 207, 2, 24, 440568) 1 Vide “Hind Swaraj”,22 11 1909
('19', 207, 3, 25, 440600) 2 Mathura.
('19', 207, 3, 26, 440611) The order was served at Kosi.
('19', 208, 0, 1, 440641) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 209
('19', 208, 1, 2, 440689) closed, crowds gathered, and murder, arson, pillage, wire cutting and attempt at derailment followed.
('19', 208, 1, 3, 440791) I had worked in the midst of Kaira raiyats just before and had mixed among thousands of men and women.
('19', 208, 1, 4, 440894) I had worked at the instance of and with Miss Anasuya Sarabhai among the mill hands of Ahmedabad.
('19', 208, 1, 5, 440992) The mill hands appreciated her philanthropic work and adored her.
('19', 208, 1, 6, 441058) The fury of the labourers in Ahmedabad reached white heat when a false rumour was started that she too was arrested.
('19', 208, 1, 7, 441175) Both of us had visited and interceded for the mill hands of Viramgam when they were in trouble.
('19', 208, 1, 8, 441271) And it is my firm belief that the excesses were due to the great resentment of the mobs over my arrest and the rumoured arrest of Miss Anasuya Sarabhai.
('19', 208, 1, 9, 441424) I have mixed with the masses in practically the whole of India and talked to them freely.
('19', 208, 1, 10, 441514) I do not believe that there was any revolutionary movement behind the excesses.
('19', 208, 1, 11, 441594) They could hardly be dignified by the term ‘rebellion’.
('19', 208, 1, 12, 441650) And, in my opinion, the Government erred in prosecuting the offenders for waging war.
('19', 208, 1, 13, 441736) This hasty view has caused unmerited or disproportionate suffering.
('19', 208, 1, 14, 441804) The fine imposed on poor Ahmedabad was heavy and the manner of collecting it from the labourers was unnecessarily harsh and irritating.
('19', 208, 1, 15, 441940) I doubt the justice of inflicting on the labourers a fine so large as 1,76,000 (one hundred and seventy six thousand) rupees.
('19', 208, 1, 16, 442066) The imposition of the cost from the farmers of Barejadi and from the Banias and Patidars of Nadiad was totally unjustified and even vindictive.
('19', 208, 1, 17, 442210) I think that the introduction of Martial Law in Ahmedabad was also unjustified and its thoughtless administration resulted in the loss of several innocent lives.
('19', 208, 1, 18, 442372) At the same time, and subject to the reservations mentioned by me, I have no doubt that, in the Bombay Presidency, the authorities acted with considerable restraint at a time when the atmosphere was surcharged with mutual suspicion and the attempt at wrecking the train which was bringing the troops to restore order had naturally angered the authorities.

('19', 209, 1, 2, 443103) 156. LETTER TO SECRETARY, DISORDERS INQUIRY COMMITTEE
('19', 209, 2, 3, 443157) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, [January 5, 1920] 1
('19', 209, 3, 4, 443207) DEAR SIR, I beg to enclose herewith my statement 2 for submission to the Disorders Inquiry Committee.
('19', 209, 3, 5, 443309) If the Committee wish to entertain my evidence I shall esteem it a favour if I am given an early day so as to free me for my other engagements.

('19', 214, 4, 5, 454766) The manager of the Ashram, Mr. Maganlal Gandhi, has applied for some time for permission to build a stable in the non Inami 1
('19', 214, 5, 6, 454892) Ashram ground, but the permission has not yet been received.
('19', 214, 5, 7, 454953) The stable is to be used for keeping cattle.
('19', 214, 5, 8, 454998) I understand that some inquiry has been made about the use to be made of the cattle.
('19', 214, 5, 9, 455083) This question would have been unnecessary if it had been recognized that we are essentially an agricultural colony.
('19', 214, 5, 10, 455199) The manner in which the whole ground is being used shows it.
('19', 214, 5, 11, 455260) We have now a fairly large number of cattle.
('19', 214, 5, 12, 455305) And it is risky to keep them without proper shelter for any length of time.
('19', 214, 5, 13, 455381) I shall therefore thank you if you could see your way to issue the permission at once.
('19', 214, 5, 14, 455468) I shall be able to satisfy you any day that we are not using the cattle for trade purposes.
('19', 214, 5, 15, 455560) We keep cattle for ploughing for the manure they give, and the cows and buffaloes for the milk they give for our food in addition to the manure.
('19', 214, 6, 16, 455705) Yours sincerely,

('19', 215, 5, 10, 456557) It is, as I have conceived it, an extension of the domestic law on the political field, and my own experience has led me to the conclusion that that movement and that movement alone can rid India of the possibilities of violence spreading throughout the length and breadth of the land for the redress of grievances, supposed or real.

('19', 296, 4, 7, 641060) I think the speech puts it like that.

('19', 296, 6, 11, 641489) I said to myself, “This is what appears to have happened,” and I discussed with those friends who called there and instead of disputing the proposition, they said, “Yes”.

('19', 296, 9, 16, 641942) You had a sort of conference on the morning of the 14th at the district court house with Mr. Pratt and Mr. Chatfield and the Officer Commanding.

('19', 299, 5, 6, 646316) SIR, Mr. Andrews cabling from Mombasa says :
('19', 299, 6, 7, 646361) Full draft proposed ordinance menacing Indian political freedom reads thus:
('19', 299, 7, 8, 646437) “Firstly, the Bill may be cited as Removal of Undesirables Ordinance, 1919.
('19', 299, 8, 9, 646513) “Secondly, any person within East African Protectorate not being a native, who from information officially received is deemed by Governor in Council undesirable, may be ordered by Governor to remove himself from the Protectorate before the date prescribed in such order.
('19', 299, 9, 10, 646784) “Thirdly, any person contravening such order shall be liable on conviction to a fine up to Rs. 1,500 or to imprisonment of either description not exceeding six months or both together.
('19', 299, 9, 11, 646969) Such conviction shall not affect Governor’s power to issue further order under preceding section against same person.”
('19', 299, 10, 12, 647088) Legislative Council meets January 19th.
('19', 299, 10, 13, 647128) This ordinance entirely lacks safeguards against political misuse.
('19', 299, 10, 14, 647195) Economic Commission’s volume of evidence contains no valid substantiation of Indian moral depravity.
('19', 299, 10, 15, 647296) Our vindication of Indian character has carried conviction but European determination to follow south African policy still gravely serious.
('19', 299, 10, 16, 647436) Hardly any comment is necessary on this cablegram.
('19', 299, 10, 17, 647487) There is a dead set against the Indian settler in East Africa.
('19', 299, 10, 18, 647550) The proposed ordinance is, in my humble opinion, most mischievous in character and leaves every Indian at the mercy of an executive subservient to the interested European agitator against the Indian.
('19', 299, 10, 19, 647750) The unscrupulous nature of the agitation is manifest from the utterly false charges flung about moral depravity against the Indian settler.
('19', 299, 10, 20, 647890) I regard the proposed ordinance as the first definite legal step towards the reduction of the Indian to complete servility.
('19', 299, 10, 21, 648014) He has dared to claim an equal status with the recently arrived European settler.
('19', 299, 10, 22, 648096) He has dared to dispute the
('19', 299, 11, 23, 648124) 1 This was released to the Press generally and was published in Young India, 14 1 1920.
('19', 300, 0, 1, 648212) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 301
('19', 300, 1, 2, 648260) haughty position taken up by his European rival in trade.
('19', 300, 1, 3, 648318) The latter has therefore captured the executive.
('19', 300, 1, 4, 648367) The East African position admits of no compromise such as was possible and perhaps necessary in South Africa where the condition was totally different from the East African condition.
('19', 300, 1, 5, 648551) The Indian adds the right of priority to the ordinary natural right to live on terms of equality with every other kind of settler in East Africa.
('19', 300, 1, 6, 648697) And I venture to hope that his claim will be universally supported in India for the preservation of his full political and municipal status, and that the Government of India will exercise to the full its undoubted right and perform the duty of protecting the British Indian settler in East Africa.
('19', 300, 2, 7, 648995) Yours, etc.,
('19', 300, 3, 8, 649008) M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 12 1 1920
('19', 300, 4, 9, 649053) 161. THE CONGRESS
('19', 300, 5, 10, 649071) The last Congress having been held there, Amritsar became a place of pilgrimage.
('19', 300, 5, 11, 649152) Thousands of people came to Amritsar solely because the Congress was held there, and the first thing they did on arrival was to visit Jallianwala Bagh.
('19', 300, 5, 12, 649304) Hundreds of people who came to see me told me in reply to my questions: “Directly on our arrival, we visited Jallianwala Bagh.” Many applied to their foreheads the dust of the place, as if it were sacred ash; many took away with them some earth made holy by the blood of innocent people.
('19', 300, 5, 13, 649592) In this way everyone, from south, east and west, felt sanctified by paying homage to their dead brethren and believed that their purpose in coming to attend the Congress had been fulfilled.
('19', 300, 5, 14, 649782) In Amritsar, it usually rains in December.
('19', 300, 5, 15, 649825) As the city is on a low level, the water collects on the ground when there is rain.
('19', 300, 5, 16, 649909) As the rain started just with the commencement of the Congress session, there was much inconvenience.
('19', 300, 5, 17, 650011) The Congress pandal 1 and the tents for accommodating people were in Acheson Park, which, being on a low level, was flooded with water and it was a job putting up the visitors.
('19', 300, 5, 18, 650188) The residents of Amritsar, however, treated the visitors as their own people.
('19', 300, 5, 19, 650266) The Hindi
('19', 300, 6, 20, 650276) 1 Temporary canopied structure
('19', 301, 0, 1, 650307) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 301, 1, 2, 650349) word for this, apanaya 1 is a very apt one.
('19', 301, 1, 3, 650393) If we render it into Gujarati, we should say apanayya.
('19', 301, 1, 4, 650448) Those who could accommodate any of them in their homes, did so and treated them hospitably, and thus it seemed as if the delegates and the spectators had arrived on a condolence visit.
('19', 301, 1, 5, 650633) This hospitality, besides, was no mere manners but was sincerely felt.
('19', 301, 1, 6, 650704) There was no limit to the generosity of the residents.
('19', 301, 1, 7, 650759) This is one side of the picture, the beautiful one.
('19', 301, 1, 8, 650811) Its other side was the expense of Rs. 22,000 incurred for putting up a pandal for the Congress and the tents.
('19', 301, 1, 9, 650921) This expense was not unavoidable and I do not believe, either, that after all this expenditure, we gave anything special to the people.
('19', 301, 1, 10, 651057) I think we can go on well enough without a pandal.
('19', 301, 1, 11, 651108) If we hold the meeting in the open air instead of in a pandal, many more people can be accommodated and the expense will be less.
('19', 301, 1, 12, 651238) The pandal protects us from the heat, but this in December is not severe.
('19', 301, 1, 13, 651312) Moreover, one can protect oneself against the heat at less expense than required in putting up a pandal.
('19', 301, 1, 14, 651417) I mentioned rain but that also is no excuse for it was because of the rain that the Congress session had to be postponed by a day.
('19', 301, 1, 15, 651548) Erecting a roof for protection against rain would have cost still more.
('19', 301, 1, 16, 651620) And the same thing about the tents.
('19', 301, 1, 17, 651656) Instead of incurring expense on them, arrangements for accommodation could have been made with the citizens from the very outset.
('19', 301, 1, 18, 651786) But we cannot change the habit which we have formed from the beginning [of the congress] and so the Congress, though it is such a big national gathering, has not yet fully entered the life of the people.
('19', 301, 1, 19, 651990) The fair in Amritsar on the first day of every Vaishakh 2 attracts many more people than the number attending the Congress, and yet they are all accommodated; no special arrangements have to be made for them and no heavy expenditure has to be incurred in advance.
('19', 301, 1, 20, 652254) Such is our age old way.
('19', 301, 1, 21, 652279) It ensures grand results with little effort.
('19', 301, 1, 22, 652324) With modern ways of working, we produce a small result after a big effort.
('19', 301, 1, 23, 652399) But why complain in this way when describing a happy occasion, someone may ask.
('19', 301, 1, 24, 652479) I complain simply with the idea that, in future, we may make better arrangements.
('19', 301, 1, 25, 652561) These thoughts have occurred to others as well and, in consequence, the All India Congress has even appointed a Committee for the purpose.
('19', 301, 1, 26, 652700) Its tasks are as under :
('19', 301, 2, 27, 652725) 1 Accepted as one of themselves 2 Month in Indian calendar, roughly corresponding to April May
('19', 302, 0, 1, 652820) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 303
('19', 302, 1, 2, 652868) 1. To examine the Congress constitution and consider necessary changes in it.
('19', 302, 1, 3, 652946) 2. To examine and consider the financial transactions of the different departments of the congress.
('19', 302, 1, 4, 653046) 3. To make suggestions for the next year’s session of the Congress.
('19', 302, 1, 5, 653114) Mr. Kelkar, Mr. Rangaswami Ayyangar, Mr. I.B. Sen, the Hon’ble Mr. Vithalbhai Patel and I have been appointed on this committee and it has been asked to submit its report before June 30. I have yet another complaint to make.
('19', 302, 1, 6, 653339) The speeches of the chairman of the Reception Committee and the congress President are generally so lengthy that it would be an infliction to read them out to anyone on any occasion; but it is nothing less than torture to read out long speeches to 15,000 persons.
('19', 302, 1, 7, 653603) The speeches are bound to be lengthy.
('19', 302, 1, 8, 653641) It is but natural that a detailed discussion of several topics should fill pages.
('19', 302, 1, 9, 653723) What is the way out, then?
('19', 302, 1, 10, 653750) I think both these speeches should be printed in Hindustani (in both Urdu and Devnagari script), in English and in the regional language of the province where the Congress is to be held and copies supplied to the delegates and the audience at the entrance gate.
('19', 302, 1, 11, 654012) Later, both could read out, in half an hour, the main part of their speeches or explain their substance.
('19', 302, 1, 12, 654117) The speeches themselves were thought provoking.
('19', 302, 1, 13, 654165) That of Swami Shraddhanandji was touched with his religious zeal.
('19', 302, 1, 14, 654231) How can we hate the English?
('19', 302, 1, 15, 654260) They gave us Andrews, Hume, Wedderburn and others.
('19', 302, 1, 16, 654311) In this way, they have shown their goodwill for us.
('19', 302, 1, 17, 654363) There was bitterness in Pandit Motilal’s speech.
('19', 302, 1, 18, 654412) He has seen the suffering of the Punjab, and has suffered in his soul.
('19', 302, 1, 19, 654483) He let this be seen in his speech.
('19', 302, 1, 20, 654518) Since the Swamiji’s speech was in Hindi, people followed it very attentively, though some were bored towards the end.
('19', 302, 1, 21, 654636) As Motilal’s speech was read out in English, people were not prepared to hear him at all.
('19', 302, 1, 22, 654726) It was all noise in the beginning but, thanks to Pandit Malaviya’s persuasion, quiet was restored somewhat.
('19', 302, 1, 23, 654834) Much of the speech had to be omitted in the reading.
('19', 302, 2, 24, 654887) RESOLUTIONS The Congress resolutions were of great importance.
('19', 302, 2, 25, 654950) The first offered thanks to the Emperor.
('19', 302, 2, 26, 654991) There was discussion enough even on that resolution, but in the end it was passed.
('19', 302, 2, 27, 655074) The liberal spirit noticeable in the Emperor’s Proclamation was absent in the earlier
('19', 303, 0, 1, 655160) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 303, 1, 2, 655202) Proclamation.
('19', 303, 1, 3, 655216) It is no small gain, we can see, that those who had been rotting [in jail] merely because of suspicion have been released.
('19', 303, 1, 4, 655339) There may have been injustice in throwing them into jail, but doubtless there was generosity in releasing them.
('19', 303, 1, 5, 655451) It was our duty, therefore, to express our thanks for this.
('19', 303, 2, 6, 655511) The most important resolution, however, was the one in which we admitted and condemned our lapses.
('19', 303, 2, 7, 655610) It was a little difficult to understand the unwillingness to pass this.
('19', 303, 2, 8, 655682) That in Ahmedabad, Viramgam, Amritsar, Gujranwala and Kasur, our own people set fire to buildings, killed people, burnt down bridges, removed rail tracks and cut wires needs no proof.
('19', 303, 2, 9, 655866) Maybe there is truth in what some people say, that the C.I.D. instigated the mobs, that it had a hand in it; even then, the fact remains that some of us played into their hands and did unforgivable things.
('19', 303, 2, 10, 656072) We must denounce these.
('19', 303, 2, 11, 656096) The individual or nation that refuses to see his or its lapses or fears to admit them can never progress.
('19', 303, 2, 12, 656202) So long as we refuse to see the evil around us, we do not acquire the strength to fight it and the evil goes deep.
('19', 303, 2, 13, 656317) Moreover, we have no right whatsoever either to notice or condemn other people’s faults so long as we do not roundly denounce our own.
('19', 303, 2, 14, 656452) We cannot be purified unless we feel sorry for having set Government buildings on fire and atone for it; until then we have no right to condemn General Dyer’s terrible crime and, if we fail to admit our faults, we dare not demand the dismissal of Sir Michael O’Dwyer and the recall of Lord Chelmsford.
('19', 303, 2, 15, 656754) It is also asked whether we should not take into account the nature of the provocation to the people.
('19', 303, 2, 16, 656856) The answer to this is that, even so, we are bound to denounce our misdeeds such as setting fire to buildings and killing innocent people.
('19', 303, 2, 17, 656994) That man alone wins who, whatever the cause, refuses to be provoked and such a one alone may be said to be a law abiding man.
('19', 303, 2, 18, 657120) The nation which does not know how to obey laws has no right to protest against injustice.
('19', 303, 2, 19, 657211) The Government arrested me and the people were enraged; well, what did they gain by burning down police stations?
('19', 303, 2, 20, 657325) How did they profit by setting fire to the students’ examination pandal?
('19', 303, 2, 21, 657398) The loss is obvious enough.
('19', 303, 2, 22, 657426) We had to pay the fine, many went to jail, and many suffered the agonies of suspense.
('19', 303, 2, 23, 657512) Personally, I am convinced that, had we not committed the mistakes we did on April 10, we would have made great advances by now and the Rowlatt Act would have long since been repealed.
('19', 304, 0, 1, 657697) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 305
('19', 304, 1, 2, 657745) innocent persons, almost one thousand of them, who were killed at Jallianwala Bagh would not have been killed and other innocent persons would not have had to suffer in prison.
('19', 304, 1, 3, 657922) Looking at the matter from any angle we choose, we can come to only one conclusion.
('19', 304, 1, 4, 658006) It is that we were in duty bound to condemn the violence and arson committed by our people.
('19', 304, 1, 5, 658098) If we tolerate such misdeeds when we become fully independent, we would show ourselves to be barbarians.
('19', 304, 1, 6, 658203) The third important resolution related to the Reforms Act.
('19', 304, 1, 7, 658262) The differences on this resolution were so strong that the Congress came to the point of putting it to the vote in the open session.
('19', 304, 1, 8, 658395) Without going into the whole story, it will be enough to understand the differences which had remained unresolved.
('19', 304, 1, 9, 658510) There were three clauses in the resolution moved by Mr. Das.
('19', 304, 1, 10, 658571) One of them stated that we were fit for swaraj this very day; the second that the Reforms were inadequate, unsatisfactory and disappointing, and the third that the Parliament should grant full independence as early as possible.
('19', 304, 1, 11, 658799) The Hon’ble Pandit Malaviya, Mr. Jinnah and I felt that the nation would not know what it was to do if we said no more than this.
('19', 304, 1, 12, 658929) If in fact we want to avail ourselves of the Reforms, they could not be described as disappointing; if we want to do so, we should frankly admit it.
('19', 304, 1, 13, 659078) Likewise, if we admit that Mr. Montagu worked hard for India to secure the Reforms which have been granted, we ought to thank him.
('19', 304, 1, 14, 659209) I saw that everyone wanted to work the Reforms.
('19', 304, 1, 15, 659257) We should, therefore, admit this fact and delete the word “disappointing”, and we should also thank Mr. Montagu.
('19', 304, 1, 16, 659370) Ultimately, the adjective “disappointing” was retained and the amendment suggested by me, worded suitably so as to be acceptable to both sides, was passed unanimously.
('19', 304, 1, 17, 659538) But prior to that, the preparations for the taking of votes were a great thing, a credit to the people of India.
('19', 304, 1, 18, 659651) Including the spectators, there were no less than 15,000 men in the pandal and there was not even enough room to move about.
('19', 304, 1, 19, 659776) Among all these people, there were as many who were not entitled to vote as those who were.
('19', 304, 1, 20, 659868) Counting of votes, in these circumstances, would generally be considered impossible.
('19', 304, 1, 21, 659953) This was the first time, therefore, in the 34 years of the life of the Congress, that excellent arrangements were made to do the counting after keeping out the spectators and the representatives of peasants.
('19', 304, 1, 22, 660161) For practically five hours, speeches by people holding different opinions went on.
('19', 305, 0, 1, 660244) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 305, 1, 2, 660286) Meanwhile, all the parties came to the conclusion that it would be better to have a compromise and dispense with the taking of votes.
('19', 305, 1, 3, 660420) Consultations began.
('19', 305, 1, 4, 660441) Ultimately a compromise was reached and a resolution, thanking Mr. Montagu and advising the people to work the Reforms, was passed without a vote.
('19', 305, 1, 5, 660588) The wording of the resolution which Mr. Das’s party agreed upon was not quite to my liking.
('19', 305, 1, 6, 660680) Retaining the word “disappointing” was also a little hard; nevertheless, where the essence was maintained, I thought it advisable not to create divisions and Panditji, Mr. Jinnah and others agreed with me.
('19', 305, 1, 7, 660886) Thus, the amendment was passed in a form acceptable to both the parties.
('19', 305, 1, 8, 660959) Had the congress not accepted this amendment, it would have been, in my humble opinion, a matter of shame for us.
('19', 305, 1, 9, 661073) Indeed, a person like me would have had nothing to say if we did not want to work the Reforms or had the courage to reject them.
('19', 305, 1, 10, 661202) When it was agreed, however, that they should be worked, not to say this in public and not to thank the gentlemen who had been instrumental in our getting them seemed to me dishonest, and it also seemed disgraceful not to respond to sentiments expressed in the Emperor’s Proclamation.
('19', 305, 1, 11, 661487) To think of withholding co operation with the officers because of fear is a sign of weakness.
('19', 305, 1, 12, 661581) It bespeaks manli ness to co operate with them and trust them on all matters which advance the country’s interests.
('19', 305, 1, 13, 661697) Thus, from every point of view, we can say that the amendment accepted by the Congress is a good one and I am sure that, if we use all the provisions of the Reforms wisely and secure appropriate improvements in them, we should achieve full swaraj in no more than a few years.
('19', 305, 1, 14, 661973) Apart from this, resolutions were passed about Lord Chelmsford and other officers.
('19', 305, 1, 15, 662056) It seems to me that it would have been better if the resolutions on Lord Chelmsford and Sir Michael O’Dwyer had been postponed till after the Congress Sub committee’s report was published.
('19', 305, 1, 16, 662245) However, we have the right, on strong grounds, to demand the removal of any officer from his post and, therefore, though I believe that these two resolutions were passed prematurely, now that they have been passed there is no need to comment on them further.
('19', 305, 1, 17, 662504) However, the speeches on the resolution for the recall of Lord Chelmsford were shameful and deserve condemnation.
('19', 305, 1, 18, 662618) To regard Lord Chelmsford unfit for his post is one thing; but it is quite another to insult him and to use discourteous and unmannerly language about
('19', 306, 0, 1, 662769) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 307
('19', 306, 1, 2, 662817) the Emperor’s representative.
('19', 306, 1, 3, 662847) We shall lower ourselves in the estimation of others thereby and such language, if it became common among the people, would be a blot on the virtues of humanity, courtesy and magnanimity which still remain ours.
('19', 306, 1, 4, 663059) I just do not believe that the nation can gain anything through exaggeration.
('19', 306, 1, 5, 663137) Exa ggeration is a particularly bad species of falsehood; even if the nation can advance through untruthfulness, it would be better for us to refuse to advance in such a manner because, ultimately, such advance will bring about our fall.
('19', 306, 1, 6, 663375) Besides these, the other resolutions which were passed to give a lead to the nation should be considered excellent.
('19', 306, 1, 7, 663491) The Congress welcomed the current movement for swadeshi and has given a place in its programme to hand spinning and hand weaving.
('19', 306, 1, 8, 663621) The All India Congress Committee was requested to investigate the conditions of the peasants and a resolution was passed to support the Muslims on the Khilafat issue: similar other useful resolutions which were passed will help us forward and, if the nation implements them, good results cannot but follow.
('19', 306, 1, 9, 663928) The country must be proud that Jallianwala Bagh has passed into its possession.

('19', 307, 0, 1, 664799) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 307, 1, 2, 664841) 162. CHILD MORTALITY
('19', 307, 2, 3, 664862) We wish to draw the particular attention of readers to Mr. Kanchanlal Khandwala’s letter about the relative figures of child mortality.
('19', 307, 2, 4, 664998) In New Zealand, 51 children out of one thousand die in a year.
('19', 307, 2, 5, 665061) In Bombay 320 and in the United Provinces 352. Whatever way we look at these figures, they make us shudder.
('19', 307, 2, 6, 665169) There are quite strong reasons for this state of affairs but the causes are such as can be remedied and so deserve attention.
('19', 307, 2, 7, 665295) Besides, the unfavourable factors continue to increase in number.
('19', 307, 2, 8, 665361) Some of these factors are as follows: (1) Climate, (2) diet, (3) child marriage and ill matched unions, (4) self indulgence, (5) ignorance about sanitation and, now, (6) excessively high prices.
('19', 307, 2, 9, 665556) Of all these factors, the Government can be held responsible at present for the last one only; the reason for our making this distinction is that, for our innumerable ailments and shortcomings we blame the Government.
('19', 307, 2, 10, 665774) It has become a habit with us to argue that, if we get swaraj, all our maladies, even the heavy rate of child mortality, will vanish instantly.
('19', 307, 2, 11, 665918) It is true in a general way that starvation, which is becoming more widespread in the country, will probably decrease after we get swaraj.
('19', 307, 2, 12, 666057) Even then, many of our ailments will persist, despite swaraj, if we do not adopt remedial measures.
('19', 307, 2, 13, 666157) One such ailment is our present subject.
('19', 307, 2, 14, 666198) We cannot change climate of the country.
('19', 307, 2, 15, 666239) New Zealand is among the countries with the best climate.
('19', 307, 2, 16, 666297) Relatively, the climate in India is generally believed to be enervating.
('19', 307, 2, 17, 666370) It is difficult to develop a good constitution in intense heat.
('19', 307, 2, 18, 666434) It is the general experience that moist air is even more injurious than heat.
('19', 307, 2, 19, 666512) Even so, God has given man such strength that, by and large, he succeeds in overcoming such obstacles.
('19', 307, 2, 20, 666615) To a greater or less extent, all of us do.
('19', 307, 2, 21, 666658) To the extent that the climate is among the unfavourable factors which militate against reduction in the rate of child mortality, we can take suitable measures to counteract the harmfulness of the climate.
('19', 307, 2, 22, 666864) Our poverty is the greatest obstacle in this.
('19', 307, 2, 23, 666910) Our ignorance about how children should be brought up is another obstacle of like magnitude.
('19', 307, 2, 24, 667003) The child does not always get the food it needs.
('19', 307, 2, 25, 667052) The requirements of infant diet are easy to understand.
('19', 307, 2, 26, 667108) The child should be brought up on mother’s milk and, when it is no longer available, it
('19', 308, 0, 1, 667196) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 309
('19', 308, 1, 2, 667244) should get cow’s milk.
('19', 308, 1, 3, 667267) Instead, the child is switched on to cooked food even before it has cut teeth.
('19', 308, 1, 4, 667346) It is fed on cereals even before its stomach is ready for them.
('19', 308, 1, 5, 667410) Consequently, the child is attacked by diseases, grows weak and often dies an untimely death.
('19', 308, 1, 6, 667504) Our poverty and ignorance are the main reasons for the unsuitable food [of our children].
('19', 308, 2, 7, 667594) An even more important reason than the two mentioned above is child marriage and ill matched unions.
('19', 308, 2, 8, 667695) A girl of fifteen can never be fit for delivery.
('19', 308, 2, 9, 667744) A child born of such a girl is deficient in vitality.
('19', 308, 2, 10, 667798) Our children are so sickly that bringing them up becomes a veritable job indeed, with the result that many children die within a year of their birth.
('19', 308, 2, 11, 667948) Along with child marriage, we should hold ill matched unions responsible for the deaths of a great many infants.
('19', 308, 2, 12, 668061) It is not at all surprising that the children of men who marry when they are no longer fit for marriage do not survive.
('19', 308, 2, 13, 668181) It is also certain that excessive indulgence increases the rate of infant mortality.
('19', 308, 2, 14, 668266) People in the West limit births, not with any religious idea, to be sure, but for reasons of health and for fear of having to bring up too many children.
('19', 308, 2, 15, 668420) For us, such fear is not enough of a check on self indulgence.
('19', 308, 2, 16, 668483) However, we in India lay great claim to being more religious in our lives than people in the West, and yet we ignore the restraints imposed by religion.
('19', 308, 2, 17, 668636) Hence it is that many parents, regardless of both dharma and worldly considerations, remain steeped in carnal pleasures and bring forth children regardless of circumstances.
('19', 308, 2, 18, 668810) In the result, whether we want them or not, diseased children are born and die in their infancy.
('19', 308, 2, 19, 668907) The fifth reason is our colossal ignorance of the rules of health.
('19', 308, 2, 20, 668974) Neither the mother nor the father knows anything about them.
('19', 308, 2, 21, 669035) People who have knowledge are disinclined to profit by it or lack the means of doing so.
('19', 308, 2, 22, 669124) The result is the same; infant deaths keep increasing.
('19', 308, 2, 23, 669179) Often, an ignorant midwife becomes the cause of an infant’a death.
('19', 308, 2, 24, 669246) She has no notion of how a woman in confinement should be looked after.
('19', 308, 2, 25, 669318) She does not make the mother observe even simple rules.
('19', 308, 2, 26, 669374) Hence, from its very birth the infant is looked after miserably and succumbs.
('19', 308, 2, 27, 669452) If it survives the first two months the mother, as ignorant as the midwife, brings it up as well as she knows how to and, though she may not kill it, harms its health all right.
('19', 309, 0, 1, 669630) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 309, 1, 2, 669672) The last reason is the excessively high prices, ever soaring higher.
('19', 309, 1, 3, 669741) Because of the high prices, milk and ghee have become scarce.
('19', 309, 1, 4, 669803) Where people need wheat in their diet, they do not get it either.
('19', 309, 1, 5, 669869) Consequently, the mother’s milk continues to deteriorate in quality day by day and, when it stops altogether, the baby has to go without good milk, or a sufficient quantity of it, though the mother may well be aware of its needs.
('19', 309, 1, 6, 670099) During the cold days, sufficient clothing is not available.
('19', 309, 1, 7, 670159) The comforts in the house are also inadequate.
('19', 309, 1, 8, 670206) Thus, there are so many adverse circumstances that it is difficult to bring down the terrific rate of child mortality pointed out by Mr. Khandwala.
('19', 309, 1, 9, 670354) Even so, remedial measures must be taken.
('19', 309, 1, 10, 670396) They are easy enough.
('19', 309, 1, 11, 670418) If the education of the people is put on a sound footing, they will easily acquire some general knowledge about child care.
('19', 309, 1, 12, 670542) Mean while, small booklets explaining rules of child care may be written in very simple language and circulated, and parents may be educated through lectures.
('19', 309, 1, 13, 670701) Everyone can, with a little effort, save himself from moist air to some extent.
('19', 309, 1, 14, 670781) The moisture within and round about the house can be removed by our own efforts.
('19', 309, 1, 15, 670862) It should not be impossible to buy milk for the children, even by economizing in other matters, if need be.
('19', 309, 1, 16, 670970) More than anything else, milk is a perfect food.
('19', 309, 1, 17, 671019) Every man should exercise self control in the matter of sex and have children only when he is fit for the purpose and capable of looking after them.
('19', 309, 1, 18, 671168) Knowing, at least, that to bring forth chidren in such difficult times is a terrible violence, one needs to control one’s desire.
('19', 309, 1, 19, 671298) It is not at all difficult to understand the rules of sound health.
('19', 309, 1, 20, 671366) The high cost of living is an evil for which, we believe, a remedy will somehow be found.
('19', 309, 1, 21, 671456) If the people’s income increases, the high prices would be easy to bear.
('19', 309, 1, 22, 671529) We have no doubt, then, that either the prices will come down or people’s income will increase.
('19', 309, 1, 23, 671625) Our duty, all the same, is to take steps to bring down the prices.
('19', 309, 1, 24, 671692) This, however, is quite a separate problem and a big one.
('19', 309, 1, 25, 671750) We shall consider it some other time.
('19', 309, 1, 26, 671788) We hope that every reader who is a public worker will take all the steps he can to reduce the rate of mortality among infants.

('19', 313, 1, 4, 676907) I know that, very likely, my words will not be fully understood by those here since the Arya Samaj is not as strong elsewhere as it is in the Punjab in the north.
('19', 313, 1, 5, 677070) But, what with the various writings, sermons and speeches which I had the opportunity of studying while in South Africa, I can tell you this truth from my own experience.

('19', 313, 1, 16, 678239) Sir Alfred Lyall writes in the book of his that real dharma spreads so silently that the people do not even know that it does.

('19', 316, 3, 4, 682719) DEAR MISS PETERSEN,
('19', 316, 4, 5, 682739) I was delighted to hear from you after a long absence.

('19', 316, 4, 7, 682935) I can thoroughly appreciate the Christian sentiment that friends and relations should gather together and have sweet communion during the Xmas season.
('19', 316, 4, 8, 683086) I must confess to you that Miss Faering’s presence in the Ashram is uplifting for us all.
('19', 316, 4, 9, 683176) She is such a good natured loving girl with all the loftiest aspirations that anyone can be capable of.
('19', 316, 4, 10, 683280) We are all looking forward to meeting her again.
('19', 316, 4, 11, 683329) I only wish that she will be able to keep her health here and become a better and a stronger Christian for her presence at the Ashram.
('19', 316, 4, 12, 683464) As I have so often told her, her living at the Ashram can be justified only if she not only retains undiminished her Christianity but that, in the environment of the Ashram, it becomes purer and more ref[ined] than ever before.
('19', 316, 4, 13, 683692) I consider myself a Hindu of Hindus.
('19', 316, 4, 14, 683729) I believe that I have a fine perception of the truth of Hinduism and the priceless lesson I have learnt from it is that I should not wish that others may become Hindus but that they become best specimens in their own faith.
('19', 316, 4, 15, 683953) I hold an unfortified day cast in your lot with me here.
('19', 316, 4, 16, 684010) Let not the Indian summer frighten you.
('19', 316, 4, 17, 684050) I can easily arrange for you to pass the two hottest months of the year in a cool place.
('19', 316, 4, 18, 684139) There are many such in India.
('19', 316, 4, 19, 684169) They are not inaccessible.

('19', 317, 2, 3, 684323) January 13, 1920
('19', 317, 3, 4, 684340) DEAR SIR GEORGE BARNES, I enclose herewith a cablegram 1 I have received from South Africa.
('19', 317, 3, 5, 684432) You will perhaps easily understand reference to the Kruger dorp Case 2 .
('19', 317, 3, 6, 684505) It means that the partial protection that was attempted to be secured by the new Act has been undone by the latest judgment.
('19', 317, 3, 7, 684630) The judgment is under appeal, that assuming that the appeal also is decided against us the verdict cannot be accepted.
('19', 317, 3, 8, 684749) Courts of law provide no remedy where the law itself is defective.
('19', 317, 3, 9, 684816) This was forcibly illustrated when a High Court judgment 3 upset the South African practice which recognized Indians’ marriages as lawful and you know that the legislation of 1914 4 remedied the mischief created by the judgment in question and I trust that you will see to it and instruct Sir Benjamin Roberston that the right of Indians to hold landed property by forming corporations otherwise is not in any way interfered with.
('19', 317, 3, 10, 685247) The second point raised in the cablegram is in connection with the Commission that is now sitting to consider the proposed extension of the power of the Municipalities.
('19', 317, 3, 11, 685416) It does seem strange that one should ever have to dread extension of popular power, but here where the power is sought in order to crush the very life of the unrepresented people, any further extension of such power is really a crime.
('19', 317, 3, 12, 685651) I hope therefore that Sir Benjamin Robertson will see that any law that may be passed to extend the existing power of the municipalities of South Africa will duly safe guard the rights of Indians who are totally unrepresented in the municipalities of the Transvaal and the [Orange] Free State and only partially at the Cape and Natal.
('19', 317, 3, 13, 685986) The East African question is, you may have noticed, becoming more and more troublesome.

('19', 319, 9, 15, 689313) 173. IS BOYCOTT SWADESHI?
('19', 319, 10, 16, 689339) Mr. Baptista 3 has addressed himself to showing that boycott is not only the same as swadeshi in effect but is superior to it.
('19', 319, 10, 17, 689466) His reasons for saying so are that, whilst it fully serves the purpose of swadeshi in that it stimulates the use of home made articles, it produces an effect upon the British merchant and manufacturer by touching his pocket.
('19', 319, 10, 18, 689691) Mr. Baptista adds that my opposition to boycott being purely a spiritual conception, is not understood by the British people, whereas they have always recognized boycott as a perfectly constitutional and legitimate weapon which they understand.
('19', 319, 10, 19, 689936) To say that boycott is the same as swadeshi even in effect is not to understand either.
('19', 319, 10, 20, 690024) Swadeshi is an eternal principle whose neglect has brought
('19', 319, 11, 21, 690083) 1 The reference is to the article “The Parties of the Future” which Aiyer had requested Gandhiji to glance over.
('19', 319, 11, 22, 690196) 2 This, in Gandhiji’s hand, indicates the file in which the letter was to be placed.
('19', 319, 11, 23, 690281) 3 Joseph Baptista; nationalist leader who was associated with the Home Rule Movement
('19', 320, 0, 1, 690366) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 321
('19', 320, 1, 2, 690414) untold grief to mankind.
('19', 320, 1, 3, 690439) It means production and distribution of articles manufactured in one’s own country.
('19', 320, 1, 4, 690523) In its narrow and present form it means the saving of sixty crore rupees annually through the instrumentality of the peasant population.
('19', 320, 1, 5, 690660) It therefore also means giving 72 p.c.
('19', 320, 1, 6, 690699) of the population a much needed supplementary industry.
('19', 320, 1, 7, 690755) Swadeshi is a constructive programme.
('19', 320, 1, 8, 690793) Boycott, on the other hand, is a temporary makeshift resorted to in order to compel the hands of the British people by deliberately making an attempt to inflict a monetary loss upon them.
('19', 320, 1, 9, 690981) Boycott, therefore, operates as an undue influence brought in to secure one’s purpose.
('19', 320, 1, 10, 691068) It may indirectly result, but not unless it is persistent and prolonged, in greater manufacture at home, but it certainly means the introduction of another disturbing factor, for, boycott does not mean exclusion of all foreign goods.
('19', 320, 1, 11, 691302) It means exclusion of British goods only.
('19', 320, 1, 12, 691344) It, therefore, involves greater encouragement of other foreign agencies, as for instance, Japanese and American.
('19', 320, 1, 13, 691457) I certainly do not contemplate with equanimity the evergrowing influence of Japan upon Indian trade and commerce.
('19', 320, 1, 14, 691571) Boycott to the effective has to be fairly universal whereas the observance of swadeshi by a single person is so much to the national good.
('19', 320, 1, 15, 691710) One can make boycott successful only by an appeal to angry passions.
('19', 320, 1, 16, 691779) It may therefore result in unintended consequences and may even lead to a permanent estrangement between parties.
('19', 320, 1, 17, 691893) Mr. Baptista, however, denies that appeal to angry passions is a necessary consequence of boycott especially if some one like me were to manage the movement.
('19', 320, 1, 18, 692051) I venture to challenge the position.
('19', 320, 1, 19, 692088) A man suffering from an injustice is exposed to the temptations of having his worst passions roused on the slightest pretext.
('19', 320, 1, 20, 692214) By asking him to boycott British goods you inculcate the idea of punishing the wrongdoer.
('19', 320, 1, 21, 692304) And punishment necessarily evokes anger.
('19', 320, 1, 22, 692345) Mr. Zahoor Ahmed who has also written to combat my position says that withdrawal of co operation is the same in essence as boycott, only it is far less effective because it is almost impossible of execution.
('19', 320, 1, 23, 692553) Now, if I am serving co operating with a wrongdoer, I am participating in the wrong.
('19', 320, 1, 24, 692638) Therefore withdrawal of co operation becomes a duty when a wrong is serious.
('19', 320, 1, 25, 692715) And even if one man ceases to co operate it is effective to that extent because of the performance of his duty by even one man.
('19', 320, 1, 26, 692843) But since boycott is a punishment and as no punishment can be a duty, boycott unless it produces its effect is wasted energy.
('19', 320, 1, 27, 692969) And boycott by half a dozen persons is like hitting an elephant with a straw.
('19', 321, 0, 1, 693047) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 321, 1, 2, 693089) I admit, however, that my fundamental opposition to boycott is based on a spiritual conception.
('19', 321, 1, 3, 693185) But that is to say that I am endeavouring to extend the spiritual law to the political world.
('19', 321, 1, 4, 693279) I deny however that the British people will not understand it.
('19', 321, 1, 5, 693342) I had no difficulty in making the Europeans of South Africa understand and appreciate it.
('19', 321, 1, 6, 693432) Nor, in order to render it effective, is it necessary to follow the spiritual conception of a spiritual act.
('19', 321, 1, 7, 693541) My contention is that an act purely spiritual is the simplest to understand and the easiest to execute.
('19', 321, 1, 8, 693645) Spirituality is nothing if it is not eminently practical.
('19', 321, 1, 9, 693703) It is not difficult to understand that we must wash our hands when they are dirty.
('19', 321, 1, 10, 693786) It is equally simple to do so, yet it is essentially a spiritual practice.
('19', 321, 1, 11, 693861) Mens sana in corpore sano is a doctrine of the soul.
('19', 321, 1, 12, 693914) And even if we accept the necessity of cleaning dirty hands without a spiritual conception of cleanliness, so may we accept the practical failure of boycott and the practical necessity under definite conditions of non co operation without waiting to understand their spiritual basis.
('19', 321, 1, 13, 694198) Is boycott, then, practical?
('19', 321, 1, 14, 694227) Mr. Baptista has approved of boycott of the British goods.
('19', 321, 1, 15, 694286) I hold that if the highest and permanent good of the country cannot be sufficient incentive to our merchants for supporting swadeshi to the exclusion of foreign goods an appeal to the merchants that, in order to bring justice from the British people, they shall temporarily stop their custom, will, I venture to submit, fall flat.
('19', 321, 1, 16, 694617) Boycott after the event is of no consequence.
('19', 321, 1, 17, 694663) Boycott to influence the result must be instant action.
('19', 321, 1, 18, 694719) The area of boycott is too large for any organization that can be brought into being at a moment’s notice.
('19', 321, 1, 19, 694826) And I can see no difficulty about British manufacturers introducing their wares into India through Japan or America even as Germany years ago introduced into India her goods through England.
('19', 321, 1, 20, 695017) I swear by swadeshi because it is an evolutionary process gaining strength as it goes forward.
('19', 321, 1, 21, 695112) Any organization can serve it.
('19', 321, 1, 22, 695143) It is independent of the justice or the injustice of the rulers or the British people.
('19', 321, 1, 23, 695230) It is its own reward.
('19', 321, 1, 24, 695252) “There is no waste of energy; no failure, even a little practice of this dharma saves one from a great danger.” Swadeshi and boycott are, therefore, not the same but are at the opposite poles.
('19', 321, 1, 25, 695445) Young India, 14 1 1920
('19', 322, 0, 1, 695468) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 323
('19', 322, 1, 2, 695516) 174. THE REFORMS RESOLUTION IN THE CONGRESS
('19', 322, 2, 3, 695560) The divergence of views on the Reforms Resolution, summ arized in one of our notes 1, is not to be wondered at.
('19', 322, 2, 4, 695672) Compromises never give complete satisfaction to all parties.
('19', 322, 2, 5, 695733) In their very nature they must just fall short of that and yet be acceptable to all.
('19', 322, 2, 6, 695818) In our opinion the country did get the lead through the Congress that it was possible to give it.
('19', 322, 2, 7, 695916) The Congress must, if it is to serve the country, more and more tend to represent not one view but many, and that not merely in the Subjects Committee, but on the open platform.
('19', 322, 2, 8, 696094) There is no denying the fact there are several parties in the country.
('19', 322, 2, 9, 696165) Extremist and Moderate do not cover all parties.
('19', 322, 2, 10, 696214) There are, for instance, in the Extremist camp Mr. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar’s, Mr. Das’, and Lokamanya Tilak’s parties.
('19', 322, 2, 11, 696331) No doubt they sailed under the Extremist flag.
('19', 322, 2, 12, 696378) But as differences become accentured, as they must be in course of time, each group will begin to assert itself.
('19', 322, 2, 13, 696491) The Hon’ble Pandit Malaviyaji represents a body of opinion distinct from the Extremist.
('19', 322, 2, 14, 696579) Similarly in the Moderate camp there are undoubtedly divisions, which as time goes on will become sharper, rather than otherwise, and with a proper constitution there is no reason why the Congress should not represent a resultant of all these different views thrashed out with calmness and becoming dignity on the Congress an open and reasoned discussion took place before the delegates, on a matter of the greatest importance to the country, and for the first time were those elaborate preparations made in order to ascertain by their votes the decision of the Congress.
('19', 322, 2, 15, 697151) That in itself, in our opinion, was something worth attaining.
('19', 322, 2, 16, 697214) But there was more than this.
('19', 322, 2, 17, 697244) No doubt it was open to either party to push the matter to a division.
('19', 322, 2, 18, 697315) We cannot accept Mrs. Besant’s view that L[okamanya] Tilak had told his followers to vote for Mr. Gandhi’s amendment if he had held out, and even if Mrs. Besant’s information is correct, it would hardly have been proper for Mr. Gandhi to have pushed the matters to such an extreme.
('19', 322, 2, 19, 697597) His amendment alone brought forth Mr. Pal’s.
('19', 322, 2, 20, 697642) The latter was a purely tactical move.
('19', 322, 2, 21, 697681) Had the audience been called upon merely to decide between the original proposition, i.e., without co operation and thanks, and Mr. Gandhi’s, with thanks, a division would have been a duty.
('19', 322, 3, 22, 697871) 1 These have not been reproduced here.
('19', 322, 3, 23, 697910) For a detailed discussion on the subject, however, vide “The Congress”, 11 1 1920.
('19', 323, 0, 1, 697993) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 323, 1, 2, 698035) Mr. Pal’s amendment came as a feeler and also was an earnest of the extremist groups to conciliate an opposing amendment, so long as they could consistently do so.
('19', 323, 1, 3, 698199) Mr. Pal’s amendment could not be accepted because of the offensive word ‘use’ in it.
('19', 323, 1, 4, 698284) Naturally therefore a third amendment providing a middle course had to be framed, and comfort lies not merely in the fact of the compromise but in the fact that all were anxious to avoid an open division.
('19', 323, 1, 5, 698489) Surely, for the country it means that the Congress desires to co operate with the authorities in so far as that co operation can hasten the advent of the responsible government, and to thank Mr. Montagu for his valuable labours on the Reforms.
('19', 323, 1, 6, 698733) We would certainly have liked it better if the graceful language of the original amendment had been accepted, if thanks had been expressed in warmer terms and extended to Lord Sinha.
('19', 323, 1, 7, 698916) But it would have been wrong to divide the house after the principle of co operation and thanks were granted by the three leaders.
('19', 323, 1, 8, 699047) We are unable to associate ourselves with the suggestion that L. Tilak in accepting the amendment wanted to use Messrs Malaviya and Gandhi as his tools, and if they allowed themselves to be so used, it would not be the Lokamanya who would be to blame, but Messrs Malaviya and Gandhi would be clearly held blameworthy for their simplicity.
('19', 323, 1, 9, 699386) For as party formation progresses, we suppose it would be considered quite the proper thing for party leaders to use others as tools so long as there are any to be used.
('19', 323, 1, 10, 699556) Care will therefore have to be taken rather to purify our politics, than, for fear of being used as tools, to hesitate to take the right course.
('19', 323, 1, 11, 699701) L. Tilak represents a definite school of thought of which he makes no secret.
('19', 323, 1, 12, 699779) He considers that everything is fair in politics.
('19', 323, 1, 13, 699829) We have joined issue with him in that conception of political life.
('19', 323, 1, 14, 699897) We consider that political life of the country will become thoroughly corrupt if we import Western tactics and methods.
('19', 323, 1, 15, 700017) We believe that nothing but the strictest adherence to honesty, fairplay and charity can advance the true interests of the country.
('19', 323, 1, 16, 700149) But we refuse, because of the essential difference just pointed out, to believe that, in accepting the amendment, L. Tilak was guided by any motive other than that of meeting his opponents’ views so far as it was possible.
('19', 323, 1, 17, 700372) On the whole, therefore, in our opinion, the analysis given by The Times of India is the only true analysis of the position ultimately arrived at under the compromise.
('19', 323, 1, 18, 700540) Young India, 14 1 1920

('19', 326, 1, 2, 703694) we are that joyfully.

('19', 327, 1, 2, 705613) 179. THE HUNTER COMMITTEE
('19', 327, 2, 3, 705639) This Committee has completed its work in regard to Ahmedabad.
('19', 327, 2, 4, 705701) The evidence placed before it goes to prove that the first mistake was made by the people and not by the Government.
('19', 327, 2, 5, 705818) We should ignore the fact of Mr. Gandhi’s arrest, for, when the Government arrests a person who happens to be popular among the people if the belief comes to prevail that on no account can the Government arrest such a person, the work of Government just cannot be carried on.
('19', 327, 2, 6, 706094) True, the Government should have valid reason for arresting the person.
('19', 327, 2, 7, 706166) It is also true that, before making the arrest the Government must have made adequate arrangements to preserve order.
('19', 327, 2, 8, 706284) Even so, because the Government arrests a particular person, the people do not get the right to start killing and burning.
('19', 327, 2, 9, 706407) Besides, the police had not done anything in Ahmedabad on April 11 which could provide the people with even the semblance of an excuse for doing what they did.
('19', 327, 2, 10, 706567) Thus, the evidence goes to prove that, in killing and setting buildings on fire, the people erred grievously and harmed Ahmeda bad.
('19', 327, 2, 11, 706699) We also hear it said that the Government released Mr. Gandhi only because of the riots.
('19', 327, 2, 12, 706787) A look at the dates will show that this is not true, since, when Mr. Gandhi was released, there had been no violence in Ahmedabad.
('19', 327, 2, 13, 706918) He was released in the afternoon of April 11. The decision to set him free in Bombay was made on the evening of the 10th.
('19', 327, 2, 14, 707040) Nothing had happened in Ahmedabad up to that time.
('19', 327, 2, 15, 707091) We know, however, that much harm was done because of the violence and arson.
('19', 327, 2, 16, 707168) Many people have had to go to jail; a large fine has been imposed on Ahmedabad and the city has had reason to feel ashamed.
('19', 327, 2, 17, 707292) It would be somewhat brazen faced to criticize or denounce the Government for the steps it took to quell the riots.
('19', 327, 2, 18, 707408) Compared to the Punjab, the Government here has been so forbearing that it would not be right on our part to condemn its minor lapses; even so, when we are examining the question from all points of views, we are bound to point out the lapses too.
('19', 327, 2, 19, 707655) There was no need for Martial Law and for the order issued under it.
('19', 327, 2, 20, 707724) It resulted in the death of innocent people.
('19', 327, 2, 21, 707769) An unjust and one sided order of fine on Nadiad and Barejadi was issued.
('19', 328, 0, 1, 707842) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 329
('19', 328, 1, 2, 707890) were evident mistakes by the Government.
('19', 328, 1, 3, 707931) The Hunter Committee is to some extent the means of getting them rectified.
('19', 328, 1, 4, 708007) The discussion on satyagraha between the members of the Committee on the one hand and Mr. Gandhi on the other is note worthy.
('19', 328, 1, 5, 708133) We shall, therefore, try to reproduce it, as faithfully as possible.
('19', 328, 1, 6, 708202) The discussion brings out effectively that satyagraha is a remedy for violence and a means of safeguarding the rights of the people.

('19', 329, 2, 3, 709788) DELHI, January 18, 1920
('19', 329, 3, 4, 709812) J. L. MAFFEY, ESQ., C.I.E. PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE VICEROY
('19', 329, 4, 5, 709887) I have come here in connection with the Khilafat Deputation and to form part of the deputation that is to wait on His Excellency tomorrow.
('19', 329, 4, 6, 710026) I had now read the Statement 1 to be submitted to His Excellency before I was invited.
('19', 329, 4, 7, 710113) I did not like the manner of presentation of the case.
('19', 329, 4, 8, 710168) It is vague and in general terms, whereas at a critical moment like this, the statement should have been dignified, brief, precise, as unargumentative as possible, confining itself merely to bare facts and presenting the case from the highest platform and not from the platform of diplomacy.
('19', 329, 4, 9, 710460) But I observe that it is now too late to redraw the whole statement and to take up any more of His Excellency’s time.
('19', 329, 4, 10, 710578) I therefore suggested that there should be at least an accurate statement of what is about the least that will satisfy Moslem sentiment.
('19', 329, 4, 11, 710715) They have now drawn up an addendum which is incorporated in the statement.
('19', 329, 4, 12, 710790) I venture to trust that His Excellency will have no objection to the addendum.
('19', 329, 4, 13, 710869) I enclose herewith copy of the statement with the addition.
('19', 329, 4, 14, 710929) I am sorry that it is written in a slovenly manner.
('19', 329, 4, 15, 710981) I hope to send you a reprint in the course of the day but, in order to save time, I am sending you meanwhile what I have.
('19', 329, 4, 16, 711103) I hope that you are keeping well.
('19', 329, 4, 17, 711137) I was distressed to read in the papers that Lady Chelmsford was ailing in Calcutta.
('19', 329, 4, 18, 711221) I trust she is completely recovered.
