('19', 330, 1, 2, 711852) 182. NOTE ON TALKS’S LETTER 1
('19', 330, 2, 3, 711882) [DELHI, After January 18, 1920] I naturally feel the greatest diffidence about joining issue with the Lokamanya in matters involving questions of interpretation of religious work.
('19', 330, 2, 4, 712062) But there are things in or about which instinct transcends even interpretation.
('19', 330, 2, 5, 712142) For me there is no conflict between the two texts quoted by the Lokamanya.
('19', 330, 2, 6, 712217) The Buddhist text lays down an eternal principle.
('19', 330, 2, 7, 712267) The text from the Bhagavad Gita shows to me how the principle of conquering hate by love, untruth by truth, can and must be applied.
('19', 330, 2, 8, 712400) If it be true that God metes out the same measure to us that we mete out to others, it follows that if we would escape condign punishment, we may not return anger but gentleness even against anger.
('19', 330, 2, 9, 712598) And this is the law not for the unworldly but essentially for the worldly.
('19', 330, 2, 10, 712673) With deference to the Lokamanya, I venture to say that it betrays mental laziness to think that the world is not for sadhus.
('19', 330, 2, 11, 712798) The epitome of all religions is to promote purushartha, and purushartha is nothing but a desperate attempt to become sadhu, i.e., to become a gentleman in every sense of the term.
('19', 330, 2, 12, 712978) Finally, when I wrote the sentence about ‘everything being fair in politics’ according to the Lokamanya’s creed, I had in mind his oft repeated quotation '
('19', 330, 3, 13, 713134) 2. To me it enunciates bad law.
('19', 330, 3, 14, 713166) And I shall not despair of the Lokamanya with all his acumen agreeably surprising India one day with a philosophical dissertation proving the falsity of the doctrine.
('19', 330, 4, 15, 713333) 1 This was in reply to the following letter dated Poona, January 18, 1920, from Lokamanya Tilak: “I am sorry to see that in your article on ‘Reforms Resolution’ in the last issue, you have represented me as holding that I considered ‘everything fair in politics’.
('19', 330, 4, 16, 713597) I write this to you to say that my view is not correctly represented therein.
('19', 330, 4, 17, 713675) Politics is a game of worldly people and not of sadhus, and instead of the maxim as preached by Buddha, I prefer to rely on the maxim of Shri Krishna .
('19', 330, 4, 18, 713827) That explains the whole difference and also the meaning of my phrase ‘responsive co operation’.
('19', 330, 4, 19, 713923) Both methods are equally honest and righteous but the one is more suited to this world than the other.
('19', 330, 4, 20, 714026) Any further explanation about the difference will be found in my Gita Rahasya.” For the article referred to, vide “The Reforms Resolution in the Congress”, 14 1 1920. 2 Wickedness unto the wicked

('19', 331, 2, 4, 714379) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 28 1 1920
('19', 331, 3, 5, 714415) 183. AN APPEAL TO MADRAS
('19', 331, 4, 6, 714440) I use the word Madras here in its popular sense, meaning the people of the whole of the Madras Presidency, speaking all the Dravidian languages.
('19', 331, 4, 7, 714585) I observe that Mrs. Besant was disappointed that the proceedings of the Congress were conducted mainly in Hindustani, and she has therefore come to the amazing conclusion that it became a Provincial rather than a National Assembly.
('19', 331, 4, 8, 714817) I entertain a very high regard for Mrs. Besant and her services to India.
('19', 331, 4, 9, 714891) No one has popularised the idea of Home Rule for India with so much success as she.
('19', 331, 4, 10, 714975) The best of us, much younger in age, are unable to approach her in her industry, zeal and organising ability, all devoted to the service of India.
('19', 331, 4, 11, 715122) She has devoted the best part of her mature life to the service of India and she has deservedly attained popularity in India second perhaps only to that of Lokamanya Tilak.
('19', 331, 4, 12, 715295) But, for the present moment her views being unacceptable to a large body of educated Indians, she has become somewhat unpopular, and it grieves me to have to dissent publicly from her view about Hindustani making the Congress provincial.
('19', 331, 4, 13, 715533) In my humble opinion it is a grave error of judgement, and duty compels me to draw attention to it.
('19', 331, 4, 14, 715633) I have attended all the Congress sessions but one since 1915. I have studied them specially in order to study the utility of Hindustani compared to English for the conduct of its proceedings.
('19', 331, 4, 15, 715825) I have spoken to hundreds of delegates and thousandes of visitors and I have perhaps covered a larger area and seen a much larger number of people, literate and illiterate, than any public man, not excluding Mrs. Besant and Lokamanya Tilak, and I have come to the deliberate conclusion that no language except Hindustani a resultant of Hindi and Urdu can possibly become a national medium for exchange of ideas or for the conduct of national proceedings.
('19', 331, 4, 16, 716280) It is also my deliberate opinion based upon extensive experience that the nation has very materially suffered by reason of the proceedings of the Congress having been conducted almost
('19', 331, 5, 17, 716464) 1 Truth even unto the wicked
('19', 332, 0, 1, 716493) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 333
('19', 332, 1, 2, 716541) entirely in English except during the last two years.
('19', 332, 1, 3, 716595) I further wish to state as a fact that, barring the presidency of Madras everywhere else the majority of the visitors and delegates to the National Congress have always been able to understand more Hindustani than English.
('19', 332, 1, 4, 716818) The astounding result therefore has been that the Congress has been national throughout all these long years only as a spectacle but never for its real educative value.
('19', 332, 1, 5, 716987) In any other country in the world, an assembly of this character that has become progressively popular from year to year would have, during thirty four years of life, given a political education that would have entered every home because the people would have had various questions thrashed out before them in their own language.
('19', 332, 1, 6, 717317) Whatever therefore the shortcomings of the last Congress, it has certainly been more fully national than any of its predecessors, by reason of the majority of the delegates and visitors having understood the proceedings.
('19', 332, 1, 7, 717538) If the audience was weary of Mrs. Besant, it was not becasue it was indifferent or disrespectful to her but because it could not follow her speech, interesting and able though it was.
('19', 332, 1, 8, 717722) And as national consciousness develops and as the appetite for political knowledge and education grows, as it must, it will become more and more difficult, and rightly so, for a speaker, no matter how able and popular, to command the attention of a popular audience if he spoke in English.
('19', 332, 1, 9, 718012) I therefore appeal to the people of Madras Presidency to recognize the national necessity for public men to learn Hindustani.
('19', 332, 1, 10, 718138) Audiences outside Madras can more or less understand Hindustani without difficulty.
('19', 332, 1, 11, 718222) Dayananda Saraswati enthralled audiences outside Northern India with his Hindustani eloquence and could be understood by even the common people without difficulty.
('19', 332, 1, 12, 718386) That means that out of a population of three hundred and fifteen millions only over thirty eight millions composing the Madras Presidency cannot follow a Hindustani speaker.
('19', 332, 1, 13, 718560) I have deducted the Mohammedan population for it is common knowledge that the majority of the Mohammedans of Madras Presidencyunderstand Hindustani.
('19', 332, 1, 14, 718709) The question therefore is: what is the duty of the thirty eight million inhabitants of that Presidency?
('19', 332, 1, 15, 718813) Should India for their sake learn English?
('19', 332, 1, 16, 718856) Or should they for the sake of two hundred seventy seven million inhabitants of India learn Hindustani?
('19', 332, 1, 17, 718960) The late Justice Krishnaswami, with his unerring instinct, recognized Hindustani as the only possible medium of expression between the different parts of India.
('19', 332, 1, 18, 719121) I am not aware that the proposition is seriously challenged by anybody at the present
('19', 333, 0, 1, 719207) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 333, 1, 2, 719249) moment.
('19', 333, 1, 3, 719257) It is not possible for thousands of people to make English their common tongue, and it would be highly undesirable even if it were possible, for the simple reason that the higher and technical knowledge being acquired through English cannot percolate to the masses, as it would if it became current among the upper classes through any of the vernaculars.
('19', 333, 1, 4, 719612) It is easier, for instance, to translate the writings of Sir J.C. Bose from Bengalee into Gujarati than it is to translate Huxley from English into Gujarati.
('19', 333, 1, 5, 719770) And what does the proposition that the Madrasis should learn Hindustani for the sake of the rest of India amount to?
('19', 333, 1, 6, 719887) It simply means that those public workers in Madras who want to work outside India and who want to take part in national assemblies outside the Madras Presidency should devote an hour a day for one year to learning Hindustani.
('19', 333, 1, 7, 720114) Such an effort would enable several thousand Madrasis to pick up sufficient Hindustani to enable them to follow at least the drift of the Congress proceedings at the end of a year’s study.
('19', 333, 1, 8, 720303) They have got in several parts of the Presidency Hindi Prachar Offices where HIndustani is taught free of charge to all who wish to learn.
('19', 333, 1, 9, 720442) I appeal to Mrs. Besant, who is already devoting New India from time to time to the cause of Hindustani learning, to support my appeal.
('19', 333, 2, 10, 720578) Young India, 21 1 1920
('19', 333, 3, 11, 720601) 184. SPEECH AT MEERUT MEETING 1
('19', 333, 4, 12, 720633) January 22, 1920
('19', 333, 5, 13, 720650) After expressing his gratitude to the citizens of Meerut and the volunteers for the hearty reception they had accorded to him, he said that of all the problems that faced India to day that of the Khilafat was the most important, for it was the problem of our Muslim brethren.
('19', 333, 5, 14, 720926) His English and Hindu friends had been asking him why a staunch Hindu like him interested himself so keenly in the Khailafat question.
('19', 333, 5, 15, 721061) His answer to them all was that he and his Hindu brothers wanted to maintain peace and love with the 7 crores of Mussalmans in India.
('19', 333, 5, 16, 721195) Until the Khilafat question was settled according to Muslim ideas of justice, there could be no peace in India.
('19', 333, 5, 17, 721307) The Government might succeed in suppressing discontent for a time, but men, whose

('19', 334, 1, 2, 721618) feelings were seriously hurt, could not live in peace for ever.
('19', 334, 2, 3, 721682) He wanted to say to his Muslim brothers that there was no means more effective to settle the question than satyagraha.
('19', 334, 2, 4, 721801) They could never settle the Khilafat question by physical force.
('19', 334, 2, 5, 721866) But they could themselves see the great chances of success if they adopted satyagraha.

('19', 334, 18, 32, 723290) 185. INTERVIEW TO S.W. CLEMES
('19', 334, 19, 33, 723320) [MEERUT, January 22, 1920]
('19', 334, 20, 34, 723347) Mr. Gandhi, what can nations of the West do in furthering the all round development of the East, and particularly of India?
('19', 334, 20, 35, 723471) Mr. Gandhi answered the question indirectly: India is just now in the state of unlearning.
('19', 334, 20, 36, 723562) She has learned a lot that is useless and unprofitable.
('19', 334, 20, 37, 723618) From my observation of the West, and particularly of your own country, I have learned two outstanding facts: First, cleanliness; second, energy.
('19', 334, 20, 38, 723763) I am fully convinced that my people cannot advance spiritually, until they clean up.
('19', 334, 20, 39, 723848) Your people are wonderfully energetic.
('19', 334, 20, 40, 723887) To a large extent, it has been energy after
('19', 335, 0, 1, 723931) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 335, 1, 2, 723973) things material.
('19', 335, 1, 3, 723990) If Indian people could have that same amount of energy, rightly directed, they would receive a great blessing.
('19', 335, 2, 4, 724101) Mr. Gandhi, will you kindly tell me how Christianity can best help India, in
('19', 335, 3, 5, 724178) view of the spirit of nationalism that is abroad?
('19', 335, 3, 6, 724228) He replied: What we need, most of all, is sympathy.
('19', 335, 3, 7, 724280) When I was down in Africa, I found this illustration.
('19', 335, 3, 8, 724334) I had to dig some artesian wells.
('19', 335, 3, 9, 724368) In order to search the pure flowing streams, I had to dig deep.
('19', 335, 3, 10, 724432) Many of the people who come out here to study my people only scratch the surface.
('19', 335, 3, 11, 724514) If they would dig deep by means of sympathy, they would find a stream of life there, pure and clear.
('19', 335, 4, 12, 724615) And will you kindlly tell me, Mr. Gandhi, what book or person has influenced you the most?
('19', 335, 4, 13, 724706) He frankly confessed that he was not an omnivorous reader, but rather a careful selector of the very best.
('19', 335, 4, 14, 724813) The order in which he spoke of the books was as follows: The Bible, Ruskin, Tolstoi.
('19', 335, 4, 15, 724898) Speaking of the Bible, he said: There have been many times when I did not know which way to turn.
('19', 335, 4, 16, 724996) But I have gone to the Bible, and particularly the New Testament, and have drawn strength from its message.
('19', 335, 5, 17, 725104) I was anxious to know how our Meerut Graduates’ Association, composed of
('19', 335, 6, 18, 725177) the finest of the educated men in the city, could further the city’s welfare.
('19', 335, 6, 19, 725255) In reply to
('19', 335, 7, 20, 725267) the question, he gave me his one word.

('19', 341, 1, 2, 734037) 193. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('19', 341, 2, 3, 734064) [Before January 25, 1920] The following is the extension of a cable received by me from Mr. Aswat, Chairman of the British Indian Association, Transvaal, regarding the Krugersdorp Municiplality v.
('19', 341, 2, 4, 734261) Dadoo, Ltd., referred to in the memorandum presented to the Union Premier:
('19', 341, 3, 5, 734336) The Court has set aside the transfers.
('19', 341, 3, 6, 734375) It held that the formation of Indian companies for the purpose of acquiring fixed property is illegal.
('19', 341, 3, 7, 734478) It declared transfers so obtained were fraudem legis, saying that legislation cannot be
('19', 341, 4, 8, 734566) laughed at (Section 130).
('19', 341, 4, 9, 734592) The Gold Law was intended to prevent indiscriminate mingling of Coloured [persons and] Europeans.
('19', 341, 4, 10, 734690) Further in the judgment in Potchefstroom, under the Local Ordinance 9, 1912, the magistrate upholds the Council’s contention that the Asiatic’s presence causes annoyance and detriment to European commerce and on that ground holds Indians as undesirable.
('19', 341, 4, 11, 734944) Both judgments mean the ruination of the community.
('19', 341, 4, 12, 734996) Appeals noted.
('19', 341, 4, 13, 735011) Europeans tendering evidence before the local Government Commission are specialising on the Indian question, urging complete autonomy for municipalities.
('19', 341, 4, 14, 735165) Make representations to the proper quarters immediately.
('19', 341, 4, 15, 735222) The Association prays to hold meetings throughout India.
('19', 341, 4, 16, 735279) New Act 37 gives no protection even to old companies and traders.
('19', 341, 4, 17, 735345) The position is most precarious.
('19', 341, 4, 18, 735378) Strenuous action is imperative for the sake of saving the community.
('19', 341, 4, 19, 735447) This cablegram cannot fail to disconcert those who have at all studied the South African question, for, as Mr. Aswat says, it is calculated to undo even the little that the new Act was claimed to accomplish.
('19', 341, 4, 20, 735655) Dadoo, Ltd., is an old established Indian company in Krugersdorp.
('19', 341, 4, 21, 735721) It holds extensive landed property in that township, and, the meaning of the cablegram is that the transfers registered in the name of the company of landed properties are illegal, because, as the Court seems to have contended, the transaction was in fraud of the law and that legislation could not be laughed at.
('19', 341, 4, 22, 736035) I wish to say nothing regarding the propriety of the judgment or the reasoning on which it seems to be based.
('19', 341, 4, 23, 736145) Thousands of pounds’ worth of landed property is registered in the names of companies in which Indians enjoy a dominating
('19', 341, 5, 24, 736267) 1 A Gujarati translation of this appeared in Navajivan, 25 1 1920.
('19', 342, 0, 1, 736334) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 343
('19', 342, 1, 2, 736382) position.
('19', 342, 1, 3, 736392) If the judgment stands, everyone of these companies will become dispossessed of the land they have occupied for years, land which they have acquired openly and under legal advice and which has been registered in the Land Registry Office.
('19', 342, 1, 4, 736630) With the full knowledge of all the circumstances by the registrars, and only last year, when the new disabling Act was passed by the South African Legislature, we were told that the holding of land in this manner, prior to July 31 last, would not be affected by the legislation, and in justification of the measure, we were told by all the speakers in the Union Assembly that the legislation would protect existing companies and mortgages.
('19', 342, 1, 5, 737070) The judgment in question comes, therefore, as an eye opener.
('19', 342, 1, 6, 737131) I venture to submit that, even if the judgment is sound, it evidently frustrates the intention of the Legislature and deprives Indians of rights they have enjoyed without question for years past.
('19', 342, 1, 7, 737327) I hold that the impending sin 1 must be averted, even if it is to be done by special legislation, as was done in 1914 in connection with the legal recognition of Indian marriages.
('19', 342, 1, 8, 737507) The second point raised in the cablegram refers to a magisterial judgment, and it means that Indians as Indians may be declared as undesirable, not on ground of insanitation or immorality, but because they compete with the European traders to their detriment.
('19', 342, 1, 9, 737767) If this doctrine were to hold good, not a single Indian can engage in any trade whatever in South Africa 2 .
('19', 342, 1, 10, 737876) Sir Benjamin Robertson will presently sail for South Africa.
('19', 342, 1, 11, 737937) His diplomatic talent and his trusteeship will be taxed to the utmost before he secures, not a full status for the Indians in South Africa, but even a tolerably respectable footing for them to secure, i.e., the right to trade and own landed property without restriction, save such as are common to all as well in theory as in practice.
('19', 342, 1, 12, 738273) One can only hope that the
('19', 342, 2, 13, 738300) 1 The original has “sum”, evidently a misprint.
('19', 342, 2, 14, 738348) 2 A Gujarati version of the letter in Navajivan, 25 1 1920, has the following additional paragraph: “The third point raised in the cable is about the proposed increase in the powers of municipalities.
('19', 342, 2, 15, 738549) Ordinarily, everyone would welcome such an increase but, looking to what has happened in the present case, in South Africa and the other Colonies, this increase will mean investing the municipalities with power to persecute the dependent and disenfranchisedclasses.

('19', 343, 1, 3, 739390) India, 27 2 1920
('19', 343, 2, 4, 739407) 194. OFF THE RAILS
('19', 343, 3, 5, 739426) Letters, loving and not so loving, come pouring in to me; and, since I became editor, their number has increased.
('19', 343, 3, 6, 739540) I cannot publish many of them; they are not worth publishing.
('19', 343, 3, 7, 739602) Some, however, are such as may do good if published.
('19', 343, 3, 8, 739655) I received one such recently and I give it here exactly as it is.
('19', 343, 4, 9, 739721) The writer of this letter is a hard working young man.
('19', 343, 4, 10, 739776) He has patriotism, but, as one with a squint in the eye sees everything out of focus, so this friend, in the bitterness of his heart, sees everything wrong about me.
('19', 343, 4, 11, 739942) Once he had nothing but love for me; however, what with his bitterness against the British and my attitude to them free from malice, even those actions of mine which he once thought good or about which he used to be neutral seem bad to him.
('19', 343, 4, 12, 740183) Not only this; he has even found it possible to argue my incapacity from the very actions which I consider to be my best.
('19', 343, 4, 13, 740305) This is no exception.
('19', 343, 4, 14, 740327) I had this experience in South Africa and have it here too.
('19', 343, 4, 15, 740387) What is it which reduces man to such a state?
('19', 343, 4, 16, 740433) The answer to this is given in the Bhagavad Gita, in the best possible language: By constantly dwelling on objects, the mind develops attachment, from attachment grows desire, desire brings forth anger, anger clouds one’s perception, this obscures memory, from that comes loss of reason and, reason lost, one is utterly destroyed.
('19', 343, 5, 17, 740764) This is a vivid picture of the mental states as they succeed one another.
('19', 343, 5, 18, 740838) All who dwell on objects of sense do not, however, ultimately end up thus, because all do not lose self awareness completely.
('19', 343, 5, 19, 740964) With the writer of this letter, the object [on which his thought dwells] is his hatred of “bureaucracy”.
('19', 343, 5, 20, 741069) This has roused anger in him
('19', 343, 6, 21, 741098) 1 This is not reproduced here.
('19', 343, 6, 22, 741129) The correspondent had argued that Gandhiji had failed miserably in every cause he had espoused in India and that he was no longer “fit to work in politics”.
('19', 343, 6, 23, 741286) 2 Bhagavad Gita, II, 62 63
('19', 344, 0, 1, 741313) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 345
('19', 344, 1, 2, 741361) and, in the heat of his anger, he has lost his judgment of good and bad and even forgotten his former words.
('19', 344, 1, 3, 741470) I have published this letter to warn people so that they may, if possible, save themselves from this state of mind.
('19', 344, 1, 4, 741586) It is not necessary that we should be able to approve of all the actions of a “bureaucracy” or any other “cracy”.
('19', 344, 1, 5, 741700) I do not like many of its actions, but I do not hate it for that reason.
('19', 344, 1, 6, 741773) In consequence, I can point out its errors with a precision which, I think, few others show.
('19', 344, 1, 7, 741866) There must be very few who have fought it as doggedly as I have during these four years.
('19', 344, 1, 8, 741955) But, not possessed by anger, I have not lost my judgment.
('19', 344, 1, 9, 742013) That is exactly the fault this angry friend has seen in me.
('19', 344, 1, 10, 742073) Let us now examine his letter.
('19', 344, 1, 11, 742104) All his accusations are half true, and I have described half truth as falsehood multiplied one and a half times, for it confuses both.
('19', 344, 1, 12, 742239) The person who states a half truth is unaware of the incompleteness of his statement and the listener thinks that the half truth is the whole truth and accepts it as such.
('19', 344, 1, 13, 742411) It is true that only after the people of Kheda had already paid most of the revenue due from them that the payment was declared to be voluntary, but securing this was only one of the aims of the movement in Kheda.
('19', 344, 1, 14, 742625) The other result, that the Government had to reverse its stand, was an important one.
('19', 344, 1, 15, 742711) I think, and so do the thousands of men and women of Kheda, that the awakening among the people and the Government’s admission of defeat in passing the order it did were significant results.
('19', 344, 1, 16, 742902) Had the correspondent known that self interest has no place in satyagraha, he would not have blamed me in this particular matter.
('19', 344, 1, 17, 743032) That I have started a movement against varnashrama is a delusion of the writer’s; that untouchability is a part of varnashrama is a half truth.
('19', 344, 1, 18, 743176) I have declared again and again that I believe in varnashrama.
('19', 344, 1, 19, 743239) However, I have steadfastly endeavoured to rid varnashrama of the taint of untounchability by pointing out that it is sin to refuse to touch Bhangis and others, and this is my purest service to Hinduism.
('19', 344, 1, 20, 743443) That I have hurt the feelings of Hindus is also a half truth.
('19', 344, 1, 21, 743505) The attitude behind it is that the feelings of Hindus ought never to be hurt.
('19', 344, 1, 22, 743583) If following truth hurts people’s feelings, it is one’s dharma to hurt them.
('19', 344, 1, 23, 743660) How can I or anyone else escape this dharma?
('19', 344, 1, 24, 743705) It is a half truth to say that I started recruiting work in opposition to the stand taken up by Lokamanya Tilak.
('19', 344, 1, 25, 743818) He was not opposed to this activity of mine; his view was that such efforts would be more successful if equality of rights was conceded.
('19', 344, 1, 26, 743955) There is, thus,
('19', 345, 0, 1, 743971) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 345, 1, 2, 744013) much difference between the view really held by the Lokamanya and the view attributed to him by this friend.
('19', 345, 1, 3, 744122) How I, a believer in non violence, came forward to secure recruits is a question which occurred to many.
('19', 345, 1, 4, 744227) I have given my reply to it.
('19', 345, 1, 5, 744256) Without discussing it here, [I need only observe that] from a general point of view my action was much appreciated; to this friend, however, it seems unworthy.
('19', 345, 1, 6, 744416) The half truth about the Rowlatt Bills is evident enough.
('19', 345, 1, 7, 744474) But how can I explain to an angry man that I should not be held responsible for people having been killed, for the misdeeds of those who set fire to buildings?
('19', 345, 1, 8, 744634) I do not think it right to comment on the half truths about Reforms and related matters.
('19', 345, 1, 9, 744723) I would advise those who are apt to get angry all too quickly to reflect over this letter and I wish that they save themselves from such delusions.
('19', 345, 1, 10, 744871) Let the people, by all means, make their charges against me.
('19', 345, 1, 11, 744932) Let it be that I have no service to my credit about Kheda district and in other matters.
('19', 345, 1, 12, 745021) Opinions may differ on these points.
('19', 345, 1, 13, 745058) We should not, however, be carried away by anger.
('19', 345, 1, 14, 745108) We ought to see that, merely because some actions of a man have seemed bad to us, we do not set down as bad those very actions of his which we had once, on full consideration, held to be good.
('19', 345, 2, 15, 745301) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 25 1 1920

('19', 346, 1, 2, 745897) 196. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('19', 346, 2, 3, 745927) Sunday [January 25] 1920 1
('19', 346, 3, 4, 745954) MY DEAR CHILD, Narahari tells me you are now boarding with Imam Saheb.
('19', 346, 3, 5, 746025) I am glad you will certainly feel at home there more than anywhere else if only because you have someone who will talk to you constantly in English.
('19', 346, 3, 6, 746174) And you can shower your discriminating love on Fatima with immediate results.
('19', 346, 3, 7, 746252) I shall feel deeply hurt if you lose your health and your peace of mind.
('19', 346, 3, 8, 746325) ‘Resist not evil’ has a much deeper meaning than appears on the surface.
('19', 346, 3, 9, 746398) The evil in Ba, for instance, must not be resisted, i.e., you or for that matter I must not fret over it or be impatient and say to ourselves, ‘why will not this woman see the truth or return the love I give her’.
('19', 346, 3, 10, 746612) She can no more go against her nature than a leopard can change his spots.
('19', 346, 3, 11, 746687) If you or I love, we act according to our nature.
('19', 346, 3, 12, 746737) If she does not respond, she acts according to hers.
('19', 346, 3, 13, 746790) And if we worry, we ‘resist evil’.
('19', 346, 3, 14, 746825) Do you agree ?
('19', 346, 3, 15, 746840) I feel that that is the deeper meaning of the injunction.
('19', 346, 3, 16, 746898) And so, in your dealings with everybody I want you to keep your equanimity.
('19', 346, 3, 17, 746974) Secondly please do not deny yourself anything you may need for your bodily comfort.
('19', 346, 3, 18, 747058) Ask me, if you will not ask anybody.
('19', 346, 3, 19, 747095) I want you to write to me daily whilst I feel uneasy about you.
('19', 346, 3, 20, 747159) With love and prayers,
('19', 346, 4, 21, 747182) Yours, BAPU

('19', 348, 1, 2, 749136) 198. LETTER TO ASAF ALI
('19', 348, 2, 3, 749160) January 25, 1920
('19', 348, 3, 4, 749177) MY DEAR ASAF ALI, I was sorry to hear of your illness.
('19', 348, 3, 5, 749232) I hope you are now better if not quite restored.
('19', 348, 3, 6, 749281) I thank you for your frank letter.
('19', 348, 3, 7, 749316) I shall certainly take every step to see that there is no misunderstanding regarding the cow slaughter resolution.
('19', 348, 3, 8, 749431) I quite agree with you that no false hopes should be raised regarding the Mahomedan attitude on [the] point and that all propaganda on our (Hindus’) part among Mahomedans should be avoided.
('19', 348, 3, 9, 749621) I am glad too that you have raised the moral issue and discussed it not on purely orthodox religious but on broad and humanitarian grounds.
('19', 348, 3, 10, 749761) I would however say on the orthodox religious grounds that, when two great communities live side by side, the religious sense of the one demands a scrupulous regard for the practices of the other, so long as they are not immoral from a universal stand point.
('19', 348, 3, 11, 750020) For instance I see nothing wrong in non Muslims going to Mecca.
('19', 348, 3, 12, 750084) But there is nothing immoral in your prohibiting non Muslims from entering it.
('19', 348, 3, 13, 750163) And as the sentiment of prohibition has grown during all these 1,300 years, I support it.
('19', 348, 3, 14, 750253) So may it be for the Mahomedan regarding the cow slaughter.
('19', 348, 3, 15, 750313) Now for the broad humanitarian ground: we shall probably have to agree to differ; your view point seems to be so different from mine.
('19', 348, 3, 16, 750447) I consider that God has not created lower forms of animal life for man to use them as he will.
('19', 348, 3, 17, 750542) Man realises his highest station not by indulging but by abstinence.
('19', 348, 3, 18, 750611) I have no right to destroy animal life if I can subsist healthily on vegetable life.
('19', 348, 3, 19, 750696) I have no right to slaughter all animal life because I find it necessary to slaughter some animal life.
('19', 348, 3, 20, 750800) Therefore if I can live well on goats, fish and fowl (surely enough in all conscience) it is sin for me to destroy cows for my sustenance.
('19', 348, 3, 21, 750939) And it was some such argument that decided the rishis of old in regarding the cow as sacred, especially when they found that the cow was the greatest economic asset in national life.
('19', 348, 3, 22, 751122) And I see nothing wrong, immoral or sinful in offering worship to an animal so serviceable as the cow so long as my worship does not put her on a level with her Creator.
('19', 348, 3, 23, 751292) I immensely appreciate the idea (so emphasized by Islam)
('19', 349, 0, 1, 751349) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 349, 1, 2, 751391) that special worship must be reserved for the Creator of us all.
('19', 349, 1, 3, 751456) But I must not mix up cow worship and cow slaughter.
('19', 349, 1, 4, 751509) If you accept the proposition that man is more man as he abstains more, you will have no difficulty in allowing that cow slaughter is indefensible on moral grounds.
('19', 349, 1, 5, 751674) I agree with you that so far as the economic ground is concerned, the slaughter for the Europeans is much the most important.
('19', 349, 1, 6, 751800) In my opinion the cry against the Mahomedan slaughter on the Bakr Id is unbecoming so long as we Hindus remain dumb about the daily slaughter going on in the public abattoirs.
('19', 349, 1, 7, 751976) We strain at a gnat and swallow a camel.
('19', 349, 2, 8, 752017) Yours sincerely,
('19', 349, 3, 9, 752034) From a photostat of the draft in Gandhiji’s hand : S. N. 7064
('19', 349, 4, 10, 752096) 199. LETTER TO SOMEONE IN MADANPALLI
('19', 349, 5, 11, 752133) LAHORE, January 25, 1920
('19', 349, 6, 12, 752158) DEAR MR. .
('19', 349, 7, 13, 752169) I have drawn the distinction between passive resistance as understood and practised in the West and satyagraha before I had evolved the doctrine of the latter to its full logical and spiritual extent.
('19', 349, 7, 14, 752370) I often used passive resistance and saytagraha as synonymous terms : but as the doctrine of satyagraha developed, the expression passive resistance ceases even to be synonymous, as passive resistance has admitted of violence as in the case of suffragettes and has been universally acknowledged to be a weapon of the weak.
('19', 349, 7, 15, 752692) Moreover passive resistance does not necessarily involve complete adherence to truth under every circumstance.
('19', 349, 7, 16, 752803) Therefore it is different from satyagraha in three essentials: Satyagraha is a weapon of the strong; it admits of no violencer under any circumstance whatever; and it ever insists upon truth.
('19', 349, 7, 17, 752995) I think I have now made the distinction perfectly clear.
('19', 349, 7, 18, 753052) Yours sincerely,
('19', 349, 8, 19, 753069) TO MADANPALLI (P.O.)
('19', 349, 9, 20, 753090) From a photostat of the handwritten draft : S. N. 7071
('19', 349, 10, 21, 753145) 1 The addressee’s name is illegible.

('19', 352, 8, 17, 756880) 206. PUNJAB LETTER
('19', 352, 9, 18, 756899) LAHORE, Magh Sud 6 [January 27, 1920]
('19', 352, 10, 19, 756937) (9) DELHI I am back to my pilgrimage of the Punjab and have thus the opportunity of renewing my Punjab Letters for readers of Navajivan.
('19', 352, 10, 20, 757074) I shall first say something about my stay in Delhi and a few other places before I came back here.
('19', 352, 10, 21, 757173) I had hoped to go to Bombay and, having met friends, inspected the work of the Swadeshi Sabha and Satyagraha Sabha and met the men and women engaged in spinning, to proceed to Prayag and thence to Lahore.
('19', 352, 10, 22, 757378) But either God or the Khilafat Committee had planned otherwise.
('19', 352, 10, 23, 757442) Haji ul Mulk Hakimji Ajmal Khan wired to me requesting
('19', 353, 0, 1, 757497) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 353, 1, 2, 757539) me to join the Khilafat deputation which was to wait on the Viceroy.
('19', 353, 1, 3, 757608) Reports of this deputation have already appeared in the papers.
('19', 353, 1, 4, 757672) I shall, therefore, write nothing about it.
('19', 353, 1, 5, 757716) The inclusion of Hindus in the deputation has created an excellent impression.
('19', 353, 1, 6, 757795) I could see how the Ali Brothers had been able to win the affection of their community.
('19', 353, 1, 7, 757883) Their sweet speech, their constant readiness for work, their loving nature and sympathy for all, their religious zeal≈who would not be charmed by such qualities!
('19', 353, 1, 8, 758045) Their very presence fill our Muslim brethren with happiness.
('19', 353, 1, 9, 758106) They are, as it were, the eyes of the Muslims and now, by their love, they are winning over the Hindus as well.
('19', 353, 2, 10, 758218) KANPUR From Delhi I had in any case to go to Prayag.
('19', 353, 2, 11, 758271) When I returned from there after meeting Pandit Motilal Nehru, I was pressed to go to Kanpur.
('19', 353, 2, 12, 758365) The citizens of Kanpur urged me to go there for a few hours and open the Swadeshi Bhandar, saying I could leave by the next train.
('19', 353, 2, 13, 758496) I could not refuse them.
('19', 353, 2, 14, 758521) Kanpur is between Prayag and Delhi and is four hours from Prayag by Mail.
('19', 353, 2, 15, 758595) It is a centre of commerce and mills, like Bombay.
('19', 353, 2, 16, 758646) The climate too is excellent.
('19', 353, 2, 17, 758676) This was the first venture here by way of a swadeshi store, Hasrat Mohani’s being the chief hand behind it.
('19', 353, 2, 18, 758784) Thousands attended the opening ceremony and the people’s enthusiasm was boundless.
('19', 353, 3, 19, 758867) A PAINFUL INCIDENT The Ali Brothers had preceded me and a huge procession was organized for them.
('19', 353, 3, 20, 758965) The horse drawing their carriage shied and started kicking.
('19', 353, 3, 21, 759025) The crowd was thick.
('19', 353, 3, 22, 759046) A young and sturdy Muslim named Abdul Hafeez was standing close by.
('19', 353, 3, 23, 759114) Recently he had been devoting himself entirely to public service.
('19', 353, 3, 24, 759180) He was hit in the chest and collapsed.
('19', 353, 3, 25, 759219) In a second this youth, who had looked as if he could never die, passed away.
('19', 353, 3, 26, 759297) The two brothers came down from the carriage on the instant, asked for a cot to be brought and laid the body on it.
('19', 353, 3, 27, 759413) They both bore it on their shoulders and went with the procession for some distance.
('19', 353, 3, 28, 759498) Others then took their places and they went away to their work.
('19', 353, 3, 29, 759562) The procession which had started as a celebration now accompanied a bier.
('19', 353, 3, 30, 759636) The day was darkened.
('19', 353, 3, 31, 759658) I arrived within about four hours of this occurrence and the news was given to me at the station.
('19', 353, 3, 32, 759756) I made a request that the procession organized for me be cancelled and that I be taken direct to the Bhandar and, after the opening ceremony was gone through, to
('19', 354, 0, 1, 759918) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 355
('19', 354, 1, 2, 759966) see the body of Abdul Hafeez; the leaders agreed.
('19', 354, 1, 3, 760016) Having opened the Bhandar some of us proceeded to pay our homage to the body of our brother who had passed away.
('19', 354, 1, 4, 760129) The sight of the dead body of Abdul Hafeez was heart rending.
('19', 354, 1, 5, 760191) I was overwhelmed with grief as I looked upon that sturdy frame and that charming face, but I took heart from the fortitude of the Muslim brethren standing around.
('19', 354, 1, 6, 760355) I observed no wailing and weeping near the body.
('19', 354, 1, 7, 760404) The people were exchanging remarks, unmoved with fear, as though standing round someone in deep sleep, and described to me how he had been killed.
('19', 354, 1, 8, 760551) The scene appealed to me greatly.
('19', 354, 1, 9, 760585) I thought of the wailing and crying usual among the Hindus.
('19', 354, 1, 10, 760645) I wished that we were delivered from that horror.
('19', 354, 1, 11, 760695) I also told myself that we could do a great many things if we discarded this fear of death.
('19', 354, 1, 12, 760787) I have often felt that the followers of Hinduism, who should least fear death, fear it most.
('19', 354, 1, 13, 760880) The very thought of this makes me feel ashamed.
('19', 354, 1, 14, 760928) We learn right from our childhood that the soul is immortal and the body transitory, and that every act will have its consequence.
('19', 354, 1, 15, 761059) Why then do we fear death?
('19', 354, 1, 16, 761086) The only son of Abdul Hafeez was standing by my side.
('19', 354, 1, 17, 761140) He too spoke as if untouched by fear.
('19', 354, 1, 18, 761178) May God give peace to the soul of Abdul Hafeez.
('19', 354, 2, 19, 761226) VISIT TO MEERUT I left Kanpur by the evening train and reached Merrut the following morning, i.e., on the 22nd.
('19', 354, 2, 20, 761338) Meerut is on the G.I.P. line on the way to Lahore.
('19', 354, 2, 21, 761389) I had promised to stop there for a few hours.
('19', 354, 2, 22, 761435) The citizens had made elaborate preparations.
('19', 354, 2, 23, 761481) There was almost a competition between the Hindus and the Muslims in showering affection on me.
('19', 354, 2, 24, 761577) The Ali Brothers had been there only recently and had stayed in the house of a Hindu.
('19', 354, 2, 25, 761663) I was to stay at the house of a well known Muslim barrister of Meerut, Bhai Ismail Khan.
('19', 354, 2, 26, 761752) Seven hundred and fifty volunteers were active in the reception, many of them being from aristocratic families.
('19', 354, 2, 27, 761864) A mounted cadet corps also stood at attention.
('19', 354, 2, 28, 761911) Flag Poles had been erected along a three mile route and ropes tied connecting them.
('19', 354, 2, 29, 761996) The procession moved along inside the rope fence and the crowds stood outside.
('19', 354, 2, 30, 762075) It included a band, camel drawn carriages, men on horseback, people in fancy dress, etc.
('19', 354, 2, 31, 762164) The procession, I imagine must have been a mile long.
('19', 354, 2, 32, 762218) Thousands had come in from neighbouring villages.
('19', 354, 2, 33, 762268) Yet the arrangements were excellent.
('19', 354, 2, 34, 762305) Addresses were presented to me by the Municipality, the Khilafat Committee, the general public, Hindu and Muslim women.
('19', 354, 2, 35, 762425) There was a separating meeting for women.
('19', 354, 2, 36, 762467) They were overflowing with joyous enthusiasm.
('19', 354, 2, 37, 762513) About a thousand women
('19', 355, 0, 1, 762536) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 355, 1, 2, 762578) were present.
('19', 355, 1, 3, 762592) I was almost terrified.
('19', 355, 1, 4, 762616) how could I support so much affection?
('19', 355, 1, 5, 762655) I offered it up then and there to Lord Krishna.
('19', 355, 1, 6, 762703) My sincere efforts in the cause of the Khilafat have commended themselves to our Muslim brethren.
('19', 355, 1, 7, 762801) As long as they base their case on justice and fight non violently, I shall be ready to lay down my life for them.
('19', 355, 1, 8, 762916) If they put forward unreasonable demands, I will offer satyagraha even against them.
('19', 355, 1, 9, 763001) This statement of mine has appealed to them and they have taken strength from it.
('19', 355, 1, 10, 763083) All, Hindus and Muslims, have welcomed the emphasis on truth, whether they themselves abide by it or not.
('19', 355, 1, 11, 763189) They are therefore showering affection on me.
('19', 355, 1, 12, 763235) If the time comes for me to offer satyagraha against them, they may be angry with me, too.
('19', 355, 1, 13, 763326) Those who love us have also the right to be angry with us.
('19', 355, 1, 14, 763385) MUZAFFARNAGAR From Meerut, I was taken the same night to Muzaffarnagar.
('19', 355, 1, 15, 763457) There had been some minor differences between Hindus and Muslims in this place and I had been dragged there to settle them.
('19', 355, 1, 16, 763581) The car reached there at 9 p.m.
('19', 355, 1, 17, 763613) The crowds were all enthusiasm.
('19', 355, 1, 18, 763645) No one was in a mood to take instructions from anyone else.
('19', 355, 1, 19, 763705) Men on horseback were present but there was no order as in Meerut.
('19', 355, 1, 20, 763772) The people surrounded the car.
('19', 355, 1, 21, 763803) I was taken through it with great difficulty and put into a carriage.
('19', 355, 1, 22, 763873) I had no longer the strength to bear their joyous tumult.
('19', 355, 1, 23, 763931) Literally, I had stuffed my ears with cotton wool.
('19', 355, 1, 24, 763982) Somebody’s foot was hurt.
('19', 355, 1, 25, 764008) I was reminded of Abdul Hafeez and took the injured man into the carriage.
('19', 355, 1, 26, 764083) I bagged the people to move away.
('19', 355, 1, 27, 764117) But who would listen and to whom?
('19', 355, 1, 28, 764151) I then brought out my usual weapon.
('19', 355, 1, 29, 764187) I announced that, if the carriage started before the crowds had moved aside, I would jump out to the ground, for I could not tolerate anyone being injured.
('19', 355, 1, 30, 764343) This miraculous weapon had an electric effect.
('19', 355, 1, 31, 764390) The people became quiet and, a little firghtened, moved away, whereupon I asked [the driver] to be quick and start the carriage.
('19', 355, 1, 32, 764519) The control was with me now.
('19', 355, 1, 33, 764548) All this took a lot of time.
('19', 355, 1, 34, 764577) The roads were illuminated as on the festival of lights and a good deal of time was spent in passing through them.
('19', 355, 1, 35, 764692) The meeting was yet to take place.
('19', 355, 1, 36, 764727) The time for the departure of my train was fast approaching and it was imperative that I reach Lahore the following day.
('19', 355, 1, 37, 764848) But the people had realized that they should no longer make noise nor press round me.
('19', 355, 1, 38, 764934) We reached the pandal at 11 p.m.
('19', 355, 1, 39, 764967) There, at the meeting, everything was in wonderful order, without anyone’s efforts.
('19', 355, 1, 40, 765051) Those present must have been 4,000
('19', 356, 0, 1, 765086) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 357
('19', 356, 1, 2, 765134) or more.
('19', 356, 1, 3, 765143) My voice was slightly hoarse but the audience maintained such silence that I could be heard even by those sitting farthest from me.
('19', 356, 1, 4, 765275) I said a few words on how, if we were to work among lakhs of people, it was necessary to maintain order.
('19', 356, 1, 5, 765380) I then referred to the local dispute and, having advised them to show a spirit of accommodation and resolve their differences, I took leave from them.
('19', 356, 1, 6, 765531) Having thus rushed through these two towns, I reached Lahore on the morning of the 23rd.
('19', 356, 2, 7, 765620) A MIRACLE Where earlier I had seen a woman, separated from her husband and living all alone, the image of a lioness, I saw today a happy couple.
('19', 356, 2, 8, 765765) Pandit Rambhuj Dutt Choudhri was long since out of jail.
('19', 356, 2, 9, 765822) I saw a new glow on Smt.
('19', 356, 2, 10, 765847) Sarladevi’s face.
('19', 356, 2, 11, 765865) The face which had been lined with care was today bright with joy.
('19', 356, 2, 12, 765932) Or perhaps I am doing her an injustice.
('19', 356, 2, 13, 765972) Even during separation Sarladevi had not lost the light on her face.
('19', 356, 2, 14, 766041) However, I could see a difference between that light and this; let us say, rather, that I imagined such a difference.
('19', 356, 2, 15, 766159) It is certain that the sadness I used to feel when I stayed before at Sarladevi’s house has entirely disappeared now, thanks to the return of Choudhriji.
('19', 356, 2, 16, 766313) KHILAFAT DISCUSSED
('19', 356, 3, 17, 766332) Immediately on arrival I was to engage myself in consultations.
('19', 356, 3, 18, 766396) It had been decided to have a meeting with the Ali Brothers and other prominent Muslim friends in Lahore on the 23rd.
('19', 356, 3, 19, 766514) They had also, therefore, arrived by some other trains and the entire day was occupied in preparing a draft of their demands.
('19', 356, 3, 20, 766640) Sarladevi’s house has become a veritable dharmsala.
('19', 356, 3, 21, 766692) This lady proffered her hospitality to these distinguished Muslim friends as if she were their sister.
('19', 356, 3, 22, 766795) The day passed in preparing the draft and in accepting the hospitality.
('19', 356, 3, 23, 766867) Night fell and the time came for the Ali Brothers to depart.
('19', 356, 3, 24, 766928) “When you offer satyagraha, invite me to join you; at other times, I am not with you.” Listening to these words and accepting this as the agreement between us, the Brothers and Hastrat Mohani Saheb made their departure.
('19', 356, 3, 25, 767148) The three have but one thought day and night how to secure justice on the Khilafat issue.
('19', 356, 3, 26, 767238) The Brothers do not put unqualified faith in satyagraha.
('19', 356, 3, 27, 767295) Hasrat Mohani Saheb, however, whispered to me in passing, “I cannot say whether satyagraha can always be a practicable proposition but, for this purpose and in these times, I too believe that there is no other weapon like it.
('19', 356, 3, 28, 767521) I shall therefore certainly propagate it.”
('19', 357, 0, 1, 767564) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 357, 1, 2, 767606) The Ali Brothers embraced Hastrat Mohani, introducing him as “our mad Mullah” 1. This man does not want honour nor does he mind insults.
('19', 357, 1, 3, 767743) He remains engrossed in his work, indifferent to heat and cold and making no difference between day and night.
('19', 357, 1, 4, 767854) These are three jewels of the Muslim community and I feel that Hasrat Mohani is the brightest of the three.
('19', 357, 1, 5, 767962) There are not many even among Hindus who could rival him in his single minded devotion it is doubtful if there is any.
('19', 357, 1, 6, 768081) And just as they are true Muslims, they are true Indians.
('19', 357, 1, 7, 768139) The fate of the Khilafat case and the future peace of India depend largely on the wisdom of these three.
('19', 357, 1, 8, 768244) I can see that none of them will be afraid to follow the path they think is right.
('19', 357, 2, 9, 768327) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 2 1920
('19', 357, 3, 10, 768363) 207. THE KHILAFAT
('19', 357, 4, 11, 768381) The question of questions today is the Khilafat question, otherwise known as that of the Turkish peace terms.
('19', 357, 4, 12, 768491) His Excellency the Viceroy deserves our thanks for receiving the joint deputation even at this late hour 2 especially when he was busy preparing to receive the heads of the different provinces.
('19', 357, 4, 13, 768685) His Excellency must be thanked for the unfailing courtesy with which he received the deputation and the courteous language in which his reply was couched.
('19', 357, 4, 14, 768840) But mere courtesy, valuable as it is at all times, never so valuable as at this, is not enough at this critical moment.
('19', 357, 4, 15, 768960) “Sweet words butter no parsnips” is a proverb more applicable today than ever before.
('19', 357, 4, 16, 769046) Behind the courtesy there was the determination to punish Turkey.
('19', 357, 4, 17, 769112) Punishment of Turkey is a thing which Muslim sentiment cannot tolerate for a moment.
('19', 357, 4, 18, 769197) Muslim soldiers are as responsible for the result of the War as any others.
('19', 357, 4, 19, 769273) It was to appease them that Mr. Asquith said, when Turkey decided to join the Central Powers, that the British Government had no designs on Turkey and that His Majesty’s Government would never think of punishing the Sultan for the misdeeds of the Turkish Committee.
('19', 357, 4, 20, 769539) Examined by that standard the Viceregal reply is not only disappointing but it is a fall from truth and justice.
('19', 357, 5, 21, 769652) 1 Gandhiji uses the English words.
('19', 357, 5, 22, 769687) 2 The deputation waited on the Viceroy on January 19.
('19', 358, 0, 1, 769741) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 359
('19', 358, 1, 2, 769789) What is this British Empire?
('19', 358, 1, 3, 769818) It is as much Mohammedan and Hindu as it is Christian.
('19', 358, 1, 4, 769873) Its religious neutrality is not a virtue, or if it is, it is a virtue of necessity.
('19', 358, 1, 5, 769957) Such a mighty Empire could not be held together on any other terms.
('19', 358, 1, 6, 770025) British ministers are therefore bound to protect Mohammedan interests as any other.
('19', 358, 1, 7, 770109) Indeed, as the Muslim rejoinder says, they are bound to make the cause their own.
('19', 358, 1, 8, 770191) What is the use of His Excellency having presented the Muslim claim before the Conference?
('19', 358, 1, 9, 770282) If the cause is lost, the Mohammedans will be entitled to think that Britain did not do her duty by them.
('19', 358, 1, 10, 770388) And the Viceregal reply confirms the views.
('19', 358, 1, 11, 770432) When His Excellency says that Turkey must suffer for her having joined the Central Powers, he but expresses the opinion of the British ministers.
('19', 358, 1, 12, 770578) We hope, therefore, with the framers of the Muslim rejoinder that His Majesty’s ministers will mend the mistakes if any have been committed and secure a settlement that would satisfy Mohammedan sentiment.
('19', 358, 1, 13, 770783) What does the sentiment demand?
('19', 358, 1, 14, 770815) The preservation of the Khilafat with such gurantees as may be necessary for the protection of the interests of the non Muslim race living under Turkish rule and the Khalif’s control over Arabia and the Holy Places with such arrangement as may be required for guaranteeing Arab selfrule, should the Arabs desire it.
('19', 358, 1, 15, 771131) It is hardly possible to state the claim more fairly than has been done.
('19', 358, 1, 16, 771204) It is a claim backed by justice, by the declarations of British ministers and by the unanimous Hindu and Muslim opinion.
('19', 358, 1, 17, 771325) It would be midsummer madness to reject or whittle down a claim so backed.
('19', 358, 1, 18, 771400) Young India, 28 1 1920

('19', 366, 4, 11, 783417) 220. THE KHILAFAT
('19', 366, 5, 12, 783435) The question of the Khilafat 2 that is, of the peace terms with Turkey, is so important a one that before it all others fade into insignificance, for on a satisfactory solution of this problem depends the peace of India.
('19', 366, 5, 13, 783656) The Government may with its armed might succeed in maintaining an artificial peace for the time being but, should the solution of this problem prove unsatisfactory, a peace enforced by strength of arms will not be an enduring peace.
('19', 366, 5, 14, 783889) There are questions which may not be satisfactorily solved, but the dissatis faction is forgotten in the course of time.
('19', 366, 5, 15, 784010) If, however, the solution of the Khilafat problem is felt to be unsatisfactory, time will be no cure for the resulting discontent; on the contrary, the effects will grow in strength from day to day and unrest will go on increasing.
('19', 366, 6, 16, 784242) Hence it is the duty of every Indian to know what the problem is and know its right solution, and to take steps to bring about a satisfactory settlement.
('19', 366, 6, 17, 784396) What has hurt seven crores of Muslims ought to hurt Hindus too.
('19', 366, 6, 18, 784460) We do not, therefore, hesitate to place this issue before the people again and again.
('19', 366, 6, 19, 784546) The Government’s duty in this matter is as important as that of the people.
('19', 366, 7, 20, 784622) 1 Madan Mohan Malaviya.
('19', 366, 8, 21, 784646) 2 The Caliphate.
('19', 366, 8, 22, 784663) The object of the Khilafat movement was to ensure that the Sultan of Turkey was restored to the status which he enjoyed before World War I.
('19', 367, 0, 1, 784803) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 367, 1, 2, 784845) The deputation which waited 1 on His Excellency the Viceroy included both Hindus and Muslims.
('19', 367, 1, 3, 784939) His Excellency’s reply was courteous.
('19', 367, 1, 4, 784977) He showed the utmost consideration to the deputation and spared time for it from his heavy schedule of work.
('19', 367, 1, 5, 785086) We should thank him for all this.
('19', 367, 1, 6, 785120) But mere courtesy and good manners cannot satisfy the Muslims or the nation this time.
('19', 367, 1, 7, 785207) Courtesy is essential at all times, but there are occasions when courtesy fails to meet one’s object.
('19', 367, 1, 8, 785309) There is a saying in English that “fine words butter no parsnips”.
('19', 367, 1, 9, 785376) This applies very well to the present situation.
('19', 367, 2, 10, 785425) The Viceroy pointed out that there was nothing strange in Turkey, having taken the sword against the Allies, paying the penalty for doing so.
('19', 367, 2, 11, 785567) No Muslim would admit the justice of this.
('19', 367, 2, 12, 785610) When Turkey threw in its lot with Germany, Mr. Asquith, the then Prime Minister, said that the Sultan had no hand in this step; it was the mistake of a few Turks and Turkey would not have to suffer for it.
('19', 367, 2, 13, 785816) Why did he have to declare this?
('19', 367, 2, 14, 785849) Surely, not for reasons of good manners or justice.
('19', 367, 2, 15, 785901) He said it lest there be disaffection among Muslim troops.
('19', 367, 2, 16, 785960) The result was as desired.
('19', 367, 2, 17, 785987) The Muslim troops remained staunch in their loyalty.
('19', 367, 2, 18, 786040) A promise of reward thus made in order to reassure people cannot be lightly set aside now.
('19', 367, 2, 19, 786131) If it is, one should not be surprised that Muslims feel hurt.
('19', 367, 2, 20, 786193) Thus the threat uttered by the viceroy or the hint dropped by him as to the shape of things to come is such as can lead only to discontent, and the statement issued 2 by the deputation in reply to the Viceroy is very much to the point.
('19', 367, 2, 21, 786429) Let us hope that the Government will give its best attention to it.
('19', 367, 2, 22, 786497) What is the Muslim demand?
('19', 367, 2, 23, 786524) The Khilafat means the Turkish Empire.
('19', 367, 2, 24, 786563) Its authority should remain substantially what it was at the commencement of the War.
('19', 367, 2, 25, 786649) The Allies may demand any guarantees they choose for the protection of the interests of non Muslim subjects of the Empire.
('19', 367, 2, 26, 786772) Turkish rule, however, should be preserved.
('19', 367, 2, 27, 786816) Likewise, the Khalifa’s control over Arabia which is called Jazirat ul Arab 3 and
('19', 367, 3, 28, 786898) 1 On January 19, 1920. The deputation consisted of Gandhiji, Hakim Ajmal Khan and Maulanas Abul Kalam Azad, Abdul Bari, Mahomed Ali and Shaukat Ali.
('19', 367, 3, 29, 787047) 2 On January 20, 1920 3 Literally, “the island of Arabia” which, as defined by Muslim religious authorities, included Syria, Palestine and Mesopotamia as well as the peninsula of Arabia
('19', 368, 0, 1, 787233) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 369
('19', 368, 1, 2, 787281) over other holy places of Islam should remain.
('19', 368, 1, 3, 787328) It has been objected against this that Arabs too are Muslims; why should they not [it is asked] have swaraj in Arabia?
('19', 368, 1, 4, 787447) Our Muslim friends reply that they have no objection to a scheme of swaraj for Arabia.
('19', 368, 1, 5, 787534) Their only claim is that Arabia should not be subject to any but Muslim authority.

('19', 372, 1, 2, 793784) 225. PUNJAB LETTER 1
('19', 372, 2, 3, 793805) LAHORE, Magh Sud 13 [February 2, 1920]
('19', 372, 3, 4, 793844) TWO DEPUTATIONS Deputations from Fiji and British Guiana have been in India for some time.
('19', 372, 3, 5, 793935) 2 The Fiji Islands are in the vicinity of Australia.
('19', 372, 3, 6, 793988) During the last 50 years, there has been extensive cultivation of sugar cane in these islands with the help of indentured labour from India and through this means the Australian Central Sugar Company has enrned to the tune of crores.
('19', 372, 3, 7, 794222) Our friend Andrews 3 has graphically described to us the iniquity of the indenture system.
('19', 372, 3, 8, 794313) Now, however, thanks to the firmness of the Viceroy, even the indentures whose terms had not expired have been terminated.
('19', 372, 4, 9, 794436) British Guiana is a part of South America.
('19', 372, 4, 10, 794479) It is situated south of the equator.
('19', 372, 4, 11, 794516) Here also, sugar cane is grown on a colossal scale and sugar can be produced at the rate of three tons per acre.
('19', 372, 4, 12, 794629) In India the production is one ton per acre.
('19', 372, 4, 13, 794674) This question is being investigated at the moment by the Sugar Committee, which has the well known Mr. Burjorji Padshah as one of its members.
('19', 372, 4, 14, 794817) It may, therefore,be hoped that some good will result from their deliberations.
('19', 372, 4, 15, 794897) According to them, at present we may even be suffering losses in sugar cane cultivation.
('19', 372, 4, 16, 794986) Imported sugar is found cheaper and no one is thrown out of work by our not producing sugar in the country.
('19', 372, 4, 17, 795094) I report this information just as it has come to my ears.
('19', 372, 4, 18, 795152) I cannot say, either, that these are Mr. Padshah’s final conclusions, nor do I wish to discuss the matter here.
('19', 372, 4, 19, 795264) I merely mention this incidentally while on the subject of British Guiana.
('19', 372, 4, 20, 795339) Be the condition of our sugar trade what it may, British Guiana and Fiji have both prospered entirely because of this trade of theirs.
('19', 372, 4, 21, 795474) Indentured labourers used to emigrate to British Guiana as well.
('19', 372, 5, 22, 795539) 1 Gandhiji toured the Punjab in November and December 1919, and again in February 1920. From there he dispatched this weekly series of news letters for Navajivan, the first appearing in the issue of November 2, 1919.
('19', 372, 6, 23, 795756) 2 Both were unofficial deputations.
('19', 372, 6, 24, 795792) 3 C. F. Andrews (1871 1940); English missionary, author, educationist and a close associate of Gandhiji 4 The Government of Fiji cancelled all indentures with effect from January 2, 1920.
('19', 373, 0, 1, 795980) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 373, 1, 2, 796022) No knowledgeable person has visited that place and we are ignorant of the local labour conditions.
('19', 373, 1, 3, 796121) Emigration of indentured labour to that place has also been stopped.
('19', 373, 1, 4, 796190) Consequently, it has now become a problem of great urgency for both the countries how to maintain their prosperity.
('19', 373, 1, 5, 796306) If they are unable to secure further Indian labour, it will be a serious matter for them.
('19', 373, 1, 6, 796396) They cannot get British labourers for this work.
('19', 373, 1, 7, 796445) The latter cannot settle in those parts, as they cannot stand the climate.
('19', 373, 1, 8, 796520) If, therefore, they fail to secure Indian labour, they will have to think of China or other sources.
('19', 373, 1, 9, 796621) It is said that they do not find the honesty and submissiveness of the Indian labourer in his Chinese counterpart.
('19', 373, 1, 10, 796736) These two deputations have come here to consult with the Indian Government and public men.
('19', 373, 1, 11, 796827) They have come to ascertain under what conditions independent Indian labour may emigrate to these two places, and to make the required arrangements.
('19', 373, 1, 12, 796976) I have met both the deputations here.
('19', 373, 1, 13, 797014) The one from British Guiana includes their Attorney General 1 and some Indians long settled there.
('19', 373, 1, 14, 797113) From Fiji have come the Bishop and another Englishman.
('19', 373, 1, 15, 797168) The suggestion of British Guiana is that some of our agriculturists should emigrate voluntarily and take up farming there.
('19', 373, 1, 16, 797291) They need not work as labourers.
('19', 373, 1, 17, 797324) In British Guiana, there is equality between Indians and whites.
('19', 373, 1, 18, 797389) This is not due to the magnanimity of the white people but is the result of circumstances.
('19', 373, 1, 19, 797480) The British belong mainly to the officer class, and in any case cannot undertake agriculture.
('19', 373, 1, 20, 797574) It need not be imagined that the whites in that area have cast off their prejudice against us.
('19', 373, 1, 21, 797669) However, it may be admitted that in British Guiana they do not have two classes of citizens as in other countries, and If Indians settle there, they are not likely to be harassed as in East Africa.
('19', 373, 1, 22, 797867) In Fiji the conditions are different.
('19', 373, 1, 23, 797905) The Fiji deputation does not ask for Indians of independent means but for Indians who will work as free labourers.
('19', 373, 1, 24, 798020) The latter will go, not as indentured labourers but as independent workers, in the same way as they go to Singapore and other places.
('19', 373, 1, 25, 798154) I have been asked to give my opinion on both these matters.
('19', 373, 1, 26, 798214) I have not yet done so publicly.
('19', 373, 1, 27, 798247) The Attorney General of British Guiana has, however, taken my signature to certain observations I made to him.
('19', 373, 2, 28, 798358) 1 Dr. Joseph Nunan 2 Gandhiji met Dr. Nunan on February I, 1920.
('19', 374, 0, 1, 798423) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 375
('19', 374, 1, 2, 798471) I feel that we are not yet ready to send out “colonists” 1. Our people have not yet developed the requisite independence or self reliance.
('19', 374, 1, 3, 798610) Therefore, I think it unlikely that any independent labourers will, in fact, go.
('19', 374, 1, 4, 798691) Nor do I think it possible that any agriculturists will go there as independent men and succeed in maintaining their independence.
('19', 374, 1, 5, 798822) There is not that ingenuity in us; we are not drawn to the idea of emigration, nor is there any need for us to emigrate.
('19', 374, 1, 6, 798943) If an ignorant but adventurous class does emigrate, it is essential that it be followed by an educated class devoted to higher aims.
('19', 374, 1, 7, 799076) If such men go to serve the people, I am sure that excellent results will follow.
('19', 374, 1, 8, 799158) But there are few such men even in India.
('19', 374, 1, 9, 799200) Where, then, are we to find any who might go abroad?
('19', 374, 1, 10, 799253) Therefore, though I would not like peasants to be prevented by law from emigration to these parts as labourers or otherwise, I would not, directly or indirectly, encourage them to go either.
('19', 374, 1, 11, 799444) All I can do at the moment is to place this humble opinion before my readers.

('19', 375, 4, 9, 800312) 227. BRITISH GUIANA AND FIJI DEPUTATIONS 4
('19', 375, 5, 10, 800355) [Before February 4, 1920] 5
('19', 375, 6, 11, 800383) There are at present two deputations in India from overseas.
('19', 375, 6, 12, 800444) The one headed by its Attorney General, Dr. Nunan, is from British Guiana, and the other by the Bishop of Polynesia is from Fiji.
('19', 375, 6, 13, 800574) Both these deputations have arrived from their respective colonies for the purpose of obtaining Indian labour.
('19', 375, 6, 14, 800685) Hitherto both have had indentured labour.
('19', 375, 6, 15, 800727) In both, the existing indentures have only just been cancelled.
('19', 375, 7, 16, 800791) 1 Then Chief Secretary to the Punjab Government 2 A revolutionary leader of the Punjab who was sentenced to life transportation but was subsequently released; later became President of All India Hindu Mahasabha 3 In his reply of February 6, 1920, the Chief Secretary stated that out of 734 prisoners, 638 had been released in view of His Majesty’s Proclamation, that cases of those sentenced under the Lahore Conspiracy trials (including Bhai Parmanand’s) were still under consideration and that undertakings had been taken from those charged with the more serious non political offences.
('19', 375, 7, 17, 801380) 4 Vide also “Punjab Letter”, 2 2 1920, “Letter to V. S. Srinivasa Sastri”, before February 4, 1920, and “Letter to Dr. Joseph Nunan”, February 5, 1920. 5 This article was evidently written before February 4, 1920; vide the following item.
('19', 376, 0, 1, 801619) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 377
('19', 376, 1, 2, 801667) His Excellency the Viceroy, whose attitude on the status of British Indians living in the different colonies has been generally correct, put the popular case very clearly when His Excellency said that India could not be expected to consider the convenience of the colonies at her own expense nor could the Government of India prevent free Indian emigration if there were Indians who wanted to go to any of the colonies with a view to bettering their own position.
('19', 376, 1, 3, 802131) His Excellency further added that a committee of probably non official members would be appointed to confer with these deputations and consider the question, and that the Government would be guided by the advice of that committee.
('19', 376, 2, 4, 802362) Now let us examine the position.
('19', 376, 2, 5, 802395) The British Guiana deputation wants free Indian settlers of the farmer type for its plantations.
('19', 376, 2, 6, 802492) The Fiji deputation wants free in the place of indentured labour.
('19', 376, 2, 7, 802558) Both are tropical countries chiefly growing sugar cane.
('19', 376, 2, 8, 802614) These colonies unlike South Africa and the Uplands of East Africa cannot hold European colonists.
('19', 376, 2, 9, 802712) These places are not fit for European colonization, but they are being developed by European capital assisted by Indian labour.
('19', 376, 2, 10, 802840) If they cannot get Indian labour, whether as servants or master workers, they must tap some other sources, possibly China.
('19', 376, 2, 11, 802963) I had the pleasure of meeting both the deputations—the British Guiana more than once.
('19', 376, 2, 12, 803049) From British Guiana there have been no complaints of ill treatment of its indentured Indians.
('19', 376, 2, 13, 803143) There is no doubt that there are no legal inequalities in British Guiana.
('19', 376, 2, 14, 803217) In Fiji, too, there are probably no glaring inequalities in law.
('19', 376, 2, 15, 803282) I believe, too, that the Fiji Government and the planters are now willing to treat the Indian labour better and offer better terms.
('19', 376, 3, 16, 803414) The question for us, however, to consider is : do we want Indian labour to go to these colonies, and, if we do, are the terms such as would make the Indians morally and materially better?
('19', 376, 3, 17, 803602) In my opinion we want all the labour we have in India.
('19', 376, 3, 18, 803657) A willing labourer has ample scope for earning a substantial living in India.
('19', 376, 3, 19, 803735) Our industries require labour.
('19', 376, 3, 20, 803766) India is not over populated.
('19', 376, 3, 21, 803795) The pure agriculturist does not need to go out of India to earn a
('19', 376, 4, 22, 803861) 1 In February 1920, a resolution was accepted by the Indian Legislative Council appointing this Committee.
('19', 376, 4, 23, 803968) 2 In the beginning of 1920 Indian labourers in Fiji went on a strike apparently designed to secure better pay and working conditions but which subsequently let to serious disorder which was frocibly repressed.
('19', 377, 0, 1, 804178) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 377, 1, 2, 804220) living.
('19', 377, 1, 3, 804228) Emigration cannot solve the problem of Indian poverty.
('19', 377, 1, 4, 804283) The causes are too deep and widespread to be solved by a scheme of emigration no matter how ambitious it may be.
('19', 377, 1, 5, 804396) A few thousand emigrants going out every year can produced no effect on the deep and deepening poverty of the vast masses of India.
('19', 377, 1, 6, 804528) My convic tion is that the returned emigrants in the majority of cases disrupt the home life without doing any counter balancing benefit to society in gene ral or the members of the home so disrupted in particular.
('19', 377, 1, 7, 804743) Whilst, there fore, I would not interfere with any agriculturist, I would not encourage him to leave India unless there was a distinct moral advantage to be gained by emigrating.
('19', 377, 1, 8, 804922) We are not a colonizing nation in the modern sense of the term.
('19', 377, 1, 9, 804986) The labourers are not followed by their better class countrymen who whilst they would want to earn a living would make it dependent upon their service of their countrymen.
('19', 377, 1, 10, 805158) The religious and the social tie is loosened.
('19', 377, 1, 11, 805204) The restraints of Indian environment do not follow the emigrant.
('19', 377, 1, 12, 805269) Going therefore to an environment which has become debased by servility and degraded by the inevitable immorality of the system under which his predecessors have lived, the new emigrant succumbs to that environment.
('19', 377, 1, 13, 805485) It is not right to expose the would be emigrants to such grave moral risks.
('19', 377, 1, 14, 805561) Both the deputations have urged that it is our duty to send more emigrant families in order that the deficiency in the female Indian population may be redressed.
('19', 377, 1, 15, 805723) In other words we should send more women to these colonies.
('19', 377, 1, 16, 805783) I totally dissent from the view.
('19', 377, 1, 17, 805816) I would not be a party to sending a single woman to be exposed to a life of shame.
('19', 377, 1, 18, 805899) The only remedy for the evil to which both the colonies and the Government of India have been party is for the superfluous young men, if they are so minded, to come to India, get decently married and take their wives with them.
('19', 377, 1, 19, 806127) Such an uplifting movement can only come from the colonies.
('19', 377, 1, 20, 806187) And I suggest to both the deputations that if they are in earnest about the moral welfare of the Indian settlers in their midst they will start societies in the colonies for the encouragement of young men temporarily returning to India for the purpose of seeking life companions.
('19', 377, 1, 21, 806467) Indeed, the mention of this great difficulty tempts me to say that if both the missions were to occupy themselves in clearing the moral atmosphere around them, one would be better able to respond to their mission.
('19', 377, 1, 22, 806681) Moreover, no scheme of free emigration can be really success ful until the relations between Englishmen and ourselves have
('19', 378, 0, 1, 806804) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 379
('19', 378, 1, 2, 806852) considerably improved everywhere.
('19', 378, 1, 3, 806886) The Englishman in South Africa is no worse than in India or in Fiji and British Guiana.
('19', 378, 1, 4, 806974) In South Africa a short sighted conception of his interest demands expulsion of the Indian.
('19', 378, 1, 5, 807066) And he is struggling between his conscience and his interest.
('19', 378, 1, 6, 807128) In British Guiana his interest and conscience coincide.
('19', 378, 1, 7, 807184) He therefore desires Indian settlement.
('19', 378, 1, 8, 807224) But he no more considers the Indian to be his equal than the Englishman in South Africa.
('19', 378, 1, 9, 807313) What is more, the average Indian considers that he is not the Englishman’s equal.
('19', 378, 1, 10, 807395) There is, therefore, mutual distrust, despise [sic] on the one hand and fear on the other.
('19', 378, 1, 11, 807486) Until the relations become normal and natural it is not proper to encourage or countenance even free emigration to these colonies.
('19', 378, 1, 12, 807617) These deputations, I take it, propose to set up a kind of agency or bureau for the collection of the type of emigrants they require.
('19', 378, 1, 13, 807750) I cannot contemplate with equanimity the idea of Indians going to Fiji as free labourers.
('19', 378, 1, 14, 807840) With their present equipment, they would not know the distinction between free and indentured labour after being in Fiji.
('19', 378, 1, 15, 807962) In British Guiana the agriculturist will not know what to do with himself and would drift into the plantations as a labourer.
('19', 378, 1, 16, 808088) Side by side with this free agency, there must be a corresponding advisory agency on our part to enable the people to make their choice.
('19', 378, 1, 17, 808225) I have suggested an experimental shipment to Dr. Nunan and the sending of Mr. C. F. Andrews or some leading Indian with a knowledge of labour conditions to British Guiana and report [sic].
('19', 378, 1, 18, 808414) This is about as much as is possible to be done at the present moment.
('19', 378, 1, 19, 808485) And I hope that neither the proposed non official committee nor the public will countenance anything more.
