('19', 383, 5, 7, 815163) 235. VALUE OF KHADI
('19', 383, 6, 8, 815183) Mr. Vithaldas Jerajani sends news from Bombay that the demand for khadi there has gone down or altogether vanished.
('19', 383, 6, 9, 815299) This was painful reading for me, but not at all surprising.
('19', 383, 6, 10, 815359) It was painful because the reduced demand indicates that our enthusiasms are short lived, that they lack the backing of a religious sentiment or ideal.
('19', 383, 6, 11, 815511) The people who, in the name of religion, are prepared to drink dirty water, the Hindus who, in the name of religion, abstain from eating while travelling in a train and prefer to remain hungry for fear of pollution, the Muslims who refuse to eat meat unless it has been prepared in a specific way—if such a people were to view the use of khadi as a duty dictated by compassion, as something holy, they would not give it up.
('19', 383, 6, 12, 815935) That all khadi is not of equally good quality; that is easily crumples and coat and trousers do not remain stiff; it shrinks so much that the sleeve recedes from the wrist to the elbow; it looks like a sieve so much so that moong 4 grains can easily pass through it: people perhaps have had experience of one or the other of all these things but my personal experience is that the more I wear khadi shirts the softer they feel.
('19', 383, 6, 13, 816363) I do not find even the dhotis heavy, so that now I find it something of a hardship to have to wear machine made dhotis.
('19', 383, 6, 14, 816483) All this may be sheer fancy; anyway, for me wearing khadi is a matter of dharma.
('19', 383, 7, 15, 816564) 1 Sent in reply to a telegram, dated February 5, 1920, inviting Gandhiji to Calcutta, presumably to attend the Bengal Provincial Khilafat Conference held in the last week of February under the presidentship of Maulana Azad.
('19', 383, 7, 16, 816788) Gandhiji drafted this reply on the back of the telegram from C. R. Das, evidently on or after February 5. 2 Chitta Ranjan Das (1870 1925); eminent lawyer and Congress leader; orator and author; elected President of the Congress in 1921 3 In regard to the Punjab Disorders Inquiry, as the meeting of the Commissioners appointed by the Congress Punjab Sub committee was to be held at Banaras on February 20, 1920, to finalize the draft report 4 one of the pulses
('19', 384, 0, 1, 817249) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 385
('19', 384, 1, 2, 817297) How is all this khadi made?
('19', 384, 1, 3, 817325) The yarn is spun mostly by our poor sisters.
('19', 384, 1, 4, 817370) The lives of some of them were wretched, but have now improved; again, there are those who had no occupation, but have now begun to earn an anna a day, if not more.
('19', 384, 1, 5, 817535) They can use it for buying vegetables for the family or milk for their children.
('19', 384, 1, 6, 817616) The anna we casually throw away in Bombay is certainly worth four annas in the villages.
('19', 384, 1, 7, 817705) Those who weave this khadi are weavers who had either left off their profession or were about to do so.
('19', 384, 1, 8, 817809) Using khadi is the foundation of swadeshi, since khadi is the only thing which can be made from thick yarn, and made easily.
('19', 384, 1, 9, 817934) It has not so far had to compete with machine made cloth.
('19', 384, 1, 10, 817992) The consumption of khadi alone enables lakhs of poor people to earn an honest living, staying at home.
('19', 384, 1, 11, 818095) This khadi will show, it has been showing, daily improvement.
('19', 384, 1, 12, 818157) It has a variety of uses.
('19', 384, 1, 13, 818183) If shirts made of it seem impossible, loose shirts and underwear are decidedly wearable.
('19', 384, 1, 14, 818272) Handkerchiefs, large and small, can be made of it, also covering for pillows and bedding.
('19', 384, 1, 15, 818362) It can be used for making quilts.
('19', 384, 1, 16, 818396) It can thus be put to a variety of uses.
('19', 384, 1, 17, 818437) I do not say, of course, that those who have no need of new clothes should throw away their money just that they might use khadi; even if that is done, the advantage to the people will not be very great.
('19', 384, 1, 18, 818641) I do certainly say, however, that we should use khadi alone wherever it is possible to use it.
('19', 384, 1, 19, 818736) A good use for khadi will easily be found if one is keen on it.
('19', 384, 1, 20, 818800) The effort to increase production of khadi continues; in fact production has increased.
('19', 384, 1, 21, 818888) Now efforts must also be made to sell it.
('19', 384, 1, 22, 818930) In this I want help from the Bombay business men.
('19', 384, 1, 23, 818980) Suggestions for necessary improvements in khadi will also prove useful.
('19', 384, 1, 24, 819052) Wherever swadeshi stores have been opened, they should proceed to order khadi.
('19', 384, 1, 25, 819131) Besides khadi, production of other goods will also increase.
('19', 384, 1, 26, 819192) It is only when people develop a liking for hand woven, swadeshi good that hand spinning and hand weaving will gather full speed.
('19', 384, 1, 27, 819322) From my experience in the Punjab I see that, if people cultivated a sincere regard for swadeshi, large numbers of Punjabi women would take up their ancient occupation of spinning.

('19', 385, 2, 4, 819874) 236. CONDITION OF LABOUR 1
('19', 385, 3, 5, 819901) Two paths are open before India today, either to introduce the western principle of ‘might is right’ or to uphold the eastern principle that truth alone triumphs, that truth knows no mishap, that the strong and the weak have alike a right to secure justice.
('19', 385, 3, 6, 820159) The choice is to begin with the labouring class.
('19', 385, 3, 7, 820208) Should the labourers obtain an increment in their wages by violence, even if that be possible?
('19', 385, 3, 8, 820303) They cannot resort to anything like violence howsoever legitimate their claim may be.
('19', 385, 3, 9, 820389) To use violence for securing rights may seem an easy path, but it proves to be thorny in the long run.
('19', 385, 3, 10, 820492) Those who live by the sword also die by the sword.
('19', 385, 3, 11, 820543) The swimmer often dies by drowning.
('19', 385, 3, 12, 820579) Look at Europe.
('19', 385, 3, 13, 820595) No one seems to be happy there; no one is contented.
('19', 385, 3, 14, 820648) The labourer does not trust the capitalist and the capitalist has no faith in the labourer.
('19', 385, 3, 15, 820740) Both have a sort of vigour and strength but even the bulls have it.
('19', 385, 3, 16, 820808) They fight to the very bitter end.
('19', 385, 3, 17, 820843) All motion is not progress.
('19', 385, 3, 18, 820871) We have got no reason to believe that the people of Europe are progressing.
('19', 385, 3, 19, 820947) Their possession of wealth does not argue the possession of any moral or spiritual qualities.
('19', 385, 3, 20, 821041) King Duryodhana 2 was a master of untold wealth, but with all that he was pauper in comparison to Vidura 3 and Sudama 4 .
('19', 385, 3, 21, 821163) Today the world adores Vidura and Sudama, whereas Duryodhana’s name is remembered only as a byword for the evil qualities one should shun.
('19', 385, 3, 22, 821302) What shall we do then?
('19', 385, 3, 23, 821325) The labourers in Bombay made a fine stand.
('19', 385, 3, 24, 821368) I was not in a position to know all the facts 5. But this much I could see that they could fight in a better way.
('19', 385, 3, 25, 821482) The millowner may be wholly in the wrong.
('19', 385, 3, 26, 821524) In the struggle between capital and labour it may be generally said that more often than not the capitalists are in
('19', 385, 4, 27, 821640) 1 This translation is reproduced from Young India, 11 2 1920. 2 Characters in the Mahabharata.

('19', 386, 1, 4, 822208) The mill owners will have to work on the terms dictated by labour if the latter could command intelligence of the former.
('19', 386, 1, 5, 822330) It is clear, however, that labour will never attain to that intelligence.
('19', 386, 1, 6, 822404) If it does, labour will cease to be labour and become itself the master.
('19', 386, 1, 7, 822477) The capitalists do not fight on the strength of money alone.
('19', 386, 1, 8, 822538) They do possess intelligence and tact.
('19', 386, 1, 9, 822577) The question before us is this : when the labourers, remaining what they are, develop a certain consciousness what should be their course?
('19', 386, 1, 10, 822716) It would be suicidal if the labourers rely upon their numbers or brute force, i.
('19', 386, 1, 11, 822797) e., violence.
('19', 386, 1, 12, 822811) By so doing they will do harm to industries in the country.
('19', 386, 1, 13, 822871) If, on the other hand, they take their stand on pure justice and suffer in their person to secure it, not only will they always succeed but they will reform their masters, develop industries and both masters and men will be as members of one and the same family.
('19', 386, 1, 14, 823134) A satisfactory solution of the condition of labour must include the following : 1. The hours of labour must leave the workmen some hours of leisure.
('19', 386, 1, 15, 823283) 2. They must get facilities for their own education.
('19', 386, 1, 16, 823336) 3. Provision should be made for an adequate supply of milk, clothing and necessary education for their children.
('19', 386, 1, 17, 823449) 4. There should be sanitary dwellings for the workmen.
('19', 386, 1, 18, 823504) 5. They should be in a position to save enough to maintain themselves during their old age.
('19', 386, 1, 19, 823596) None of these conditions is satisfied today.
('19', 386, 1, 20, 823641) For this both the parties are responsible.
('19', 386, 1, 21, 823684) The masters care only for the service they get.
('19', 386, 1, 22, 823732) What becomes of the labourers does not concern them.
('19', 386, 1, 23, 823785) All their endeavours are generally confined to obtaining maximum service with minimum payment.
('19', 386, 1, 24, 823880) The labourer on the other hand, tries to hit upon all tricks whereby he can get maximum pay with minimum work.
('19', 386, 1, 25, 823991) The result is that although the labourers get an increment there is no improvement in the work turned out.
('19', 386, 1, 26, 824098) The relations between the two parties are not purified and the labourers do not make proper use of the increment they get.
('19', 386, 1, 27, 824221) A third party has sprung up between these two parties.
('19', 386, 1, 28, 824276) It has become the labourers’ friend.
('19', 386, 1, 29, 824313) There is need for such a party.
('19', 386, 1, 30, 824345) Only to the extent to which this party has disinterested friendship for the labourers can it befriend them.
('19', 386, 1, 31, 824453) A time has come now when attempts will be made to use labour

('19', 387, 1, 2, 824556) as a pawn in more ways than one.

('19', 392, 6, 7, 833765) JALLIANWALA BAGH The Hon’ble Pandit Malaviya had announced during the Congress session 2 that Jallianwala Bagh 3 had become the nation’s property.
('19', 392, 6, 8, 833912) But later, serious difficulties were encountered.
('19', 392, 6, 9, 833962) There was nothing in writing and some of the joint proprietors changed their mind.
('19', 392, 6, 10, 834045) They thought of presenting a small part of the Bagh to the nation and putting the rest to sale.
('19', 392, 6, 11, 834141) Everything was done to explain to them that a cemetery should not be cut up, that there was not a corner of that garden which had not been stained by the blood of innocent men and it would be improper, therefore, to exploit it for financial gain.
('19', 392, 6, 12, 834388) Moreover, it had been announced through a staunch worker, grown old in the service of India, that the entire Bagh had become the nation’s property.
('19', 392, 6, 13, 834536) In these circumstances, it was undesirable that there be any division of the plot.
('19', 392, 6, 14, 834619) The owners, however, who had changed their mind remained unconvinced.
('19', 392, 6, 15, 834689) Finally, Panditji and Swami Shraddhanand 4 had to go to Amritsar.
('19', 392, 6, 16, 834755) A settlement has now been reached and a temporary agreement signed.
('19', 392, 6, 17, 834823) FIVE LAKHS The land has been valued at rupees five lakhs and it has been agreed to pay the amount within three months.
('19', 392, 6, 18, 834942) If payment is not made by the end of that period, there is every danger that the land will be lost to the public.

('19', 394, 5, 18, 839713) To be content merely to give our share is a sign of miserliness.
('19', 394, 5, 19, 839778) There is magnanimity in what is done with love.
('19', 394, 5, 20, 839826) Love will not have its actions weighed in a pair of scales.
('19', 394, 5, 21, 839886) Anything which does so is not love, but the spirit of business.
('19', 394, 5, 22, 839950) Such an attitude is out of place here.

('19', 399, 4, 13, 849559) Subscriptions should be remitted direct to one of these banks or their branches and the fact should be communicated to the treasurer or the secretary.
('19', 399, 4, 14, 849710) A formal receipt signed by the treasurer and the secretary, will be sent to every donor.
('19', 399, 4, 15, 849799) Relying upon the enthusiasm shown in this matter as an index of the national wish, we trust that the donors

('19', 400, 1, 4, 850306) Though we have come to no final conclusion, we propose that the Bagh should be converted into a park, whereon a simple memorial will be erected with a suitable inscription perpetuating the memory of the dead and commemorating Hindu Muslim unity.

('19', 400, 5, 15, 851933) Gujrat is the name of a district in the Punjab with Gujrat as the main town.
('19', 400, 5, 16, 852010) The battle of Gujrat which occurred during the Sikh War
('19', 401, 0, 1, 852066) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 401, 1, 2, 852108) in 1849 is well known.

('19', 401, 1, 5, 852254) 1 Sarladevi Chowdhrani 2 accompanied us on this journey.
('19', 401, 1, 6, 852311) There is a small village called Jalalpur Jata near Gujrat, which also we had to visit.
('19', 401, 1, 7, 852398) This village may be said to be inhabited almost entirely by weavers.
('19', 401, 1, 8, 852467) The women spin and the men weave.
('19', 401, 1, 9, 852501) The whole of the little lane had been decorated with hand made cloth.
('19', 401, 1, 10, 852571) The cloth was not just white khadi but khadi dyed red and embroidered with silk.
('19', 401, 1, 11, 852652) Such cloth is known here as phulkari 3. Beautiful designs are worked on the cloth and these make the cloth delightful to the eye.
('19', 401, 1, 12, 852782) At a marriage this phulkari is presented to the bride and the bridegroom and in many families the garments are preserved.
('19', 401, 1, 13, 852904) Many women may be observed wearing scarves of phulkari.
('19', 401, 1, 14, 852960) Nowadays people also make curtains of it.
('19', 401, 1, 15, 853002) The seats prepared for me are, I generally see, decorated with such phulkari and the affection which inspires this gives me great happiness.
('19', 401, 1, 16, 853143) But the sight of the bazaar filled with phulkaris also saddened me and my heart became heavy.
('19', 401, 1, 17, 853237) The thought that this beautiful craft, which had been the chief source of India’s prosperity, is about to vanish made me disconsolate.
('19', 401, 1, 18, 853372) The beauty and the sanctity, the conservation of our resources which I see in this phulkari, I do not see in foreign saris.
('19', 401, 1, 19, 853496) The prosperity of Indian homes lies in spinning.
('19', 401, 1, 20, 853545) With the disappearance of this occupation, prosperity too has gone.
('19', 401, 1, 21, 853613) The Commissioner had not requested the imposition of Martial Law in this district of Gujrat and when, nevertheless, it did come he dispatched a telegram to make sure, thinking that possibly Gujarat in the Bombay Presidency was intended—so innocent was the Gujarat district in the Punjab.

('19', 402, 2, 11, 855310) MALAKVAL From Sargodha we went to Malakval, which is a city in Gujrat district.
('19', 402, 2, 12, 855390) Being a railway junction, it has become a well known place.
('19', 402, 2, 13, 855450) This place, too, had been under Martial Law.
('19', 402, 2, 14, 855495) The people here had been so suppressed that their leaders did not have the courage to put us up.

('19', 402, 2, 18, 855840) The leaders, however, continued to remain aloof out of fear.
('19', 402, 2, 19, 855901) We had to stay here for the night.
('19', 402, 2, 20, 855936) Early next morning, men and women came from near by villages playing on their instruments and woke us up.

('19', 402, 2, 22, 856137) In the end, it was only after I had led the people to a maidan near by and held a meeting that I could have some peace.
('19', 402, 2, 23, 856257) In all these meetings, some times composed of thousands, I am always both chairman and speaker or, perhaps, it would be more correct to say that there is no chairman at all.
('19', 402, 2, 24, 856431) Day by day the number of women attending these meetings is found to be increasing.

('19', 402, 3, 26, 856559) SCENES ON THE WAY This is a junction on the main line and is two and a half hours’ journey from Malakval.
('19', 402, 3, 27, 856665) There are four or five intermediate stations.
('19', 402, 3, 28, 856711) I can scarcely describe the scenes at these stations.
('19', 402, 3, 29, 856765) Although at almost every station the train stopped for only a few minutes, hundreds of people—both men and women—used to collect.

('19', 403, 0, 1, 856917) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 403, 1, 2, 856959) the way called Bahuddin.
('19', 403, 1, 3, 856984) The village is a fairly large one.
('19', 403, 1, 4, 857019) A multitude of men and women stood there as far as my eye could reach and women competed with the men in their efforts to come to me.
('19', 403, 1, 5, 857153) In every place, the women made offerings to me of yarn spun with their own hands.
('19', 403, 1, 6, 857235) But, at a station named Dhinga where the train stops for five to seven minutes, the scene was simply wonderful.
('19', 403, 1, 7, 857347) The women stood behind the men and, from there, they threw ball after ball of handspun yarn and we in the train and the men who stood in between caught them as they came.
('19', 403, 1, 8, 857518) I understood the feelings of these women and my heart overflowed with joy.
('19', 403, 1, 9, 857593) To the question, ‘Why do all these women show such love?’ I found the answer in the miracle at Dhinga station.
('19', 403, 1, 10, 857704) It is my deep conviction that the women of the Punjab have understood my message.
('19', 403, 1, 11, 857786) They have felt that swadeshi is not merely a means of protecting India’s wealth but that it makes for protection of women’s honour, that it is a form of Ishwar bhakti 1 and that in it lies the country’s best freedom.
('19', 403, 1, 12, 858003) Moreover, they have been able instinctively to grasp the significance of the holy message of satyagraha and have received from it great peace of mind and a new assurance.
('19', 403, 1, 13, 858174) They feel that, if my message if adopted by the country, peace will prevail in India and through India, in the whole world and the Satyayuga 2 will be born.
('19', 403, 1, 14, 858331) They have understood that, whether all this is realized in the near future or not, it is for us to work on with faith for these two objectives and this is why they come to me in ever larger numbers, shedding their fear.
('19', 403, 1, 15, 858551) I was convinced during this journey that there is no exaggeration in saying that women have understood how we can fight our opponents with love and without hate, and be a match for them, how we can fearlessly point out to the officers their errors and they will have to listen to us, and that, seeing all this, they are extremely happy.
('19', 403, 1, 16, 858888) I hope the reader will not get the impression that I am indulging in self praise in all this.
('19', 403, 1, 17, 858982) The admission of imperfection that I made before the Hunter Committee 3 was no gesture of modesty.
('19', 403, 1, 18, 859081) It was literally true.
('19', 403, 1, 19, 859104) I said that I could not claim to be a perfect satyagrahi.
('19', 403, 1, 20, 859162) If I had been one, it would not have been necessary even to write this sentence.
('19', 403, 1, 21, 859243) I would not, then, have had even the fear that I might be accused of self praise.
('19', 403, 1, 22, 859325) I have not the self assurance to claim that I never praise myself.
('19', 403, 1, 23, 859392) But in order that I might engage the genuine
('19', 403, 2, 24, 859437) 1 Worship of God 2 The Age of Truth 3 On January 9, 1920 at Ahmedabad, in his evidence before the Committee
('19', 404, 0, 1, 859545) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 405
('19', 404, 1, 2, 859593) interest of readers in truth and swadeshi, I beg leave to state, deliberately and knowingly, that I do not believe the profound feelings of the Punjabi women to be directed towards me personally.
('19', 404, 1, 3, 859789) They are taken up with admiration for me because of the truth they see in me and the simplicity of swadeshi which they have come to realize through me.
('19', 404, 1, 4, 859941) The men’s love is no less.
('19', 404, 1, 5, 859968) But I am not sure of its purity.
('19', 404, 1, 6, 860001) Some are drawn to me because I am a fighter against the Government.
('19', 404, 1, 7, 860069) Some think that, though I do not speak out, in fact I harbour a good deal of hatred which, being a shrewd man, I hide from others.
('19', 404, 1, 8, 860200) Some consider that I have great fighting capacity, no doubt, but that I am something of a fool for lack of intellect.
('19', 404, 1, 9, 860318) They do not, therefore, think it wrong to avail themselves of my fighting capacity and to show me sufficient regard with that end in view.
('19', 404, 1, 10, 860457) Others are genuine lovers of truth and swadeshi and, regarding me as more experienced in these matters than themselves, bear sincere affection for me.
('19', 404, 1, 11, 860608) Thus, since I suspect that men’s feelings for me are mixed, I am frequently uneasy and nervous when surrounded by men and sometimes I fear lest they and I together bring about some calamity.
('19', 404, 1, 12, 860799) But with regard to women, such an idea would not occur to me even in a dream.
('19', 404, 1, 13, 860877) They come to me with but one feeling in their heart and therefore their presence, even by the thousand, gives me nothing but a sense of peace.
('19', 404, 1, 14, 861020) They strengthen my faith and confidence in satyagraha and swadeshi, make me ever more resolute and create a new zest in me and inspire me to greater effort.
('19', 404, 1, 15, 861177) If I could inspire in men devotion as pure as I find in the women, within a year India would be raised to a height impossible to imagine.
('19', 404, 1, 16, 861315) As for swaraj, it would be the easiest thing in the world.
('19', 404, 1, 17, 861374) A Muslim servant of Sarladevi said something to her and she reported it to me.
('19', 404, 1, 18, 861453) I shall place it before my readers and close this letter with a request to them to ponder over it very carefully.
('19', 404, 1, 19, 861567) Many men and women address Sarladevi as Mataji or mother This servant said, “Mataji, if Mahatmaji keeps talking to all women about the spinning wheel, surely it is not without reason.
('19', 404, 1, 20, 861751) He is a man of God and believes that the Indian women can safeguard their dharma through it.
('19', 404, 1, 21, 861844) This is why he does what he does.” Sarladevi told me in some context that this servant was a good and devout man, and she passed on his ideas about swadeshi to me.
('19', 404, 1, 22, 862008) She was amazed to find such wisdom in one who could be called ignorant.
('19', 404, 1, 23, 862080) I was greatly pleased but by no means surprised.
('19', 404, 1, 24, 862129) The wisdom I have seen and learnt from so called illiterate people I have not learnt from others.
('19', 404, 1, 25, 862227) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 22 2 1920

('19', 405, 1, 2, 862306) 250. LETTER TO L. FRENCH
('19', 405, 2, 3, 862331) 2, MOZANG ROAD, LAHORE, February 15, 1920
('19', 405, 3, 4, 862373) DEAR MR. FRENCH, I have just returned from Sargodha where I heard from the lips of many witnesses the story of the persecution they said they underwent at the hands of the Tahsildar, Nadir Hosen Shah, who was in 1918 cruelly murdered, and other officials whilst recruiting was going on.
('19', 405, 3, 5, 862660) 1 I think that hard recruiting was necessary during the late War and that some kind of moral pressure was inevitable.
('19', 405, 3, 6, 862778) I think too that a certain amount of overzeal on the part of the inferior officials was to be looked for and can only now be looked [sic].
('19', 405, 3, 7, 862917) But the stories that had been repeated to me by several witnesses—men and women—cannot be ignored and I am sure His Honour 2 will not desire to excuse the oppression that is said to have been practised.
('19', 405, 3, 8, 863120) The statements made before me go to show that villagers were brought up on a wholesale scale and were called upon on pain of suffering inhuman tortures and indignities to send their sons as recruits if they were at all of age.
('19', 405, 3, 9, 863347) It is stated that for this purpose men were made naked, they were whipped on their buttocks and were made to bend themselves on thorns whilst they were whipped.
('19', 405, 3, 10, 863508) Women were made to drag men whose modesty was outraged.
('19', 405, 3, 11, 863564) Women themselves were made naked and subjected to disgraceful treatment because their husbands and boys were hiding themselves.
('19', 405, 3, 12, 863692) It has also been stated that men were falsely challaned 3 and otherwise brought under legal processes, that punitive police has been imposed on several villages in connection with the murder of the deceased Tahsildar and that members of the police levy unlawful exactions from the poor villagers.
('19', 405, 3, 13, 863989) In my humble opinion this is essentially a matter which requires a searching investigation and the officials who can be found to have
('19', 405, 4, 14, 864123) 1 Vide “Congress Report on the Punjab Disorders”, 25 3 1920.
('19', 405, 5, 15, 864184) 2 The Lt. Governor of the Punjab 3 Charge sheeted
('19', 406, 0, 1, 864234) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 407
('19', 406, 1, 2, 864282) persecuted villagers deprived [sic] of the opportunity of so doing.
('19', 406, 1, 3, 864350) I venture to think that the punitive police should be removed without delay and villagers freed from daily exactions.
('19', 406, 1, 4, 864468) The statements made are so serious that I feel it my duty not to publish them without at least drawing His Honour’s attention to them.
('19', 406, 1, 5, 864603) I shall be pleased to submit the statements for His Honour’s inspection should he desire to see them.
('19', 406, 1, 6, 864705) I am also prepared to wait on His Honour in this matter and render what assistance I may be capable of rendering in order to bring the true situation to light.
('19', 406, 1, 7, 864865) I am leaving today for Benares, c/o Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, by the Calcutta Mail and shall be there up to the 20th instant; thereafter at Sabarmati, B. B. & C. I. Railway.
('19', 406, 1, 8, 865042) I could wait on His Honour some time after the 6th March.
('19', 406, 1, 9, 865100) Urgent business will keep me away from the Punjab at least till that date.
('19', 406, 1, 10, 865175) I shall esteem it a favour if you will please drop me a line to say what His Honour’s wishes are in this important matter.
('19', 406, 2, 11, 865298) Yours sincerely,
('19', 406, 3, 12, 865315) L. FRENCH

('19', 407, 2, 3, 865499) MY DEAR CHILD, I am on my way to Benares 2 and we shall soon meet.

('19', 409, 1, 13, 870258) If national instinct does not mean at least this much kinship, it has no mea ning for me.

('19', 409, 1, 15, 870537) We must prov ide against them; we must not seek them, but we must be ready to face them if they come again.
('19', 409, 1, 16, 870645) I would not have us flinch from the battle of national life.

('19', 409, 1, 18, 870872) Some of us made stupid mistakes and the innocent suffered for them.
('19', 409, 1, 19, 870940) We must in future try to avoid the mistakes but in spite of our best effort, we may fail to convert everyone to sanity.

('19', 410, 1, 2, 871611) to the nation for maintenance in case of need.

('19', 411, 4, 6, 873985) SIR, On the 14th November 1919, the Punjab Sub committee of the All India Congress Committee appointed yourself, the Hon'ble Fazlul Haq 2, and Messrs C. R. Das, Abbas Tayabji 3 and M. K. Gandhi, as Commissioners, with Mr. K. Santanam as Secretary, to examine, sift , collate, and analyse the evidence already collected by and on behalf of the Sub commitee regarding the events of last April in the Punjab, and to supplement such evidence where necessary, and to present their conclusions thereon.
('19', 411, 4, 7, 874482) On being nominated President elect of the National Congress you considered it necessary to resign your office as Commissioner.
('19', 411, 4, 8, 874609) The resignation was duly accepted by the Sub committee and as the work of taking evidence was practically concluded when you resigned, no other commissioner was appointed in your place.
('19', 411, 4, 9, 874795) The Hon'ble Fazlul Haq was called away on important business immediately after his arrival.
('19', 411, 4, 10, 874887) Mr. M. R. Jayakar of the Bombay Bar was therefore appointed in his place.
('19', 411, 4, 11, 874961) We entered upon our work on the 17th November 1919. We examined the statements of over 1,700 witnesses and we have selected for publication about 650 statements, which will be found in the accompanying volumes of our report.
('19', 411, 4, 12, 875186) The statements excluded were mostly statements proving [the] same class of acts.
('19', 411, 4, 13, 875267) Every admitted statements was verified by one of us and was

('19', 412, 1, 19, 878116) We have endeavoured to procure the most accurate translations, but

('19', 415, 3, 4, 882753) MY DEAR CHILD, I found three love letters form you awaiting me on my return today.
('19', 415, 3, 5, 882836) I was delighted to note the air of cheerfulness, quiet resignation and trust in God in your letters.
('19', 415, 3, 6, 882937) The latter you always had in you.
('19', 415, 3, 7, 882971) But your letters show deeper trust.
('19', 415, 3, 8, 883007) May your trust go deeper and deeper still till at last you are freed from all doubt and therefore are all joy whatever happens.
('19', 415, 3, 9, 883135) For as we go forward in our journey of life, we have always problems coming up for decision and they are the hardest when the voice of Satan nearly approaches the voice of God.
('19', 415, 3, 10, 883312) Only fullest trust and perfect purity and extreme humility can lead us to the right choice.
('19', 415, 3, 11, 883404) I hope to be at the Ashram for at least a week and then hope to seek solitude and rest for a fortnight.
('19', 415, 3, 12, 883508) I shall certainly miss you tonight at the time of retiring.
('19', 415, 3, 13, 883568) With love,
('19', 415, 7, 14, 883579) You will be glad to learn that S. 's father has returned your watch.
('19', 415, 7, 15, 883648) The value lies not in the return but in the motive behind it.
('19', 415, 7, 16, 883710) You will take it when you return on your way to Denmark.

('19', 416, 7, 10, 884383) 259. HINDU MOHAMMEDAN UNITY Mr. Candler some time ago asked me in an imaginary interview whether, if I was sincere in my professions of Hindu Mohammedan unity, I would eat and drink with a Mohammedan and give my daughter in marriage to a Mohammedan.
('19', 416, 7, 11, 884633) This question has been asked again by some friends in another form.
('19', 416, 7, 12, 884701) Is it necessary for Hindu Mohammedan unity that there should be inter dining and intermarrying?
('19', 416, 7, 13, 884797) The questioners say that if the two are necessary, real unity can never take place because crores of Sanatanis would never reconcile themselves to inter dining, much less to inter marriage.
('19', 416, 7, 14, 884987) I am one of those who do not consider caste to be a harmful institution.
('19', 416, 7, 15, 885060) In its origin caste was a wholesome custom and pro moted national well being.
('19', 416, 7, 16, 885138) In my opinion the idea that inter dining or intermarrying is necessary for national growth is a supersti tion borrowed from the West.
('19', 416, 7, 17, 885272) Eating is a process just as vital as the other sanitary necessities of life.
('19', 416, 7, 18, 885349) And if mankind had not, much to its harm, made of eating a fetish and indulgence, we would have performed the operation of eating in private even as one performs the
('19', 416, 8, 19, 885515) 1 This date has been taken from the postal cancellation mark on the envelope.
('19', 416, 8, 20, 885593) 2 Investiture of a Parsi with the kasti, a sacred thread d worn round the waist
('19', 417, 0, 1, 885673) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 417, 1, 2, 885715) other necessary functions of life in private.
('19', 417, 1, 3, 885761) Indeed the highest culture in Hinduism regards eating in that light and there are thousands of Hindus still living who will not eat their food in the presence of anybody.
('19', 417, 1, 4, 885932) I can recall the names of several cultured men and women who ate their food in entire privacy but who never had any ill will against anybody and who lived on the friendliest terms with all.
('19', 417, 1, 5, 886122) Intermarriage is a still more difficult question.
('19', 417, 1, 6, 886172) If brothers and sisters can live on the friendliest footing without ever thinking of marrying each other, I can see no difficulty in my daughter regarding every Mohammedan as a brother and vice versa.
('19', 417, 1, 7, 886373) I hold strong views on religion and on marriage.
('19', 417, 1, 8, 886422) The greater the restraint we exercise with regard to our appetites whether about eating or marrying, the better we become from a religious standpoint.
('19', 417, 1, 9, 886573) I would despair of ever cultivating amicable relations with the world if I had to recognize the right or the propriety of any young man offering his hand in marriage to my daughter or to regard it as necessary for me to dine with anybody and everybody.
('19', 417, 1, 10, 886826) I claim that I am living on terms of friendliness with the whole world; I have never quarrelled with a single Mohammedan or Christian, but for years I have taken nothing but fruit in Mohammedan or Christian households.
('19', 417, 1, 11, 887045) I would most certainly decline to eat cooked food from the same plate with my son or to drink water out of a cup which his lips have touched and which has not been washed.
('19', 417, 1, 12, 887217) But the restraint or the exclusiveness exercised in these matters by me has never affected the closest com panionship with the Mohammedan or the Christian friends or my sons.
('19', 417, 1, 13, 887392) But inter dining and intermarriage have never been a bar to disunion, quarrels and worse.
('19', 417, 1, 14, 887482) The Pandavas 1 and the Kauravas 2flew at one another's throats without compunction although they inter dined and intermarried [sic].
('19', 417, 1, 15, 887615) The bitterness between the English and the Germans has not yet died out.
('19', 417, 1, 16, 887688) The fact is that intermarriage and inter dining are not neces sary factors in friendship and unity though they are often emblems thereof.
('19', 417, 1, 17, 887826) But insistence on either the one or the other can easily become and is today a bar to Hindu Mohammedan unity.
('19', 417, 1, 18, 887936) If we make ourselves believe that Hindus and Mohammedans cannot be one unless they inter dine or intermarry, we would be creating an
('19', 417, 2, 19, 888069) 1 The Pandavas, sons of King Pandu, and the Kauravas, sons of King Dhritarashtra, fought against each other the epic battle described in the Mahabharata, although they were cousins.
('19', 418, 0, 1, 888251) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 419
('19', 418, 1, 2, 888299) artificial barrier between us which it might be almost impossible to remove.
('19', 418, 1, 3, 888376) And it would seriously interfere with the growing unity between Hindus and Mohammedans if, for example, Mohammedan youths consider it lawful to court Hindu girls.
('19', 418, 1, 4, 888539) The Hindu parents will not, even if they [merely] suspected any such thing, freely admit Mohammedans to their homes as they have begun to do now.
('19', 418, 1, 5, 888685) In my opinion it is necessary for Hindu and Mohammedan young men to recognize this limitation.
('19', 418, 1, 6, 888780) I hold it to be utterly impossible for Hindus and Mohammedans to intermarry and yet retain intact each other's religion.
('19', 418, 1, 7, 888901) And the true beauty of Hindu Mohammedan unity lies in each remaining true to his own religion and yet being true to each other.
('19', 418, 1, 8, 889029) For, we are thinking of Hindus and Mohammedans even of the most orthodox type being able to regard one another as natural friends instead of regarding one another as natural enemies as they have done hitherto.
('19', 418, 1, 9, 889239) What then does the Hindu Mohammedan unity consist in and how can it be best promoted?
('19', 418, 1, 10, 889325) The answer is simple.
('19', 418, 1, 11, 889347) It consists in our having a common purpose, a common goal and common sorrows.
('19', 418, 1, 12, 889425) It is best promoted by co operating to reach the common goal, by sharing one another's sorrows and by mutual toleration.
('19', 418, 1, 13, 889546) A common goal we have.
('19', 418, 1, 14, 889569) We wish this great country of ours to be greater and self governing.
('19', 418, 1, 15, 889638) We have enough sorrows to share.
('19', 418, 1, 16, 889671) And today seeing that the Mohammedans are deeply touched on the question of Khilafat and their case is just, nothing can be so powerful for winning Mohammedan friendship for the Hindu as to give his whole hearted support to the Mohammedan claim.
('19', 418, 1, 17, 889917) No amount of drinking out of the same cup or dining out of the same bowl can bind the two as this help in the Khilafat question.
('19', 418, 1, 18, 890046) And mutual toleration is a necessity for all time and for all races.
('19', 418, 1, 19, 890115) We cannot live in peace if the Hindu will not tolerate the Mohammedan form of worship of God and his manners and customs or if the Mohammedans will be impatient of Hindu idolatry or cow worship.
('19', 418, 1, 20, 890310) It is not necessary for toleration that I must approve of what I tolerate.
('19', 418, 1, 21, 890385) I heartily dislike drinking, meat eating and smoking, but I tolerate all these in Hindus, Mohammedans and Christians even as I expect them to tolerate my abstinence from all these although they may dislike it.
('19', 418, 1, 22, 890595) All the quarrels between the Hindus and the Mohammedans have arisen from each wanting to force the other to his view.

('19', 419, 1, 2, 890778) 260. SPEECH AT MEETING OF MILL HANDS, AHMEDABAD 1
('19', 419, 2, 3, 890828) February 25, 1920 We have assembled here today to set up a union of workers, to approve its rules and adopt the necessary resolutions.
('19', 419, 2, 4, 890963) Before we start on this work, I must tell you that we should be perfectly clear about the aim of the organization we have undertaken to set up.
('19', 419, 2, 5, 891107) About two or three years ago, revered Anasuyabehn 2 had thought of founding a union of weavers and she had even taken some steps in that direction.
('19', 419, 2, 6, 891255) But my advice to her then was that it was responsible work and that, though we may have taken it up with the idea of serving the workers, if later we failed to shoulder the responsibility adequately we might, instead of serving the workers, do them much harm.
('19', 419, 2, 7, 891515) I do not mean to say that I am free of that fear today, but it is becoming plain to me that, in some ways, conditions in India are changing so much that we would do well to watch these changes carefully, study them and set up some such organizations by way of protection.
('19', 419, 2, 8, 891787) All I want you to understand is that, if we do not have, for running our organizations, sincere workers who know their duties well, we would be bringing down the axe on our own feet.
('19', 419, 2, 9, 891970) If such workers are not available, we had better not take up the difficult business of running a union.
('19', 419, 2, 10, 892074) This is exactly what I said two years ago, and I repeat it here today.
('19', 419, 2, 11, 892145) All manner of movements are going on these days among the workers of our country.
('19', 419, 2, 12, 892227) In all the countries ruled by the British and the European States, there is such chaos after the War that, if the workers fail to look after and safeguard their interests, they would be crushed.
('19', 419, 2, 13, 892422) Today, those people who cannot stand together as a nation and do not keep in step with other nations will find it impossible to survive.
('19', 419, 2, 14, 892559) The very machinery of Government is such that anyone who refuses to play his part in it and remains ignorant of his interests is sure to be wiped out.
('19', 419, 2, 15, 892710) In former times, there was no need for us to know what the king was doing, no need even to mention his name.
('19', 419, 2, 16, 892819) It was enough then if one paid the revenue dues in time, gave a bold

('19', 420, 1, 3, 893186) Today one cannot get away in this way.
('19', 420, 1, 4, 893225) Whether we want it or not, we are so intimately connected with the administration that, if we do not learn to look closely into affairs and understand our interests, we are bound to be crushed.
('19', 420, 1, 5, 893419) It is for this reason that I, though religiously inclined and having no interest in politics whatever, have been busy for the last several months with nothing but politics.

('19', 420, 1, 7, 893726) And this is exactly the point I wish to explain to you in simple words, namely, that the workers have no option but in some measure to interest themselves in politics.
('19', 420, 1, 8, 893894) Formerly, we knew only our fields.
('19', 420, 1, 9, 893929) There were neither mills, nor mill owners, nor laws governing them.
('19', 420, 1, 10, 893997) All these things have come in now.
('19', 420, 1, 11, 894032) We should therefore know what they are.
('19', 420, 1, 12, 894072) There are laws of dharma and of family life.
('19', 420, 1, 13, 894117) We do not, however, call them laws because they provide for no punishment or fine.
('19', 420, 1, 14, 894200) Now the time has come when no single individual can do us good, nor harm us either.
('19', 420, 1, 15, 894284) We shall have to manage our affairs ourselves.
('19', 420, 1, 16, 894331) It may so happen, in all this, that our representatives in the Government or the legislature may cut our throats for us while professing to speak for us.

('19', 420, 1, 18, 894550) We shall have to learn how to bring up our children, shall have to discover the reasons why the facilities for their education are poor and know why the prices of food grains rise.
('19', 420, 1, 19, 894731) The mothers present here will also have to learn how to bring up their children.
('19', 420, 1, 20, 894812) The time will come when it will be compulsory for us to send our children to the schools which will be opened.
('19', 420, 1, 21, 894923) If we do not exert ourselves to understand how these things work, to our advantage or otherwise, if we do not learn to be independent of others, we are as good as dead.
('19', 420, 1, 22, 895092) We have always had unions of Vanias 1and Brahmins, even of Kshatriyas, of a slightly different kind.
('19', 420, 1, 23, 895193) Now the time is ripe for unions of workers in which weavers, smiths, and spinners may come together and establish unity among their ranks, may discover what is good in themselves and what is bad and remedy the latter.
('19', 420, 1, 24, 895411) I caution you once again; by all means set up organizations, establish your unions, but see that you frame your rules and select your representatives, men to whom you will entrust your interests, with a full understanding of your responsibility.

('19', 423, 2, 12, 901761) 261. LETTER TO REGISTRAR, HIGH COURT, BOMBAY 1
('19', 423, 3, 13, 901808) THE SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 27, 1920

('19', 425, 4, 13, 905075) 263. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD
('19', 425, 5, 14, 905100) February 27, 1920 Perhaps all of you know that for some time past I have been something of an invalid and I shall, therefore, address you sitting.
('19', 425, 5, 15, 905247) I hope you will excuse me for doing so.
('19', 425, 5, 16, 905287) I find my name, too, included in the list of speakers at this meeting.
('19', 425, 5, 17, 905358) I have been assigned the duty of thanking Sarladevi and the Chairman.
('19', 425, 5, 18, 905428) 5 The sister who addressed you today and the Chairman are known to me very well and it gives me great pleasure, therefore, to perform this duty.
('19', 425, 5, 19, 905573) I am, personally, a beggar.
('19', 425, 5, 20, 905601) In my begging, I especially seek out sisters.
('19', 425, 5, 21, 905647) Men I have found everywhere.
('19', 425, 5, 22, 905676) But I try especially to seek out sisters, for I know that, unless our sisters in the country give their blessings to the brothers, India's progress is impossible.
('19', 425, 5, 23, 905839) In Ahmedabad, particularly, I have found such a sister.
('19', 425, 5, 24, 905895) At Bombay,

('19', 426, 1, 2, 906524) Madras and elsewhere, too, I have found someone or other.
('19', 426, 1, 3, 906582) In the Punjab, I found Sarladevi.
('19', 426, 1, 4, 906616) I first came to know her in 1910 and then I saw the husband and wife again in Hardwar.
('19', 426, 1, 5, 906703) Sarladevi invited me to the Punjab.
('19', 426, 1, 6, 906739) I accepted the invitation but felt nervous.
('19', 426, 1, 7, 906783) At the time she extended it, she was separated from her husband.
('19', 426, 1, 8, 906848) That made me wonder whether it would be proper for me to accept her hospitality.
('19', 426, 1, 9, 906929) However, I look upon it as my good fortune if I can share others' suffering and so I stayed with her in the Punjab.
('19', 426, 1, 10, 907045) I had from her as much service as from one's own sister and thus became her debtor.
('19', 426, 1, 11, 907129) If any sister carries my message to the country, I would bow to her in all reverence.
('19', 426, 1, 12, 907215) But, at the moment, I want to tell you that she has delivered to you not my message but Pandit Rambhuj Dutt Chowdhari's.
('19', 426, 1, 13, 907336) On an occasion such as this, this lady, ever doting on her husband, thought only of conveying her husband's message , and so put him on a pedestal.
('19', 426, 1, 14, 907484) Well, Chowdhariji's message is the message of the entire Punjab.
('19', 426, 1, 15, 907549) It asks you never to fear, never to accept defeat come what may, to love God and work on with patience and fortitude.
('19', 426, 1, 16, 907667) We would do well to inscribe this message in our hearts.
('19', 426, 1, 17, 907724) I go after good men as I do after good women.
('19', 426, 1, 18, 907770) This Chairman at today's meeting is known for his simplicity, his amiable nature and other fine qualities.
('19', 426, 1, 19, 907877) He has added to the achievements of his father and earned greater fame for himself.
('19', 426, 1, 20, 907961) As a reformer as also in other capacities, Shri Ramanbhai has done much.
('19', 426, 1, 21, 908034) If we learn his virtues and achieve something, that will be doing a great deal.
('19', 426, 1, 22, 908114) I once again thank Sarladevi and the Chairman on behalf of you all.

('19', 427, 6, 8, 908632) 265. PUNJAB LETTER
('19', 427, 7, 9, 908651) LEFT THE PUNJAB I am writing this letter sitting in the Ashram, after prayers.
('19', 427, 7, 10, 908730) How can a letter written in the Ashram be called a Punjab Letter?
('19', 427, 7, 11, 908796) I take the liberty of calling it so because my soul is still in the Punjab.
('19', 427, 7, 12, 908872) I find it impossible to forget the frankness and the plain living of the Punjabis, their simplicity and magnanimity of heart, nor can I forget their sufferings.
('19', 427, 7, 13, 909033) I feel that I have been purified by sharing, in however small a measure, in their tribulations.
('19', 427, 7, 14, 909129) I can now better understand the greatness of the religion of compassion and love sung by Tulsidas.
('19', 427, 7, 15, 909228) If I get time, I shall take some occasion to place before readers certain concrete instances of how that dharma is being followed.
('19', 427, 7, 16, 909359) However, my heart being still in the Punjab is not sufficient justification for calling this a Punjab Letter.
('19', 427, 7, 17, 909469) This letter, though written outside, will be mainly about the Punjab and for that reason can rightly be called a Punjab Letter.
('19', 427, 8, 18, 909597) PILGRIMAGE TO KASHI Last week I described the journey to the Gujrat district of the Punjab.
('19', 427, 8, 19, 909689) After this no more journeys were necessary for the purpose of the Committee's report .
('19', 427, 8, 20, 909776) It was time, moreover, that the report was

('19', 428, 0, 1, 910021) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 429
('19', 428, 1, 2, 910069) finalized.
('19', 428, 1, 3, 910080) The question was where the Commissioners 1 should assemble to read it over.
('19', 428, 1, 4, 910156) Kashi was likely to suit Pandit Motilal Nehru, Mr. C. R. Das and Pandit Malaviya.
('19', 428, 1, 5, 910238) It was decided, therefore, that all should go to Kashi.
('19', 428, 1, 6, 910294) Mr. Jayakar was already in Lahore.
('19', 428, 1, 7, 910329) He, together with Mr. Santanam, Dr. Parasram and Lala Harikishen Lal left Lahore for Kashi on the 15th.
('19', 428, 1, 8, 910433) On the way, Lala Girdhari Lal joined them at Amritsar.
('19', 428, 1, 9, 910488) Dr. Jivaraj Mehta 2 also came along to look after me.
('19', 428, 1, 10, 910542) We reached Kashi on the 16th.
('19', 428, 1, 11, 910572) I was deeply gratified to see Pandit Malaviya and our pious and scholarly Bhai Anandshankar Dhruva 3 on the platform.
('19', 428, 1, 12, 910690) The duty of drafting the report had been laid on me and I had not been able to complete the drafting in Lahore.
('19', 428, 1, 13, 910802) I had, therefore, to spend the entire time in writing it out and the other Commissioners in reading what I had written.
('19', 428, 1, 14, 910922) The commissioners guarded me and saved me out of their great affection.
('19', 428, 1, 15, 910994) This is a memory which I shall ever cherish.
('19', 428, 1, 16, 911039) Malaviyaji's love is something I cannot describe.
('19', 428, 1, 17, 911089) He literally stood guard and, although our relations are such that we would scarcely allow a moment to pass without talking about the virtue of service, we both controlled ourselves and refrained from conversation.
('19', 428, 1, 18, 911304) I wanted very much to have a talk with Anandshankar and listen to his experiences in Kashi but had to restrain myself.
('19', 428, 1, 19, 911423) It was in this sanctifying and loving atmosphere that the report was completed.
('19', 428, 1, 20, 911503) We may now confidently expect that it will be published in the beginning of March.
('19', 428, 2, 21, 911586) SUNRISE We were staying with Panditji on the banks of the Ganga.
('19', 428, 2, 22, 911651) Dawn and sunrise are impressive everywhere, but from these banks the sight was simply sublime.
('19', 428, 2, 23, 911746) As the clouds brightened with the light of dawn, a golden sheen would appear on the waters of the Ganga and, when the sun had come into view over the horizon, there seemed to stand in the water of the river a great pillar of gold.
('19', 428, 2, 24, 911977) It was a scene on which the eyes would rest with supreme satisfaction and make the pious devotee burst forth spontaneously into the gayatri 4 hymn.
('19', 428, 3, 25, 912125) 1 Appointed by the Punjab Sub committee of the Congress; vide “Letter to Motilal Nehru”, 20 2 1920. 2 An eminent physician who later became the first Chief Minister of Gujarat State 3 Vice Chancellor, Banaras Hindu university 4 Vedic prayer to the sun god for illumination
('19', 429, 0, 1, 912398) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 429, 1, 2, 912440) witnessing this magnificent sight, I felt I understood a little better the worship of the sun, the adoration of the rivers and the significance of the gayatri hymn.
('19', 429, 1, 3, 912605) Walking on that spot, I was filled with pride for our country and our traditions but at the same time, as I thought of the present conditions, I felt sad.
('19', 429, 1, 4, 912760) I observed people defecating on the very banks of the river.
('19', 429, 1, 5, 912821) We no more go out to the jungle but, instead, go to the river bank.
('19', 429, 1, 6, 912889) In this holy spot, it should be possible for us to walk barefoot with our eyes closed, whereas one has to walk here with the greatest caution.
('19', 429, 1, 7, 913032) One also feels disgust to sip the Ganga water at this spot.
('19', 429, 1, 8, 913092) Before I had finished thinking of the filth of this spot, I was reminded of the Kashi Vishvanath temple.
('19', 429, 1, 9, 913197) The narrow lane leading to the temple, the stink, the heap of rotting flowers which I had seen there, the harshness and the lack of cleanliness of the Brahmin priests—as I thought of all these, I heaved a sigh and remembered the cause of degradation of the Hindus.
('19', 429, 1, 10, 913462) From this my mind turned to Panditji and his work.
('19', 429, 1, 11, 913513) He will be judged in future by the success of the Kashi University.
('19', 429, 1, 12, 913581) Will he pass the test?
('19', 429, 1, 13, 913604) I remembered his piety, his sacrifices, his magnificent service to Bharatvarsha 1. Dhruvaji 2 is his right hand.
('19', 429, 1, 14, 913717) Remembering that the affairs of the university were in the hands of two such pious men, I felt reassured.
('19', 429, 1, 15, 913823) I thought that, if the students of this university grew to be religious and learned men, there was room to hope for cleanliness in the temple and on the banks of the Ganga.
('19', 429, 1, 16, 913996) Whether the university has this capacity or not, it is the task of every Hindu to find ways to remove the inner and outer defilement that has crept into the Hindu religion and every Hindu, even sitting in his own home, can make a start this very day.
('19', 429, 1, 17, 914247) If each one was scrupulous about his own cleanliness, the Kashi Vishvanath would soon be as clean as we could wish.
('19', 429, 2, 18, 914363) STUDENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY Having been commanded by Panditji to say a few words to the students, I spoke before them at 7.30 on the morning of my departure, and gave them my ideas about student life 3 .
('19', 429, 2, 19, 914566) The student's stage of life is similar to the sannyasi's and his life should, therefore, be pure and celibate.
('19', 429, 2, 20, 914677) Today two cultures are competing for the students' attention—the ancient and the modern.
('19', 429, 2, 21, 914766) Self restraint was the
('19', 429, 3, 22, 914789) 1 India 2 Anandshanker Dhruva 3 Vide “Speech at Meeting of Students, Banaras”, 21 2 1920.
('19', 430, 0, 1, 914879) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 431
('19', 430, 1, 2, 914927) key note of the former.
('19', 430, 1, 3, 914951) Ancient culture tells us that a man advances in the measure that he deliberately and with full knowledge reduces his wants.
('19', 430, 1, 4, 915075) Modern civilization teaches us that man progresses by increasing his wants.
('19', 430, 1, 5, 915151) The difference between self restraint and self indulgence is the difference between dharma and adharma 1 .
('19', 430, 1, 6, 915258) The ideal of self restraint attaches less importance to the outward life than to the inner.
('19', 430, 1, 7, 915350) There is a danger that in place of the ancient culture based on self restraint, the modern civilization of self indulgence will be accepted.
('19', 430, 1, 8, 915491) Students can play decisive part in averting this danger.
('19', 430, 1, 9, 915548) University students will be judged, not by their knowledge, but solely by their good conduct.
('19', 430, 1, 10, 915642) Religious education and ethical conduct should be given the first place in this university.
('19', 430, 1, 11, 915734) This requires the fullest co operation from the students.
('19', 430, 1, 12, 915792) Panditji himself is a man of piety and virtue.
('19', 430, 1, 13, 915839) By bringing another man of similar qualities, viz., Anandshankar, he has provided an opportunity to the students.
('19', 430, 1, 14, 915953) I should like them to make the best use of this opportunity and adorn their learning with dharma.
('19', 430, 1, 15, 916051) These were the thoughts I placed before them on that morning.
('19', 430, 1, 16, 916113) I have repeatedly expressed these ideas, in one form or another, at several places, and a summary of these same ideas which I explained to the students of Kashi University on getting this happy opportunity, I now lay before readers of Navajivan for them to think over.
('19', 430, 1, 17, 916382) I am convinced that we cannot profit from political reforms unless we also give thought to religion.
('19', 430, 1, 18, 916483) Religion will not be revived through these reforms.
('19', 430, 1, 19, 916535) Rather, it is religion which will supply what the reforms may lack.
('19', 430, 2, 20, 916603) GUJARATIS IN KASHI I did not know till today that a large number of Gujaratis lived in Kashi.
('19', 430, 2, 21, 916697) Anandshankarbhai got me an opportunity of meeting them.
('19', 430, 2, 22, 916753) Panditji was also present.
('19', 430, 2, 23, 916780) The Gujaratis showed their sense of propriety by using this occasion for presenting an address to him.
('19', 430, 2, 24, 916883) While offering my thanks to them, I put a few suggestions before them.
('19', 430, 2, 25, 916954) I advised them to send back to Gujarat those defects which were regarded as typical of Gujaratis, and bank only on their good qualities.
('19', 430, 2, 26, 917091) By so doing they would bring credit both to Gujarat and to the country.
('19', 430, 2, 27, 917163) In practical affairs, every man encounters numerous moral difficulties.
('19', 430, 2, 28, 917235) At such times, a friend becomes a necessity.
('19', 430, 2, 29, 917280) This they had in the person of Anandshankarbhai.
('19', 430, 2, 30, 917329) I hoped that they would take ample advantage of his presence among them.

('19', 431, 1, 2, 917468) from Kashi to Delhi, I met the Hon'ble Srinivasa Sastri and, bringing Sarladevi 1 along with me, I was back in the Ashram on the 23rd.
('19', 431, 1, 3, 917603) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 29 2 1920
('19', 431, 2, 4, 917640) 266. HINDU MUSLIM UNITY It would be no exaggeration to say that the unity which prevails today between the Hindus and the Muslims is unparallelled in the present age.
('19', 431, 2, 5, 917807) We all desire that it should remain undisturbed.
('19', 431, 2, 6, 917856) However, unless our desire is backed up by efforts to that end, this unity cannot be kept up, nor can it be strengthened.
('19', 431, 2, 7, 917978) There is no doubt that, if it has been brought about to serve self interest, it will not continue once the interests have been served.
('19', 431, 2, 8, 918113) We should therefore examine the reasons for this growth in unity.
('19', 431, 2, 9, 918179) Many of my friends question me about it.
('19', 431, 2, 10, 918220) Some misun derstandings may be removed if I repeat here the answer I gave them.
('19', 431, 2, 11, 918300) Some of them feel I am not well advised to take a leading part on the Khilafat issue.
('19', 431, 2, 12, 918386) One party asserts that it is impossible to overcome the bitter hostility between the Hindus and the Muslims.
('19', 431, 2, 13, 918495) I do not wish to answer this question here.
('19', 431, 2, 14, 918539) I can only observe that, if we keep raising such questions it will become impossible for us to solve many of our complicated problems.
('19', 431, 2, 15, 918674) It is said the human effort can achieve anything and we see that indeed it does.
('19', 431, 2, 16, 918755) If so, we need not assume that the problem is incapable of solution.
('19', 431, 2, 17, 918824) Another party argues that, though the Khilafat may well be a religious issue for Muslims, they do not have justice on their side.
('19', 431, 2, 18, 918954) How are we concerned with Turkey?
('19', 431, 2, 19, 918988) There is no limit to the injustices perpetrated by that country.
('19', 431, 2, 20, 919053) What good will it do to the world to restore its tyrannical rule?
('19', 431, 2, 21, 919119) A number of similar questions are raised.
('19', 431, 2, 22, 919161) I shall try to answer them all some other time, but the main points I shall examine now.
('19', 431, 2, 23, 919250) I believe that, on the Khilafat issue, the Muslim stand is entirely just.
('19', 431, 2, 24, 919324) If it were purely a case of religious feelings and these feelings did not appeal to our reason, I admit that we would in no wise be bound to help them in the matter.
('19', 431, 2, 25, 919490) Even apart from the religious issues involved in the Khilafat, the Muslims are still on the path of justice.
('19', 431, 2, 26, 919599) The Allies had accepted, and so had President Wilson, the principle that the boundaries of the different countries as they
('19', 431, 3, 27, 919722) 1 Sarladevi Chowdhrani
('19', 432, 0, 1, 919745) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 433
('19', 432, 1, 2, 919793) existed when the War started should remain intact, and that no country should be made to suffer by way of punishment.
('19', 432, 1, 3, 919911) The Muslims want them to abide by this principle.
('19', 432, 1, 4, 919961) They demand that the territories held by Turkey in August 1914 be restored to her, that Arabia and the holy places of Islam remain under the control of the Khalifa, and they say that they would not mind the Sultan being asked to furnish reasonable guarantees for the protection of his Christian and Jewish subjects, consistent with his dignity.
('19', 432, 1, 5, 920306) The Arabs may remain free.
('19', 432, 1, 6, 920333) I find none of these demands unreasonable.
('19', 432, 1, 7, 920376) They meet the objec tion based on the alleged oppression by Turkey.
('19', 432, 1, 8, 920444) There have been pro mises by British ministers 1 to this effect.
('19', 432, 1, 9, 920509) If, now, the Muslims do not get what was promised, they will suffer grave injustice and their religious feelings will be hurt.
('19', 432, 1, 10, 920636) Hence I feel that, if we wish to do our duty by our neighbours, it is incumbent on us to help our Muslim brethren.
('19', 432, 2, 11, 920751) The orthodox Hindus, however, tell me : ‘All right, we shall help them.
('19', 432, 2, 12, 920823) But nowadays Hindus drink water from the same glass, sit at meals together with them and talk of Hindus and Muslims giving their sons and daughters in marriage to one another.’ This is a genuine fear among the orthodox Hindus, but there is no good reason for entertaining it.
('19', 432, 2, 13, 921099) In order that we may help them on the Khilafat issue, there is absolutely no need to drink water from the same glass, sit together at meals or give sons and daughters in marriage.
('19', 432, 2, 14, 921279) Unity will come about only when the Hindu, while scrupulously following his own religion, regards the Muslim as his brother.
('19', 432, 2, 15, 921404) I do not love my son the less though I wash clean the glass he has used, or do not allow him to drink from my glass without washing it .
('19', 432, 2, 16, 921541) A brother and a sister do not marry, but where else shall we find such pure love as exists between them?
('19', 432, 2, 17, 921646) Many Hindus do not marry in the same gotra 2 but this does not detract from their unity.
('19', 432, 2, 18, 921735) Really speaking, if we consider such freedom in matters of drinking, eating and marriage essential for unity, then unity between Hindus and Muslims will never come about.
('19', 432, 2, 19, 921906) Hence, whenever I hear that a Hindu and a Muslim drank from the same glass or ate from the same plate, I feel sorry because an orthodox Hindu is bound to be hurt even on hearing of these things.
('19', 432, 2, 20, 922101) It would be an entirely different matter if there is some good reason why we should not mind hurting them.
('19', 432, 2, 21, 922208) When, however, drinking
('19', 432, 3, 22, 922232) 1 Asquith and Lloyd George 2 Lineage on the male side
('19', 433, 0, 1, 922286) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 433, 1, 2, 922328) water from the same glass implies no unity, to give prominence to the act as an expression of unity is creating an obstacle in the way of unity.
('19', 433, 1, 3, 922473) I personally believe that we have given false importance to eating and thus invited disease and starvation, and made self control difficult.

('19', 435, 2, 12, 928419) She completed her B.A. at the age of 19, and from then onwards has been engaged in public service in one form or another.
('19', 435, 2, 13, 928541) It was she who started the Bengali monthly, named Bharati, and it is said that she showed in it the great power of her pen.
('19', 435, 2, 14, 928665) Her poetic power is of a high order and her sweet song “I bow to India”, which was sung in Banaras, is known all over the country.
('19', 435, 2, 15, 928796) Shrimati Sarladevi took a leading part in establishing committees in Bengal and, when the War broke out, and it came to telling the educated Bengalis that they should join the army and do their duty, few were as effective as this lady.

('19', 435, 2, 17, 929090) Her musical talent perhaps exceeds her gift for poetry and she is, therefore, in demand at every Congress.

('19', 436, 2, 3, 929765) PROPAGATION OF SWADESHI IN NADIAD
('19', 436, 3, 4, 929799) To propagate swadeshi in Nadiad, a company named the “Swadeshi Bhandar Limited” has been formed.
('19', 436, 3, 5, 929896) It has ten shares of a lakh each and ten thousand shares of ten rupees each.
('19', 436, 3, 6, 929973) This enterprise has been launched with the purpose of supplying sufficient cloth to those who have taken the vows of pure and of mixed swadeshi in Nadiad and other places and for popularizing hand spun, hand woven cloth.
('19', 436, 3, 7, 930194) The company's profit is restricted to a maximum of six and a quarter per cent and the commission for the agents has been fixed at 25 per cent on the net profit.
('19', 436, 3, 8, 930355) This venture has been started not with the object of making profit, but solely for the purpose of propagating swadeshi, and the friends who will manage it have joined it, we believe, wholly with the idea of service.
('19', 436, 3, 9, 930571) We have, therefore, welcomed this enterprise.
('19', 436, 3, 10, 930617) The organizers hope that, instead of a few persons buying up the shares, a large number will buy a few shares each.
('19', 436, 3, 11, 930733) It is also their aim to permit no speculation in the name of this company and no transfer of shares purely for such purpose.
('19', 436, 3, 12, 930858) The shareholders, too, it is hoped, will not subscribe with the sole object of earning heavy interest but entirely with the idea of encouraging swadeshi.
('19', 436, 3, 13, 931012) A company formed with such restrictions ought to be welcomed.
('19', 436, 3, 14, 931074) We, therefore, hope that people of ordinary means will buy shares in this company and encourage this enterprise, and also that the organizers, despite any difficulties they may have to face, will never give up the aims they have set before them.

('19', 438, 2, 10, 934417) Its political significance can be gauged from the fact that as soon as the news was received in Lahore all the preparations that were made to accord a fitting welcome to Lala Lajpat Rai were immediately cancelled and the capital of the Punjab was reported to be in deep mourning.

('19', 442, 1, 2, 941965) 275. SPEECH ON PRESS ACT, BOMBAY 1
('19', 442, 2, 3, 942000) March 5, 1920 The fact that the man 2 who struggled more than anyone else for the repeal of this law is not present here is a shame both to the people and the Government.
('19', 442, 2, 4, 942171) If the Government offered to repeal this Act, but wanted to shelve the question of Horniman’s return to India, 3 I am sure the Indian people would not accept that.
('19', 442, 2, 5, 942335) The question which I keep asking myself is this: ‘if there were no newspapers to give expression to public opinion, how would the Government ever know it?’ For want of independent newspapers, the Government has to rely upon the C.I.D 4. The people, therefore, request the Government that, if it wanted to lighten this burden on the C.I.D., if it was anxious to see independent newspapers in India and felt the need for people’s co operation, it should not gag newspapers, which are representatives of public opinion.
('19', 442, 2, 6, 942852) The Government’s condition at present is like that of the meteorologist who has smashed his barometer and would yet measure the atmospheric pressure.
('19', 442, 2, 7, 943002) Not only journalists but the entire public should carry on a powerful agitation to secure repeal of this Act.
('19', 442, 2, 8, 943112) Were I to describe the worries and hardships of journalists, I would fill a volume as big as the Mahabharata.
('19', 442, 2, 9, 943222) People sometimes praise me and some times swear at me as well; sometimes they defend the authorities, and occasionally denounce them too.
('19', 442, 2, 10, 943360) It is for journalists to sepa rate the grain from the chaff in all this.
('19', 442, 2, 11, 943433) It is the journalist’s duty to throw light on every matter of public concern.
('19', 442, 2, 12, 943511) However, not to admit in one’s paper a single adjective which does not serve the people’s cause in the most effective means of securing the repeal of the Press Act.

('19', 443, 12, 14, 944865) 278. CONDITION OF “NAVAJIVAN”
('19', 443, 13, 15, 944895) At the time the Navajivan was converted into a weekly and I took over its editorship, 4 I had mentally decided upon certain conditions.
('19', 443, 13, 16, 945031) Some of those which the reader knows I recall here : 1. Not to accept advertisements for money in Navajivan.
('19', 443, 13, 17, 945140) 2. Not to publish Navajivan at a loss.
('19', 443, 13, 18, 945179) These days about nine thousand copies of Navajivan are sold.
('19', 443, 13, 19, 945240) I would not be satisfied till the number rises to twenty thousand and would not be surprised if it increased to fifty thousand.
('19', 443, 13, 20, 945368) So far, however, we have not been able to provide for the printing of so many copies.
('19', 443, 13, 21, 945454) We do not have such a machine, nor the required number of men.
('19', 443, 13, 22, 945517) We do not have a building in which so many copies can be printed with ease; moreover, my co workers and I are not yet able to supply articles of the quality and in quantity to tempt fifty thousand
('19', 443, 14, 23, 945714) 1 Who had gone to Calcutta in connection with the Bengal Provincial Khilafat Conference held on February 28 and 29 2 March 19, the Khilafat Day 3 In regard to the Punjab atrocities of 1919. Gandhiji had asked for these as he was preparing the manuscript of the Congress Report thereon for the press and also to send to Lt. Governor of the Punjab; Vide “Letter to L. Franch”, 29 2 1920. 4 This was with effect from September 7, 1919
('19', 444, 0, 1, 946146) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 445
('19', 444, 1, 2, 946194) subscribers.
('19', 444, 1, 3, 946207) God willing, such a time will come.
('19', 444, 1, 4, 946243) I would consider the last issue to be of such a standard; previously, too, a few such issues came out.
('19', 444, 1, 5, 946346) But, as an English saying has it, one swallow does not make a summer.
('19', 444, 1, 6, 946416) Similarly one good issue of Navajivan cannot be the standard for judging all.
('19', 444, 1, 7, 946494) The last issue was especially good because of Sarladevi’s article, “Bandhu”, appearing in it.
('19', 444, 1, 8, 946588) It was written in two instalments.
('19', 444, 1, 9, 946623) The first part was written several years ago when she was living in some region covered with woods, but it had remained un published.
('19', 444, 1, 10, 946757) Recently, on my begging her, she searched it out, supple mented it and made it into the likeness of a perfect poem and then gifted it to me.
('19', 444, 1, 11, 946898) The original article is in Bengali.
('19', 444, 1, 12, 946934) As it was found difficult to translate, its appearance in Navajivan was delayed.
('19', 444, 1, 13, 947015) Two or three meanings can be read in this article.
('19', 444, 1, 14, 947066) But I would advise my readers to peruse it several times over and extract all the sweetness from it.
('19', 444, 1, 15, 947167) They will discover that its sweetness is inexhaustible.
('19', 444, 1, 16, 947223) But I have digressed.
('19', 444, 1, 17, 947245) These days Navajivan is sold at a loss.
('19', 444, 1, 18, 947285) The cost of one copy comes to 16 pies, of which eight pies are for paper.
('19', 444, 1, 19, 947359) Having started with good quality paper, we do not like to change over to inferior quality.
('19', 444, 1, 20, 947450) Hence it has been decided to effect some saving by reducing the size.
('19', 444, 1, 21, 947520) Instead of sixteen pages, only twelve pages are given this time, but not even four pies are saved in this way.
('19', 444, 1, 22, 947631) And so it has been decided to sell single copies in Bombay and Ahmedabad at five pice instead of four.
('19', 444, 1, 23, 947734) This will stop the loss.
('19', 444, 1, 24, 947759) The reader will see that so long as basically Navajivan suffers loss, increasing its sale would mean increased loss.
('19', 444, 1, 25, 947876) In its present state of loss, therefore, even increasing its sale is out of the question.
('19', 444, 1, 26, 947966) When Navajivan was started, eight pages were promised but, the circumstances having permitted, sixteen pages were given.
('19', 444, 1, 27, 948087) Even now the reader will get more than the promised eight pages.
('19', 444, 1, 28, 948152) I wish to state at the same time that no subjects will be avoided for lack of space, but more concise articles, costing greater effort,will be given and an attempt made to include as many subjects as at present.
('19', 444, 1, 29, 948364) Often lengthy articles are produced in order to fill up space in papers.
('19', 444, 1, 30, 948437) Frequently the author writes his articles in haste and fails to arrange his ideas properly.
('19', 444, 1, 31, 948529) One finds it difficult to understand them and, sometimes, a thought in itself easy to understand is expressed in such a roundabout way that it costs an effort to understand it.
('19', 444, 1, 32, 948706) I hope, therefore, that contributors to Navajivan will write more concisely and, looking upon themselves as joint proprietors, co operate to make it prosper.
('19', 444, 1, 33, 948864) Our aim in starting Navajivan was not business; it was,
('19', 445, 0, 1, 948920) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 445, 1, 2, 948962) through its means, to render what little service we could to the people and, at a time when new life was flowing into them, to guide them, to the best of our ability, along straightforward and simple paths and help them in solving complicated problems.
('19', 445, 1, 3, 949215) Contributors to Navajivan should, therefore, try and see that, though they write more briefly, they do not give less substance.
('19', 445, 1, 4, 949343) If the price of paper comes down, or if any losses are due to our inefficiency in the Navajivan Press or the office and if matters can be set right, we will do so and start giving sixteen pages again.
('19', 445, 1, 5, 949544) If we do not want Navajivan to run at a loss, we do not want any profit either.
('19', 445, 1, 6, 949624) Any saving, therefore, will be passed on to readers.
('19', 445, 1, 7, 949677) I hope they will see this, and, looking upon Navajivan as their own property, co operate in improving its condition.
