('19', 446, 2, 5, 951553) 280. LETTER TO THE PRESS [March 7, 1920] 1
('19', 446, 3, 6, 951596) The Khilafat question has now become a question of questions.
('19', 446, 3, 7, 951658) It has become an Imperial question of the first magnitude.
('19', 446, 3, 8, 951717) The great prelates of England and the Mohammedan leaders combined have brought the question to the fore.
('19', 446, 3, 9, 951822) The prelates threw down the challenge.
('19', 446, 3, 10, 951861) The Muslim leaders have taken it up.
('19', 446, 3, 11, 951898) I trust that the Hindus will realize that the Khilafat question overshadows the Reforms 2 and everything else.
('19', 446, 3, 12, 952009) If the Muslim claim was unjust apart from the Muslim scriptures, one might hesitate to support it merely on scriptural authority.
('19', 446, 3, 13, 952139) But when a just claim is supported by scriptures, it becomes irresistible.
('19', 446, 3, 14, 952214) Briefly put, the claim is that the Turks should retain Euro pean Turkey subject to full guarantees for the protection of non Muslim races under the Turkish Empire and that the Sultan should control the holy places of Islam and should have suzeraint over Jazirat ul Arab, i.e., Arabia as defined by the Muslim savants subject to self governing rights being given to the Arabs if they so desire.
('19', 446, 3, 15, 952608) This was what was promised 3 by Mr. Lloyd George and this was what Lord Hardinge had contemplated.
('19', 446, 3, 16, 952707) 4 The Mohammedan soldiers would not have fought to deprive Turkey of her possessions.
('19', 446, 3, 17, 952793) To deprive the
('19', 446, 4, 18, 952808) 1 This “manifesto” on the Khilafat question was released from Sabarmati Ashram Ahmedabad, on March 7, 1920. 2 The Montagu Chelmsford Reforms of 1919 3 In his speech of January 5, 1918, wherein he declared that the Allies were not fighting “to deprive Turkey of its capital or of the rich and renowned lands of Asia Minor and Thrace” 4 Evidently the reference is to the Proclamation issued by the Government of India on November 2, 1914, which declared that “no question of a religious character was involved” in the War.
('19', 447, 0, 1, 953329) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 447, 1, 2, 953371) Khalif of the suzerainty of Arabia is to reduce the Khilafat to a nullity.
('19', 447, 1, 3, 953446) To restore to Turkey, subject to necessary guarantees, what was hers before the War is a Christian solution.
('19', 447, 1, 4, 953555) To wrest any of her possessions from her for the sake of punishing her is a gun powder solution.
('19', 447, 1, 5, 953652) The Allies or England in the hour of triumph must be scrupulously just.
('19', 447, 1, 6, 953724) To reduce the Turks to impotence would be not only unjust.
('19', 447, 1, 7, 953783) It would be a breach of solemn declarations and promises.
('19', 447, 1, 8, 953841) It is to be wished that the Viceroy will take his courage in both his hands and place himself at the head of the Khilafat agitation as Lord Hardinge did at the time of the South African“passive resistance” struggle 1 and thus like his predecessor give a clear and emphatic direction to an agitation which under impulsive or faulty leadership may lead to disastrous consequences.
('19', 447, 1, 9, 954220) But the situation rests more with us Hindus and Mohammedans than with the Viceroy and still more with the Muslim leaders than with the Hindus or the Viceroy.
('19', 447, 1, 10, 954378) There are signs already of impatience on the part of Muslim friends and impatience may any day be reduced to madness and the latter must inevitably lead to violence.
('19', 447, 1, 11, 954544) And I wish I could persuade everyone to see that violence is suicide.
('19', 447, 1, 12, 954614) Supposing the Muslim demands are not granted by the Allies or, say, England!
('19', 447, 1, 13, 954691) I see nothing but hope in Mr. Montagu’s brave defence of the Muslim position and Mr. Lloyd George’s interpretation of his own declaration.

('19', 447, 1, 15, 954899) But we must suppose the worst and expect and strive for the best.
('19', 447, 1, 16, 954965) How to strive is the question.
('19', 447, 1, 17, 954996) What we may not do is clear enough : 1. There should be no violence in thought, speech or deed.
('19', 447, 1, 18, 955092) 2. Therefore there should be no boycott of British goods, by way of revenge or punishment.
('19', 447, 1, 19, 955183) Boycott, in my opinion, is a form of violence.
('19', 447, 1, 20, 955230) Moreover, even if it were desirable, it is totally impracticable.
('19', 447, 1, 21, 955296) 3. There should be no rest till the minimum is achieved.
('19', 447, 1, 22, 955353) 4. There should be no mixing up of other questions with the Khilafat, e.g., the Egyptian question.
('19', 447, 1, 23, 955452) Let us see what must be done :

('19', 450, 1, 2, 960033) 282. THE 6TH APRIL AND THE 13TH
('19', 450, 2, 3, 960065) It is impossible for us to forget the 6th of April 1 which vitalized the whole of India and the13th of April 2 which by the spilling of innocent blood has made the Punjab a place of pilgrimage for the whole of India.
('19', 450, 2, 4, 960282) The 6th of April saw the advent of satyagraha.
('19', 450, 2, 5, 960329) One may dissent from the civil disobedience part of it but no one can dissent from the essential doctrine of truth and love or non injury.
('19', 450, 2, 6, 960468) With satya combined with ahimsa you can bring the world to your feet.
('19', 450, 2, 7, 960538) Satyagraha in its essence is nothing but the introduction of truth and gentleness in the political, i.e., the national life.
('19', 450, 2, 8, 960663) And whether one takes the satyagraha pledge or not, there can be no doubt that the spirit of satyagraha has pervaded the masses.
('19', 450, 2, 9, 960792) Anyway, that is my experience of thousands of Punjabis I met throughout my tour in the Punjab.
('19', 450, 2, 10, 960887) The 6th of April again saw the inauguration of a definite plan of Hindu Muslim unity and swadeshi.
('19', 450, 2, 11, 960986) It was the 6th of April which broke the spirit underlying the Rowlatt Act and made it a dead letter.
('19', 450, 2, 12, 961087) The 13th of April saw not merely the terrific tragedy, but in that tragedy Hindu Muslim blood flowed freely in a mingled stream and sealed the compact.
('19', 450, 2, 13, 961239) How to commemorate or celebrate these two great national events?
('19', 450, 2, 14, 961304) I venture to suggest that those who will, should devote the 6th April next to fast (twenty four hours abstention from food)and prayer and that all over India at 7 p.m., public meetings should be held praying for the repeal of the Rowlatt Act and expressing the national belief that there will be no peace in the land till that Act is repealed.
('19', 450, 2, 15, 961648) That the Act is a dead letter is not enough.
('19', 450, 2, 16, 961693) Either it is a disgrace or it is not.
('19', 450, 2, 17, 961731) If it is, the Act must be repealed.
('19', 450, 2, 18, 961767) The repeal before the reforms 3 will be a token of goodwill on the part of the Government.
('19', 450, 2, 19, 961858) The whole of the week beginning from the 6th should be devoted to some work connected with the tragedy of the 13th.
('19', 450, 2, 20, 961974) I therefore venture further to suggest that the week should be devoted to the collecting of funds for the Jallianwala Bagh memorial, it being remembered that the sum to be collected is ten lakhs of rupees.
('19', 450, 3, 21, 962180) 1 April 6, 1919, the day of universal hartal 2 April 13, 1919, the day of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre 3 The Montagu Chelmsford reforms of 1919, then awaiting implementation
('19', 451, 0, 1, 962355) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 451, 1, 2, 962397) village or town can devise its own plan of collection, guarding against misappropriation and fraud.
('19', 451, 1, 3, 962497) The collection should be finished by the evening of the 12th April.
('19', 451, 1, 4, 962565) Then the 13th.
('19', 451, 1, 5, 962580) That day of days should be devoted to fasting and prayer.

('19', 451, 1, 8, 962733) We do not want to remember the wickedness of the deed.

('19', 451, 1, 10, 962866) On that day I would also have the nation to remember the mass excesses 1 and feel penitent for them.
('19', 451, 1, 11, 962967) We close the week by meetings throughout India to pass resolutions urging the Government, both Imperial and Indian, to take effective steps to render a repetition of the tragedy impossible.
('19', 451, 1, 12, 963157) I would further urge that during the week each one does his or her best in his or her own person to realize more fully than ever the princi ples of satyagraha, Hindu Muslim unity and swadeshi.
('19', 451, 1, 13, 963350) In order to empha size Hindu Muslim unity I would advise joint meetings of Hindus and Mohammedans on Friday, the 12th April, at 7 p.m., urging that the Khi lafat question be decided in accordance with the just Muslim sentiments.
('19', 451, 1, 14, 963579) Thus this national week should be a week of purification, self examination, sacrifice, exact discipline and expression of cherished national sentiments.
('19', 451, 1, 15, 963732) There should be no trace of bitterness, no violence of language but absolute fearlessness and firmness.
('19', 451, 1, 16, 963836) Should there not also be hartal on the 6th and the 13th?
('19', 451, 1, 17, 963893) My answer is an emphatic ‘no’.
('19', 451, 1, 18, 963924) The week is a Satyagraha Week for those who believe in truth and non violence.
('19', 451, 1, 19, 964003) The hartal of the 6th was a satyagraha hartal in the sense that it was a prelude to satyagraha.
('19', 451, 1, 20, 964099) The hartal of the 6th April last, though it was spontaneous, was not altogether free from undue pressure during the course of the day in the way of asking people not to use carriages, etc.
('19', 451, 1, 21, 964288) I would therefore not advise hartal at all for this week of discipline and penance.
('19', 451, 1, 22, 964372) Moreover hartal must not be made cheap.
('19', 451, 1, 23, 964412) It must be only for rare occasions.
('19', 451, 1, 24, 964448) I respectfully trust that all parties and all classes will see their way to take their full share in the observances of the national week and make it an event for the true and definite progress in national awakening.

('19', 452, 1, 2, 964766) 283. WAS IT CONTEMPT OF COURT ?
('19', 452, 2, 3, 964798) This rule 2 was heard by the Hon’ble Justices Marten, Hayward and Kajiji on the 3rd instant.
('19', 452, 2, 4, 964891) The Editor, Mr. Gandhi and the Publisher, Mr. Desai, of Young India were to show cause why they should not be committed for contempt having published with comments in the issue of the 6th August, 1919 of their paper, a letter addressed by Mr. Kennedy, District Judge of Ahmedabad, to the Registrar of the High Court complaining of the conduct of certain satyagrahi lawyers of Ahmedabad.
('19', 452, 2, 5, 965278) The Hon’ble Sir Thomas Strangman, Advocate General, with Messrs Bahadurji and Pocock appeared for the applicant.
('19', 452, 2, 6, 965391) Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Desai appeared in person.
('19', 452, 2, 7, 965436) The Advocate General, in opening the case, said that the proceedings were in contempt against Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Desai, about whose being Editor and Publisher respectively there was no dispute.
('19', 452, 2, 8, 965630) It appeared that Mr. Kennedy in April last, finding that certain lawyers in Ahmedabad had signed the Satyagraha Pledge 3, asked them to explain why their sanads should not be cancelled for their having signed the pledge, and as he did not consider their explanation satisfactory he addressed a letter to the Registrar of the High Court on the 22nd April, 1919. In consequence, two notices were issued by the High Court to the lawyers concerned.
('19', 452, 2, 9, 966075) A copy of Mr. Kennedy’s letter was given by the Registrar to Mr. Divetia, pleader for one of the lawyers, who handed the same to Mr. Kalidas J. Jhaveri, one of the satyagrahi lawyers, who in turn handed it to Mr. Gandhi.
('19', 452, 2, 10, 966296) On the 6th August this letter was published in his paper under the heading “O’Dwyerism in Ahmedabad” along with an article headed “Shaking Civil Resisters” 4, commenting on the letter.
('19', 452, 2, 11, 966481) (The Advocate General at this stage read the letter and the article.) It appeared from the article, said he, that by “O’Dwyer” was meant a disturber of peace.
('19', 452, 2, 12, 966640) The article said that the District Judge was
('19', 452, 3, 13, 966685) 1 This article has been attributed to Gandhiji in The Law and the Lawyers, a compilation edited by S.B. Kher and published by Navajivan Publishing House, Ahmedabad.
('19', 452, 3, 14, 966850) 2 Rule nisi issued against Gandhiji and Mahadev Desai; vide “Letter to Registrar, High Court, Bombay”, 27 2 1920. 3 Drafted by Gandhiji in protest against the Rowlatt Bills and signed on February 24, 1919 by Gandhiji himself, Vallabhbhai Patel, Sarojini Naidu, Horniman and others; vide “The Satyagraha Pledge”, 24 2 1919. 4 Vide “Shaking Civil Resisters”, 6 8 1919
('19', 453, 0, 1, 967216) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 453, 1, 2, 967258) prejudging the issue.
('19', 453, 1, 3, 967280) His conduct was described as not only ungentlemanly, but something worse, unpardonable.
('19', 453, 1, 4, 967368) He was said to be fanning the fire of Bolshevism.
('19', 453, 1, 5, 967418) Those were shortly the charges made against Mr. Kennedy.
('19', 453, 1, 6, 967475) Then proceedings took place in the High Court.
('19', 453, 1, 7, 967522) After the proceedings the Registrar addressed a letter to Mr. Gandhi requesting him to attend the Chief Justice’s Chamber to give an explanation as regards the publication of the letter.
('19', 453, 1, 8, 967709) Mr. Gandhi replied by telegram 1 explaining his inability to attend on the appointed date as he was going to the Punjab, and inquiring if a written explanation would be sufficient.
('19', 453, 1, 9, 967890) The Registrar replied saying that the Chief Justice did not wish to interfere with Mr. Gandhi’s appointment and that a written explanation would do.
('19', 453, 1, 10, 968039) On the 22nd October Mr. Gandhi sent a written explanation 2 in which he stated that the letter was received by him in the ordinary course and that he published it as he believed it was of great public importance and that he thought that he was doing a public service in commenting on it.
('19', 453, 1, 11, 968327) He, therefore, claimed that in publishing and commenting on the letter, he was within the rights of a journalist.
('19', 453, 1, 12, 968441) In reply to this the Registrar wrote 3 saying that the Chief Justice was not satisfied with the explanation, but that it would be considered sufficient if an apology in the following terms were published in the next issue of Young India.
('19', 453, 2, 13, 968679) FORM OF APOLOGY
('19', 453, 3, 14, 968695) Whereas on the 6th August, 1919 we published in Young India a
('19', 453, 4, 15, 968757) private letter written by Mr. Kennedy, District Judge of Ahmedabad, to the Registrar of the High Court of Justice at Bombay and whereas on the same date we also published certain comments on the said letter and whereas it has been pointed out to us that pending certain proceedings in the said High Court in connection with the said letter we were not justified in publishing the said letter or in commenting thereon.
('19', 453, 4, 16, 969175) Now we do hereby express our regret and apologize to the Hon’ble the Chief Justice and Judges of the said High Court for the publication of the said letter and the comments thereon.
('19', 453, 4, 17, 969357) The Advocate General said that he submitted with some confidence that it was an apology which the opponent should have published.
('19', 453, 4, 18, 969487) A milder form of apology, he thought, it was difficult to
('19', 453, 5, 19, 969545) 1 Vide “Shaking Civil Resisters”, 6 8 1919 2 Ibid
('19', 453, 6, 20, 969595) 3 A letter dated October 31, 1919, which Gandhiji received on November 7, 1919 while at Lahore
('19', 454, 0, 1, 969690) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 455
('19', 454, 1, 2, 969738) conceive.
('19', 454, 1, 3, 969748) Mr. Gandhi, however, did not publish the apology and took counsel’s opinion and addressed a letter to the Registrar expressing his inability to apologize.
('19', 454, 1, 4, 969903) Before the receipt of this letter a notice was ordered by the High Court on the 11th of December to be issued for contempt on which the proceedings were based.
('19', 454, 1, 5, 970063) The text of Mr. Gandhi’s letter dated 11th December, 1919, is as follows.
('19', 454, 2, 6, 970137) A few days before the hearing of the rule Mr. Gandhi addressed a letter to the Registrar dated 27th February, with which he enclosed copies of statements which he and Mr. Desai desired to submit before the Court.
('19', 454, 2, 7, 970350) The text of the two statements is given below.
('19', 454, 3, 8, 970397) Continuing the Advocate General proceeded to cite rulings to show what constitutes Contempt of Court.
('19', 454, 3, 9, 970499) 2 Q.B., page 36, showed that there were two kinds of contempt : (1) any act or writing tending to scandalize the court; (2) any act or writing calculated to obstruct or interfere with the due course of justice or the lawful process of the court.
('19', 454, 3, 10, 970745) The Advocate General submitted that the publication of the letter and the comments thereon constituted contempt in two respects : (1) in the language of Lord Hardwicke it scandalized Mr. Kennedy; and (2) it was an attempt to interfere with the course of justice.
('19', 454, 3, 11, 971008) He further said that the High Court could punish for contempt of an inferior court.
('19', 454, 3, 12, 971092) The District Court of Ahmedabad was under the superintendence of the High Court and it had no power to commit for contempt except for what was done in the face of the Court.
('19', 454, 3, 13, 971266) Mr. Justice Marten asked if it was Contempt of Court in a civil action to publish the plaint or the written statement.
('19', 454, 3, 14, 971385) The Advocate General replied it was a contempt.
('19', 454, 3, 15, 971433) The pleadings did not become public documents until the case was heard.
('19', 454, 3, 16, 971505) The Advocate General also referred to (1906) 1 Kings Branch, page 132, and (1903) 2 K.B. He added that publication after trial was different from publication before it.
('19', 454, 3, 17, 971674) In conclusion the Advocate General drew the deduction that the gist of Mr. Gandhi’s article was that as Mr. Kennedy was fanning the fire of Bolshevism, the High Court, if it acted on his letter, would likewise disturb the peace and fan the fire of Bolshevism.
('19', 454, 3, 18, 971934) Mr. Gandhi addressing the Court said that he did not propose to say anything beyond what he had already said in his statement.
('19', 454, 4, 19, 972061) 1 Not reproduced here.
('19', 454, 4, 20, 972084) For the text of the letter, vide”Letter to Registrar, High Court, Bombay”, 11 12 1919. 2 For text of the letter and the statements, vide “Letter to Registrar, High Court, Bombay”, 27 2 1920.
('19', 455, 0, 1, 972275) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 455, 1, 2, 972317) Esteemed friends had asked him to consider if he was not obstinate in not making the required apology.
('19', 455, 1, 3, 972420) He had considered the matter over and over again and whatever view the Court held, he asked them to believe him that nothing was farther from his thoughts than obstinacy.
('19', 455, 1, 4, 972591) He wished to pay all respect to the Honourable Court.
('19', 455, 1, 5, 972645) On the other hand he did expect that the Honourable Court would not grudge his paying the same respect to his own sense of honour and to the dignity of journalism.
('19', 455, 1, 6, 972809) He had heard the Advocate General carefully to see if anything he said could convince him that he had been in the wrong.
('19', 455, 1, 7, 972930) But he had remained entirely unconvinced.
('19', 455, 1, 8, 972972) Had he been convinced he would readily have withdrawn his statement and tendered apology.
('19', 455, 1, 9, 973062) He did not wish to say anything more.
('19', 455, 1, 10, 973100) Mr. Justice Marten said that the point of law was against Mr. Gandhi.
('19', 455, 1, 11, 973170) Mr. Gandhi had said that he was entitled as a journalist to do what he had done.
('19', 455, 1, 12, 973251) But the Advocate General had cited authorities against him.
('19', 455, 1, 13, 973311) Had he any authorities to support his position?
('19', 455, 1, 14, 973359) Mr. Gandhi said he differed from the Advocate General on the point of law, but he did not rest his case, such as it was, on points of law.
('19', 455, 1, 15, 973498) He did not wish to argue legal points and go beyond the limits he had set to himself.
('19', 455, 1, 16, 973584) The Court had before now done justice in many undefended cases and he wished himself to be considered as undefended.
('19', 455, 1, 17, 973701) He would be entirely content with their Lordships’ finding on points of law.
('19', 455, 1, 18, 973778) Mr. Justice Marten reminded Mr. Gandhi that he was himself a member of the Bar and that he could argue out the case from the legal standpoint.
('19', 455, 1, 19, 973921) Mr. Gandhi said he was unprepared to do so and repeated that he would be content to take the ruling of the Court with regard to law.
('19', 455, 1, 20, 974054) But since the Court had coaxed him to argue he would say that what he felt was that he had not prejudiced any party.
('19', 455, 1, 21, 974171) The Hon.
('19', 455, 1, 22, 974180) the Advocate General had said that his comments on the District Judge constituted contempt of a judge.
('19', 455, 1, 23, 974283) Mr. Gandhi commented on the District Judge not as a judge but as an individual.
('19', 455, 2, 24, 974363) J. MARTEN : Take the case of a sensational murder trial.
('19', 455, 2, 25, 974420) Supposing the Press commented on the events while the case was going on, what would happen?
('19', 455, 3, 26, 974512) MR. GANDHI : I would respectfully draw a distinction as a layman between the two cases.
('19', 455, 3, 27, 974600) The District Judge writes this letter as a com plainant and not as a Judge.
('19', 455, 4, 28, 974676) J. MARTEN : He was writing as a judge exercising jurisdiction over certain lawyers.
('19', 456, 0, 1, 974760) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 457
('19', 456, 1, 2, 974808) MR. GANDHI : I agree.
('19', 456, 1, 3, 974830) But he was not sitting in court to decide an action.
('19', 456, 1, 4, 974883) I feel again that I am travelling beyond the limits I set to myself.
('19', 456, 1, 5, 974952) The whole law of Contempt of Court is that one ought not to do anything which might prejudice proceedings before a court.
('19', 456, 1, 6, 975074) But here the Judge does something as an individual.
('19', 456, 1, 7, 975126) I have not done anything to prejudice in any shape or form the judgment of the judges.
('19', 456, 2, 8, 975213) J. MARTEN : Would it not be dangerous if the Press made comments during pendency of proceedings?
('19', 456, 2, 9, 975310) The court would cease to be the tribunal and the Press would be the tribunal instead.
('19', 456, 3, 10, 975396) MR. GANDHI : I would again respectfully draw a distinction.
('19', 456, 3, 11, 975456) If a son wrongly brought a suit against his father then I would be justified in commenting on the son’s conduct in bringing such a suit against his father, without in any way thereby prejudicing the decision of the Court.
('19', 456, 3, 12, 975678) And do our courts prevent public men from inducing litigants to settle their claims outside?
('19', 456, 3, 13, 975771) I submit I have committed no contempt.
('19', 456, 3, 14, 975810) I have prejudiced no party and have made no comment on the action of Mr. Kennedy as a judge.
('19', 456, 3, 15, 975903) I am anxious to satisfy the Court that there is not an iota of disrespect shown to the Court in commenting on Mr. Kennedy’s letter.
('19', 456, 3, 16, 976035) I may have erred, and in the view of the Court, erred grievously but I have not done so dishonestly or disrespectfully.
('19', 456, 3, 17, 976155) I need not add that all that I have said applies to the case of Mr. Desai, the Publisher.
('19', 456, 3, 18, 976245) J. Marten then drew Mr. Gandhi’s attention to a decision in England reported in a recent issue of the London Times whereby the editor, publisher and printer of a newspaper were fined for contempt.
('19', 456, 4, 19, 976442) MR. GANDHI : There also I submit it is possible for me to draw a distinction.
('19', 456, 4, 20, 976520) While I was in England the famous Mrs. Maybrick’s case was going on and the whole newspaper Press divided itself into two parties, one condemning Mrs. Maybrick and the other going for the Judge, Mr. Justice Stephen, and even suggesting that he was unfit to try the case.
('19', 456, 5, 21, 976791) J. MARTEN : But that was all after trial?
('19', 456, 5, 22, 976833) MR. GANDHI : No.
('19', 456, 5, 23, 976850) It was while the case was going on.
('19', 456, 5, 24, 976886) I followed the proceedings in the case from day to day throughout the many months that it was going on.
('19', 456, 6, 25, 976990) J. MARTEN : It did not go on, Mr. Gandhi, for many months.
('19', 456, 6, 26, 977049) It went on for some days.
('19', 456, 7, 27, 977075) MR. GANDHI : Of course here I am speaking subject to correction, but I am quite sure that while the case was going on, the newspaper
('19', 457, 0, 1, 977208) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 457, 1, 2, 977250) Press was so full with all sorts of innuendoes, insinuations and aspersions, that I am sure I, as a journalist, would not even at this day be able to go the length they went.
('19', 457, 1, 3, 977425) Mr. Desai stated that he entirely associated himself with the sentiment expressed by Mr. Gandhi.
('19', 457, 1, 4, 977522) He was sure he was infinitely more incapable of arguing the case than Mr. Gandhi and he would not presume to do that.

('19', 461, 1, 4, 985188) Every word I have written is justifiable but you may wish to take the responsibility of altering where I do not see my way clear.

('19', 461, 2, 13, 985766) 290. PRESS ACT AND HORNIMAN
('19', 461, 3, 14, 985794) The meeting 1 held in Bombay for demanding repeal of the Press Act was an important one.
('19', 461, 3, 15, 985883) Sir Narayan Chandavarkar 2 was able to show that it was as much in the Government’s interest as in the public’s to repeal the Act.
('19', 461, 3, 16, 986014) It is said of the ostrich that when it sees any danger, it buries its head in sand and imagines that there is no danger and gets caught in the end.
('19', 461, 3, 17, 986162) Through the Press Act, the Government has put itself in the condition of the ostrich.
('19', 461, 3, 18, 986248) If public feeling is against the Government, it can find expression only through the medium of newspapers.
('19', 461, 3, 19, 986355) By suppressing the expression, one cannot change the feeling.
('19', 461, 3, 20, 986417) To keep the Press Act alive is to behave like the meteorologist who, after smashing his barometer, would know the state of atmospheric pressure.
('19', 461, 3, 21, 986562) By putting it on the statute book, the Government has damaged the machine which indicates the direction and the state of the current of popular feeling, and consequently it can no longer keep itself informed about the exact state of public feeling.
('19', 461, 3, 22, 986811) The only course for the Government, therefore, is to repeal the Press Act and it is the duty of the public to strive for its repeal.
('19', 461, 4, 23, 986944) 1 On March 5, 1920 2 Narayan Ganesh Chandavarkar (1855 1923); Liberal leader of Bombay who presided over the meeting
('19', 462, 0, 1, 987061) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 463
('19', 462, 1, 2, 987109) Mr. Horniman, however, was a victim of the very same attitude which the Government displays in retaining the Press Act.
('19', 462, 1, 3, 987229) It cannot tolerate a frank expression of public opinion and, therefore, it cannot tolerate Mr. Horniman who expressed it with such vigour.
('19', 462, 1, 4, 987368) Very few men have shown Mr. Horniman’s capacity for educating public opinion or inspired the people with the same spirit as he did.
('19', 462, 1, 5, 987500) Even assuming that Mr. Horniman did not possess any such gift, from the point of view of simple justice also no charge has been proved against him.
('19', 462, 1, 6, 987648) People ought not to tolerate it, if despite this, the Government should arbitrarily keep him out.
('19', 462, 1, 7, 987746) It is not true at all that those alone who agree with Mr. Horniman’s methods and ideas can work for the removal of the restrictions against him.
('19', 462, 1, 8, 987891) We have plenty of grounds for differing with him.
('19', 462, 1, 9, 987941) His language is sometimes harsher than it need be.
('19', 462, 1, 10, 987992) Even so, we have not the slightest doubt that he should be as free as anyone else to enter India.
('19', 462, 1, 11, 988090) Accordingly, we welcome the resolution passed at the foregoing meeting; not only this, we even believe that people should take effective steps to keep alive the agitation for his return and force the Bombay Government to cancel the orders against him.
('19', 462, 1, 12, 988342) 1 The third resolution passed at the meeting was to the effect that the securities obtained from any of the presses should be returned to them.
('19', 462, 1, 13, 988486) 2 We hope the Government will pay attention to all these three points.

('19', 464, 22, 24, 991530) The Leader of Allahabad and Young India have drifted apart.
('19', 464, 22, 25, 991590) I entertain such sneaking regard for the former that I struggle hard to
('19', 464, 23, 26, 991662) 1 This telegram was in reply to one from Girdhari Lal which read : “Kindly wire if Amritsar observe hartal and extent Hindus participation in resolution.” 2 On March 19, the Khilafat Day 3 Vide “Letter to the Press”, 7 3 1920.
('19', 465, 0, 1, 991889) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 465, 1, 2, 991931) accept the view that may be put forth by The Leader.
('19', 465, 1, 3, 991984) But in spite of the struggle of late I have invariably failed.
('19', 465, 1, 4, 992047) The latest instance is the confusion into which The Leader has fallen over boycott and non co operation.
('19', 465, 1, 5, 992152) I had thought that my meaning was clear and that there was no inconsistency.
('19', 465, 1, 6, 992229) Boycott is a punishment and is conceived in a vindictive spirit.
('19', 465, 1, 7, 992294) The idea of boycotting British goods is that although British goods may be better than, say, Japanese, I should not buy the former because I want to revenge myself upon the British people for a wrong done to me by British ministers, or for the utterly irresponsible and insolent language of some Englishmen regarding the Khilafat.
('19', 465, 1, 8, 992625) I hold that boycott under such circumstances is a form of violence.
('19', 465, 1, 9, 992693) Non co operation stands on a different footing.
('19', 465, 1, 10, 992741) If the Government do wrong I become a participator in its wrongdoing by co operating with it and thus making it possible for them to do the wrong.
('19', 465, 1, 11, 992888) It is my duty, not by way of punishment or by way of revenge but to the end that I may not make myself responsible for the wrongdoing, to withdraw my support off that Government.
('19', 465, 1, 12, 993067) Indeed I should be justi fied in bringing that Government to a standstill.
('19', 465, 1, 13, 993142) It is clear to me, therefore, that non co operation is as different from boycott as an elephant from an ass.
('19', 465, 1, 14, 993251) The Leader also sees ill logic in my disapproval of violence and approval of hartal.
('19', 465, 1, 15, 993336) I see none because I feel that hartal does not necessarily lead to violence.
('19', 465, 1, 16, 993413) One cannot always avoid doing the right thing because there are risks to be run.
('19', 465, 1, 17, 993494) The Leader’s diffi culty arises perhaps from the belief that strong and definite action is not necessary and that it is possible for the Mohammedans of India to keep their peace even after an adverse decision 1 by the Allied Powers.
('19', 465, 1, 18, 993727) In my opinion the movement 2 is bound to endorse violence unless a non violent course of action is found that would lead to a just solution of the question.
('19', 465, 1, 19, 993884) All strong action may bring about violence but we may not fear to do the right lest it may be misinterpreted and lead to wrong.
('19', 465, 1, 20, 994012) All that is, humanly speaking, possible is to guard against mistakes and misunderstanding and with trust in God to go forward.
('19', 465, 1, 21, 994139) I know that on the Khilafat question that course and that alone can avoid violence if, short of a proper solution of the question, anything is to avoid it at all.
('19', 465, 1, 22, 994302) I therefore trust that Indians of all shades of opinion will join this movement.
('19', 465, 1, 23, 994383) A firm and unanimous stand on
('19', 465, 2, 24, 994413) 1 In regard to the temporal and spiritual authority of the Sultan of Turkey 2 The Khilafat movement
('19', 466, 0, 1, 994513) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 467
('19', 466, 1, 2, 994561) the part of the Hindus will certainly put courage and hope into Mohammedan hearts.
('19', 466, 1, 3, 994644) Any lukewarmness or indifference will lead to loss of hope and desperation.
('19', 466, 1, 4, 994720) Much the same is to be said about the objection to satyagraha.
('19', 466, 1, 5, 994783) I still believe that for the moment I consider that I am alone capable of offering satyagraha in its fine form.
('19', 466, 1, 6, 994895) But if that belief were to deter me from making experiments, satyagraha would never make headway.
('19', 466, 1, 7, 994993) But here, there is the further fallacy of the ambiguous middle.
('19', 466, 1, 8, 995057) Satyagraha in the form of civil resistance has possibilities of mischief.
('19', 466, 1, 9, 995131) But hartal is no new weapon and hartal may or may not be satyagraha.
('19', 466, 1, 10, 995200) Nor need non co operation be necessarily satyagraha.
('19', 466, 1, 11, 995253) When the Hon’ble Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya resigned his membership on the Imperial Council 1 or when Sir Rabindranath Tagore asked to be relieved of his distinction 2 they did not do so as satyagrahis.
('19', 466, 1, 12, 995457) Of course there is danger in widespread non co operation.
('19', 466, 1, 13, 995515) But that is merely stating a truism.
('19', 466, 1, 14, 995552) The one thing to be remembered is that for the Mohammedans the Khilafat is a question of life and death.
('19', 466, 1, 15, 995657) It is essential for them to secure a proper solution.
('19', 466, 1, 16, 995711) It is the sacred duty of the Hindus to give their all for the sake of their brothers so long as they work along the lines of non violence.
('19', 466, 1, 17, 995850) And I know no better way of keeping them on that path save by all Hindus, Christians, Parsees and Jews, who have made India their own, whole heartedly support ing them and suggesting to them forcible methods of attaining redress without resort to violence.

('19', 470, 1, 2, 1000967) 300. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI 1
('19', 470, 2, 3, 1001007) BOMBAY, March 18, 1920
('19', 470, 3, 4, 1001030) DEAR MR. SASTRI, As I took an active part in the Congress affairs last year I have been asked to interest myself still more actively to the extent of joining an organization.
('19', 470, 3, 5, 1001205) The demand has come from those with whom I have had the privilege of working although I was not connected with their organization.
('19', 470, 3, 6, 1001336) They have asked me to join the All India Home Rule League.
('19', 470, 3, 7, 1001395) I have told them that at my time of life and with views firmly formed on several matters I could only join an organization to affect its policy and not be affected by it.
('19', 470, 3, 8, 1001566) This does not mean that I would not keep or that I do not have an open mind to receive new light.
('19', 470, 3, 9, 1001664) I simply wish to emphasize the fact that any new light will have to be specially dazzling in order to entrance me.
('19', 470, 3, 10, 1001779) I placed before the friends the following points on which I hold decided views : 1. [The] highest honesty must be introduced in the political life of the country if we are to make our mark as a nation.
('19', 470, 3, 11, 1001981) This presupposes at the present moment a very firm and definite accep tance of the creed of Truth at any cost.
('19', 470, 3, 12, 1002092) 2. Swadeshi must be our immediate goal.
('19', 470, 3, 13, 1002132) The future aspirants after membership of the Council 2 should be asked to pledge them selves to an out and out protection of the country’s industries— spe cially cloth manufacture.
('19', 470, 3, 14, 1002313) 3. Definite acceptance of Hindustani—a resultant of Hindi and Urdu—as a national language of intercourse in the immediate future.
('19', 470, 3, 15, 1002443) The would be members will be therefore pledged so to work in the Imperial Council as to introduce Hindustani and in the Local Councils the respective vernaculars, at least as an optional medium for the time being till we are able to dispense with English for the conduct of national affairs.
('19', 470, 3, 16, 1002735) They will also be pledged to introduce Hindustani as a compulsory second language in our schools with Devanagari or Urdu as an optional script.
('19', 470, 3, 17, 1002879) English will be recognized as a language of Imperial intercourse, diplomacy and international commerce.
('19', 470, 3, 18, 1002983) 4. Acceptance of the principle of redistribution of provinces so far as possible on a linguistic basis at the earliest opportunity.
('19', 470, 4, 19, 1003115) 1 Copies of this letter were also addressed by Gandhiji to other friends, like Natesan, for private circulation.
('19', 470, 4, 20, 1003228) 2 Gandhiji presumably has in mind the Imperial Legislative Council, Delhi.
('19', 471, 0, 1, 1003303) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 471, 1, 2, 1003345) 5. Hindu Mohammedan unity in its essence and from a political and religious standpoint as an unalterable article of faith.
('19', 471, 1, 3, 1003468) This contemplates mutual help, mutual toleration and recognition of the sufferings of one section to be the sufferings of all.
('19', 471, 1, 4, 1003595) This will exclude, from the official programme of the League, the unity propa ganda by means of inter dining and intermarriage and will include vigorous co operation on the Khilafat question.
('19', 471, 1, 5, 1003787) In my discussions amongst the friends I have also told them that I will not think of asking for official recognition of my creed of civil disobedience and that I do not belong to any party and would like to make the League a non party organization helping all honest men if they are otherwise capable of doing justice to the service they may choose irrespective of party.
('19', 471, 1, 6, 1004159) The League, according to my opinion, cannot become an anti Congress organization but it should work as it is now doing to further the interests of the Congress.
('19', 471, 1, 7, 1004320) Do you advise me, knowing me as you do with my qualifi cations and limitations, to join the League?
('19', 471, 2, 8, 1004420) Yours sincerely,

('19', 471, 4, 10, 1004488) 301. LETTER TO MAZHARUL HAQUE 2
('19', 471, 5, 11, 1004520) LABURNAM ROAD, GRAMDEVI BOMBAY, March 18, 1920

('19', 474, 1, 2, 1008911) 303. SPEECH ON KHILAFAT, BOMBAY 1
('19', 474, 2, 3, 1008945) March 19, 1920 It gives me the greatest pleasure to be able to move the only resolution 2 of this great conference.
('19', 474, 2, 4, 1009061) I beg to congratulate the organizers and the volunteers on the splendid success of the peaceful demonstration of today.
('19', 474, 2, 5, 1009181) We had many warnings given to us as to the consequences that were likely to follow from suspension of business.
('19', 474, 2, 6, 1009293) Bombay at least has, thanks to the effort of the Khilafat Committee, behaved nobly in the matter.
('19', 474, 2, 7, 1009391) The hartal was spontaneous a nd voluntary.
('19', 474, 2, 8, 1009434) No pressure whatever was used.
('19', 474, 2, 9, 1009465) It was a matter of great satisfaction to me to note that the Committee followed the advice tendered by me that mill hands should not be called upon to participate in the hartal.
('19', 474, 3, 10, 1009643) 1 Made on the occasion of the Khilafat Day at a mass meeting consisting of about thirty thousand Muslims, Hindus and other citizens, presided over by Mia Mahomed Haji Jan Mahomed Chhotani 2 The next of the resolution read : This meeting of Hindus, Muslims and other citizens of Bombay hereby enters its emphatic protest against the violent and irresponsible agitation going on in the United Kingdom calculated to wound the deepest susceptibilities of the Muslims and therefore the whole of India, and trusts that not only will His Majesty’s Ministers and other statesmen who desire the retention of India in the Empire as a free partner dissociate themselves from that agitation but will reassure the inhabitants of India of the fellow feeling of the people of the United Kingdom by securing a settlement of the Khilafat question compatible with the just and religious sentiments of millions of the Muslim subjects of His Majesty.
('19', 474, 3, 11, 1010574) This meeting further records its deep conviction that any other solution of the question must eventually result in complete withdrawal of co operation from the Government and therefore appeals to all the statesmen of the Empire to prevent such a severe strain being put upon India’s loyalty.
('19', 474, 3, 12, 1010866) This meeting at the same time wishes to place upon record the fact that, whatever joint steps it may be necessary to take in order to give effect to the just sentiments of Indians, there shall be no resort to violence whether in speech or deed and is firmly of opinion that any violence practised in connection with the movement will seriously injure it and cause irreparable harm.
('19', 474, 3, 13, 1011248) In the event of the failure of the joint movement, the Muslims reserve to themselves the right of taking such steps as the exigencies of the situation might dictate.
('19', 474, 3, 14, 1011414) That the President of this meeting be authorized to send a copy of this resolution to His Excellency the Viceroy with a request to convey the same to His Majesty the King Emperor.
('19', 474, 3, 15, 1011594) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 24 3 1920.

('19', 475, 1, 2, 1011669) In these days of tension between employers and employees in the various industrial concerns 1 of the country, we may not encourage labourers to absent themselves from work without the willing consent of the employers.
('19', 475, 1, 3, 1011887) Our resolution divides itself into four parts.
('19', 475, 1, 4, 1011934) The first part consists of a protest and a prayer.
('19', 475, 1, 5, 1011985) It protests against violent and irresponsible agitation 2 set up in England in connection with the Khilafat question, and appeals to the Ministers and other statesmen to dissociate themselves from this agitation and reassure us of the fellow feeling of the people of the United Kingdom by securing an honou rable settlement consistent with the just religious sentiments of the Mussulmans of India.
('19', 475, 1, 6, 1012383) The second part warns those concerned that an adverse solution is likely to eventuate in complete withdrawal of co operation from the Government and will put an undue strain upon Indian loyalty, 3 and if such a step unfortunately becomes a necessity there is likely to be excitement.
('19', 475, 1, 7, 1012667) The third part of the resolution warns the people in the most emphatic language against violence of speech or deed and gives it as the opinion of this great meeting that any exercise of violence is calculated to injure the sacred cause and to do irreparable harm.
('19', 475, 1, 8, 1012931) So far the resolution is a joint transaction between the Hindus, Mohammedans and others to whom this great land is their mother country or their adopted home.
('19', 475, 2, 9, 1013090) And it commits the joint movement to a policy of non violence in the course of the struggle.
('19', 475, 2, 10, 1013183) But Mohammedans have special Koranic obligations in which Hindus may or may not join.
('19', 475, 2, 11, 1013269) They, therefore, reserve to themselves the right, in the event of the failure of non co operation cum non violence, in order to enforce justice, to resort to all such methods as may be enjoined by the Islamic scriptures.
('19', 475, 2, 12, 1013490) I venture heartily to associate myself with this resolution.
('19', 475, 2, 13, 1013551) I consider the resolution to be thoroughly respectful and moderate in tone.

('19', 479, 1, 2, 1021168) of known respectability and unquestionable honesty we need have no receipts but simple collection from all and sundry.
('19', 479, 1, 3, 1021287) Monied men and women can go out and collect in the quarters best known to them.
('19', 479, 1, 4, 1021367) But it is not so much the manner as the matter which I wish to emphasize.
('19', 479, 1, 5, 1021441) I hope that there will be no difference of opinion as to the desirability of passing the week in the manner suggested by me or of having a memorial in connection with massacre 1 of the 13th.
('19', 479, 1, 6, 1021632) In presenting the case to the people I would advise that the memory of the dead and not of the atrocity be treated as the impelling motive.

('19', 479, 1, 10, 1022186) I wish to give you my experience in this direction as a specialist par excellence.
('19', 479, 1, 11, 1022269) I do not know any contemporary of mine who has reduced fasting and prayer to an exact science and who has reaped a harvest so abundant as I have.
('19', 479, 1, 12, 1022415) I wish that I could infect the nation with my experience and make it resort to fasting and prayer with intelligence, honesty and intensity.
('19', 479, 1, 13, 1022555) We would thus, incredible as it may appear, do millions of things pertaining to the nation without elaborate organization and checks upon checks, but I know that fasting and prayer, to be as effective as I have found them to be in my own experience, have to be not mechanical things but definite spiritual acts.
('19', 479, 1, 14, 1022867) Fasting then is crucifixion of the flesh with a corresponding freedom of the spirit and prayer is a definite conscious longing of the soul to be utterly pure—the purity thus attained being dedicated to the realization of a particular object which is in itself pure.
('19', 479, 1, 15, 1023133) I hope therefore that if you believe in the ancient institution of fasting and prayer you will dedicate the 6th and the 13th to the purpose and induce your neighbours to do likewise.
('19', 479, 1, 16, 1023316) Then there remain the three meetings 2 which I doubt not you will organize and make them a thorough success.
('19', 479, 2, 17, 1023425) Yours sincerely,
('19', 479, 3, 18, 1023442) M. K.GANDHI

('19', 481, 4, 13, 1026840) 308. KHILAFAT
('19', 481, 5, 14, 1026854) The Khilafat issue is a splendid opportunity as much as a grave problem.
('19', 481, 5, 15, 1026927) It is the latter because on it hangs the future peace of eight crores of Muslims and therefore of the whole of India.
('19', 481, 5, 16, 1027045) It is a splendid opportunity because, if the Muslims use wisdom in solving the problem, their moral power will increase and India will come to enjoy a moral empire; Hindu Muslim unity will increase, both Hindus and Muslims will grow stronger, their moral level will rise and the English will stop looking down upon us as an inferior race.
('19', 481, 5, 17, 1027384) Friendship is possible only between equals.
('19', 481, 5, 18, 1027428) The English do not regard us as their equals; even we consider ourselves as their inferiors.
('19', 481, 5, 19, 1027521) And, therefore, we, Hindus and Muslims, should solve this problem and ensure that the three become equals.
('19', 481, 5, 20, 1027628) The sword makes men equal.
('19', 481, 5, 21, 1027655) After fighting with one another like so many bulls, till they all get exhausted, the opponents salute
('19', 482, 0, 1, 1027757) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 483
('19', 482, 1, 2, 1027805) each other and become friends.
('19', 482, 1, 3, 1027836) Anyone who shows weakness will humiliate himself.
('19', 482, 1, 4, 1027886) The other method is, instead of using physical force against the opponent, to employ soul force and win ascendancy over him.
('19', 482, 1, 5, 1028011) This ascendancy is accepted not out of fear but out of love, and so both become equals.
('19', 482, 1, 6, 1028099) One does not consider it humiliating to admit another’s moral superiority.

('19', 482, 1, 8, 1028226) Hence both be have respectfully towards each other.
('19', 482, 1, 9, 1028278) We must give up the very thought of overcoming the English by the sword.
('19', 482, 1, 10, 1028351) I do not want to argue that it would be impossible for us to employ such force; only, in order to use it we shall have to resort to hypocrisy, falsehood, treachery and so on, and even for employing these we shall have to acquire various other unprofitable abilities.
('19', 482, 1, 11, 1028618) We shall have to put forward all our strength against them and fight on till both of us are out of breath.
('19', 482, 1, 12, 1028725) They will not, naturally, let matters go so far; that is human nature.
('19', 482, 1, 13, 1028796) Even in ancient times the arts of fighting were guarded secrets.
('19', 482, 1, 14, 1028861) A proud man does not easily part with the means of gratifying his pride.
('19', 482, 1, 15, 1028934) Strength of arms necessarily carries pride with it.
('19', 482, 1, 16, 1028986) Therefore, if we wish to be the equals of our enemies through force of arms, we shall have to press on till the point of their defeat and, at the end of it all, we shall for ever remain enemies.

('19', 482, 1, 18, 1029229) Leaving aside the question whether or not it is right to fight, if we think merely of the result, we shall see that military strength will never solve the problem.
('19', 482, 1, 19, 1029393) The fight for the Khilafat is not solely against the English; it is a fight between Christians and Muslims.
('19', 482, 1, 20, 1029501) 1 The Christians are very well united and well versed in the art of war; the Muslims are not equipped, the Muslims of India evidently are not, today at any rate, to try their strength against them; and the Hindus cannot stand shoulder to shoulder with the latter in a trial of strength.
('19', 482, 1, 21, 1029788) Under these circumstances, it is well nigh impossible, from a practical point of view, for the Muslims to seek a settlement of the Khilafat issue by force.
('19', 482, 1, 22, 1029944) One who tries his strength in fighting cannot say : ‘God’s will be done.’ He alone can say this who believes in fighting with moral force, for in such a contest defeat is out of the question.

('19', 485, 9, 11, 1034873) 311. REFLECTIONS ON THE SATYAGRAHA WEEK 1
('19', 485, 10, 12, 1034915) This national week will soon be upon us.
('19', 485, 10, 13, 1034956) We trust that it will be worthy of the occasion which it is to commemorate.
('19', 485, 10, 14, 1035032) The chief item of work which can be measured and which will be an acid test of our genuineness and feeling for the Punjab will be the collection of a fund 2 to pay for the memorial site for commemora ting the memory of the martyrs of the 13th April last.
('19', 485, 10, 15, 1035287) To collect ten lacs from a population of thirty crores is not a difficult task if suitable workers can be found.
('19', 485, 10, 16, 1035400) If rich and well known ladies and gentlemen could be persuaded to take up the work, it could be finished inside the week.
('19', 485, 10, 17, 1035522) The proper thing no doubt will be to collect pro rata from every

('19', 486, 1, 2, 1035852) province.

('19', 486, 1, 4, 1035901) But each province should try to collect as much more as it can, than its share.
('19', 486, 1, 5, 1035981) It would not matter if we succeed in collecting more.
('19', 486, 1, 6, 1036035) Ten lacs is not the highest sum required.
('19', 486, 1, 7, 1036077) It is the minimum.
('19', 486, 1, 8, 1036096) Everyone therefore is expected to subscribe liberally.
('19', 486, 1, 9, 1036151) * * * Then there is the fasting and prayer.
('19', 486, 1, 10, 1036195) This is a hoary institution.
('19', 486, 1, 11, 1036224) A genuine fast cleanses body, mind and soul.
('19', 486, 1, 12, 1036269) It crucifies the flesh and to that extent sets the soul free.
('19', 486, 1, 13, 1036331) A sincere prayer can work wonders.
('19', 486, 1, 14, 1036366) It is an intense longing of the soul for its even greater purity.
('19', 486, 1, 15, 1036432) Purity thus gained when it is utilized for a noble purpose becomes a prayer.
('19', 486, 1, 16, 1036509) The mundane use of gayatri, its repetition for healing the sick, illustrates the meaning we have given to prayer.
('19', 486, 1, 17, 1036623) When the same gayatri jap is performed with a humble and concentrated mind in an intelligent manner in times of national difficulties and calamities, it becomes a most potent instrument for warding off danger.
('19', 486, 1, 18, 1036833) There can be no greater mistake than to suppose that the recitation of the gayatri, the namaz or the Christian prayer are superstitions fit to be practised by the ignorant and the credulous.
('19', 486, 1, 19, 1037024) Fasting and prayer therefore are a most powerful process of purification and that which purifies necessarily enables us the better to do our duty and to attain our goal.
('19', 486, 1, 20, 1037194) If therefore fasting and prayer seem at times not to answer, it is not because there is nothing in them but because the right spirit is not behind them.
('19', 486, 1, 21, 1037347) * * * A man who fasts and gambles away the whole of the day as do so many on Janmashtami day 1, naturally not only obtains no result from the fast in the shape of greater purity but such a dissolute fast leaves him on the contrary degraded.
('19', 486, 1, 22, 1037588) A fast to be true must be accompanied by a readiness to receive pure thoughts and determi nation to resist all Satan’s temptations.
('19', 486, 1, 23, 1037720) Similarly a prayer to be true has to be intelligible and definite.
('19', 486, 1, 24, 1037787) One has to identify oneself with it.
('19', 486, 1, 25, 1037824) Counting beads with the name of Allah on one’s lips whilst the mind wanders in all directions is worse than useless.
('19', 486, 1, 26, 1037941) We therefore hope that the coming week of dedication to national fasting and prayer will become a universal reality and not merely a formal observation.

('19', 487, 2, 10, 1039173) 312. VIOLENCE VERSUS NON VIOLENCE
('19', 487, 3, 11, 1039207) The Khilafat day has come and gone.
('19', 487, 3, 12, 1039243) It was a great success and a complete triumph of satyagraha, i.e., not civil disobedience but truth and non violence.
('19', 487, 3, 13, 1039361) No hartal has been so voluntary as that of the 19th March in that all the canvassing that ever took place was before the 19th.
('19', 487, 3, 14, 1039488) 2 It was an example of wonderful self restraint on the part of the Committee 3 not to have called out the mill hands.
('19', 487, 3, 15, 1039606) The Committee deserves the highest praise for its efficient management and for the definite recognition of voluntarism.
('19', 487, 3, 16, 1039726) If the people continue to show the discipline and self restraint shown on the 19th and add thereto in an equal measure the spirit of self sacrifice, nothing can prevent the full fruition of our hopes regarding Khilafat.
('19', 487, 3, 17, 1039946) Nobody could have believed a year ago the possibility of peace being observed by the fanatical element among the Mohammedans on a matter of life and death to them and on a day of no business for the idlers.
('19', 487, 3, 18, 1040153) But there can be no idleness when there is prayer.
('19', 487, 3, 19, 1040204) All were enjoined not to quarrel, not to be angry but to pray for the right to be done.
('19', 487, 3, 20, 1040292) It is true that all did not definitely pray, but the spirit of prayer was abroad and it dominated the people rather than the spirit of revenge,
('19', 487, 4, 21, 1040436) 1 On March 19, the Khilafat day 2 The Hindu shopkeepers of Bombay had voluntarily observed the hartal on the Khilafat day.
('19', 487, 4, 22, 1040559) 3 The Khilafat Committee, Bombay

('19', 488, 1, 2, 1040640) anger, excitement, and so we had the amazing spectacle of the hartal day passing off like an ordinary day when everybody expects peace to be observed.
('19', 488, 1, 3, 1040791) The vast meeting of Bombay attended perhaps by thirty thousand men was a sight worth seeing.
('19', 488, 1, 4, 1040884) There was firmness in the faces of those thousands of people who listened to the speeches, yet without applause or any other effusive demonstration.
('19', 488, 1, 5, 1041033) The organizers deserve the warmest praise for having introduced into our meetings the ancient peacefulness,quiet, determination and orderliness in the place of modern fluster, excitement and disorderliness.
('19', 488, 1, 6, 1041240) The one develops just the qualities that make for satyagraha, the other inevitably leads to violence.
('19', 488, 1, 7, 1041342) And the message of the great meeting and the very successful hartal is not violence but non violence.
('19', 488, 1, 8, 1041444) I hope that the authorities will not misread the situation.

('19', 488, 1, 10, 1041767) I hope, too, that they will read the spirit of the movement in the manner in which it is developing.

('19', 488, 1, 12, 1042192) I hope that Government will not repeat the sin of last April and entertain any false hope of tyranny and unquenchable spirit that has come into being and that will suffer everything but humiliation, dishonour and defeat [sic].

('19', 488, 1, 14, 1042553) Surely a people so stricken with grief and with disappoint ment probably staring them in the face must have an outlet for orderly manifestation.
('19', 488, 1, 15, 1042698) It was because not very long ago we were afraid to speak or write what we thought that our sentiments burrowed under and became foul with stench because of the absence of the fierce sun and the open air of public opinion playing upon them.

('19', 488, 1, 17, 1042984) Today, thank God, we seem to have outlived the evil day.
('19', 488, 1, 18, 1043041) We dare to think, speak and write openly, with out fear, but under restraint that openness imposes upon mankind.
('19', 488, 1, 19, 1043154) I appeal to the members of the Liberal League and those who think with them to recognize this plain fact and to
('19', 489, 0, 1, 1043266) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 489, 1, 2, 1043308) appreciate the superiority of boldness over timid caution.
('19', 489, 1, 3, 1043367) If they desire to harness all the innumerable forces that are coming daily into being for the uplift of the nation, if they wish to become privileged participators in the throes of the new birth, let them not ignore the signs of the time, let them not reject the advances of the younger generation, let them not chill their ardent hopes and aspirations, but let them head this growing party of young, enthusiastic, self sacrificing dare devil men.
('19', 489, 1, 4, 1043815) Sympathize with them, respond to the heart’s throb, regulate it, for they are amenable to reason or an appeal to their high souledness—and you have a disciplined party, obedient to the call of the country.
('19', 489, 1, 5, 1044021) But if they feel neglected, if they feel that the older heads will not patiently listen to their wants, will not give them a helping hand, they may despair and despair may lead to desperation resulting in a catastrophic destruction.
('19', 489, 1, 6, 1044254) I can recall no time so magnificently suitable for leading India to the method of satyagraha—not necessarily civil disobedience, but truth and non violence—in which there is no defeat and in which if there is any error it hurts but those who err.

('19', 489, 2, 8, 1044524) 313. CONTEMPT OF COURT The long expected hearing of the case against the editor and the publisher of Young India in connection with the publication of a letter of the District Judge of Ahmedabad regarding satyagrahi lawyers and my comments thereon has been heard and judgment has been pronounced.
('19', 489, 2, 9, 1044821) 1 Both the editor and the publisher have been severely reprimanded.
('19', 489, 2, 10, 1044889) But the Court did not see its way to pass any sentence upon either of us.
('19', 489, 2, 11, 1044963) If I dwell upon the judgment it is only because I am anxious as a satyagrahi to draw a moral from it.
('19', 489, 2, 12, 1045065) I wish to assure those friends who, out of pure friendliness, advised us to tender the required apology, that I refused to accept their advice not out of obstinacy but because there was a great principle at stake.
('19', 489, 2, 13, 1045279) I had to conserve a journalist’s independence and yet respect the law.
('19', 489, 2, 14, 1045350) My own reading of the law was that there was no contempt committed by me.
('19', 489, 2, 15, 1045424) But my defence rested more upon the fact that I could not offer an apology if I was not prepared not to repeat the offence on a similar
('19', 489, 3, 16, 1045560) 1 It was pronounced on March 12, 1920; for Gandhiji’s account of the hearing, vide “Was It Contempt of Court?”, 10 3 1920.
('19', 490, 0, 1, 1045683) VOL. 19 : 29 SEPTEMBER, 1919 24 MARCH, 1920 491
('19', 490, 1, 2, 1045731) occasion.
('19', 490, 1, 3, 1045741) Because I hold that an apology tendered to a Court to be true has to be as sincere as a private apology.
('19', 490, 1, 4, 1045846) At the same time I owed a duty to the Court.
('19', 490, 1, 5, 1045891) It was no light thing for me to refuse to accept the advice of the Chief Justice especially when the Chief Justice was so very considerate in the correspondence with me.
('19', 490, 1, 6, 1046061) I was on the horns of a dilemma.
('19', 490, 1, 7, 1046094) I therefore decided not to offer any defence but simply to make a statement frankly and fully defining my position, leaving it to the Court to pass any sentence it thought fit in the event of an adverse decision.
('19', 490, 1, 8, 1046307) In order to show that I meant no disrespect of the Court and that I did not desire to advertise the case I took extraordinary precautions to prevent publicity and I venture to think that I succeeded eminently in convincing the Court that behind my disobedience—if it was disobedience—there was no defiance but perfect resignation; there was no anger or ill will but perfect restraint and respect; that, if I did not apologize, I did not because an insincere apology would have been contrary to my conscience.
('19', 490, 1, 9, 1046816) I hold that it was about as perfect an instance of civil disobedience as it ever has been my privilege to offer.
('19', 490, 1, 10, 1046929) And I feel that the Court reciprocated in a most handsome manner and recognized the spirit of civility that lay behind my so called disobe dience.
('19', 490, 1, 11, 1047076) The luminous judgment of Justice Marten lays down the law, and decides against me.
('19', 490, 1, 12, 1047159) But I feel thankful that it does not question the propriety of my action.
('19', 490, 1, 13, 1047233) Justice Hayward’s judgment recognizes it as an instance of passive, i.e., civil, resistance and practically makes it the reason for not awarding any sentence.
('19', 490, 1, 14, 1047392) Here then we have an almost complete vindication of civil disobedience.
('19', 490, 1, 15, 1047464) Disobedience to be civil must be sincere, respectful, restrained, never defiant, must be based upon some well understood principle, must not be capricious and above all must have no ill will or hatred behind it.
('19', 490, 1, 16, 1047676) I submit that the disobe dience offered by Mr. Desai and myself contained all these ingredients.
('19', 490, 2, 17, 1047773) Young India, 24 3 1920
('19', 491, 0, 1, 1047796) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('19', 491, 1, 2, 1047838) APPENDICES
('19', 491, 2, 3, 1047849) APPENDIX I
('19', 491, 3, 4, 1047860) ROWLATT PETITION
('19', 491, 5, 5, 1047877) THE RIGHT HONOURABLE THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INDIA
('19', 491, 6, 6, 1047931) THE HUMBLE MEMORIAL OF THE UNDERSIGNED INDIAN
('19', 491, 7, 7, 1047977) SUBJECTS OF HIS MAJESTY THE KING EMPPEROR
('19', 491, 8, 8, 1048019) HUMBLY AND RESPECTFULLY SHOWETH AS FOLLOWS:
('19', 491, 9, 9, 1048063) (1) Your petitioners have learnt with great concern the announcement recently made by you in answer to a question in the House of Commons that you would not advise His majesty to signify his disallowance of the Anarchical and Revolutionary Crimes Act being Act XI of 1919 (generally known as the Rowlatt Act).
('19', 491, 10, 10, 1048373) (2) Your petitioners submit that the said Act contains provisions which are highly prejudicial to the liberties of His Majesty’s Indian subjects, among others those which empower the Indian Executive to assume at its own discretion practically uncontrolled powers of depriving His Majesty’s Indian subjects of their right to be tried by the Ordinary Tribunals of the land and those which deprive the offenders placed for trial under the said Act of many privileges which have been recognized by civilised jurisprudence as absolutely necessary for safeguarding their innocence.
('19', 491, 11, 11, 1048950) (3) Your petitioners further submit that on account of the aforesaid and other objections to which the principle and the provisions of the said Act are open it has met with universal disapprobation and opposition in India and has given rise to an agitation the like of which in extent and intensity has never been known or heard of before in India.
('19', 491, 12, 12, 1049299) (4) Your petitioners feel that constitutional reforms inaugurating responsible Government in India can have no value or meaning if the said Act is retained on the Indian Statute Book in open and deliberate defiance of public opinion in India.
('19', 491, 13, 13, 1049542) (5) Your petitioners, therefore, submit that under the circumstances aforesaid, you will be pleased to reconsider your decision and advise His Majesty to signify through you his disallowance of the said Act.
('19', 491, 14, 14, 1049750) (6) And for this act of kindness your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
('19', 491, 14, 15, 1049833) Your most obedient servants,

('19', 492, 2, 3, 1050024) LETTER FROM SECRETARY, HUNTER COMMITTEE, TOMALAVIYA
('19', 492, 3, 4, 1050076) In his reply to Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, Mr. Stokes writes that Lord Hunter’s Committee feel that it is not within their province to review the discretion of the local Government.
('19', 492, 3, 5, 1050260) If in the course of their inquiry, it should appear that the evidence of any person, now in custody, is necessary to throw light on the causes of disturbances or measures taken to deal therewith, such persons will be called before the Committee and in the event, the Committee do not doubt that the Government of the Punjab will place no obstacle in the way of their appearance.
('19', 492, 3, 6, 1050639) The Committee observe, “Indeed, from the communication of the Private Secretary to His Honour the Lieutenant Governor of which a copy is annexed to your letter, it is seen that an assurance has been conveyed to you on this point and also an undertaking that proper facilities will be allowed for consultation between persons in custody and counsel engaged in the inquiry which has been entrusted to the Committee and Lord Hunter’s Committee would expect that.
('19', 492, 3, 7, 1051099) In this matter, Government would afford the fullest reasonable facilities.
('19', 492, 3, 8, 1051174) Lord Hunter has independently suggested to the Punjab Government that this should be done.
('19', 492, 3, 9, 1051265) Beyond this Lord Hunter’s Committee feel that they cannot properly make any further suggestions.
('19', 492, 3, 10, 1051362) If the Congress Subcommittee still should feel unable to co operate in the inquiry and should adhere to their decision to forgo the opportunity for full investigation which it is the desire of Lord Hunter’s Committee to make, His Lordship’s Committee, I am to say, can only acquiesce with regret in that decision.”
